text: PREFACE
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As there cannot be said to be a beaten path in philosophy, and as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Introductions" to the subject differ widely from one another, it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proper that I should give an indication of the scope of the present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: volume.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It undertakes:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 1.  To point out what the word "philosophy" is made to cover in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universities and colleges at the present day, and to show why it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given this meaning.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 2.  To explain the nature of reflective or philosophical thinking, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to show how it differs from common thought and from science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 3.  To give a general view of the main problems with which philosophers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have felt called upon to deal.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 4.  To give an account of some of the more important types of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical doctrine which have arisen out of the consideration of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such problems.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 5.  To indicate the relation of philosophy to the so-called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical sciences, and to the other sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 6.  To show, finally, that the study of philosophy is of value to us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, and to give some practical admonitions on spirit and method.  Had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these admonitions been impressed upon me at a time when I was in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: especial need of guidance, I feel that they would have spared me no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little anxiety and confusion of mind.  For this reason, I recommend
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them to the attention of the reader.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such is the scope of my book.  It aims to tell what philosophy is.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not its chief object to advocate a particular type of doctrine.  At
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same time, as it is impossible to treat of the problems of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy except from some point of view, it will be found that, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Chapters III to XI, a doctrine is presented.  It is the same as that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented much more in detail, and with a greater wealth of reference,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in my "System of Metaphysics," which was published a short time ago.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the Notes in the back of this volume, the reader will find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: references to those parts of the larger work which treat of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subjects more briefly discussed here.  It will be helpful to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: teacher to keep the larger work on hand, and to use more or less of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material there presented as his undergraduate classes discuss the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapters of this one.  Other references are also given in the Notes,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it may be profitable to direct the attention of students to them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The present book has been made as clear and simple as possible, that no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unnecessary difficulties may be placed in the path of those who enter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the thorny road of philosophical reflection.  The subjects treated
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are deep enough to demand the serious attention of any one; and they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are subjects of fascinating interest.  That they are treated simply and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly does not mean that they are treated superficially.  Indeed,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when a doctrine is presented in outline and in a brief and simple
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement, its meaning may be more readily apparent than when it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treated more exhaustively.  For this reason, I especially recommend,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even to those who are well acquainted with philosophy, the account of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the external world contained in Chapter IV.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For the doctrine I advocate I am inclined to ask especial consideration
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on the ground that it is, on the whole, a justification of the attitude
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taken by the plain man toward the world in which he finds himself.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of the race is not a thing that we may treat lightly.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, it is maintained that there is a real external world presented in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our experience--not a world which we have a right to regard as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations or ideas of any mind.  It is maintained that we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence that there are minds in certain relations to that world, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we can, within certain limits, determine these relations.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pointed out that the plain man's belief in the activity of his mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his notion of the significance of purposes and ends are not without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justification.  It is indicated that theism is a reasonable doctrine,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it is held that the human will is free in the only proper sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "freedom."  Throughout it is taken for granted that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher has no private system of weights and measures, but must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason as other men reason, and must prove his conclusions in the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sober way.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have written in hopes that the book may be of use to undergraduate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: students.  They are often repelled by philosophy, and I cannot but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think that this is in part due to the dry and abstract form in which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers have too often seen fit to express their thoughts.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same thoughts can be set forth in plain language, and their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance illustrated by a constant reference to experiences which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we all have--experiences which must serve as the foundation to every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theory of the mind and the world worthy of serious consideration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But there are many persons who cannot attend formal courses of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: instruction, and who, nevertheless, are interested in philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These, also, I have had in mind; and I have tried to be so clear that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they could read the work with profit in the absence of a teacher.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Lastly, I invite the more learned, if they have found my "System of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Metaphysics" difficult to understand in any part, to follow the simple
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement contained in the chapters above alluded to, and then to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: return, if they will, to the more bulky volume.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I. INTRODUCTORY

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: THE MEANING OF THE WORD "PHILOSOPHY" IN THE PAST AND IN THE PRESENT
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I must warn the reader at the outset that the title of this chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems to promise a great deal more than he will find carried out in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter itself.  To tell all that philosophy has meant in the past, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all that it means to various classes of men in the present, would be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: task of no small magnitude, and one quite beyond the scope of such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: volume as this.  But it is not impossible to give within small compass
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a brief indication, at least, of what the word once signified, to show
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: how its signification has undergone changes, and to point out to what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sort of a discipline or group of disciplines educated men are apt to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apply the word, notwithstanding their differences of opinion as to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: truth or falsity of this or that particular doctrine.  Why certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subjects of investigation have come to be grouped together and to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as falling within the province of the philosopher, rather than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain other subjects, will, I hope, be made clear in the body of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: work.  Only an indication can be given in this chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 1. THE BEGINNINGS OF PHILOSOPHY.--The Greek historian Herodotus
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (484-424 B.C.) appears to have been the first to use the verb "to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophize."  He makes Croesus tell Solon how he has heard that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "from a desire of knowledge has, philosophizing, journeyed through many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lands."  The word "philosophizing" seems to indicate that Solon pursued
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge for its own sake, and was what we call an investigator.  As
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the word "philosopher" (etymologically, a lover of wisdom), a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain somewhat unreliable tradition traces it back to Pythagoras
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (about 582-500 B.C.).  As told by Cicero, the story is that, in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conversation with Leon, the ruler of Phlius, in the Peloponnesus, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: described himself as a philosopher, and said that his business was an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigation into the nature of things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: At any rate, both the words "philosopher" and "philosophy" are freely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: used in the writings of the disciples of Socrates (470-399 B.C.), and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is possible that he was the first to make use of them.  The seeming
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: modesty of the title philosopher--for etymologically it is a modest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one, though it has managed to gather a very different signification
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the lapse of time--the modesty of the title would naturally appeal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to a man who claimed so much ignorance, as Socrates; and Plato
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represents him as distinguishing between the lover of wisdom and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wise, on the ground that God alone may be called wise.  From that date
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to this the word "philosopher" has remained with us, and it has meant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many things to many men.  But for centuries the philosopher has not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been simply the investigator, nor has he been simply the lover of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wisdom.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: An investigation into the origin of words, however interesting in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself, can tell us little of the uses to which words are put after
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they have come into being.  If we turn from etymology to history, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: review the labors of the men whom the world has agreed to call
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers, we are struck by the fact that those who head the list
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chronologically appear to have been occupied with crude physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speculations, with attempts to guess what the world is made out of,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather than with that somewhat vague something that we call philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to-day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Students of the history of philosophy usually begin their studies with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the speculations of the Greek philosopher Thales (b. 624 B.C.).  We are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: told that he assumed water to be the universal principle out of which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all things are made, and that he maintained that "all things are full
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of gods."  We find that Anaximander, the next in the list, assumed as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the source out of which all things proceed and that to which they all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: return "the infinite and indeterminate"; and that Anaximenes, who was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perhaps his pupil, took as his principle the all-embracing air.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This trio constitutes the Ionian school of philosophy, the earliest of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Greek schools; and one who reads for the first time the few vague
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements which seem to constitute the sum of their contributions to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge is impelled to wonder that so much has been made of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This wonder disappears, however, when one realizes that the appearance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of these thinkers was really a momentous thing.  For these men turned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their faces away from the poetical and mythologic way of accounting for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, which had obtained up to their time, and set their faces toward
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Science.  Aristotle shows us how Thales may have been led to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: formulation of his main thesis by an observation of the phenomena of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature.  Anaximander saw in the world in which he lived the result of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: process of evolution.  Anaximenes explains the coming into being of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fire, wind, clouds, water, and earth, as due to a condensation and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expansion of the universal principle, air.  The boldness of their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speculations we may explain as due to a courage born of ignorance, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the explanations they offer are scientific in spirit, at least.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, these men do not stand alone.  They are the advance guard of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an army whose latest representatives are the men who are enlightening
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world at the present day.  The evolution of science--taking that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word in the broad sense to mean organized and systematized
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge--must be traced in the works of the Greek philosophers from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thales down.  Here we have the source and the rivulet to which we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: trace back the mighty stream which is flowing past our own doors.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Apparently insignificant in its beginnings, it must still for a while
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem insignificant to the man who follows with an unreflective eye the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: course of the current.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It would take me too far afield to give an account of the Greek schools
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which immediately succeeded the Ionic: to tell of the Pythagoreans, who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: held that all things were constituted by numbers; of the Eleatics, who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: held that "only Being is," and denied the possibility of change,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thereby reducing the shifting panorama of the things about us to a mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: delusive world of appearances; of Heraclitus, who was so impressed by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the constant flux of things that he summed up his view of nature in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: words: "Everything flows"; of Empedocles, who found his explanation of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world in the combination of the four elements, since become
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: traditional, earth, water, fire, and air; of Democritus, who developed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a materialistic atomism which reminds one strongly of the doctrine of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: atoms as it has appeared in modern science; of Anaxagoras, who traced
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the system of things to the setting in order of an infinite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: multiplicity of different elements,--"seeds of things,"--which setting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in order was due to the activity of the finest of things, Mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is a delight to discover the illuminating thoughts which came to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds of these men; and, on the other hand, it is amusing to see how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recklessly they launched themselves on boundless seas when they were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unprovided with chart and compass.  They were like brilliant children,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who know little of the dangers of the great world, but are ready to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undertake anything.  These philosophers regarded all knowledge as their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: province, and did not despair of governing so great a realm.  They were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ready to explain the whole world and everything in it.  Of course, this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can only mean that they had little conception of how much there is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: explain, and of what is meant by scientific explanation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is characteristic of this series of philosophers that their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attention was directed very largely upon the external world.  It was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natural that this should be so.  Both in the history of the race and in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that of the individual, we find that the attention is seized first by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things, and that it is long before a clear conception of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind and of its knowledge is arrived at.  Observation precedes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection.  When we come to think definitely about the mind, we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all apt to make use of notions which we have derived from our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of external things.  The very words we use to denote mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: operations are in many instances taken from this outer realm.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "direct" the attention; we speak of "apprehension," of "conception," of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "intuition."  Our knowledge is "clear" or "obscure"; an oration is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "brilliant"; an emotion is "sweet" or "bitter."  What wonder that, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we read over the fragments that have come down to us from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Pre-Socratic philosophers, we should be struck by the fact that they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sometimes leave out altogether and sometimes touch lightly upon a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number of those things that we regard to-day as peculiarly within the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: province of the philosopher.  They busied themselves with the world as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they saw it, and certain things had hardly as yet come definitely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: within their horizon.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 2. THE GREEK PHILOSOPHY AT ITS HEIGHT.--The next succeeding period sees
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain classes of questions emerge into prominence which had attracted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: comparatively little attention from the men of an earlier day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Democritus of Abdera, to whom reference has been made above, belongs
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chronologically to this latter period, but his way of thinking makes us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class him with the earlier philosophers.  It was characteristic of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these latter that they assumed rather naively that man can look upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world and can know it, and can by thinking about it succeed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: giving a reasonable account of it.  That there may be a difference
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between the world as it really is and the world as it appears to man,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that it may be impossible for man to attain to a knowledge of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absolute truth of things, does not seem to have occurred to them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fifth century before Christ was, in Greece, a time of intense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intellectual ferment.  One is reminded, in reading of it, of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: splendid years of the Renaissance in Italy, of the awakening of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human mind to a vigorous life which cast off the bonds of tradition and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: insisted upon the right of free and unfettered development.  Athens was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the center of this intellectual activity.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In this century arose the Sophists, public teachers who busied
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves with all departments of human knowledge, but seemed to lay
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no little emphasis upon certain questions that touched very nearly the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life of man.  Can man attain to truth at all--to a truth that is more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than a mere truth to him, a seeming truth?  Whence do the laws derive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their authority?  Is there such a thing as justice, as right?  It was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with such questions as these that the Sophists occupied themselves, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such questions as these have held the attention of mankind ever since.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When they make their appearance in the life of a people or of an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individual man, it means that there has been a rebirth, a birth into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the life of reflection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When Socrates, that greatest of teachers, felt called upon to refute
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the arguments of these men, he met them, so to speak, on their own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ground, recognizing that the subjects of which they discoursed were,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indeed, matter for scientific investigation.  His attitude seemed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many conservative persons in his day a dangerous one; he was regarded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as an innovator; he taught men to think and to raise questions where,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before, the traditions of the fathers had seemed a sufficient guide to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men's actions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And, indeed, he could not do otherwise.  Men had learned to reflect,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and there had come into existence at least the beginnings of what we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: now sometimes rather loosely call the mental and moral sciences.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the works of Socrates' disciple Plato (428-347 B.C.) and in those of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Plato's disciple Aristotle (384-322 B.C.), abundant justice is done to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these fields of human activity.  These two, the greatest among the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Greek philosophers, differ from each other in many things, but it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: worthy of remark that they both seem to regard the whole sphere of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge as their province.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Plato is much more interested in the moral sciences than in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical, but he, nevertheless, feels called upon to give an account of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: how the world was made and out of what sort of elements.  He evidently
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not take his own account very seriously, and recognizes that he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on uncertain ground.  But he does not consider the matter beyond his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: jurisdiction.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As for Aristotle, that wonderful man seems to have found it possible to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represent worthily every science known to his time, and to have marked
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out several new fields for his successors to cultivate.  His philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: covers physics, cosmology, zooelogy, logic, metaphysics, ethics,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychology, politics and economics, rhetoric and poetics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus we see that the task of the philosopher was much the same at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: period of the highest development of the Greek philosophy that it had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been earlier.  He was supposed to give an account of the system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  But the notion of what it means to give an account of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of things had necessarily undergone some change.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher had to be something more than a natural philosopher.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 3. PHILOSOPHY AS A GUIDE TO LIFE.--At the close of the fourth century
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before Christ there arose the schools of the Stoics, the Epicureans,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the Skeptics.  In them we seem to find a somewhat new conception of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy--philosophy appears as chiefly a guide to life.  The Stoic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: emphasizes the necessity of living "according to nature," and dwells
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the character of the wise man; the Epicurean furnishes certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: selfish maxims for getting through life as pleasantly as possible; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Skeptic counsels apathy, an indifference to all things,--blessed is he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who expects nothing, for he shall not be disappointed.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And yet, when we examine more closely these systems, we find a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conception of philosophy not really so very different from that which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: had obtained before.  We do not find, it is true, that disinterested
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: passion for the attainment of truth which is the glory of science.  Man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems quite too much concerned with the problem of his own happiness or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unhappiness; he has grown morbid.  Nevertheless, the practical maxims
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which obtain in each of these systems are based upon a certain view of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the system of things as a whole.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The Stoic tells us of what the world consists; what was the beginning
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and what will be the end of things; what is the relation of the system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of things to God.  He develops a physics and a logic as well as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of ethics.  The Epicurean informs us that the world originated
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a rain of atoms through space; he examines into the foundations of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge; and he proceeds to make himself comfortable in a world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from which he has removed those disturbing elements, the gods.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Skeptic decides that there is no such thing as truth, before he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enunciates the dogma that it is not worth while to worry about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything.  The philosophy of each school includes a view of the system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of things as a whole.  The philosopher still regarded the universe of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge as his province.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 4. PHILOSOPHY IN THE MIDDLE AGES.--I cannot do more than mention
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Neo-Platonism, that half Greek and half Oriental system of doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which arose in the third century after Christ, the first system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: importance after the schools mentioned above.  But I must not pass it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by without pointing out that the Neo-Platonic philosopher undertook to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: give an account of the origin, development, and end of the whole system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the Middle Ages there gradually grew up rather a sharp distinction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between those things that can be known through the unaided reason and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those things that can only be known through a supernatural revelation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The term "philosophy" came to be synonymous with knowledge attained by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the natural light of reason.  This seems to imply some sort of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: limitation to the task of the philosopher.  Philosophy is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: synonymous with all knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we must not forget to take note of the fact that philosophy, even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with this limitation, constitutes a pretty wide field.  It covers both
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the physical and the moral sciences.  Nor should we omit to notice that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the scholastic philosopher was at the same time a theologian.  Albert
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Great and St. Thomas Aquinas, the famous scholastics of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thirteenth century, had to write a "_Summa Theologiae_," or system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theology, as well as to treat of the other departments of human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Why were these men not overwhelmed with the task set them by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tradition of their time?  It was because the task was not, after all,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so great as a modern man might conceive it to be.  Gil Blas, in Le
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sage's famous romance, finds it possible to become a skilled physician
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the twinkling of an eye, when Dr. Sangrado has imparted to him the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: secret that the remedy for all diseases is to be found in bleeding the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: patient and in making him drink copiously of hot water.  When little is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: known about things, it does not seem impossible for one man to learn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that little.  During the Middle Ages and the centuries preceding, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical sciences had a long sleep.  Men were much more concerned in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the thirteenth century to find out what Aristotle had said than they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were to address questions to nature.  The special sciences, as we now
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know them, had not been called into existence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 5. THE MODERN PHILOSOPHY.--The submission of men's minds to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: authority of Aristotle and of the church gradually gave way.  A revival
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of learning set in.  Men turned first of all to a more independent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: choice of authorities, and then rose to the conception of a philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent of authority, of a science based upon an observation of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature, of a science at first hand.  The special sciences came into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: being.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But the old tradition of philosophy as universal knowledge remained.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we pass over the men of the transition period and turn our attention
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to Francis Bacon (1561-1626) and Rene Descartes (1596-1650), the two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who are commonly regarded as heading the list of the modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers, we find both of them assigning to the philosopher an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: almost unlimited field.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bacon holds that philosophy has for its objects God, man, and nature,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and he regards it as within his province to treat of "_philosophia
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prima_" (a sort of metaphysics, though he does not call it by this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name), of logic, of physics and astronomy, of anthropology, in which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: includes psychology, of ethics, and of politics.  In short, he attempts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to map out the whole field of human knowledge, and to tell those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: work in this corner of it or in that how they should set about their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: task.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As for Descartes, he writes of the trustworthiness of human knowledge,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the existence of God, of the existence of an external world, of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human soul and its nature, of mathematics, physics, cosmology,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physiology, and, in short, of nearly everything discussed by the men of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his day.  No man can accuse this extraordinary Frenchman of a lack of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appreciation of the special sciences which were growing up.  No one in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his time had a better right to be called a scientist in the modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense of the term.  But it was not enough for him to be a mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematician, or even a worker in the physical sciences generally.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be all that has been mentioned above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The conception of philosophy as of a something that embraces all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: departments of human knowledge has not wholly passed away even in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: day.  I shall not dwell upon Spinoza (1632-1677), who believed it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible to deduce a world _a priori_ with mathematical precision; upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Christian Wolff (1679-1754), who defined philosophy as the knowledge of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the causes of what is or comes into being; upon Fichte (1762-1814), who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believed that the philosopher, by mere thinking, could lay down the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: laws of all possible future experience; upon Schelling (1775-1854),
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who, without knowing anything worth mentioning about natural science,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: had the courage to develop a system of natural philosophy, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condemn such investigators as Boyle and Newton; upon Hegel (1770-1831),
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who undertakes to construct the whole system of reality out of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concepts, and who, with his immediate predecessors, brought philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for a while into more or less disrepute with men of a scientific turn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of mind.  I shall come down quite to our own times, and consider a man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whose conception of philosophy has had and still has a good deal of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence, especially with the general public--with those to whom
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy is a thing to be taken up in moments of leisure, and cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be the serious pursuit of a life.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Knowledge of the lowest kind," says Herbert Spencer, "is _un-unified_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge; Science is _partially-unified_ knowledge; Philosophy is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _completely-unified_ knowledge." [1]  Science, he argues, means merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the family of the Sciences--stands for nothing more than the sum of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge formed of their contributions.  Philosophy is the fusion of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these contributions into a whole; it is knowledge of the greatest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: generality.  In harmony with this notion Spencer produced a system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy which includes the following: A volume entitled "First
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Principles," which undertakes to show what man can and what man cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know; a treatise on the principles of biology; another on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: principles of psychology; still another on the principles of sociology;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and finally one on the principles of morality.  To complete the scheme
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it would have been necessary to give an account of inorganic nature
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before going on to the phenomena of life, but our philosopher found the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: task too great and left this out.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, Spencer was a man of genius, and one finds in his works many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: illuminating thoughts.  But it is worthy of remark that those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: praise his work in this or in that field are almost always men who have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves worked in some other field and have an imperfect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acquaintance with the particular field that they happen to be praising.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The metaphysician finds the reasonings of the "First Principles" rather
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: loose and inconclusive; the biologist pays little heed to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Principles of Biology"; the sociologist finds Spencer not particularly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accurate or careful in the field of his predilection.  He has tried to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a professor of all the sciences, and it is too late in the world's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history for him or for any man to cope with such a task.  In the days
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of Plato a man might have hoped to accomplish it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 6. WHAT PHILOSOPHY MEANS IN OUR TIME.--It savors of temerity to write
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: down such a title as that which heads the present section.  There are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men living to-day to whom philosophy means little else than the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of Kant, or of Hegel, or of the brothers Caird, or of Herbert
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Spencer, or even of St. Thomas Aquinas, for we must not forget that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many of the seminaries of learning in Europe and some in America still
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold to the mediaeval church philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But let me gather up in a few words the purport of what has been said
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above.  Philosophy once meant the whole body of scientific knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Afterward it came to mean the whole body of knowledge which could be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained by the mere light of human reason, unaided by revelation.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: several special sciences sprang up, and a multitude of men have for a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: long time past devoted themselves to definite limited fields of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigation with little attention to what has been done in other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fields.  Nevertheless, there has persisted the notion of a discipline
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which somehow concerns itself with the whole system of things, rather
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than with any limited division of that broad field.  It is a notion not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: peculiar to the disciples of Spencer.  There are many to whom
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy is a "_Weltweisheit_," a world-wisdom.  Shall we say that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this is the meaning of the word philosophy now?  And if we do, how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall we draw a line between philosophy and the body of the special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Perhaps the most just way to get a preliminary idea of what philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means to the men of our time is to turn away for the time being from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the definition of any one man or group of men, and to ask ourselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what a professor of philosophy in an American or European university is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: actually supposed to teach.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is quite clear that he is not supposed to be an Aristotle.  He does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not represent all the sciences, and no one expects him to lecture on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematics, mechanics, physics, chemistry, zooelogy, botany, economics,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: politics, and various other disciplines.  There was a time when he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: might have been expected to teach all that men could know, but that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time is long past.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, there is quite a group of sciences which are regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belonging especially to his province; and although a man may devote a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: large part of his attention to some one portion of the field, he would
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly be thought remiss if he wholly neglected the rest.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: group of sciences includes logic, psychology, ethics and aesthetics,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysics, and the history of philosophy.  I have not included
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: epistemology or the "theory of knowledge" as a separate discipline, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasons which will appear later (Chapter XIX); and I have included the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history of philosophy, because, whether we care to call this a special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science or not, it constitutes a very important part of the work of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: teacher of philosophy in our day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Of this group of subjects the student who goes to the university to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: study philosophy is supposed to know something before he leaves its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: walls, whatever else he may or may not know.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be remarked, again, that there is commonly supposed to be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: peculiarly close relation between philosophy and religion.  Certainly,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if any one about a university undertakes to give a course of lectures
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on theism, it is much more apt to be the professor of philosophy than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the professor of mathematics or of chemistry.  The man who has written
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an "Introduction to Philosophy," a "Psychology," a "Logic," and an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Outlines of Metaphysics" is very apt to regard it as his duty to add
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the list a "Philosophy of Religion."  The students in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theological seminaries of Europe and America are usually encouraged, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not compelled, to attend courses in philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Finally, it appears to be definitely accepted that even the disciplines
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we never think of classing among the philosophical sciences are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not wholly cut off from a connection with philosophy.  When we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occupied, not with adding to the stock of knowledge embraced within the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sphere of any special science, but with an examination of the methods
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the science, with, so to speak, a criticism of the foundations upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the science rests, our work is generally recognized as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical.  It strikes no one as odd in our day that there should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be established a "Journal of Philosophy, Psychology, and Scientific
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Methods," but we should think it strange if some one announced the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intention to publish a "Journal of Philosophy and Comparative Anatomy."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not without its significance that, when Mach, who had been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: professor of physics at Prague, was called (in 1895) to the University
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of Vienna to lecture on the history and theory of the inductive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences, he was made, not professor of physics, but professor of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The case, then, stands thus: a certain group of disciplines is regarded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as falling peculiarly within the province of the professor of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy, and the sciences which constitute it are frequently called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the philosophical sciences; moreover, it is regarded as quite proper
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the teacher of philosophy should concern himself with the problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of religion, and should pry into the methods and fundamental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions of special sciences in all of which it is impossible that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he should be an adept.  The question naturally arises: Why has his task
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come to be circumscribed as it is?  Why should he teach just these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things and no others?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this question certain persons are at once ready to give an answer.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There was a time, they argue, when it seemed possible for one man to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: embrace the whole field of human knowledge.  But human knowledge grew;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the special sciences were born; each concerned itself with a definite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class of facts and developed its own methods.  It became possible and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: necessary for a man to be, not a scientist at large, but a chemist, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physicist, a biologist, an economist.  But in certain portions of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: great field men have met with peculiar difficulties; here it cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said that we have sciences, but rather that we have attempts at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science.  The philosopher is the man to whom is committed what is left
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we have taken away what has been definitely established or is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undergoing investigation according to approved scientific methods.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is Lord of the Uncleared Ground, and may wander through it in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: compassless, irresponsible way, never feeling that he is lost, for he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has never had any definite bearings to lose.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who argue in this way support their case by pointing to the lack
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a general consensus of opinion which obtains in many parts of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: field which the philosopher regards as his own; and also by pointing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out that, even within this field, there is a growing tendency on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part of certain sciences to separate themselves from philosophy and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: become independent.  Thus the psychologist and the logician are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sometimes very anxious to have it understood that they belong among the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientists and not among the philosophers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, this answer to the question that we have raised undoubtedly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contains some truth.  As we have seen from the sketch contained in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: preceding pages, the word philosophy was once a synonym for the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sum of the sciences or what stood for such; gradually the several
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences have become independent and the field of the philosopher has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been circumscribed.  We must admit, moreover, that there is to be found
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a number of the special sciences a body of accepted facts which is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without its analogue in philosophy.  In much of his work the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher certainly seems to be walking upon more uncertain ground
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than his neighbors; and if he is unaware of that fact, it must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: either because he has not a very nice sense of what constitutes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific evidence, or because he is carried away by his enthusiasm
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for some particular form of doctrine.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, it is just to maintain that the answer we are discussing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not a satisfactory one.  For one thing, we find in it no indication
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the reason why the particular group of disciplines with which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher occupies himself has been left to him, when so many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences have announced their independence.  Why have not these, also,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: separated off and set up for themselves?  Is it more difficult to work
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in these fields than in others? and, if so, what reason can be assigned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the fact?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Take psychology as an instance.  How does it happen that the physicist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: calmly develops his doctrine without finding it necessary to make his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bow to philosophy at all, while the psychologist is at pains to explain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that his book is to treat psychology as "a natural science," and will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: avoid metaphysics as much as possible?  For centuries men have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interested in the phenomena of the human mind.  Can anything be more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: open to observation than what passes in a man's own consciousness?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Why, then, should the science of psychology lag behind? and why these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: endless disputes as to whether it can really be treated as a "natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science" at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  May we assume that, because certain disciplines have taken a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position of relative independence, therefore all the rest of the field
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will surely come to be divided up in the same way, and that there will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be many special sciences, but no such thing as philosophy?  It is hasty
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to assume this on no better evidence than that which has so far been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented.  Before making up one's mind upon this point, one should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take a careful look at the problems with which the philosopher occupies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: A complete answer to the questions raised above can only be given in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the course of the book, where the main problems of philosophy are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
