text: discussed, and the several philosophical sciences are taken up and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: examined.  But I may say, in anticipation, as much as this:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) Philosophy is reflective knowledge.  What is meant by reflective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge will be explained at length in the next chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) The sciences which are grouped together as philosophical are those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which we are forced back upon the problems of reflective thought,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and cannot simply put them aside.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) The peculiar difficulties of reflective thought may account for the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fact that these sciences are, more than others, a field in which we may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expect to find disputes and differences of opinion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) We need not be afraid that the whole field of human knowledge will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come to be so divided up into special sciences that philosophy will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: disappear.  The problems with which the philosopher occupies himself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are real problems, which present themselves unavoidably to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughtful mind, and it is not convenient to divide these up among the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: several sciences.  This will become clearer as we proceed.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "First Principles," Part II, section 37.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER II
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: COMMON THOUGHT, SCIENCE, AND REFLECTIVE THOUGHT
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 7. COMMON THOUGHT.--Those who have given little attention to the study
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the human mind are apt to suppose that, when the infant opens its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: eyes upon the new world of objects surrounding its small body, it sees
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things much as they do themselves.  They are ready to admit that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not know much _about_ things, but it strikes them as absurd for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any one to go so far as to say that it does not see things--the things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out there in space before its eyes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, the psychologist tells us that it requires quite a course
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of education to enable us to see things--not to have vague and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unmeaning sensations, but to see things, things that are known to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touchable as well as seeable, things that are recognized as having size
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and shape and position in space.  And he aims a still severer blow at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our respect for the infant when he goes on to inform us that the little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: creature is as ignorant of itself as it is of things; that in its small
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of as yet unorganized experiences there is no self that is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguished from other things; that it may cry vociferously without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowing who is uncomfortable, and may stop its noise without knowing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who has been taken up into the nurse's arms and has experienced an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: agreeable change.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This chaotic little world of the dawning life is not our world, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of common thought, the world in which we all live and move in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maturer years; nor can we go back to it on the wings of memory.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem to ourselves to have always lived in a world of things,--things in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time and space, material things.  Among these things there is one of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: peculiar interest, and which we have not placed upon a par with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rest, our own body, which sees, tastes, touches, other things.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot remember a time when we did not know that with this body are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somehow bound up many experiences which interest us acutely; for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: example, experiences of pleasure and pain.  Moreover, we seem always to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have known that certain of the bodies which surround our own rather
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: resemble our own, and are in important particulars to be distinguished
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the general mass of bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we seem always to have been living in a world of _things_ and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have recognized in that world the existence of ourselves and of other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: people.  When we now think of "ourselves" and of "other people," we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of each of the objects referred to as possessing a _mind_.  May
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we say that, as far back as we can remember, we have thought of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves and of other persons as possessing minds?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hardly.  The young child does not seem to distinguish between mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body, and, in the vague and fragmentary pictures which come back to us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from our early life, certainly this distinction does not stand out.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The child may be the completest of egoists, it may be absorbed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself and all that directly concerns this particular self, and yet it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may make no conscious distinction between a bodily self and a mental,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between mind and body.  It does not explicitly recognize its world as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world that contains minds as well as bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, however it may be with the child in the earlier stages of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: development, we must all admit that the mature man does consciously
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize that the world in which he finds himself is a world that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contains minds as well as bodies.  It never occurs to him to doubt that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there are bodies, and it never occurs to him to doubt that there are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Does he not perceive that he has a body and a mind?  Has he not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abundant evidence that his mind is intimately related to his body?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When he shuts his eyes, he no longer sees, and when he stops his ears,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he no longer hears; when his body is bruised, he feels pain; when he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wills to raise his hand, his body carries out the mental decree.  Other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men act very much as he does; they walk and they talk, they laugh and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they cry, they work and they play, just as he does.  In short, they act
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: precisely as though they had minds like his own.  What more natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than to assume that, as he himself gives expression, by the actions of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his body, to the thoughts and emotions in his mind, so his neighbor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does the same?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must not allow ourselves to underrate the plain man's knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: either of bodies or of minds.  It seems, when one reflects upon it, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sufficiently wonderful thing that a few fragmentary sensations should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: automatically receive an interpretation which conjures up before the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind a world of real things; that, for example, the little patch of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: color sensation which I experience when I turn my eyes toward the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: window should seem to introduce me at once to a world of material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objects lying in space, clearly defined in magnitude, distance, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: direction; that an experience no more complex should be the key which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should unlock for me the secret storehouse of another mind, and lay
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before me a wealth of thoughts and emotions not my own.  From the poor,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bare, meaningless world of the dawning intelligence to the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: common thought, a world in which real things with their manifold
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: properties, things material and things mental, bear their part, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indeed a long step.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And we should never forget that he who would go farther, he who would
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: strive to gain a better knowledge of matter and of mind by the aid of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science and of philosophical reflection, must begin his labors on this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foundation which is common to us all.  How else can he begin than by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accepting and more critically examining the world as it seems revealed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the experience of the race?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 8. SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE.--Still, the knowledge of the world which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have been discussing is rather indefinite, inaccurate, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unsystematic.  It is a sufficient guide for common life, but its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deficiencies may be made apparent.  He who wishes to know matter and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind better cannot afford to neglect the sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, it is important to observe that although, when the plain man grows
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific, great changes take place in his knowledge of things, yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his way of looking at the mind and the world remains in general much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what it was before.  To prevent this statement from being
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misunderstood, I must explain it at some length.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us suppose that the man in question takes up the study of botany.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Need he do anything very different from what is done more imperfectly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by every intelligent man who interests himself in plants?  There in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real material world before him are the same plants that he observed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhat carelessly before.  He must collect his information more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: systematically and must arrange it more critically, but his task is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so much to do something different as it is to do the same thing much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: better.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The same is evidently true of various other sciences, such as geology,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: zooelogy, physiology, sociology.  Some men have much accurate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: information regarding rocks, animals, the functions of the bodily
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: organs, the development of a given form of society, and other things of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sort, and other men have but little; and yet it is usually not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult for the man who knows much to make the man who knows little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: understand, at least, what he is talking about.  He is busying himself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with _things_--the same things that interest the plain man, and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the plain man knows something.  He has collected information
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touching their properties, their changes, their relationships; but to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him, as to his less scientific neighbor, they are the same things they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: always were,--things that he has known from the days of childhood.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Perhaps it will be admitted that this is true of such sciences as those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above indicated, but doubted whether it is true of all the sciences,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even of all the sciences which are directly concerned with _things_ of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _some_ sort.  For example, to the plain man the world of material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things consists of things that can be seen and touched.  Many of these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem to fill space continuously.  They may be divided, but the parts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into which they may be divided are conceived as fragments of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, and as of the same general nature as the wholes of which they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are parts.  Yet the chemist and the physicist tell us that these same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extended things are not really continuous, as they seem to us to be,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but consist of swarms of imperceptible atoms, in rapid motion, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: considerable distances from one another in space, and grouped in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: various ways.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What has now become of the world of realities to which the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pinned his faith?  It has come to be looked upon as a world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearances, of phenomena, of manifestations, under which the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, themselves imperceptible, make their presence evident to our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses.  Is this new, real world the world of things in which the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man finds himself, and in which he has felt so much at home?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: A closer scrutiny reveals that the world of atoms and molecules into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the man of science resolves the system of material things is not,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: after all, so very different in kind from the world to which the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man is accustomed.  He can understand without difficulty the language
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which it is described to him, and he can readily see how a man may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be led to assume its existence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The atom is not, it is true, directly perceivable by sense, but it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceived as though it and its motions were thus perceivable.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man has long known that things consist of parts which remain,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: under some circumstances, invisible.  When he approaches an object from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a distance, he sees parts which he could not see before; and what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears to the naked eye a mere speck without perceptible parts is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: found under the microscope to be an insect with its full complement of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: members.  Moreover, he has often observed that objects which appear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: continuous when seen from a distance are evidently far from continuous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when seen close at hand.  As we walk toward a tree we can see the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indefinite mass of color break up into discontinuous patches; a fabric,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which presents the appearance of an unbroken surface when viewed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain ways may be seen to be riddled with holes when held between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: eye and the light.  There is no man who has not some acquaintance with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the distinction between appearance and reality, and who does not make
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: use of the distinction in common life.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor can it seem a surprising fact that different combinations of atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should exhibit different properties.  Have we not always known that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things in combination are apt to have different properties from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same things taken separately?  He who does not know so much as this is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not fit even to be a cook.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: No, the imperceptible world of atoms and molecules is not by any means
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: totally different from the world of things in which the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lives.  These little objects and groups of objects are discussed very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much as we discuss the larger objects and groups of objects to which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are accustomed.  We are still concerned with _things_ which exist in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space and move about in space; and even if these things are small and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are not very familiarly known, no intellectual revolution is demanded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to enable a man to understand the words of the scientist who is talking
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about them, and to understand as well the sort of reasonings upon which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the doctrine is based.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 9. MATHEMATICS.--Let us now turn to take a glance at the mathematical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences.  Of course, these have to do with things sooner or later, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our mathematical reasonings would be absolutely useless to us if they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could not be applied to the world of things; but in mathematical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasonings we abstract from things for the time being, confident that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we can come back to them when we want to do so, and can make use of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: results obtained in our operations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, every civilized man who is not mentally deficient can perform the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental operations of arithmetic.  He can add and subtract,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: multiply and divide.  In other words, he can use _numbers_.  The man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who has become an accomplished mathematician can use numbers much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: better; but if we are capable of following intelligently the intricate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series of operations that he carries out on the paper before us, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can see the significance of the system of signs which he uses as an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aid, we shall realize that he is only doing in more complicated ways
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what we have been accustomed to do almost from our childhood.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we are interested, not so much in performing the operations, as in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inquiring into what really takes place in a mind when several units are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: grasped together and made into a new unit,--for example, when twelve
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: units are thought as one dozen,--the mathematician has a right to say:
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I leave all that to the psychologist or to the metaphysician; every one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knows in a general way what is meant by a unit, and knows that units
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can be added and subtracted, grouped and separated; I only undertake to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: show how one may avoid error in doing these things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is with geometry as it is with arithmetic.  No man is wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ignorant of points, lines, surfaces, and solids.  We are all aware that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a short line is not a point, a narrow surface is not a line, and a thin
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solid is not a mere surface.  A door so thin as to have only one side
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would be repudiated by every man of sense as a monstrosity.  When the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: geometrician defines for us the point, the line, the surface, and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solid, and when he sets before us an array of axioms, or self-evident
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truths, we follow him with confidence because he seems to be telling us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things that we can directly see to be reasonable; indeed, to be telling
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us things that we have always known.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The truth is that the geometrician does not introduce us to a new world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at all.  He merely gives us a fuller and a more exact account than was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before within our reach of the space relations which obtain in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of external objects, a world we already know pretty well.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Suppose that we say to him: You have spent many years in dividing up
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space and in scrutinizing the relations that are to be discovered in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that realm; now tell us, what is space?  Is it real?  Is it a thing, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a quality of a thing, or merely a relation between things?  And how can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any man think space, when the ideas through which he must think it are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed to be themselves non-extended?  The space itself is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed to be in the mind; how can a collection of non-extended ideas
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: give any inkling of what is meant by extension?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Would any teacher of mathematics dream of discussing these questions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with his class before proceeding to the proof of his propositions?  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is generally admitted that, if such questions are to be answered at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, it is not with the aid of geometrical reasonings that they will be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: answered.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 10. THE SCIENCE OF PSYCHOLOGY.--Now let us come back to a science which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has to do directly with things.  We have seen that the plain man has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some knowledge of minds as well as of material things.  Every one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admits that the psychologist knows minds better.  May we say that his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of minds differs from that of the plain man about as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of plants possessed by the botanist differs from that of all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intelligent persons who have cared to notice them?  Or is it a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of a quite different kind?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who are familiar with the development of the sciences within
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recent years have had occasion to remark the fact that psychology has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been coming more and more to take its place as an independent science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Formerly it was regarded as part of the duty of the philosopher to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treat of the mind and its knowledge; but the psychologist who pretends
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be no more than a psychologist is a product of recent times.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tendency toward specialization is a natural thing, and is quite in line
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with what has taken place in other fields of investigation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When any science becomes an independent discipline, it is recognized
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it is a more or less limited field in which work of a certain kind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is done in a certain way.  Other fields and other kinds of work are to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some extent ignored.  But it is quite to be expected that there should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be some dispute, especially at first, as to what does or does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: properly fall within the limits of a given science.  Where these limits
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall be placed is, after all, a matter of convenience; and sometimes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is not well to be too strict in marking off one field from another.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is well to watch the actual development of a science, and to note
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the direction instinctively taken by investigators in that particular
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: field.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we compare the psychology of a generation or so ago with that of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present day, we cannot but be struck with the fact that there is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: increasing tendency to treat psychology as a _natural science_.  By
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this is not meant, of course, that there is no difference between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychology and the sciences that concern themselves with the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things--psychology has to do primarily with minds and not with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bodies.  But it is meant that, as the other sciences improve upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of the plain man without wholly recasting it, as they accept
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world in which he finds himself and merely attempt to give us a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: better account of it, so the psychologist may accept the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter and of minds recognized by common thought, and may devote
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself to the study of minds, without attempting to solve a class of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problems discussed by the metaphysician.  For example, he may refuse to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discuss the question whether the mind can really know that there is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world with which it stands in relation, and from which it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: receives messages along the avenues of the senses.  He may claim that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is no more his business to treat of this than it is the business of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mathematician to treat of the ultimate nature of space.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus the psychologist assumes without question the existence of an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external real world, a world of matter and motion.  He finds in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world certain organized bodies that present phenomena which he regards
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as indicative of the presence of minds.  He accepts it as a fact that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: each mind knows its own states directly, and knows everything else by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inference from those states, receiving messages from the outer world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: along one set of nerves and reacting along another set.  He conceives
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of minds as wholly dependent upon messages thus conveyed to them from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without.  He tells us how a mind, by the aid of such messages,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gradually builds up for itself the notion of the external world and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the other minds which are connected with bodies to be found in that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may fairly say that all this is merely a development of and an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: improvement upon the plain man's knowledge of minds and of bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is no normal man who does not know that his mind is more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intimately related to his body than it is to other bodies.  We all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish between our ideas of things and the external things they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represent, and we believe that our knowledge of things comes to us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: through the avenues of the senses.  Must we not open our eyes to see,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and unstop our ears to hear?  We all know that we do not perceive other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds directly, but must infer their contents from what takes place in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the bodies to which they are referred--from words and actions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, we know that a knowledge of the outer world and of other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds is built up gradually, and we never think of an infant as knowing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what a man knows, much as we are inclined to overrate the minds of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infants.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fact that the plain man and the psychologist do not greatly differ
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in their point of view must impress every one who is charged with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: task of introducing students to the study of psychology and philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is rather an easy thing to make them follow the reasonings of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist, so long as he avoids metaphysical reflections.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions which he makes seem to them not unreasonable; and, as for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his methods of investigation, there is no one of them which they have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not already employed themselves in a more or less blundering way.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have had recourse to _introspection_, _i.e._ they have noticed the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena of their own minds; they have made use of the _objective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: method_, i.e. they have observed the signs of mind exhibited by other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons and by the brutes; they have sometimes _experimented_--this is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: done by the schoolgirl who tries to find out how best to tease her
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: roommate, and by the boy who covers and uncovers his ears in church to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make the preacher sing a tune.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It may not be easy to make men good psychologists, but it is certainly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not difficult to make them understand what the psychologist is doing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and to make them realize the value of his work.  He, like the workers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the other natural sciences, takes for granted the world of the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man, the world of material things in space and time and of minds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related to those material things.  But when it is a question of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: introducing the student to the reflections of the philosophers the case
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is very different.  We seem to be enticing him into a new and a strange
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world, and he is apt to be filled with suspicion and distrust.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: most familiar things take on an unfamiliar aspect, and questions are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: raised which it strikes the unreflective man as highly absurd even to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: propose.  Of this world of reflective thought I shall say just a word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in what follows.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 11. REFLECTIVE THOUGHT.--If we ask our neighbor to meet us somewhere at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a given hour, he has no difficulty in understanding what we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: requested him to do.  If he wishes to do so, he can be on the spot at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the proper moment.  He may never have asked himself in his whole life
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what he means by space and by time.  He may be quite ignorant that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughtful men have disputed concerning the nature of these for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: centuries past.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And a man may go through the world avoiding disaster year after year by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguishing with some success between what is real and what is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real, and yet he may be quite unable to tell us what, in general, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means for a thing to be real.  Some things are real and some are not;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a rule he seems to be able to discover the difference; of his method
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of procedure he has never tried to give an account to himself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That he has a mind he cannot doubt, and he has some idea of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difference between it and certain other minds; but even the most ardent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: champion of the plain man must admit that he has the most hazy of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: notions touching the nature of his mind.  He seems to be more doubtful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concerning the nature of the mind and its knowledge than he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concerning the nature of external things.  Certainly he appears to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more willing to admit his ignorance in this realm.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And yet the man can hold his own in the world of real things.  He can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish between this thing and that, this place and that, this time
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that.  He can think out a plan and carry it into execution; he can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guess at the contents of other minds and allow this knowledge to find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its place in his plan.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: All of which proves that our knowledge is not necessarily useless
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: because it is rather dim and vague.  It is one thing to use a mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: state; it is another to have a clear comprehension of just what it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and of what elements it may be made up.  The plain man does much of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinking as we all tie our shoes and button our buttons.  It would be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult for us to describe these operations, but we may perform them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very easily nevertheless.  When we say that we _know_ how to tie our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shoes, we only mean that we can tie them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, enough has been said in the preceding sections to make clear that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the vagueness which characterizes many notions which constantly recur
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in common thought is not wholly dispelled by the study of the several
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences.  The man of science, like the plain man, may be able to use
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very well for certain purposes concepts which he is not able to analyze
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfactorily.  For example, he speaks of space and time, cause and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effect, substance and qualities, matter and mind, reality and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unreality.  He certainly is in a position to add to our knowledge of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the things covered by these terms.  But we should never overlook the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fact that the new knowledge which he gives us is a knowledge of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same kind as that which we had before.  He measures for us spaces and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: times; he does not tell us what space and time are.  He points out the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causes of a multitude of occurrences; he does not tell us what we mean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whenever we use the word "cause."  He informs us what we should accept
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as real and what we should repudiate as unreal; he does not try to show
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us what it is to be real and what it is to be unreal.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In other words, the man of science _extends_ our knowledge and makes it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more accurate; he does not _analyze_ certain fundamental conceptions,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we all use, but of which we can usually give a very poor account.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, it is the task of _reflective thought_, not in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first instance, to extend the limits of our knowledge of the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter and of minds, but rather _to make us more clearly conscious of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what that knowledge really is_.  Philosophical reflection takes up and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tries to analyze complex thoughts that men use daily without caring to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analyze them, indeed, without even realizing that they may be subjected
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to analysis.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is to be expected that it should impress many of those who are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: introduced to it for the first time as rather a fantastic creation of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problems that do not present themselves naturally to the healthy mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is no thoughtful man who does not reflect sometimes and about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some things; but there are few who feel impelled to go over the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: edifice of their knowledge and examine it with a critical eye from its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turrets to its foundations.  In a sense, we may say that philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought is not natural, for he who is examining the assumptions upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which all our ordinary thought about the world rests is no longer in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world of the plain man.  He is treating things as men do not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: commonly treat them, and it is perhaps natural that it should appear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some that, in the solvent which he uses, the real world in which we all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rejoice should seem to dissolve and disappear.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have said that it is not the task of reflective thought, _in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first instance_, to extend the limits of our knowledge of the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter and of minds.  This is true.  But this does not mean that, as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: result of a careful reflective analysis, some errors which may creep
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into the thought both of the plain man and of the scientist may not be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exploded; nor does it mean that some new extensions of our knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may not be suggested.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the chapters to follow I shall take up and examine some of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problems of reflective thought.  And I shall consider first those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problems that present themselves to those who try to subject to a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: careful scrutiny our knowledge of the external world.  It is well to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: begin with this, for, even in our common experience, it seems to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed that the knowledge of material things is a something less
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague and indefinite than the knowledge of minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: II.  PROBLEMS TOUCHING THE EXTERNAL WORLD
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER III
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: IS THERE AN EXTERNAL WORLD?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 12. HOW THE PLAIN MAN THINKS HE KNOWS THE WORLD.--As schoolboys we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enjoyed Cicero's joke at the expense of the "minute philosophers."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They denied the immortality of the soul; he affirmed it; and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: congratulated himself upon the fact that, if they were right, they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would not survive to discover it and to triumph over him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: At the close of the seventeenth century the philosopher John Locke was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guilty of a joke of somewhat the same kind.  "I think," said he,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "nobody can, in earnest, be so skeptical as to be uncertain of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence of those things which he sees and feels.  At least, he that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can doubt so far (whatever he may have with his own thoughts) will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never have any controversy with me; since he can never be sure I say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything contrary to his own opinion."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, in this chapter and in certain chapters to follow, I am going to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take up and turn over, so that we may get a good look at them, some of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the problems that have presented themselves to those who have reflected
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the world and the mind as they seem given in our experience.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall begin by asking whether it is not possible to doubt that there is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an external world at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The question cannot best be answered by a jest.  It may, of course, be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absurd to maintain that there is no external world; but surely he, too,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is in an absurd position who maintains dogmatically that there is one,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and is yet quite unable to find any flaw in the reasonings of the man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who seems to be able to show that this belief has no solid foundation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And we must not forget that the men who have thought it worth while to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: raise just such questions as this, during the last twenty centuries,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have been among the most brilliant intellects of the race.  We must not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assume too hastily that they have occupied themselves with mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: trivialities.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Since, therefore, so many thoughtful men have found it worth while to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ask themselves seriously whether there is an external world, or, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: least, how we can know that there is an external world, it is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unreasonable to expect that, by looking for it, we may find in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: common experience or in science some difficulty sufficient to suggest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the doubt which at first strikes the average man as preposterous.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what can such a doubt take its rise?  Let us see.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I think it is scarcely too much to say that the plain man believes that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he _does not_ directly perceive an external world, and that he, at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same time, believes that he _does_ directly perceive one.  It is quite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible to believe contradictory things, when one's thought of them is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhat vague, and when one does not consciously bring them together.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As to the first-mentioned belief.  Does not the plain man distinguish
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between his ideas of things and the things themselves?  Does he not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believe that his ideas come to him through the avenues of the senses?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is he not aware of the fact that, when a sense is disordered, the thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as he perceives it is not like the thing "as it is"?  A blind man does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not see things when they are there; a color-blind man sees them as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: others do not see them; a man suffering under certain abnormal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conditions of the nervous system sees things when they are not there at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, _i.e._ he has hallucinations.  The thing itself, as it seems, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not in the man's mind; it is the idea that is in the man's mind, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that represents the thing.  Sometimes it appears to give a true account
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of it; sometimes it seems to give a garbled account; sometimes it is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: false representative throughout--there is no reality behind it.  It is,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: then, the _idea_ that is immediately known, and not the _thing_; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing is merely _inferred_ to exist.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I do not mean to say that the plain man is conscious of drawing this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclusion.  I only maintain that it seems a natural conclusion to draw
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the facts which he recognizes, and that sometimes he seems to draw
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the conclusion half-consciously.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, we must all admit that when the plain man is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinking about the distinction between ideas and things, but is looking
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at some material object before him, is touching it with his fingers and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turning it about to get a good look at it, it never occurs to him that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he is not directly conscious of the thing itself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He seems to himself to perceive the thing immediately; to perceive it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _as_ it is and _where_ it is; to perceive it as a really extended
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing, out there in space before his body.  He does not think of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself as occupied with mere images, representations of the object.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He may be willing to admit that his mind is in his head, but he cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think that what he sees is in his head.  Is not the object _there_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does he not _see_ and _feel_ it?  Why doubt such evidence as this?  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who tells him that the external world does not exist seems to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: denying what is immediately given in his experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The man who looks at things in this way assumes, of course, that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external object is known directly, and is not a something merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inferred to exist from the presence of a representative image.  May one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: embrace this belief and abandon the other one?  If we elect to do this,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we appear to be in difficulties at once.  All the considerations which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: made us distinguish so carefully between our ideas of things and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things themselves crowd in upon us.  Can it be that we know things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independently of the avenues of the senses?  Would a man with different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses know things just as we do?  How can any man suffer from an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hallucination, if things are not inferred from images, but are known
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independently?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difficulties encountered appear sufficiently serious even if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: keep to that knowledge of things which seems to be given in common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience.  But even the plain man has heard of atoms and molecules;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and if he accepts the extension of knowledge offered him by the man of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science, he must admit that, whatever this apparently immediately
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived external thing may be, it cannot be the external thing that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science assures him is out there in space beyond his body, and which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be a very different sort of thing from the thing he seems to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive.  The thing he perceives must, then, be _appearance_; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: where can that appearance be if not in his own mind?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The man who has made no study of philosophy at all does not usually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think these things out; but surely there are interrogation marks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: written up all over his experience, and he misses them only because he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not see clearly.  By judiciously asking questions one may often
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lead him either to affirm or to deny that he has an immediate knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the external world, pretty much as one pleases.  If he affirms it,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his position does not seem to be a wholly satisfactory one, as we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen; and if he denies it, he makes the existence of the external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholly a matter of inference from the presence of ideas in the mind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and he must stand ready to justify this inference.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To many men it has seemed that the inference is not an easy one to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justify.  One may say: We could have no ideas of things, no sensations,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if real things did not exist and make an impression upon our senses.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But to this it may be answered: How is that statement to be proved?  Is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it to be proved by observing that, when things are present and affect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the senses, there come into being ideas which represent the things?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Evidently such a proof as this is out of the question, for, if it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true that we know external things only by inference and never
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immediately, then we can never prove by observation that ideas and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things are thus connected.  And if it is not to be proved by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observation, how shall it be proved?  Shall we just assume it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dogmatically and pass on to something else?  Surely there is enough in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the experience of the plain man to justify him in raising the question
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether he can certainly know that there is an external world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 13. THE PSYCHOLOGIST AND THE EXTERNAL WORLD.--We have seen just above
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the doubt regarding the existence of the world seems to have its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: root in the familiar distinction between ideas and things, appearances
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the realities which they are supposed to represent.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist has much to say about ideas; and if sharpening and making
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear this distinction has anything to do with stirring up doubts, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is natural to suppose that they should become more insistent when one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has exchanged the ignorance of everyday life for the knowledge of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, when the psychologist asks how a given mind comes to have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of any external thing, he finds his answer in the messages
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which have been brought to the mind by means of the bodily senses.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describes the sense-organs and the nervous connections between these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the brain, and tells us that when certain nervous impulses have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: traveled, let us say, from the eye or the ear to the brain, one has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations of sight or sound.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He describes for us in detail how, out of such sensations and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
