author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: memories of such sensations, we frame mental images of external things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Between the mental image and the thing that it represents he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguishes sharply, and he informs us that the mind knows no more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about the external thing than is contained in such images.  That a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing is present can be known only by the fact that a message from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing is sent along the nerves, and what the thing is must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: determined from the character of the message.  Given the image in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absence of the thing,--that is to say, an hallucination,--the mind will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: naturally suppose that the thing is present.  This false supposition
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be corrected by a direct inspection of the thing, for such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: direct inspection of things is out of the question.  The only way in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the mind concerned can discover that the thing is absent is by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: referring to its other experiences.  This image is compared with other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: images and is discovered to be in some way abnormal.  We decide that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is a false representative and has no corresponding reality behind it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This doctrine taken as it stands seems to cut the mind off from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world very completely; and the most curious thing about it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it seems to be built up on the assumption that it is not really
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true.  How can one know certainly that there is a world of material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, including human bodies with their sense-organs and nerves, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no mind has ever been able to inspect directly anything of the sort?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How can we tell that a sensation arises when a nervous impulse has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carried along a sensory nerve and has reached the brain, if every mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is shut up to the charmed circle of its own ideas?  The anatomist and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the physiologist give us very detailed accounts of the sense-organs and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the brain; the physiologist even undertakes to measure the speed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with which the impulse passes along a nerve; the psychologist accepts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and uses the results of their labors.  But can all this be done in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absence of any first-hand knowledge of the things of which one is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: talking?  Remember that, if the psychologist is right, any external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object, eye, ear, nerve, or brain, which we can perceive directly, is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental complex, a something in the mind and not external at all.  How
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall we prove that there are objects, ears, eyes, nerves, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brains,--in short, all the requisite mechanism for the calling into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence of sensations,--in an outer world which is not immediately
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived but is only inferred to exist?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I do not wish to be regarded as impugning the right of the psychologist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to make the assumptions which he does, and to work as he does.  He has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a right to assume, with the plain man, that there is an external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that we know it.  But a very little reflection must make it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: manifest that he seems, at least, to be guilty of an inconsistency, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he who wishes to think clearly should strive to see just where the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: trouble lies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So much, at least, is evident: the man who is inclined to doubt whether
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is, after all, any real external world, appears to find in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist's distinction between ideas and things something like an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: excuse for his doubt.  To get to the bottom of the matter and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dissipate his doubt one has to go rather deeply into metaphysics.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely wish to show just here that the doubt is not a gratuitous one,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but is really suggested to the thoughtful mind by a reflection upon our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of things.  And, as we are all apt to think that the man of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science is less given to busying himself with useless subtleties than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the philosopher, I shall, before closing this chapter, present some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: paragraphs upon the subject from the pen of a professor of mathematics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and mechanics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 14. THE "TELEPHONE EXCHANGE."--"We are accustomed to talk," writes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Professor Karl Pearson,[1] "of the 'external world,' of the 'reality'
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outside us.  We speak of individual objects having an existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent of our own.  The store of past sense-impressions, our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughts and memories, although most probably they have beside their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychical element a close correspondence with some physical change or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impress in the brain, are yet spoken of as _inside_ ourselves.  On the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other hand, although if a sensory nerve be divided anywhere short of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the brain, we lose the corresponding class of sense impression, we yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speak of many sense-impressions, such as form and texture, as existing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outside ourselves.  How close then can we actually get to this supposed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world outside ourselves?  Just as near but no nearer than the brain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: terminals of the sensory nerves.  We are like the clerk in the central
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: telephone exchange who cannot get nearer to his customers than his end
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the telephone wires.  We are indeed worse off than the clerk, for to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carry out the analogy properly we must suppose him _never to have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outside the telephone exchange, never to have seen a customer or any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one like a customer--in short, never, except through the telephone
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wire, to have come in contact with the outside universe_.  Of that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 'real' universe outside himself he would be able to form no direct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impression; the real universe for him would be the aggregate of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constructs from the messages which were caused by the telephone wires
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in his office.  About those messages and the ideas raised in his mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by them he might reason and draw his inferences; and his conclusions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would be correct--for what?  For the world of telephonic messages, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the type of messages that go through the telephone.  Something definite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and valuable he might know with regard to the spheres of action and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought of his telephonic subscribers, but outside those spheres he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could have no experience.  Pent up in his office he could never have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen or touched even a telephonic subscriber _in himself_.  Very much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the position of such a telephone clerk is the conscious _ego_ of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: each one of us seated at the brain terminals of the sensory nerves.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Not a step nearer than those terminals can the _ego_ get to the 'outer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world,' and what in and for themselves are the subscribers to its nerve
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange it has no means of ascertaining.  Messages in the form of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense-impressions come flowing in from that 'outside world,' and these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we analyze, classify, store up, and reason about.  But of the nature of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 'things-in-themselves,' of what may exist at the other end of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of telephone wires, we know nothing at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "But the reader, perhaps, remarks, 'I not only see an object, but I can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _touch_ it.  I can trace the nerve from the tip of my finger to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain.  I am not like the telephone clerk, I can follow my network of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wires to their terminals and find what is at the other end of them.'
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Can you, reader?  Think for a moment whether your _ego_ has for one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moment got away from his brain exchange.  The sense-impression that you
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call touch was just as much as sight felt only at the brain end of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensory nerve.  What has told you also of the nerve from the tip of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: your finger to your brain?  Why, sense-impressions also, messages
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conveyed along optic or tactile sensory nerves.  In truth, all you have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been doing is to employ one subscriber to your telephone exchange to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tell you about the wire that goes to a second, but you are just as far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as ever from tracing out for yourself the telephone wires to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individual subscriber and ascertaining what his nature is in and for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself.  The immediate sense-impression is just as far removed from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what you term the 'outside world' as the store of impresses.  If our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: telephone clerk had recorded by aid of a phonograph certain of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: messages from the outside world on past occasions, then if any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: telephonic message on its receipt set several phonographs repeating
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: past messages, we have an image analogous to what goes on in the brain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Both telephone and phonograph are equally removed from what the clerk
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: might call the 'real outside world,' but they enable him through their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sounds to construct a universe; he projects those sounds, which are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: really inside his office, outside his office, and speaks of them as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external universe.  This outside world is constructed by him from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contents of the inside sounds, which differ as widely from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things-in-themselves as language, the symbol, must always differ from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the thing it symbolizes.  For our telephone clerk sounds would be the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real world, and yet we can see how conditioned and limited it would be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by the range of his particular telephone subscribers and by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contents of their messages.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "So it is with our brain; the sounds from telephone and phonograph
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: correspond to immediate and stored sense-impressions.  These
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense-impressions we project as it were outwards and term the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world outside ourselves.  But the things-in-themselves which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense-impressions symbolize, the 'reality,' as the metaphysicians wish
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to call it, at the other end of the nerve, remains unknown and is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unknowable.  Reality of the external world lies for science and for us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in combinations of form and color and touch--sense-impressions as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: widely divergent from the thing 'at the other end of the nerve' as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sound of the telephone from the subscriber at the other end of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wire.  We are cribbed and confined in this world of sense-impressions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: like the exchange clerk in his world of sounds, and not a step beyond
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can we get.  As his world is conditioned and limited by his particular
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: network of wires, so ours is conditioned by our nervous system, by our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: organs of sense.  Their peculiarities determine what is the nature of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the outside world which we construct.  It is the similarity in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: organs of sense and in the perceptive faculty of all normal human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beings which makes the outside world the same, or _practically_ the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same, for them all.  To return to the old analogy, it is as if two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: telephone exchanges had very nearly identical groups of subscribers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In this case a wire between the two exchanges would soon convince the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imprisoned clerks that they had something in common and peculiar to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves.  That conviction corresponds in our comparison to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognition of other consciousness."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I suggest that this extract be read over carefully, not once but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: several times, and that the reader try to make quite clear to himself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the position of the clerk in the telephone exchange, _i.e._ the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position of the mind in the body, as depicted by Professor Pearson,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before recourse is had to the criticisms of any one else.  One cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: find anywhere better material for critical philosophical reflection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As has been seen, our author accepts without question, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychological doctrine that the mind is shut up within the circle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the messages that are conducted to it along the sensory nerves, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it cannot directly perceive anything truly external.  He carries
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his doctrine out to the bitter end in the conclusion that, since we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have never had experience of anything beyond sense-impressions, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have no ground for an inference to anything beyond, we must recognize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the only external world of which we know anything is an external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world built up out of sense-impressions.  It is, thus, in the mind, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not external at all; it is only "projected outwards," _thought of_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as though it were beyond us.  Shall we leave the inconsistent position
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the plain man and of the psychologist and take our refuge in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of projected mental constructs?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Before the reader makes up his mind to do this, I beg him to consider
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the following:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) If the only external world of which we have a right to speak at all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is a construct in the mind or _ego_, we may certainly affirm that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world is in the _ego_, but does it sound sensible to say that the _ego_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is somewhere in the world?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) If all external things are really inside the mind, and are only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "projected" outwards, of course our own bodies, sense-organs, nerves,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and brains, are really inside and are merely projected outwards.  Now,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do the sense-impressions of which everything is to be constructed "come
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: flowing in" along these nerves that are really inside?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) Can we say, when a nerve lies entirely within the mind or _ego_,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that this same mind or _ego_ is nearer to one end of the nerve than it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is to the other?  How shall we picture to ourselves "the conscious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _ego_ of each one of us seated at the brain terminals of the sensory
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nerves"?  How can the _ego_ place the whole of itself at the end of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nerve which it has constructed within itself?  And why is it more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult for it to get to one end of a nerve like this than it is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: get to the other?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) Why should the thing "at the other end of the nerve" remain unknown
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and unknowable?  Since the nerve is entirely in the mind, is purely a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental construct, can anything whatever be at the end of it without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: being in the mind?  And if the thing in question is not in the mind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: how are we going to prove that it is any nearer to one end of a nerve
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is inside the mind than it is to the other?  If it may really be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said to be at the end of the nerve, why may we not know it quite as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well as we do the end of the nerve, or any other mental construct?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It must be clear to the careful reader of Professor Pearson's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: paragraphs, that he does not confine himself strictly to the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mere "projections," to an outer world which is really _inner_.  If he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: did this, the distinction between inner and outer would disappear.  Let
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us consider for a moment the imprisoned clerk.  He is in a telephone
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange, about him are wires and subscribers.  He gets only sounds and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must build up his whole universe of things out of sounds.  Now we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposing him to be in a telephone exchange, to be receiving messages,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be building up a world out of these messages.  Do we for a moment
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of him as building up, out of the messages which came along the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wires, those identical wires which carried the messages and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subscribers which sent them?  Never! we distinguish between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange, with its wires and subscribers, and the messages received and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: worked up into a world.  In picturing to ourselves the telephone
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange, we are doing what the plain man and the psychologist do when
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they distinguish between mind and body,--they never suppose that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: messages which come through the senses are identical with the senses
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: through which they come.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But suppose we maintain that there is no such thing as a telephone
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange, with its wires and subscribers, which is not to be found
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: within some clerk.  Suppose the real external world is something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _inner_ and only "projected" without, mistakenly supposed by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unthinking to be without.  Suppose it is nonsense to speak of a wire
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is not in the mind of a clerk.  May we under such circumstances
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describe any clerk as _in a telephone exchange_? as _receiving
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: messages_? as _no nearer_ to his subscribers than his end of the wire?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: May we say that sense-impressions _come flowing in_ to him?  The whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: figure of the telephone exchange becomes an absurdity when we have once
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: placed the exchange within the clerk.  Nor can we think of two clerks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as connected by a wire, when it is affirmed that every wire must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "really" be in some clerk.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The truth is, that, in the extracts which I have given above and in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many other passages in the same volume, the real external world, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world which does not exist in the mind but _without_ it, is much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discredited, and is yet not actually discarded.  The ego is placed at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the brain terminals of the sensory nerves, and it receives messages
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which _flow in_; _i.e._ the clerk is actually placed in an exchange.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That the existence of the exchange is afterward denied in so many words
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not mean that it has not played and does not continue to play an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: important part in the thought of the author.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is interesting to see how a man of science, whose reflections compel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him to deny the existence of the external world that we all seem to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive and that we somehow recognize as distinct from anything in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds, is _nevertheless compelled to admit the existence of this world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at every turn_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But if we do admit it, what shall we make of it?  Shall we deny the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth of what the psychologist has to tell us about a knowledge of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things only through the sensations to which they give rise?  We cannot,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surely, do that.  Shall we affirm that we know the external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly, and at the same time that we do not know it directly, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only indirectly, and through the images which arise in our minds?  That
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems inconsistent.  Certainly there is material for reflection here.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless the more we reflect on that material, the more evident
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does it become that the plain man cannot be wrong in believing in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world which seems revealed in his experiences.  We find that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all attempts to discredit it rest upon the implicit assumption of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence, and fall to the ground when that existence is honestly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: denied.  So our problem changes its form.  We no longer ask: Is there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an external world?  but rather: _What_ is the external world, and how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does it differ from the world of mere ideas?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "The Grammar of Science," 2d Ed., London, 1900, pp. 60-63.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER IV
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: SENSATIONS AND "THINGS"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 15. SENSE AND IMAGINATION.--Every one distinguishes between things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived and things only imagined.  With open eyes I see the desk
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before me; with eyes closed, I can imagine it.  I lay my hand on it and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feel it; I can, without laying my hand on it, imagine that I feel it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I raise my eyes, and see the pictures on the wall opposite me; I can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sit here and call before my mind the image of the door by which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: house is entered.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What is the difference between sense and imagination?  It must be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difference of which we are all somehow conscious, for we unhesitatingly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish between the things we perceive and the things we merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagine.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is well to remember at the outset that the two classes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences are not wholly different.  The blue color that I imagine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems blue.  It does not lose this quality because it is only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imaginary.  The horse that I imagine seems to have four legs, like a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: horse perceived.  As I call it before my mind, it seems as large as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real horse.  Neither the color, nor the size, nor the distribution of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parts, nor any other attribute of the sort appears to be different in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the imaginary object from what it is in the object as given in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The two experiences are, nevertheless, not the same; and every one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knows that they are not the same.  One difference that roughly marks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out the two classes of experiences from one another is that, as a rule,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our sense-experiences are more vivid than are the images that exist in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the imagination.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I say, as a rule, for we cannot always remark this difference.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sensations may be very clear and unmistakable, but they may also be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very faint and indefinite.  When a man lays his hand firmly on my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shoulder, I may be in little doubt whether I feel a sensation or do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not; but when he touches my back very lightly, I may easily be in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doubt, and may ask myself in perplexity whether I have really been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touched or whether I have merely imagined it.  As a vessel recedes and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becomes a mere speck upon the horizon, I may well wonder, before I feel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sure that it is really quite out of sight, whether I still see the dim
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little point, or whether I merely imagine that I see it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, things merely imagined may sometimes be very vivid
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and insistent.  To some persons, what exists in the imagination is dim
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and indefinite in the extreme.  Others imagine things vividly, and can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describe what is present only to the imagination almost as though it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were something seen.  Finally, we know that an image may become so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vivid and insistent as to be mistaken for an external thing.  That is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to say, there are such things as hallucinations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The criterion of vividness will not, therefore, always serve to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish between what is given in the sense and what is only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagined.  And, indeed, it becomes evident, upon reflection, that we do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not actually make it our ultimate test.  We may be quite willing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit that faint sensations may come to be confused with what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagined, with "ideas," but we always regard such a confusion as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somebody's error.  We are not ready to admit that things perceived
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: faintly are things imagined, or that vivid "ideas" are things perceived
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by sense.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us come back to the illustrations with which we started.  How do I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know that I perceive the desk before me; and how do I know that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sitting here, I imagine, and do not see, the front door of the house?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: My criterion is this: when I have the experience I call "seeing my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: desk," the bit of experience which presents itself as my desk is in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain setting.  That is to say, the desk seen must be in a certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation to my body, and this body, as I know it, also consists of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences.  Thus, if I am to know that I see the desk, I must realize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that my eyes are open, that the object is in front of me and not behind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: me, etc.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The desk as seen varies with the relation to the body in certain ways
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we regard as natural and explicable.  When I am near it, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: visual experience is not just what it is when I recede from it.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: how can I know that I am near the desk or far from it?  What do these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expressions mean?  Their full meaning will become clearer in the next
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter, but here I may say that nearness and remoteness must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: measured for me in experiences of some sort, or I would never know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything as near to or far from my body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, all our sensory experiences are experiences that fall into a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain system or order.  It is a system which we all recognize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: implicitly, for we all reject as merely imaginary those experiences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which lack this setting.  If my eyes are shut--I am speaking now of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: eyes as experienced, as felt or perceived, as given in sensation--I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never say; "I see my desk," no matter how vivid the image of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object.  Those who believe in "second sight" sometimes talk of seeing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things not in this setting, but the very name they give to the supposed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience indicates that there is something abnormal about it.  No one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinks it remarkable that I see the desk before which I perceive myself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be sitting with open eyes.  Every one would think it strange if I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could see and describe the table in the next room, now shut away from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: me.  When a man thinks he hears his name pronounced, and, turning his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: head, seeks in vain for the speaker, he sets his experience down as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hallucination.  He says, I did not really hear that; I merely imagined
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: May one not, with open eyes, have a hallucination of vision, just as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one may seem to hear one's name pronounced when no one is by?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Certainly.  But in each case the experience may be proved to be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hallucination, nevertheless.  It may be recognized that the sensory
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: setting is incomplete, though it may not, at first, seem so.  Thus the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unreal object which seems to be seen may be found to be a thing that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be touched.  Or, when one has attained to a relatively complete
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of the system of experiences recognized as sensory, one may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make use of roundabout methods of ascertaining that the experience in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question does not really have the right setting.  Thus, the ghost which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is seen by the terrified peasant at midnight, but which cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: photographed, we may unhesitatingly set down as something imagined and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not really seen.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: All our sensations are, therefore, experiences which take their place
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a certain setting.  This is our ultimate criterion.  We need not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take the word of the philosopher for it.  We need only reflect, and ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves how we know that, in a given case, we are seeing or hearing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or touching something, and are not merely imagining it.  In every case,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we shall find that we come back to the same test.  In common life, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apply the test instinctively, and with little realization of what we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are doing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And if we turn to the psychologist, whose business it is to be more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exact and scientific, we find that he gives us only a refinement of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this same criterion.  It is important to him to distinguish between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is given in sensation and what is furnished by memory or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagination, and he tells us that sensation is the result of a message
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conducted along a sensory nerve to the brain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Here we see emphasized the relation to the body which has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mentioned above.  If we ask the psychologist how he knows that the body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he is talking about is a real body, and not merely an imagined one, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has to fall back upon the test which is common to us all.  A real hand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is one which we see with the eyes open, and which we touch with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other hand.  If our experiences of our own body had not the setting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which marks all sensory experiences, we could never say: I _perceive_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that my body is near the desk.  When we call our body real, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasted with things imaginary, we recognize that this group of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences belongs to the class described; it is given in sensation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and is not merely thought of.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It will be observed that, in distinguishing between sensations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things imaginary, we never go beyond the circle of our experiences.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do not reach out to a something _beyond_ or _behind_ experiences, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say: When such a reality is present, we may affirm that we have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation, and when it is not, we may call the experience imaginary.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If there were such a reality as this, it would do us little good, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: since it is not supposed to be perceived directly, we should have to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: depend upon the sensations to prove the presence of the reality, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could not turn to the reality and ask it whether we were or were not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiencing a sensation.  The distinction between sensations and what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is imaginary is an _observed_ distinction.  It can be _proved_ that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some experiences are sensory and that some are not.  This means that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in drawing the distinction, we remain within the circle of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There has been much unnecessary mystification touching this supposed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reality behind experiences.  In the next chapter we shall see in what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses the word "reality" may properly be used, and in what sense it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may not.  There is a danger in using it loosely and vaguely.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 16. MAY WE CALL "THINGS" GROUPS OF SENSATIONS?--Now, the external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems to the plain man to be directly given in his sense experiences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He is willing to admit that the table in the next room, of which he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely thinking, is known at one remove, so to speak.  But this desk
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: here before him: is it not known directly?  Not the mental image, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mere representative, but the desk itself, a something that is physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and not mental?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And the psychologist, whatever his theory of the relation between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind and the world, seems to support him, at least, in so far as to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintain that in sensation the external world is known as directly as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is possible for the external world to be known, and that one can get
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no more of it than is presented in sensation.  If a sense is lacking,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an aspect of the world as given is also lacking; if a sense is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: defective, as in the color-blind, the defect is reflected in the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon which one gazes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such considerations, especially when taken together with what has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said at the close of the last section about the futility of looking for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a reality behind our sensations, may easily suggest rather a startling
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possibility.  May it not be, if we really are shut up to the circle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our experiences, that the physical things, which we have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accustomed to look upon as non-mental, are nothing more than complexes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of sensations?  Granted that there seems to be presented in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience a material world as well as a mind, may it not be that this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material world is a mental thing of a certain kind--a mental thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasted with other mental things, such as imaginary things?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This question has always been answered in the affirmative by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealists, who claim that all existence must be regarded as psychical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence.  Their doctrine we shall consider later (sections 49 and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 53).  It will be noticed that we seem to be back again with Professor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Pearson in the last chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this question I make the following answer: In the first place, I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remark that even the plain man distinguishes somehow between his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and external things.  He thinks that he has reason to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believe that things do not cease to exist when he no longer has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations.  Moreover, he believes that things do not always appear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his senses as they really are.  If we tell him that his sensations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _are_ the things, it shocks his common sense.  He answers: Do you mean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to tell me that complexes of sensation can be on a shelf or in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: drawer? can be cut with a knife or broken with the hands?  He feels
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that there must be some real distinction between sensations and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things without him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the notions of the plain man on such matters as these are not very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear, and what he says about sensations and things is not always
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: edifying.  But it is clear that he feels strongly that the man who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would identify them is obliterating a distinction to which his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience testifies unequivocally.  We must not hastily disregard his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: protest.  He is sometimes right in his feeling that things are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: identical, even when he cannot prove it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the second place, I remark that, in this instance, the plain man is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the right, and can be shown to be in the right.  "Things" are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: groups of sensations.  The distinction between them will be explained
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the next section.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 17. THE DISTINCTION BETWEEN SENSATIONS AND "THINGS"--Suppose that I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stand in my study and look at the fire in the grate.  I am experiencing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations, and am not busied merely with an imaginary fire.  But may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my whole experience of the fire be summed up as an experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and their changes?  Let us see.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If I shut my eyes, the fire disappears.  Does any one suppose that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fire has been annihilated?  No.  We say, I no longer see it, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing has happened to the fire.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again, I may keep my eyes open, and simply turn my head.  The fire
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: disappears once more.  Does any one suppose that my turning my head has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: done anything to the fire?  We say unhesitatingly, my sensations have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changed, but the fire has remained as it was.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Still, again, I may withdraw from the fire.  Its heat seems to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diminished.  Has the fire really grown less hot?  And if I could
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: withdraw to a sufficient distance, I know that the fire would appear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: me smaller and less bright.  Could I get far enough away to make it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem the faintest speck in the field of vision, would I be tempted to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: claim that the fire shrunk and grew faint merely because I walked away
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from it?  Surely not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, suppose that I stand on the same spot and look at the fire without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turning my head.  The stick at which I am gazing catches the flame,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: blazes up, turns red, and finally falls together, a little mass of gray
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ashes.  Shall I describe this by saying that my sensations have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changed, or may I say that the fire itself has changed?  The plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the philosopher alike use the latter expression in such a case as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us take another illustration.  I walk towards the distant house on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the plain before me.  What I see as my goal seems to grow larger and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brighter.  It does not occur to me to maintain that the house changes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as I advance.  But, at a given instant, changes of a different sort
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make their appearance.  Smoke arises, and flames burst from the roof.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now I have no hesitation in saying that changes are taking place in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: house.  It would seem foolish to describe the occurrence as a mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: change in my sensations.  Before it was my sensations that changed; now
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is the house itself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We are drawing this distinction between changes in our sensations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changes in things at every hour in the day.  I cannot move without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: making things appear and disappear.  If I wag my head, the furniture
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems to dance, and I regard it as a mere seeming.  I count on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clock's going when I no longer look upon its face.  It would be absurd
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to hold that the distinction is a mere blunder, and has no foundation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in our experience.  The role it plays is too important for that.  If we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obliterate it, the real world of material things which seems to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed in our experience melts into a chaos of fantastic experiences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whose appearances and disappearances seem to be subject to no law.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And it is worthy of remark that it is not merely in common life that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the distinction is drawn.  Every man of science must give heed to it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The psychologist does, it is true, pay much attention to sensations;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but even he distinguishes between the sensations which he is studying
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the material things to which he relates them, such as brains and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense-organs.  And those who cultivate the physical sciences strive,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when they give an account of things and their behavior, to lay before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us a history of changes analogous to the burning of the stick and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the house, excluding mere changes in sensations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is no physicist or botanist or zooelogist who has not our common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience that things as perceived by us--our experiences of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things--appear or disappear or change their character when we open or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shut our eyes or move about.  But nothing of all this appears in their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: books.  What they are concerned with is things and their changes, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they do not consider such matters as these as falling within their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: province.  If a botanist could not distinguish between the changes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which take place in a plant, and the changes which take place in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations as he is occupied in studying the plant, but should tell us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the plant grows smaller as one recedes from it, we should set him
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: down as weak-minded.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That the distinction is everywhere drawn, and that we must not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obliterate it, is very evident.  But we are in the presence of what has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seemed to many men a grave difficulty.  Are not things presented in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience only as we have sensations?  what is it to perceive a thing?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is it not to have sensations? how, then, _can_ we distinguish between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and things?  We certainly do so all the time, in spite of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the protest of the philosopher; but many of us do so with a haunting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense that our behavior can scarcely be justified by the reason.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Our difficulty, however, springs out of an error of our own.  Grasping
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imperfectly the full significance of the word "sensation," we extend
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its use beyond what is legitimate, and we call by that name experiences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which are not sensations at all.  Thus the external world comes to seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to us to be not really a something contrasted with the mental, but a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part of the mental world.  We accord to it the attributes of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: latter, and rob it of those distinguishing attributes which belong to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it by right.  When we have done this, we may feel impelled to say, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: did Professor Pearson, that things are not really "outside" of us, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they seem to be, but are merely "projected" outside--thought of as if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they were "outside."  All this I must explain at length.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us come back to the first of the illustrations given above, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: case of the fire in my study.  As I stand and look at it, what shall I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call the red glow which I observe?  Shall I call it a _quality of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing_, or shall I call it a _sensation_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this I answer: _I may call it either the one or the other, according
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to its setting among other experiences_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen (section 15) that sensations and things merely imaginary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are distinguished from one another by their setting.  With open eyes we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see things; with our eyes closed we can imagine them: we see what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before us; we imagine what lies behind our backs.  If we confine our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attention to the bit of experience itself, we have no means of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: determining whether it is sensory or imaginary.  Only its setting can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: decide that point.  Here, we have come to another distinction of much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same sort.  That red glow, that bit of experience, taken by itself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and abstracted from all other experiences, cannot be called either a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation or the quality of a thing.  Only its context can give us the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to call it the one or the other.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This ought to become clear when we reflect upon the illustration of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fire.  We have seen that one whole series of changes has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unhesitatingly described as a series of changes in my sensations.  Why
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was this?  Because it was observed to depend upon changes in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations of my body, my senses (a certain group of experiences), to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the bit of experience I call the fire.  Another series was described as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a series of changes in the fire.  Why?  Because, the relation to my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses remaining unchanged, changes still took place, and had to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accounted for in other ways.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is a matter of common knowledge that they can be accounted for in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other ways.  This is not a discovery of the philosopher.  He can only
