title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: invite us to think over the matter and see what the unlearned and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: learned are doing at every moment.  Sometimes they are noticing that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences change as they turn their heads or walk toward or away from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objects; sometimes they abstract from this, and consider the series of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changes that take place independently of this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That bit of experience, that red glow, is not related only to my body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such experiences are related also to each other; they stand in a vast
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent system of relations, which, as we have seen, the man of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science can study without troubling himself to consider sensations at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all.  This system is the external world--the external world as known or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as knowable, the only external world that it means anything for us to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: talk about.  As having its place in this system, a bit of experience is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not a sensation, but is a quality or aspect of a thing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sensations, then, to be sensations, must be bits of experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: considered in their relation to some organ of sense.  They should never
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be confused with qualities of things, which are experiences in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different setting.  It is as unpardonable to confound the two as it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to confound sensations with things imaginary.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may not, therefore, say that "things" are groups of sensations.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may, if we please, describe them as complexes of qualities.  And we may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not say that the "things" we perceive are really "inside" of us and are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely "projected outside."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What can "inside" and "outside" mean?  Only this.  We recognize in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience two distinct orders, the _objective order_, the system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena which constitutes the material world, and the _subjective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: order_, the order of things mental, to which belong sensations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "ideas."  That is "outside" which belongs to the objective order.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word has no other meaning when used in this connection.  That is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "inside" which belongs to the subjective order, and is contrasted with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the former.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we deny that there is an objective order, an external world, and say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that everything is "inside," we lose our distinction, and even the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "inside" becomes meaningless.  It indicates no contrast.  When men fall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into the error of talking in this way, what they do is to _keep_ the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world and gain the distinction, and at the same time to _deny_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the existence of the world which has furnished it.  In other words,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they put the clerk into a telephone exchange, and then tell us that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exchange does not really exist.  He is inside--of what?  He is inside
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of nothing.  Then, can he really be inside?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We see, thus, that the plain man and the man of science are quite right
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in accepting the external world.  The objective order is known as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly as is the subjective order.  Both are orders of experiences;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are open to observation, and we have, in general, little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficulty in distinguishing between them, as the illustrations given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above amply prove.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 18. THE EXISTENCE OF MATERIAL THINGS.--One difficulty seems to remain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and to call for a solution.  We all believe that material things exist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we no longer perceive them.  We believe that they existed before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they came within the field of our observation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In these positions the man of science supports us.  The astronomer has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no hesitation in saying that the comet, which has sailed away through
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space, exists, and will return.  The geologist describes for us the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world as it was in past ages, when no eye was opened upon it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But has it not been stated above that the material world is an order of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _experiences_? and can there be such a thing as an experience that is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not _experienced_ by somebody?  In other words, can the world exist,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: except as it is _perceived to exist_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This seeming difficulty has occasioned much trouble to philosophers in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the past.  Bishop Berkeley (1684-1753) said, "To exist is to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived."  There are those who agree with him at the present day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Their difficulty would have disappeared had they examined with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sufficient care the meaning of the word "exist."  We have no right to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pass over the actual uses of such words, and to give them a meaning of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our own.  If one thing seems as certain as any other, it is that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things exist when we do not perceive them.  On what ground may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the philosopher combat the universal opinion, the dictum of common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense and of science?  When we look into his reasonings, we find that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he is influenced by the error discussed at length in the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section--he has confused the phenomena of the two orders of experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have said that, when we concern ourselves with the objective order,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we abstract or should abstract, from the relations which things bear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our senses.  We account for phenomena by referring to other phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we have reason to accept as their physical conditions or causes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We do not consider that a physical cause is effective only while we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive it.  When we come back to this notion of our perceiving a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing or not perceiving it, we have left the objective order and passed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: over to the subjective.  We have left the consideration of "things" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have turned to sensations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is no reason why we should do this.  The physical order is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent order, as we have seen.  The man of science, when he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: endeavoring to discover whether some thing or quality of a thing really
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existed at some time in the past, is not in the least concerned to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: establish the fact that some one saw it.  No one ever saw the primitive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fire-mist from which, as we are told, the world came into being.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the scientist cares little for that.  He is concerned only to prove
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the phenomena he is investigating really have a place in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objective order.  If he decides that they have, he is satisfied; he has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proved something to exist.  _To belong to the objective order is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exist as a physical thing or quality_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When the plain man and the man of science maintain that a physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing exists, they use the word in precisely the same sense.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaning they give to it is the proper meaning of the word.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justified by immemorial usage, and it marks a real distinction.  Shall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we allow the philosopher to tell us that we must not use it in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense, but must say that only sensations and ideas exist?  Surely not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This would mean that we permit him to obliterate for us the distinction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between the external world and what is mental.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But is it right to use the word "experience" to indicate the phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which have a place in the objective order?  Can an experience be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything but mental?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There can be no doubt that the suggestions of the word are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unfortunate--it has what we may call a subjective flavor.  It suggests
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, after all, the things we perceive are sensations or percepts, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must, to exist at all, exist in a mind.  As we have seen, this is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error, and an error which we all avoid in actual practice.  We do not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take sensations for things, and we recognize clearly enough that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one thing for a material object to exist and another for it to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Why, then, use the word "experience"?  Simply because we have no better
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word.  We must use it, and not be misled by the associations which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cling to it.  The word has this great advantage: it brings out clearly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the fact that all our knowledge of the external world rests ultimately
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon those phenomena which, when we consider them in relation to our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses, we recognize as sensations.  We cannot start out from mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imaginings to discover what the world was like in the ages past.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is this truth that is recognized by the plain man, when he maintains
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, in the last resort, we can know things only in so far as we see,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch, hear, taste, and smell them; and by the psychologist, when he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tells us that, in sensation, the external world is revealed as directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as it is possible that it could be revealed.  But it is a travesty on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this truth to say that we do not know things, but know only our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations of sight, touch, taste, hearing, and the like.[1]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] See the note on this chapter at the close of the volume.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER V
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: APPEARANCES AND REALITIES
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 19. THINGS AND THEIR APPEARANCES.--We have seen in the last chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that there is an external world and that it is given in our experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is an objective order, and we are all capable of distinguishing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between it and the subjective.  He who says that we perceive only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and ideas flies in the face of the common experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mankind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we are not yet through with the subject.  We all make a distinction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between things as they _appear_ and things as they _really are_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we ask the plain man, What is the real external world? the first
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: answer that seems to present itself to his mind is this: Whatever we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can see, hear, touch, taste, or smell may be regarded as belonging to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the real world.  What we merely imagine does not belong to it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That this answer is not a very satisfactory one occurred to men's minds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very early in the history of reflective thought.  The ancient skeptic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said to himself: The colors of objects vary according to the light, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: according to the position and distance of the objects; can we say that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any object has a real color of its own?  A staff stuck into water looks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bent, but feels straight to the touch; why believe the testimony of one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense rather than that of another?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such questionings led to far-reaching consequences.  They resulted in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: forlorn distrust of the testimony of the senses, and to  a doubt as to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our ability to know anything as it really is.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the distinction between appearances and realities exists for us as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well as for the ancient skeptic, and without being tempted to make such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extravagant statements as that there is no such thing as truth, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that every appearance is as real as any other, we may admit that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not very easy to see the full significance of the distinction, although
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are referring to it constantly.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For example, we look from our window and see, as we say, a tree at a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance.  What we are conscious of is a small bluish patch of color.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, a small bluish patch of color is not, strictly speaking, a tree;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but for us it represents the tree.  Suppose that we walk toward the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree.  Do we continue to see what we saw before?  Of course, we say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we continue to see the same tree; but it is plain that what we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immediately perceive, what is given in consciousness, does not remain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same as we move.  Our blue patch of color grows larger and larger;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it ceases to be blue and faint; at the last it has been replaced by an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expanse of vivid green, and we see the tree just before us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: During our whole walk we have been seeing the tree.  This appears to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mean that we have been having a whole series of visual experiences, no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two of which were just alike, and each of which was taken as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: representative of the tree.  Which of these representatives is most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: like the tree?  Is the tree _really_ a faint blue, or is it _really_ a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vivid green?  Or is it of some intermediate color?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Probably most persons will be inclined to maintain that the tree only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems blue at a distance, but that it really is green, as it appears
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when one is close to it.  In a sense, the statement is just; yet some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of those who make it would be puzzled to tell by what right they pick
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out of the whole series of experiences, each of which represents the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree as seen from some particular position, one individual experience,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they claim not only represents the tree as seen from a given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point but also represents it as it is.  Does this particular experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bear some peculiar earmark which tells us that it is like the real tree
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: while the others are unlike it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 20. REAL THINGS.--And what is this _real tree_ that we are supposed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see as it is when we are close to it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: About two hundred years ago the philosopher Berkeley pointed out that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the distinction commonly made between things as they look, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparent, and things as they are, the real, is at bottom the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between things as presented to the sense of sight and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things as presented to the sense of touch.  The acute analysis which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: made has held its own ever since.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen that, in walking towards the tree, we have a long series
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of visual experiences, each of which differs more or less from all of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the others.  Nevertheless, from the beginning of our progress to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: end, we say that we are looking at the same tree.  The images change
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: color and grow larger.  We do not say that the tree changes color and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: grows larger.  Why do we speak as we do?  It is because, all along the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: line, we mean by the real tree, not what is given to the sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sight, but something for which this stands as a sign.  This something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be given in our experience somewhere, we must be able to perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it under some circumstances or other, or it would never occur to us to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize the visual experiences as _signs_, and we should never say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that in being conscious of them in succession we are looking at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same tree.  They are certainly not the same with each other; how can we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know that they all stand for the same thing, unless we have had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of a connection of the whole series with one thing?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This thing for which so many different visual experiences may serve as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: signs is the thing revealed in experiences of touch.  When we ask: In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what direction is the tree?  How far away is the tree?  How big is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree? we are always referring to the tree revealed in touch.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonsense to say that _what we see_ is far away, if by what we see we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mean the visual experience itself.  As soon as we move we lose that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: visual experience and get another, and to recover the one we lost we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must go back where we were before.  When we say we see a tree at a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance, we must mean, then, that we know from certain visual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences which we have that by moving a certain distance we will be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: able to touch a tree.  And what does it mean to move a certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance?  In the last analysis it means to us to have a certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: quantity of movement sensations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus the real world of things, for which experiences of sight serve as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: signs, is a world revealed in experiences of touch and movement, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we speak of real positions, distances, and magnitudes, we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: always referring to this world.  But this is a world revealed in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience, and it does not seem a hopeless task to discover what may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: properly be called real and what should be described as merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparent, when both the real and the apparent are open to our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inspection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Can we not find in this analysis a satisfactory explanation of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man's claim that under certain circumstances he sees the tree as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is and under others he does not?  What he is really asserting is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that one visual experience gives him better information regarding the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real thing, the touch thing, than does another.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But what shall we say of his claim that the tree is really green, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only looks blue under certain circumstances?  Is it not just as true
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the tree only looks green under certain circumstances?  Is color
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any part of the touch thing?  Is it ever more than a sign of the touch
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing?  How can one color be more real than another?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, we may hold to Berkeley's analysis and maintain that, in general,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the real world, as contrasted with the apparent, means to us the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that is revealed in experiences of touch and movement; and yet we may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit that the word "real" is sometimes used in rather different senses.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not seem absurd for a woman to Say: This piece of silk really
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is yellow; it only looks white under this light.  We all admit that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: white house may look pink under the rays of the setting sun, and we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never call it a pink house.  We have seen that it is not unnatural to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say: That tree is really green; it is only its distance that makes it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: look blue.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When one reflects upon these uses of the word "real," one recognizes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the fact that, among all the experiences in which things are revealed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to us, certain experiences impress us as being more prominent or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: important or serviceable than certain others, and they come to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: called _real_.  Things are not commonly seen by artificial light; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sun is not always setting; the tree looks green when it is seen most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfactorily.  In each case, the real color of the thing is the color
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it has under circumstances that strike us as normal or as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: important.  We cannot say that we always regard as most real that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aspect under which we most commonly perceive things, for if a more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unusual experience is more serviceable and really gives us more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: information about the thing, we give the preference to that.  Thus we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: look with the naked eye at a moving speck on the table before us, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are unable to distinguish its parts.  We place a microscope over the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speck and perceive an insect with all its members.  The second
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience is the more unusual one, but would not every one say: Now we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive the thing _as it is_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 21. ULTIMATE REAL THINGS.--Let us turn away from the senses of the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "real," which recognize one color or taste or odor as more real than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another, and come back to the real world of things presented in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations of touch.  All other classes of sensations may be regarded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as related to this as the series of visual experiences above mentioned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was related to the one tree which was spoken of as revealed in them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, the touch tree of which they gave information.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Can we say that this world is always to be regarded as reality and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never as appearance?  We have already seen (section 8) that science
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not regard as anything more than appearance the real things which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem to be directly presented in our experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This pen that I hold in my hand seems, as I pass my fingers over it, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be continuously extended.  It does not appear to present an alternation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of filled spaces and empty spaces.  I am told that it is composed of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: molecules in rapid motion and at considerable distances from one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another.  I am further told that each molecule is composed of atoms,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and is, in its turn, not a continuous thing, but, so to speak, a group
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of little things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If I accept this doctrine, as it seems I must, am I not forced to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclude that the reality which is given in my experience, the reality
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with which I have contrasted appearances and to which I have referred
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them, is, after all, itself only an appearance?  The touch things which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have hitherto regarded as the real things that make up the external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world, the touch things for which all my visual experiences have served
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as signs, are, then, not themselves real external things, but only the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearances under which real external things, themselves imperceptible,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: manifest themselves to me.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems, then, that I do not directly perceive any real thing, or, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: least, anything that can be regarded as more than an appearance.  What,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: then, is the external world?  What are things really like?  Can we give
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any true account of them, or are we forced to say with the skeptics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we only know how things seem to us, and must abandon the attempt
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to tell what they are really like?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, before one sets out to answer a question it is well to find out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether it is a sensible question to ask and a sensible question to try
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to answer.  He who asks: Where is the middle of an infinite line?  When
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: did all time begin?  Where is space as a whole? does not deserve a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: serious answer to his questions.  And it is well to remember that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who asks: What is the external world like? must keep his question a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significant one, if he is to retain his right to look for an answer at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all.  He has manifestly no right to ask us: How does the external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: look when no one is looking?  How do things feel when no one feels
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them?  How shall I think of things, not as I think of them, but as they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we are to give an account of the external world at all, it must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidently be _an account_ of the external world; _i.e._ it must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given in terms of our experience of things.  The only legitimate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problem is to give a true account instead of a false one, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish between what only appears and is not real and what both
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears and is real.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bearing this in mind, let us come back to the plain man's experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world.  He certainly seems to himself to perceive a real world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, and he constantly distinguishes, in a way very serviceable to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself, between the merely apparent and the real.  There is, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: course, a sense in which every experience is real; it is, at least, an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience; but when he contrasts real and apparent he means something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more than this.  Experiences are not relegated to this class or to that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely at random, but the final decision is the outcome of a long
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of the differences which characterize different individual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences and is an expression of the relations which are observed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold between them.  Certain experiences are accepted as signs, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain others come to take the more dignified position of thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: signified; the mind rests in them and regards them as the real.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen above that the world of real things in which the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finds himself is a world of objects revealed in experiences of touch.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When he asks regarding anything: How far away is it?  How big is it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In what direction is it? it is always the touch thing that interests
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him.  What is given to the other senses is only a sign of this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have also seen (section 8) that the world of atoms and molecules of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the man of science tells us is nothing more than a further
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: development of the world of the plain man.  The real things with which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science concerns itself are, after all, only minute touch things,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceived just as are the things with which the plain man is familiar.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They exist in space and move about in space, as the things about us are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceived to exist in space and move about in space.  They have size
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and position, and are separated by distances.  We do not _perceive_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them, it is true; but we _conceive_ them after the analogy of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things that we do perceive, and it is not inconceivable that, if our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses were vastly more acute, we might perceive them directly.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, when we conclude that the things directly perceptible to the sense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of touch are to be regarded as appearances, as signs of the presence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these minuter things, do we draw such a conclusion arbitrarily?  By no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means.  The distinction between appearance and reality is drawn here
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: just as it is drawn in the world of our common everyday experiences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The great majority of the touch things about us we are not actually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touching at any given moment.  We only _see_ the things, _i.e._ we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain _signs_ of their presence.  None the less we believe that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things exist all the time.  And in the same way the man of science does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not doubt the existence of the real things of which he speaks; he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceives their _signs_.  That certain experiences are to be taken as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: signs of such realities he has established by innumerable observations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and careful deductions from those observations.  To see the full force
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of his reasonings one must read some work setting forth the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the atomic theory.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If, then, we ask the question: What is the real external world?  it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear that we cannot answer it satisfactorily without taking into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consideration the somewhat shifting senses of the word "real."  What is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the real external world to the plain man?  It is the world of touch
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, of objects upon which he can lay his hands.  What is the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world to the man of science?  It is the world of atoms and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: molecules, of minuter touch things that he cannot actually touch, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which he conceives as though he could touch them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be observed that the man of science has no right to deny the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real world which is revealed in the experience of the plain man.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all his dealings with the things which interest him in common life, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: refers to this world just as the plain man does.  He sees a tree and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: walks towards it, and distinguishes between its real and its apparent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: color, its real and its apparent size.  He talks about seeing things as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are, or not seeing things as they are.  These distinctions in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of things remain even after he has come to believe in atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and molecules.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the touch object, the tree as he feels it under his hand, may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come to be regarded as the sign of the presence of those entities that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science seems, at present, to regard as ultimate.  Does this prevent it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from being the object which has stood as the interpreter of all those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diverse visual sensations that we have called different views of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree?  They are still the appearances, and it, relatively to them, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reality.  Now we find that it, in its turn, can be used as a sign
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of something else, can be regarded as an appearance of a reality more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ultimate.  It is clear, then, that the same thing may be regarded both
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as appearance and as reality--appearance as contrasted with one thing,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and reality as contrasted with another.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But suppose one says: _I do not want to know what the real external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world is to this man or to that man; I want to know what the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world is_.  What shall we say to such a demand?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is a sense in which such a demand is not purely meaningless,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: though it may not be a very sensible demand to make.  We have seen that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an increase of knowledge about things compels a man to pass from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real things of common life to the real things of science, and to look
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the former as appearance.  Now, a man may arbitrarily decide that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he will use the word "reality" to indicate only that which can never in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its turn be regarded as appearance, a reality which must remain an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ultimate reality; and he may insist upon our telling him about that.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How a man not a soothsayer can tell when he has come to ultimate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reality, it is not easy to see.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Suppose, however, that we could give any one such information.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should then be telling him about things _as they are_, it is true, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his knowledge of things would not be different in _kind_ from what it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was before.  The only difference between such a knowledge of things and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a knowledge of things not known to be ultimate would be that, in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: former case, it would be recognized that no further extension of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge was possible.  The distinction between appearance and reality
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would remain just what it was in the experience of the plain man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 22. THE BUGBEAR OF THE "UNKNOWABLE."--It is very important to recognize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we must not go on talking about appearance and reality, as if our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: words really meant something, when we have quite turned our backs upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our experience of appearances and the realities which they represent.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That appearances and realities are connected we know very well, for we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive them to be connected.  What we see, we can touch.  And we not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only know that appearances and realities are connected, but we know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with much detail what appearances are to be taken as signs of what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: realities.  The visual experience which I call the house as seen from a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance I never think of taking for a representative of the hat which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I hold in my hand.  This visual experience I refer to its own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appropriate touch thing, and not to another.  If what _looks like_ a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beefsteak could _really be_ a fork or a mountain or a kitten
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indifferently,--but I must not even finish the sentence, for the words
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "look like" and "could really be" lose all significance when we loosen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the bond between appearances and the realities to which they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: properly referred.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Each appearance, then, must be referred to some particular real thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and not to any other.  This is true of the appearances which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize as such in common life, and it is equally true of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearances recognized as such in science.  The pen which I feel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between my fingers I may regard as appearance and refer to a swarm of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moving atoms.  But it would be silly for me to refer it to atoms "in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general."  The reality to which I refer the appearance in question is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: particular group of atoms existing at a particular point in space.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chemist never supposes that the atoms within the walls of his test-tube
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are identical with those in the vial on the shelf.  Neither in common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life nor in science would the distinction between appearances and real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things be of the smallest service were it not possible to distinguish
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between this appearance and that, and this reality and that, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: refer each appearance to its appropriate reality.  Indeed, it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconceivable that, under such circumstances, the distinction should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have been drawn at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These points ought to be strongly insisted upon, for we find certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophic writers falling constantly into a very curious abuse of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction and making much capital of it.  It is argued that what we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see, what we touch, what we conceive as a result of scientific
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observation and reflection--all is, in the last analysis, material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is given us in sensation.  The various senses furnish us with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different classes of sensations; we work these up into certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complexes.  But sensations are only the impressions which something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outside of us makes upon us.  Hence, although we seem to ourselves to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know the external world as it is, our knowledge can never extend beyond
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the impressions made upon us.  Thus, we are absolutely shut up to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _appearances_, and can know nothing about the _reality_ to which they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be referred.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Touching this matter Herbert Spencer writes[1] as follows: "When we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taught that a piece of matter, regarded by us as existing externally,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be really known, but that we can know only certain impressions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: produced on us, we are yet, by the relativity of thought, compelled to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of these in relation to a cause--the notion of a real existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which generated these impressions becomes nascent.  If it be proved
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that every notion of a real existence which we can frame is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistent with itself,--that matter, however conceived by us, cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be matter as it actually is,--our conception, though transfigured, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not destroyed: there remains the sense of reality, dissociated as far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as possible from those special forms under which it was before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represented in thought."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This means, in plain language, that we must regard everything we know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and can know as appearance and must refer it to an unknown reality.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sometimes Mr. Spencer calls this reality the Unknowable, sometimes he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: calls it the Absolute, and sometimes he allows it to pass by a variety
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of other names, such as Power, Cause, etc.  He wishes us to think of it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as "lying behind appearances" or as "underlying appearances."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Probably it has already been remarked that this Unknowable has brought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us around again to that amusing "telephone exchange" discussed in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: third chapter.  But if the reader feels within himself the least
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: weakness for the Unknowable, I beg him to consider carefully, before he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pins his faith to it, the following:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) If we do perceive external bodies, our own bodies and others, then
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is conceivable that we may have evidence from observation to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effect that other bodies affecting our bodies may give rise to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations.  In this case we cannot say that we know nothing but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations; we know real bodies as well as sensations, and we may refer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sensations to the real bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) If we do not perceive that we have bodies, and that our bodies are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acted upon by others, we have no evidence that what we call our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations are due to messages which come from "external things" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are conducted along the nerves.  It is then, absurd to talk of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "external things" as though they existed, and to call them the reality
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to which sensations, as appearances, must be referred,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) In other words, if there is perceived to be a telephone exchange
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with its wires and subscribers, we may refer the messages received to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the subscribers, and call this, if we choose, a reference of appearance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to reality.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But if there is perceived no telephone exchange, and if it is concluded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that any wires or subscribers of which it means anything to speak must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be composed of what we have heretofore called "messages," then it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: palpably absurd to refer the "messages" as a whole to subscribers not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed to be composed of "messages"; and it is a blunder to go on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: calling the things that we know "messages," as though we had evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that they came from, and must be referred to, something beyond
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must recognize that, with the general demolition of the exchange, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lose not only known subscribers, but the very notion of a subscriber.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It will not do to try to save from this wreck some "unknowable"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subscriber, and still pin our faith to him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) We have seen that the relation of appearance to reality is that of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain experiences to certain other experiences.  When we take the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: liberty of calling the Unknowable a _reality_, we blunder in our use of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word.  The Unknowable cannot be an experience either actual,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible, or conceived as possible, and it cannot possibly hold the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation to any of our experiences that a real thing of any kind holds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the appearances that stand as its signs.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (5) Finally, no man has ever made an assumption more perfectly useless
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and purposeless than the assumption of the Unknowable.  We have seen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the distinction between appearance and reality is a serviceable
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one, and it has been pointed out that it would be of no service
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatever if it were not possible to refer particular appearances to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their own appropriate realities.  The realities to which we actually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: refer appearances serve to explain them.  Thus, when I ask: Why do I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive that tree now as faint and blue and now as vivid and green?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the answer to the question is found in the notion of distance and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position in space; it is found, in other words, in a reference to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real world of touch things, for which visual experiences serve as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: signs.  Under certain circumstances, the mountain _ought_ to be robed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in its azure hue, and, under certain circumstances, it _ought not_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The circumstances in each case are open to investigation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, let us substitute for the real world of touch things, which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: furnishes the explanation of given visual experiences, that philosophic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fiction, that pseudo-real nonentity, the Unknowable.  Now I perceive a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree as faint and blue, now as bright and green; will a reference to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Unknowable explain why the experiences differed?  Was the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unknowable in the one instance farther off in an unknowable space, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the other nearer?  This, even if it means anything, must remain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unknowable.  And when the chemist puts together a volume of chlorine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gas and a volume of hydrogen gas to get two volumes of hydrochloric
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acid gas, shall we explain the change which has taken place by a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reference to the Unknowable, or shall we turn to the doctrine of atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and their combinations?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fact is that no man in his senses tries to account for any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individual fact by turning for an explanation to the Unknowable.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a life-preserver by which some set great store, but which no man dreams
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of using when he really falls into the water.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If, then, we have any reason to believe that there is a real external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world at all, we have reason to believe that we know what it is.  That
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some know it imperfectly, that others know it better, and that we may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hope that some day it will be known still more perfectly, is surely no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: good reason for concluding that we do not know it at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "First Principles," Part I, Chapter IV, section 26.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER VI
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: OF SPACE
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 23. WHAT ARE WE SUPPOSED TO KNOW ABOUT IT.--The plain man may admit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he is not ready to hazard a definition of space, but he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly not willing to admit that he is wholly ignorant of space and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of its attributes.  He knows that it is something in which material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objects have position and in which they move about; he knows that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has not merely length, like a line, nor length and breadth, like a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surface, but has the three dimensions of length, breadth, and depth; he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knows that, except in the one circumstance of its position, every part
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of space is exactly like every other part, and that, although objects
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may move about in space, it is incredible that the spaces themselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should be shifted about.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who are familiar with the literature of the subject know that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has long been customary to make regarding space certain other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements to which the plain man does not usually make serious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objection when he is introduced to them.  Thus it is said:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) The idea of space is _necessary_.  We can think of objects in space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as annihilated, but we cannot conceive space to be annihilated.  We can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear space of things, but we cannot clear away space itself, even in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
