author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) Space must be _infinite_.  We cannot conceive that we should come
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the end of space.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) Every space, however small, is _infinitely divisible_.  That is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say, even the most minute space must be composed of spaces.  We cannot,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even theoretically, split a solid into mere surfaces, a surface into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mere lines, or a line into mere points.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Against such statements the plain man is not impelled to rise in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rebellion, for he can see that there seems to be some ground for making
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them.  He can conceive of any particular material object as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: annihilated, and of the place which it occupied as standing empty; but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he cannot go on and conceive of the annihilation of this bit of empty
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space.  Its annihilation would not leave a gap, for a gap means a bit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of empty space; nor could it bring the surrounding spaces into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: juxtaposition, for one cannot shift spaces, and, in any case, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shifting that is not a shifting through space is an absurdity.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again, he cannot conceive of any journey that would bring him to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: end of space.  There is no more reason for stopping at one point than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at another; why not go on?  What could end space?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As to the infinite divisibility of space, have we not, in addition to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the seeming reasonableness of the doctrine, the testimony of all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematicians?  Does any one of them ever dream of a line so short
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it cannot be divided into two shorter lines, or of an angle so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: small that it cannot be bisected?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 24. SPACE AS NECESSARY AND SPACE AS INFINITE.--That these statements
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about space contain truth one should not be in haste to deny.  It seems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: silly to say that space can be annihilated, or that one can travel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "over the mountains of the moon" in the hope of reaching the end of it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And certainly no prudent man wishes to quarrel with that coldly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rational creature the mathematician.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is well worth while to examine the statements carefully and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see whether there is not some danger that they may be understood in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such a way as to lead to error.  Let us begin with the doctrine that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space is necessary and cannot be "thought away."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As we have seen above, it is manifestly impossible to annihilate in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought a certain portion of space and leave the other portions intact.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are many things in the same case.  We cannot annihilate in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought one side of a door and leave the other side; we cannot rob a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man of the outside of his hat and leave him the inside.  But we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive of a whole door as annihilated, and of a man as losing a whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hat.  May we or may we not conceive of space as a whole as nonexistent?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I do not say, be it observed, can we conceive of something as attacking
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and annihilating space?  Whatever space may be, we none of us think of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it as a something that may be threatened and demolished.  I only say,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may we not think of a system of things--not a world such as ours, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: course, but still a system of things of some sort--in which space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations have no part?  May we not conceive such to be possible?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be remarked that space relations are by no means the only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ones in which we think of things as existing.  We attribute to them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time relations as well.  Now, when we think of occurrences as related
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to each other in time, we do, in so far as we concentrate our attention
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon these relations, turn our attention away from space and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contemplate another aspect of the system of things.  Space is not such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a necessity of thought that we must keep thinking of space when we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turned our attention to something else.  And is it, indeed,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconceivable that there should be a system of things (not extended
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things in space, of course), characterized by time relations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perhaps other relations, but not by space relations?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It goes without saying that we cannot go on thinking of space and at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same time not think of space.  Those who keep insisting upon space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a necessity of thought seem to set us such a task as this, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: found their conclusion upon our failure to accomplish it.  "We can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never represent to ourselves the nonexistence of space," says the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: German philosopher Kant (1724-1804), "although we can easily conceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that there are no objects in space."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It would, perhaps, be fairer to translate the first half of this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sentence as follows: "We can never picture to ourselves the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonexistence of space."  Kant says we cannot make of it a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Vorstellung_, a representation.  This we may freely admit, for what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does one try to do when one makes the effort to imagine the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonexistence of space?  Does not one first clear space of objects, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: then try to clear space of space in much the same way?  We try to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "think space away," _i.e. to remove it from the place where it was and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: yet keep that place_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What does it mean to imagine or represent to oneself the nonexistence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of material objects?  Is it not to represent to oneself the objects as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no longer in space, _i.e._ to imagine the space as empty, as cleared of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the objects?  It means something in this case to speak of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Vorstellung_, or representation.  We can call before our minds the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: empty space.  But if we are to think of space as nonexistent, what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall we call before our minds?  Our procedure must not be analogous to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what it was before; we must not try to picture to our minds _the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absence of space_, as though that were in itself a something that could
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be pictured; we must turn our attention to other relations, such as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time relations, and ask whether it is not conceivable that such should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be the only relations obtaining within a given system.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who insist upon the fact that we cannot but conceive space as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite employ a very similar argument to prove their point.  They set
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us a self-contradictory task, and regard our failure to accomplish it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as proof of their position.  Thus, Sir William Hamilton (1788-1856)
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: argues: "We are altogether unable to conceive space as bounded--as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finite; that is, as a whole beyond which there is no further space."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And Herbert Spencer echoes approvingly: "We find ourselves totally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unable to imagine bounds beyond which there is no space."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, whatever one may be inclined to think about the infinity of space,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is clear that this argument is an absurd one.  Let me write it out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more at length: "We are altogether unable to conceive space as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bounded--as finite; that is, as a whole _in the space_ beyond which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is no further space."  "We find ourselves totally unable to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagine bounds, _in the space_ beyond which there is no further space."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The words which I have added were already present implicitly.  What can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "beyond" mean if it does not signify space beyond?  What Sir
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: William and Mr. Spencer have asked us to do is to imagine a limited
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space with a _beyond_ and yet _no beyond_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is undoubtedly some reason why men are so ready to affirm that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space is infinite, even while they admit that they do not know that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of material things is infinite.  To this we shall come back again
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: later.  But if one wishes to affirm it, it is better to do so without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: giving a reason than it is to present such arguments as the above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 25. SPACE AS INFINITELY DIVISIBLE.--For more than two thousand years
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men have been aware that certain very grave difficulties seem to attach
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the idea of motion, when we once admit that space is infinitely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divisible.  To maintain that we can divide any portion of space up into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ultimate elements which are not themselves spaces, and which have no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extension, seems repugnant to the idea we all have of space.  And if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: refuse to admit this possibility there seems to be nothing left to us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but to hold that every space, however small, may theoretically be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divided up into smaller spaces, and that there is no limit whatever to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the possible subdivision of spaces.  Nevertheless, if we take this most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natural position, we appear to find ourselves plunged into the most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hopeless of labyrinths, every turn of which brings us face to face with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a flat self-contradiction.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To bring the difficulties referred to clearly before our minds, let us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: suppose a point to move uniformly over a line an inch long, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accomplish its journey in a second.  At first glance, there appears to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be nothing abnormal about this proceeding.  But if we admit that this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: line is infinitely divisible, and reflect upon this property of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: line, the ground seems to sink from beneath our feet at once.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For it is possible to argue that, under the conditions given, the point
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must move over one half of the line in half a second; over one half of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the remainder, or one fourth of the line, in one fourth of a second;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: over one eighth of the line, in one eighth of a second, etc.  Thus the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: portions of line moved over successively by the point may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represented by the descending series:
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16, . . . [Greek omicron symbol]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, it is quite true that the motion of the point can be described in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a number of different ways; but the important thing to remark here is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, if the motion really is uniform, and if the line really is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinitely divisible, this series must, as satisfactorily as any other,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describe the motion of the point.  And it would be absurd to maintain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that _a part_ of the series can describe the whole motion.  We cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say, for example, that, when the point has moved over one half, one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fourth, and one eighth of the line, it has completed its motion.  If
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even a single member of the series is left out, the whole line has not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been passed over; and this is equally true whether the omitted member
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represent a large bit of line or a small one.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The whole series, then, represents the whole line, as definite parts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the series represent definite parts of the line.  The line can only be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: completed when the series is completed.  But when and how can this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series be completed?  In general, a series is completed when we reach
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the final term, but here there appears to be no final term.  We cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make zero the final term, for it does not belong to the series at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not obey the law of the series, for it is not one half as large
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as the term preceding it--what space is so small that dividing it by 2
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gives us [omicron]?  On the other hand, some term just before zero
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be the final term; for if it really represents a little bit of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the line, however small, it must, by hypothesis, be made up of lesser
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bits, and a smaller term must be conceivable.  There can, then, be no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last term to the series; _i.e._ what the point is doing at the very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last is absolutely indescribable; it is inconceivable that there should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a _very last_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It was pointed out many centuries ago that it is equally inconceivable
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that there should be a _very first_.  How can a point even begin to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: move along an infinitely divisible line?  Must it not before it can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: move over any distance, however short, first move over half that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance?  And before it can move over that half, must it not move over
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the half of that?  Can it find something to move over that has no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: halves?  And if not, how shall it even start to move?  To move at all,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it must begin somewhere; it cannot begin with what has no halves, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: then it is not moving over any part of the line, as all parts have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: halves; and it cannot begin with what has halves, for that is not the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beginning.  _What does the point do first?_ that is the question.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who tell us about points and lines usually leave us to call upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gentle echo for an answer.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The perplexities of this moving point seem to grow worse and worse the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: longer one reflects upon them.  They do not harass it merely at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beginning and at the end of its journey.  This is admirably brought out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by Professor W. K. Clifford (1845-1879), an excellent mathematician,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who never had the faintest intention of denying the possibility of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motion, and who did not desire to magnify the perplexities in the path
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a moving point.  He writes:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "When a point moves along a line, we know that between any two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions of it there is an infinite number . . . of intermediate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions.  That is because the motion is continuous.  Each of those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions is where the point was at some instant or other.  Between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two end positions on the line, the point where the motion began and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point where it stopped, there is no point of the line which does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belong to that series.  We have thus an infinite series of successive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions of a continuously moving point, and in that series are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: included all the points of a certain piece of line-room." [1]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we are told that, when a point moves along a line, between any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two positions of it there is an infinite number of intermediate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions.  Clifford does not play with the word "infinite"; he takes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it seriously and tells us that it means without any end: "_Infinite_;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is a dreadful word, I know, until you find out that you are familiar
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the thing which it expresses.  In this place it means that between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any two positions there is some intermediate position; between that and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: either of the others, again, there is some other intermediate; and so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on _without any end_.  Infinite means without any end."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But really, if the case is as stated, the point in question must be at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a desperate pass.  I beg the reader to consider the following, and ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself whether he would like to change places with it:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) If the series of positions is really endless, the point must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complete one by one the members of an endless series, and reach a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonexistent final term, for a really endless series cannot have a final
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: term.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) The series of positions is supposed to be "an infinite series of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successive positions."  The moving point must take them one after
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another.  But how can it?  _Between any two positions of the point
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is an infinite number of intermediate positions_.  That is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say, no two of these successive positions must be regarded as _next to_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: each other; every position is separated from every other by an infinite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number of intermediate ones.  How, then, shall the point move?  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot possibly move from one position to the next, for there is no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: next.  Shall it move first to some position that is not the next?  Or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall it in despair refuse to move at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Evidently there is either something wrong with this doctrine of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite divisibility of space, or there is something wrong with our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: understanding of it, if such absurdities as these refuse to be cleared
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: away.  Let us see where the trouble lies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 26. WHAT IS REAL SPACE?--It is plain that men are willing to make a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number of statements about space, the ground for making which is not at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: once apparent.  It is a bold man who will undertake to say that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universe of matter is infinite in extent.  We feel that we have the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to ask him how he knows that it is.  But most men are ready
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enough to affirm that space is and must be infinite.  How do they know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it is?  They certainly do not directly perceive all space, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such arguments as the one offered by Hamilton and Spencer are easily
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen to be poor proofs.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Men are equally ready to affirm that space is infinitely divisible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Has any man ever looked upon a line and perceived directly that it has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an infinite number of parts?  Did any one ever succeed in dividing a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space up infinitely?  When we try to make clear to ourselves how a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point moves along an infinitely divisible line, do we not seem to land
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in sheer absurdities?  On what sort of evidence does a man base his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements regarding space?  They are certainly very bold statements.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: A careful reflection reveals the fact that men do not speak as they do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about space for no reason at all.  When they are properly understood,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their statements can be seen to be justified, and it can be seen also
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the difficulties which we have been considering can be avoided.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The subject is a deep one, and it can scarcely be discussed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exhaustively in an introductory volume of this sort, but one can, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: least, indicate the direction in which it seems most reasonable to look
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for an answer to the questions which have been raised.  How do we come
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to a knowledge of space, and what do we mean by space?  This is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problem to solve; and if we can solve this, we have the key which will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unlock many doors.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, we saw in the last chapter that we have reason to believe that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know what the real external world is.  It is a world of things which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive, or can perceive, or, not arbitrarily but as a result of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: careful observation and deductions therefrom, conceive as though we did
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive it--a world, say, of atoms and molecules.  It is not an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unknowable behind or beyond everything that we perceive, or can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive, or conceive in the manner stated.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And the space with which we are concerned is real space, the space in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which real things exist and move about, the real things which we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly know or of which we can definitely know something.  In some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense it must be given in our experience, if the things which are in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it, and are known to be in it, are given in our experience.  How must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we think of this real space?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Suppose we look at a tree at a distance.  We are conscious of a certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complex of color.  We can distinguish the kind of color; in this case,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we call it blue.  But the quality of the color is not the only thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we can distinguish in the experience.  In two experiences of color
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the quality may be the same, and yet the experiences may be different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from each other.  In the one case we may have more of the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: color--we may, so to speak, be conscious of a larger patch; but even if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is not actually more of it, there may be such a difference that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we can know from the visual experience alone that the touch object
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before us is, in the one case, of the one shape, and, in the other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: case, of another.  Thus we may distinguish between the _stuff_ given in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our experience and the _arrangement_ of that stuff.  This is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction which philosophers have marked as that between "matter" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "form."  It is, of course, understood that both of these words, so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: used, have a special sense not to be confounded with their usual one.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This distinction between "matter" and "form" obtains in all our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences.  I have spoken just above of the shape of the touch object
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for which our visual experiences stand as signs.  What do we mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its shape?  To the plain man real things are the touch things of which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he has experience, and these touch things are very clearly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguishable from one another in shape, in size, in position, nor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are the different parts| of the things to be confounded with each
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other.  Suppose that, as we pass our hand over a table, all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations of touch and movement which we experience fused into an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undistinguishable mass.  Would we have any notion of size or shape?  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is because our experiences of touch and movement do not fuse, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remain distinguishable from each other, and we are conscious of them as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _arranged_, as constituting a system, that we can distinguish between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this part of a thing and that, this thing and that.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This arrangement, this order, of what is revealed by touch and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: movement, we may call the "form" of the touch world.  Leaving out of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consideration, for the present, time relations, we may say that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "form" of the touch world is the whole system of actual and possible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations of arrangement between the elements which make it up.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: because there is such a system of relations that we can speak of things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as of this shape or of that, as great or small, as near or far, as here
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or there.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, I ask, is there any reason to believe that, when the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speaks of _space_, the word means to him anything more than this system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of actual and possible relations of arrangement among the touch things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that constitute his real world?  He may talk sometimes as though space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were some kind of a _thing_, but he does not really think of it as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is evident from the mere fact that he is so ready to make about it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: affirmations that he would not venture to make about things.  It does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not strike him as inconceivable that a given material object should be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: annihilated; it does strike him as inconceivable that a portion of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space should be blotted out of existence.  Why this difference?  Is it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not explained when we recognize that space is but a name for all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: actual and possible relations of arrangement in which things in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch world may stand?  We cannot drop out some of these relations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: yet keep _space_, _i.e._ the system of relations which we had before.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That this is what space means, the plain man may not recognize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: explicitly, but he certainly seems to recognize it implicitly in what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he says about space.  Men are rarely inclined to admit that space is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _thing_ of any kind, nor are they much more inclined to regard it as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: quality of a thing.  Of what could it be the quality?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And if space really were a thing of any sort, would it not be the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: height of presumption for a man, in the absence of any direct evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from observation, to say how much there is of it--to declare it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite?  Men do not hesitate to say that space must be infinite.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we realize that we do not mean by space merely the actual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations which exist between the touch things that make up the world,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but also the _possible_ relations, _i.e._ that we mean the whole _plan_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the world system, we can see that it is not unreasonable to speak of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space as infinite.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The material universe may, for aught we know, be limited in extent.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The actual space relations in which things stand to each other may not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be limitless.  But these actual space relations taken alone do not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constitute space.  Men have often asked themselves whether they should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive of the universe as limited and surrounded by void space.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not nonsense to speak of such a state of things.  It would, indeed,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appear to be nonsense to say that, if the universe is limited, it does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not lie in void space.  What can we mean by void space but the system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of possible relations in which things, if they exist, must stand?  To
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say that, beyond a certain point, no further relations are possible,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems absurd.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hence, when a man has come to understand what we have a right to mean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by space, it does not imply a boundless conceit on his part to hazard
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the statement that space is infinite.  When he has said this, he has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said very little.  What shall we say to the statement that space is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinitely divisible?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To understand the significance of this statement we must come back to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the distinction between appearances and the real things for which they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stand as signs, the distinction discussed at length in the last chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When I see a tree from a distance, the visual experience which I have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is, as we have seen, not an indivisible unit, but is a complex
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience; it has parts, and these parts are related to each other; in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other words, it has both "matter" and "form."  It is, however, one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing to say that this experience has parts, and it is another to say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it has an infinite number of parts.  No man is conscious of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceiving an infinite number of parts in the patch of color which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represents to him a tree at a distance; to say that it is constituted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of such strikes us in our moments of sober reflection as a monstrous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, this visual experience is to us the sign of the reality, the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tree; it is not taken as the tree itself.  When we speak of the size,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the shape, the number of parts, of the tree, we do not have in mind the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: size, the shape, the number of parts, of just this experience.  We pass
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the sign to the thing signified, and we may lay our hand upon this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing, thus gaining a direct experience of the size and shape of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch object.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must recognize, however, that just as no man is conscious of an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite number of parts in what he sees, so no man is conscious of an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite number of parts in what he touches.  He who tells me that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when I pass my finger along my paper cutter, _what I perceive_ has an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinite number of parts, tells me what seems palpably untrue.  When an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object is very small, I can see it, and I cannot see that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: composed of parts; similarly, when an object is very small, I can feel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it with my finger, but I cannot distinguish its parts by the sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch.  There seem to be limits beyond which I cannot go in either case.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, men often speak of thousandths of an inch, or of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: millionths of an inch, or of distances even shorter.  Have such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fractions of the magnitudes that we do know and can perceive any real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence?  The touch world of real things as it is revealed in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience does not appear to be divisible into such; it does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appear to be divisible even so far, and much less does it appear to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinitely divisible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But have we not seen that the touch world given in our experience must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be taken by the thoughtful man as itself the sign or appearance of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reality more ultimate?  The speck which appears to the naked eye to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have no parts is seen under the microscope to have parts; that is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say, an experience apparently not extended has become the sign of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something that is seen to have part out of part.  We have as yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: invented no instrument that will make directly perceptible to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finger tip an atom of hydrogen or of oxygen, but the man of science
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceives of these little things as though they could be perceived.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They and the space in which they move--the system of actual and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible relations between them--seem to be related to the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed in touch very much as the space revealed in the field of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: microscope is related to the space of the speck looked at with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: naked eye.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, when the thoughtful man speaks of _real space_, he cannot mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word only the actual and possible relations of arrangement among
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the things and the parts of things directly revealed to his sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch.  He may speak of real things too small to be thus perceived, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of their motion as through spaces too small to be perceptible at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What limit shall he set to the possible subdivision of _real_ things?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unless he can find an ultimate reality which cannot in its turn become
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the appearance or sign of a further reality, it seems absurd to speak
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a limit at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, then, say that real space is infinitely divisible.  By this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement we should mean that certain experiences may be represented by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: others, and that we may carry on our division in the case of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: latter, when a further subdivision of the former seems out of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question.  But it should not mean that any single experience furnished
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us by any sense, or anything that we can represent in the imagination,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is composed of an infinite number of parts.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we realize this, do we not free ourselves from the difficulties
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which seemed to make the motion of a point over a line an impossible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absurdity?  The line as revealed in a single experience either of sight
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or of touch is not composed of an infinite number of parts.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: composed of points seen or touched--least experiences of sight or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch, _minima sensibilia_.  These are next to each other, and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point, in moving, takes them one by one.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But such a single experience is not what we call a line.  It is but one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of a line.  Though the experience is not infinitely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divisible, the line may be.  This only means that the visual or tactual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point of the single experience may stand for, may represent, what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not a mere point but has parts, and is, hence, divisible.  Who can set
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a limit to such possible substitutions? in other words, who can set a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: limit to the divisibility of a _real line_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is only when we confuse the single experience with the real line
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we fall into absurdities.  What the mathematician tells us about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real points and real lines has no bearing on the constitution of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: single experience and its parts.  Thus, when he tells us that between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any two points on a line there are an infinite number of other points,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he only means that we may expand the line indefinitely by the system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substitutions described above.  We do this for ourselves within limits
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: every time that we approach from a distance a line drawn on a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: blackboard.  The mathematician has generalized our experience for us,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that is all he has done.  We should try to get at his real meaning,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and not quote him as supporting an absurdity.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "Seeing and Thinking," p. 149.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER VII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: OF TIME
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 27. TIME AS NECESSARY, INFINITE, AND INFINITELY DIVISIBLE.--Of course, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all know something about time; we know it as past, present, and future;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we know it as divisible into parts, all of which are successive; we know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that whatever happens must happen in time.  Those who have thought a good
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deal about the matter are apt to tell us that time is a necessity of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought, we cannot but think it; that time is and must be infinite; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it is infinitely divisible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These are the same statements that were made regarding space, and, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they have to be criticised in just the same way, it is not necessary to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dwell upon them at great length.  However, we must not pass them over
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: altogether.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As to the statement that time is a _necessary_ idea, we may freely admit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we cannot in thought _annihilate_ time, or _think it away_.  It does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not seem to mean anything to attempt such a task.  Whatever time may be,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it does not appear to be a something of such a nature that we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: demolish it or clear it away from something else.  But is it necessarily
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absurd to speak of a system of things--not, of course, a system of things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which there is change, succession, an earlier and a later, but still a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of things of some sort--in which there obtain no time relations?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The problem is, to be sure, one of theoretical interest merely, for such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a system of things is not the world we know.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And as for the infinity of time, may we not ask on what ground any one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ventures to assert that time is infinite?  No man can say that infinite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time is directly given in his experience.  If one does not directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive it to be infinite, must one not seek for some proof of the fact?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The only proof which appears to be offered us is contained in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement that we cannot conceive of a time before which there was no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time, nor of a time after which there will be no time; a proof which is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no proof, for written out at length it reads as follows: we cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive of a time _in the time_ before which there was no time, nor of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time _in the time_ after which there will be no time.  As well say: We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot conceive of a number the number before which was no number, nor of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a number the number after which will be no number.  Whatever may be said
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the conclusion arrived at, the argument is a very poor one.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we turn to the consideration of time as infinitely divisible, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seem to find ourselves confronted with the same difficulties which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented themselves when we thought of space as infinitely divisible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Certainly no man was immediately conscious of an infinite number of parts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the minute which just slipped by.  Shall he assert that it did,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nevertheless, contain an infinite number of parts?  Then how did it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: succeed in passing? how did it even _begin_ to pass away?  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infinitely divisible, that is, there is no end to the number of parts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into which it may be divided; those parts and parts of parts are all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successive, no two can pass at once, they must all do it in a certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: order, one after the other.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, something must pass _first_.  What can it be?  If that something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has parts, is divisible, the whole of it cannot pass first.  It must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself pass bit by bit, as must the whole minute; and if it is infinitely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divisible we have precisely the problem that we had at the outset.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Whatever passes first cannot, then, have parts.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us assume that it has no parts, and bid it Godspeed!  Has the minute
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: begun?  Our minute is, by hypothesis, infinitely divisible; it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: composed of parts, and those parts of other parts, and so on without end.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We cannot by subdivision come to any part which is itself not composed of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: smaller parts.  The partless thing that passed, then, is no part of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minute.  That is all still waiting at the gate, and no member of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: troop can prove that it has a right to lead the rest.  In the same outer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: darkness is waiting the point on the line that misbehaved itself in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 28. THE PROBLEM OF PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE.--It seems bad enough to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have on our hands a minute which must pass away in successive bits, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to discover that no bit of it can possibly pass first.  But if we follow
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with approval the reflections of certain thinkers, we may find ourselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at such a pass that we would be glad to be able to prove that we may have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on our hands a minute of any sort.  Men sometimes are so bold as to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintain that they know time to be infinite; would it not be well for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them to prove first that they can know time at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The trouble is this; as was pointed out long ago by Saint Augustine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (354-430) in his famous "Confessions," [1] the parts of time are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successive, and of the three divisions, past, present, and future, only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one can be regarded as existing: "Those two times, past and future, how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can they be, when the past is not now, and the future is not yet?"  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present is, it seems, the only existent; how long is the present?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Even a single hour passes in fleeting moments; as much of it as has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taken flight is past, what remains is future.  If we can comprehend any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time that is divisible into no parts at all, or perhaps into the minutest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parts of moments, this alone let us call present; yet this speeds so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hurriedly from the future to the past that it does not endure even for a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little space.  If it has duration, it is divided into a past and a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: future; but the present has no duration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Where, then, is the time that we may call long?  Is it future?  We do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not say of the future: it _is_ long; for as yet there exists nothing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be long.  We say: it _will be_ long.  But when?  If while yet future it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will not be long, for nothing will yet exist to be long.  And if it will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be long, when, from a future as yet nonexistent, it has become a present,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and has begun to be, that it may be something that is long, then present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time cries out in the words of the preceding paragraph that it cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: long."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Augustine's way of presenting the difficulty is a quaint one, but the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problem is as real at the beginning of the twentieth century as it was at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the beginning of the fifth.  Past time does not exist now, future time
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not exist yet, and present time, it seems, has no duration.  Can a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man be said to be conscious of time as past, present, and future?  Who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can be conscious of the nonexistent?  And the existent is not _time_, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has no duration, there is no before and after in a mere limiting point.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Augustine's way out of the difficulty is the suggestion that, although we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot, strictly speaking, measure time, we can measure _memory_ and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _expectation_.  Before he begins to repeat a psalm, his expectation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extends over the whole of it.  After a little a part of it must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: referred to expectation and a part of it to memory.  Finally, the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psalm is "extended along" the memory.  We can measure this, at least.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But how is the psalm in question "extended along" the memory or the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expectation?  Are the parts of it successive, or do they thus exist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simultaneously?  If everything in the memory image exists at once, if all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belongs to the punctual present, to the mere point that divides past from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: future, how can a man get from it a consciousness of time, of a something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whose parts cannot exist together but must follow each other?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Augustine appears to overlook the fact that on his own hypothesis, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present, the only existent, the only thing a man can be conscious of, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an indivisible instant.  In such there can be no change; the man who is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shut up to such cannot be aware that the past is growing and the future
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diminishing.  Any such change as this implies at least two instants, an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earlier and a later.  He who has never experienced a change of any sort,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who has never been conscious of the relation of earlier and later, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: succession, cannot think of the varied content of memory as of _that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which has been present_.  It cannot mean to him what memory certainly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means to us; he cannot be conscious of a past, a present, and a future.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To extract the notion of time, of past, present, and future, from an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience which contains no element of succession, from an indivisible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: instant, is as hopeless a task as to extract a line from a mathematical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It appears, then, that, if we are to be conscious of time at all, if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are to have the least conception of it, we must have some direct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of change.  We cannot really be shut up to that punctual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present, that mere point or limit between past and future, that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
