text: present has been described as being.  But does this not imply that we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be directly conscious of what is not present, that we can _now_ perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what does _not now_ exist?  How is this possible?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not easy for one whose reading has been somewhat limited in any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given field to see the full significance of the problems which present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves in that field.  Those who read much in the history of modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy will see that this ancient difficulty touching our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness of time has given rise to some exceedingly curious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speculations, and some strange conclusions touching the nature of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, it has been argued that, since the experience of each moment is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something quite distinct from the experience of the next, a something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that passes away to give place to its successor, we cannot explain the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness of time, of a whole in which successive moments are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognized as having their appropriate place, unless we assume a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something that knows each moment and knits it, so to speak, to its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successor.  This something is the self or consciousness, which is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent of time, and does not exist in time, as do the various
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences that fill the successive moments.  It is assumed to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _timelessly_ present _at all times_, and thus to connect the nonexistent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: past with the existent present.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I do not ask the reader to try to make clear to himself how anything can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be timelessly present at all times, for I do not believe that the words
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can be made to represent any clear thought whatever.  Nor do I ask him to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: try to conceive how this timeless something can join past and present.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely wish to point out that these modern speculations, which still
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence the minds of many distinguished men, have their origin in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficulty which suggested itself early in the history of reflective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought, and are by no means to be regarded as a gratuitous and useless
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exercise of the ingenuity.  They are serious attempts to solve a real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problem, though they may be unsuccessful ones, and they are worthy of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attention even from those who incline to a different solution.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 29. WHAT IS REAL TIME?--From the thin air of such speculations as we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been discussing let us come back to the world of the plain man, the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which we all habitually live.  It is from this that we must start out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon all our journeys, and it is good to come back to it from time to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time to make sure of our bearings.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen (Chapter V) that we distinguish between the real and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparent, and that we recognize as the real world the objects revealed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sense of touch.  These objects stand to each other in certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations of arrangement; that is to say, they exist in space.  And just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as we may distinguish between the object as it appears and the object as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is, so we may distinguish between apparent space and real space,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _i.e._ between the relations of arrangement, actual and possible, which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obtain among the parts of the object as it appears, and those which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obtain among the parts of the object as it really is.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But our experience does not present us only with objects in space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations; it presents us with a succession of changes in those objects.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And if we will reason about those changes as we have reasoned about space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations, many of our difficulties regarding the nature of time may, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it seems, be made to disappear.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus we may recognize that we are directly conscious of duration, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: succession, and may yet hold that this crude and immediate experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: duration is not what we mean by real time.  Every one distinguishes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between apparent time and real time now and then.  We all know that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sermon may _seem _long and not _be_ long; that the ten years that we live
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: over in a dream are not ten real years; that the swallowing of certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: drugs may be followed by the illusion of the lapse of vast spaces of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time, when really very little time has elapsed.  What is this _real_ time?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is nothing else than the order of the changes which take place or may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take place in real things.  In the last chapter I spoke of space as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "form" of the real world; it would be better to call it _a_ "form" of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real world, and to give the same name also to time.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is very clear that, when we inquire concerning the real time of any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occurrence, or ask how long a series of such lasted, we always look for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our answer to something that has happened in the external world.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: passage of a star over the meridian, the position of the sun above the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: horizon, the arc which the moon has described since our last observation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the movement of the hands of a clock, the amount of sand which has fallen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the hourglass, these things and such as these are the indicators of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real time.  There may be indicators of a different sort; we may decide
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it is noon because we are hungry, or midnight because we are tired;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we may argue that the preacher must have spoken more than an hour because
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he quite wore out the patience of the congregation.  These are more or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: less uncertain signs of the lapse of time, but they cannot be regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences of the passing of time either apparent or real.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we see that real space and real time are the _plan_ of the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system.  They are not _things_ of any sort, and they should not be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mistaken for things.  They are not known independently of things, though,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we have once had an experience of things and their changes, we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by abstraction from the things themselves fix our attention upon their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arrangement and upon the order of their changes.  We can divide and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subdivide spaces and times without much reference to the things.  But we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should never forget that it would never have occurred to us to do this,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indeed, that the whole procedure would be absolutely meaningless to us,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were not a real world revealed in our experience as it is.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who has attained to this insight into the nature of time is in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position to offer what seem to be satisfactory solutions to the problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which have been brought forward above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) He can see, thus, why it is absurd to speak of any portion of time as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becoming nonexistent.  Time is nothing else than an order, a great system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of relations.  One cannot drop out certain of these and leave the rest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unchanged, for the latter imply the former.  Day-after-to-morrow would
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not be day-after-to-morrow, if to-morrow did not lie between it and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to-day.  To speak of dropping out to-morrow and leaving it the time it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was conceived to be is mere nonsense.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) He can see why it does not indicate a measureless conceit for a man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be willing to say that time is infinite.  One who says this need not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be supposed to be acquainted with the whole past and future history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the real world, of which time is an aspect.  We constantly abstract from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, and consider only the order of their changes, and in this order
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself there is no reason why one should set a limit at some point;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indeed, to set such a limit seems a gratuitous absurdity.  He who says
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that time is infinite does not say much; he is not affirming the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence of some sort of a thing; he is merely affirming a theoretical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possibility, and is it not a theoretical possibility that there may be an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: endless succession of real changes in a real world?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) It is evident, furthermore, that, when one has grasped firmly the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of the distinction between apparent time and real time, one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may with a clear conscience speak of time as infinitely divisible.  Of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: course, the time directly given in any single experience, the minute or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the second of which we are conscious as it passes, cannot be regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: composed of an infinite number of parts.  We are not directly conscious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of these subdivisions, and it is a monstrous assumption to maintain that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they must be present in the minute or second as perceived.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But no such single experience of duration constitutes what we mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real time.  We have seen that real time is the time occupied by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changes in real things, and the question is, How far can one go in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subdivision of this time?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the touch thing which usually is for us in common life the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing is not the real thing for science; it is the appearance under which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the real world of atoms and molecules reveals itself.  The atom is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly perceivable, and we may assign to its motions a space so small
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that no one could possibly perceive it as space, as a something with part
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out of part, a something with a here and a there.  But, as has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before pointed out (section 26), this does not prevent us from believing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the atom and the space in which it moves to be real, and we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _represent_ them to ourselves as we can the things and the spaces with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we have to do in common life.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is with time just as it is with space.  We can perceive an inch to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have parts; we cannot perceive a thousandth of an inch to have parts, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we can perceive it at all; but we can represent it to ourselves as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extended, that is, we can let an experience which is extended stand for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it, and can dwell upon the parts of that.  We can perceive a second to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have duration; we cannot perceive a thousandth of a second to have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: duration; but we can conceive it as having duration, _i.e._ we can let
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some experience of duration stand for it and serve as its representative.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, then, reasonable to speak of the space covered by the vibration of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an atom, and it is equally reasonable to speak of the time taken up by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its vibration.  It is not necessary to believe that the duration that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: actually experience as a second must itself be capable of being divided
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: up into the number of parts indicated by the denominator of the fraction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we use in indicating such a time, and that each of these parts must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be perceived as duration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is, then, a sense in which we may affirm that time is infinitely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divisible.  But we must remember that apparent time--the time presented
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in any single experience of duration--is never infinitely divisible; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that real time, in any save a relative sense of the word, is not a single
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of duration at all.  It is a recognition of the fact that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences of duration may be substituted for each other without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assignable limit.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) But what shall we say to the last problem--to the question how we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be conscious of time at all, when the parts of time are all successive?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How can we even have a consciousness of "crude" time, of apparent time,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of duration in any sense of the word, when duration must be made up of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moments no two of which can exist together and no one of which alone can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constitute time?  The past is not now, the future is not yet, the present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is a mere point, as we are told, and cannot have parts.  If we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious of time as past, present, and future, must we not be conscious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a series as a series when every member of it save one is nonexistent?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Can a man be conscious of the nonexistent?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difficulty does seem a serious one, and yet I venture to affirm that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if we examine it carefully, we shall see that it is a difficulty of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: own devising.  The argument quietly makes an assumption--and makes it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gratuitously--with which any consciousness of duration is incompatible,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and then asks us how there can be such a thing as a consciousness of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: duration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The assumption is that _we can be conscious only of the existent_, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this, written out a little more at length, reads as follows: _we can be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious only of the now existent_, or, in other words _of the present_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Of course, this determines from the outset that we cannot be conscious of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the past and the future, of duration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The past and the future are, to be sure, nonexistent from the point of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: view of the present; but it should be remarked as well that the present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is nonexistent from the point of view of the past or the future.  If we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are talking of time at all we are talking of that no two parts of which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are simultaneous; it would be absurd to speak of a past that existed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simultaneously with the present, just as it would be absurd to speak of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present existing simultaneously with the past.  But we should not deny to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: past, present, and future, respectively, their appropriate existence; nor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is it by any means self-evident that there cannot be a consciousness of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: past, present, and future as such.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We fall in with the assumption, it seems, because we know very well that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are not directly conscious of a remote past and a remote future.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represent these to ourselves by means of some proxy--we have present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: memories of times long past and present anticipations of what will be in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the time to come.  Moreover, we use the word "present" very loosely; we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say the present year, the present day, the present hour, the present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minute, or the present second.  When we use the word thus loosely, there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems no reason for believing that there should be such a thing as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: direct consciousness that extends beyond the present.  It appears
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasonable to say: No one can be conscious save of the present.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be remembered, however, that the generous present of common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discourse is by no means identical with the ideal point between past and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: future dealt with in the argument under discussion.  We all say: I now
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see that the cloud is moving; I now see that the snow is falling.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there can be no moving, no falling, no change, in the timeless "now" with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we have been concerned.  Is there any evidence whatever that we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shut up, for all our immediate knowledge, to such a "now"?  There is none
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatever.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fact is that this timeless "now" is a product of reflective thought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and not a something of which we are directly conscious.  It is an ideal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point in the real time of which this chapter has treated, the time that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is in a certain sense infinitely divisible.  It is first cousin to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ideal mathematical point, the mere limit between two lines, a something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not perceptible to any sense.  We have a tendency to carry over to it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what we recognize to be true of the very different present of common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discourse, a present which we distinguish from past and future in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhat loose way, but a present in which there certainly is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness of change, of duration.  And when we do this, we dig for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves a pit into which we proceed to fall.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, then, conclude that we are directly conscious of more than the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present, in the sense in which Augustine used the word.  We are conscious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of _time_, of "crude" time, and from this we can pass to a knowledge of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real time, and can determine its parts with precision.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] Book XI, Chapters 14 and 15.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: III. PROBLEMS TOUCHING THE MIND
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: WHAT IS THE MIND?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 30. PRIMITIVE NOTIONS OF MIND.--The soul or mind, that something to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we refer sensations and ideas of all sorts, is an object that men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do not seem to know very clearly and definitely, though they feel so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sure of its existence that they regard it as the height of folly to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call it in question.  That he has a mind, no man doubts; what his mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is, he may be quite unable to say.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen (section 7) that children, when quite young, can hardly be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said to recognize that they have minds at all.  This does not mean that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is mental is not given in their experience.  They know that they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must open their eyes to see things, and must lay their hands upon them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to feel them; they have had pains and pleasures, memories and fancies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In short, they have within their reach all the materials needed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: framing a conception of the mind, and in drawing clearly the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between their minds and external things.  Nevertheless,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are incapable of using these materials; their attention is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: engrossed with what is physical,--with their own bodies and the bodies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of others, with the things that they can eat, with the toys with which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they can play, and the like.  It is only later that there emerges even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a tolerably clear conception of a self or mind different from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical and contrasted with it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Primitive man is almost as material in his thinking as is the young
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: child.  Of this we have traces in many of the words which have come to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be applied to the mind.  Our word "spirit" is from the Latin
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _spiritus_, originally a breeze.  The Latin word for the soul, the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: used by the great philosophers all through the Middle Ages, _anima_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (Greek, anemos), has the same significance.  In the Greek New
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Testament, the word used for spirit (pneuma) carries a similar
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: suggestion.  When we are told in the Book of Genesis that "man became a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: living soul," we may read the word literally "a breath."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What more natural than that the man who is just awakening to a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness of that elusive entity the mind should confuse it with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that breath which is the most striking outward and visible sign that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguishes a living man from a dead one?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That those who first tried to give some scientific account of the soul
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or mind conceived it as a material thing, and that it was sufficiently
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: common to identify it with the breath, we know from direct evidence.  A
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: glance at the Greek philosophy, to which we owe so much that is of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: value in our intellectual life, is sufficient to disclose how difficult
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it was for thinking men to attain to a higher conception.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, Anaximenes of Miletus, who lived in the sixth century before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Christ, says that "our soul, which is air, rules us."  A little later,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Heraclitus, a man much admired for the depth of his reflections,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintains that the soul is a fiery vapor, evidently identifying it with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the warm breath of the living creature.  In the fifth century, B.C.,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Anaxagoras, who accounts for the ordering of the elements into a system
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of things by referring to the activity of Mind or Reason, calls mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "the finest of things," and it seems clear that he did not conceive of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it as very different in nature from the other elements which enter into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the constitution of the world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Democritus of Abdera (between 460 and 360 B.C.), that great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigator of nature and brilliant writer, developed a materialistic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine that admits the existence of nothing save atoms and empty
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space.  He conceived the soul to consist of fine, smooth, round atoms,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which are also atoms of fire.  These atoms are distributed through the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole body, but function differently in different places--in the brain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they give us thought, in the heart, anger, and in the liver, desire.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Life lasts just so long as we breathe in and breathe out such atoms.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The doctrine of Democritus was taken up by Epicurus, who founded his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: school three hundred years before Christ--a school which lived and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prospered for a very long time.  Those who are interested in seeing how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a materialistic psychology can be carried out in detail by an ingenious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind should read the curious account of the mind presented in his great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: poem, "On Nature," by the Roman poet Lucretius, an ardent Epicurean,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who wrote in the first century B.C.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The school which we commonly think of contrasting with the Epicurean,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and one which was founded at about the same time, is that of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Stoics.  Certainly the Stoics differed in many things from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Epicureans; their view of the world, and of the life of man, was a much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nobler one; but they were uncompromising materialists, nevertheless,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and identified the soul with the warm breath that animates man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 31. THE MIND AS IMMATERIAL.--It is scarcely too much to say that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Greek philosophy as a whole impresses the modern mind as representing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the thought of a people to whom it was not unnatural to think of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind as being a breath, a fire, a collection of atoms, a something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material.  To be sure, we cannot accuse those twin stars that must ever
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remain the glory of literature and science, Plato and Aristotle, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: being materialists.  Plato (427-347, B.C.) distributes, it is true, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: three-fold soul, which he allows man, in various parts of the human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body, in a way that at least suggests the Democritean distribution of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind-atoms.  The lowest soul is confined beneath the diaphragm; the one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: next in rank has its seat in the chest; and the highest, the rational
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: soul, is enthroned in the head.  However, he has said quite enough
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about this last to indicate clearly that he conceived it to be free
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from all taint of materiality.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As for Aristotle (384-322, B.C.),  who also distinguished between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lower psychical functions and the higher, we find him sometimes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speaking of soul and body in such a way as to lead men to ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves whether he is really speaking of two things at all; but when
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he specifically treats of the _nous_ or reason, he insists upon its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complete detachment from everything material.  Man's reason is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subjected to the fate of the lower psychical functions, which, as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "form" of the body, perish with the body; it enters from without, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it endures after the body has passed away.  It is interesting to note,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: however, an occasional lapse even in Aristotle.  When he comes to speak
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the relation to the world of the Divine Mind, the First Cause of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Motion, which he conceives as pure Reason, he represents it as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _touching_ the world, although it remains itself _untouched_.  We seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to find here just a flavor--an inconsistent one--of the material.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such reflections as those of Plato and Aristotle bore fruit in later
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ages.  When we come down to Plotinus the Neo-Platonist (204-269, A.D.),
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we have left the conception of the soul as a warm breath, or as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: composed of fine round atoms, far behind.  It has become curiously
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abstract and incomprehensible.  It is described as an immaterial
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substance  This substance is, in a sense, in the body, or, at least, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is present to the body.  But it is not in the body as material things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are in this place or in that.  _It is as a whole in the whole body, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is as a whole in every part of the body_.  Thus the soul may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as divisible, since it is distributed throughout the body; but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it must also be regarded as indivisible, since it is wholly in every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let the man to whom such sentences as these mean anything rejoice in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the meaning that he is able to read into them!  If he can go as far as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Plotinus, perhaps he can go as far as Cassiodorus (477-570, A.D.), and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintain that the soul is not merely as a whole in every part of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body, but is wholly in each of its own parts.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Upon reading such statements one's first impulse is to exclaim: How is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it possible that men of sense should be led to speak in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: irresponsible way? and when they do speak thus, is it conceivable that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other men should seriously occupy themselves with what they say?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But if one has the historic sense, and knows something of the setting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which such doctrines come to the birth, one cannot regard it as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remarkable that men of sense should urge them.  No one coins them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independently out of his own brain; little by little men are impelled
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: along the path that leads to such conclusions.  Plotinus was a careful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: student of the philosophers that preceded him.  He saw that mind must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be distinguished from matter, and he saw that what is given a location
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in space, in the usual sense of the words, is treated like a material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing.  On the other hand, he had the common experience that we all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have of a relation between mind and body.  How do justice to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation, and yet not materialize mind?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What he tried to do is clear, and it seems equally clear that he had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: good reason for trying to do it.  But it appears to us now that what he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: actually did was to make of the mind or soul a something very like an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistent bit of matter, that is somehow in space, and yet not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exactly in space, a something that can be in two places at once, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: logical monstrosity.  That his doctrine did not meet with instant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rejection was due to the fact, already alluded to, that our experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the mind is something rather dim and elusive.  It is not easy for a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man to say what it is, and, hence, it is not easy for a man to say what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The doctrine of Plotinus passed over to Saint Augustine, and from him
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it passed to the philosophers of the Middle Ages.  How extremely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult it has been for the world to get away from it at all, is made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly evident in the writings of that remarkable man Descartes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes wrote in the seventeenth century.  The long sleep of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Middle Ages was past, and the several sciences had sprung into a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vigorous and independent life.  It was not enough for Descartes to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describe the relation of mind and body in the loose terms that had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prevailed up to his time.  He had made a careful study of anatomy, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he realized that the brain is a central organ to which messages are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carried by the nerves from all parts of the body.  He knew that an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: injury to the nerve might prevent the receipt of a message, _i.e._ he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knew that a conscious sensation did not come into being until something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happened in the brain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor was he content merely to refer the mind to the brain in a general
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: way.  He found the "little pineal gland" in the midst of the brain to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be in what he regarded as an admirable position to serve as the seat of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the soul.  To this convenient little central office he relegated it;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and he describes in a way that may to-day well provoke a smile the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: movements that the soul imparts to the pineal gland, making it incline
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself in this direction and in that, and making it push the "animal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spirits," the fluid contained in the cavities of the brain, towards
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: various "pores."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus he writes:[1] "Let us, then, conceive of the soul as having her
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chief seat in the little gland that is in the middle of the brain,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whence she radiates to all the rest of the body by means of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spirits, the nerves, and even the blood, which, participating in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impressions of the spirits, can carry them through the arteries to all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the members."  And again: "Thus, when the soul wills to call anything
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to remembrance, this volition brings it about that the gland, inclining
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself successively in different directions, pushes the spirits towards
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: divers parts of the brain, until they find the part which has the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: traces that the object which one wishes to recollect has left there."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must admit that Descartes' scientific studies led him to make this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind that sits in the little pineal gland something very material.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is spoken of as though it pushed the gland about; it is affected by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motions of the gland, as though it were a bit of matter.  It seems to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a less inconsistent thing than the "all in the whole body" soul of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Plotinus; but it appears to have purchased its comprehensibility at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expense of its immateriality.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Shall we say that Descartes frankly repudiated the doctrine that had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obtained for so many centuries?  We cannot say that; he still held to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.  But how could he?  The reader has perhaps remarked above that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speaks of the soul as having her _chief_ seat in the pineal gland.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems odd that he should do so, but he still held, even after he had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come to his definite conclusions as to the soul's seat, to the ancient
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine that the soul is united to all the parts of the body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "conjointly."  He could not wholly repudiate a venerable tradition.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen, thus, that men first conceived of the mind as material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and later came to rebel against such a conception.  But we have seen,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: also, that the attempt to conceive it as immaterial was not wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successful.  It resulted in a something that we may describe as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistently material rather than as not material at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 32. MODERN COMMON SENSE NOTIONS OF THE MIND.--Under this heading I mean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to sum up the opinions as to the nature of the mind usually held by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intelligent persons about us to-day who make no claim to be regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers.  Is it not true that a great many of them believe:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) That the mind is in the body?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) That it acts and reacts with matter?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) That it is a substance with attributes?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) That it is nonextended and immaterial?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I must remark at the outset that this collection of opinions is by no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means something gathered by the plain man from his own experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These opinions are the echoes of old philosophies.  They are a heritage
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the past, and have become the common property of all intelligent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons who are even moderately well-educated.  Their sources have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indicated in the preceding sections; but most persons who cherish them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have no idea of their origin.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Men are apt to suppose that these opinions seem reasonable to them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely for the reason that they find in their own experience evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of their truth.  But this is not so.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Have we not seen above how long it took men to discover that they must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not think of the mind as being a breath, or a flame, or a collection of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material atoms?  The men who erred in this way were abler than most of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us can pretend to be, and they gave much thought to the matter.  And
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when at last it came to be realized that mind must not thus be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceived as material, those who endeavored to conceive it as something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: else gave, after their best efforts, a very queer account of it indeed.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is it in the face of such facts reasonable to suppose that our friends
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and acquaintances, who strike us as having reflective powers in nowise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remarkable, have independently arrived at the conception that the mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is a nonextended and immaterial substance?  Surely they have not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought all this out for themselves.  They have taken up and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appropriated unconsciously notions which were in the air, so to speak.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They have inherited their doctrines, not created them.  It is well to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remember this, for it may make us the more willing to take up and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: examine impartially what we have uncritically turned into articles of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belief.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The first two articles, namely, that the mind is in the body and that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it acts upon, and is acted upon by, material things, I shall discuss at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: length in the next chapter.  Here I pause only to point out that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man does not put the mind into the body quite unequivocally.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think it would surprise him to be told that a line might be drawn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: through two heads in such a way as to transfix two minds.  And I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remark, further, that he has no clear idea of what it means for mind to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: act upon body or body to act upon mind.  How does an immaterial thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: set a material thing in motion?  Can it touch it?  Can it push it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Then what does it do?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But let us pass on to the last two articles of faith mentioned above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We all draw the distinction between _substance_ and its _attributes_ or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _qualities_.  The distinction was remarked and discussed many centuries
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ago, and much has been written upon it.  I take up the ruler on my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: desk; it is recognized at once as a bit of wood.  How?  It has such and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such qualities.  My paper-knife is of silver.  How do I know it?  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has certain other qualities.  I speak of my mind.  How do I know that I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have a mind?  I have sensations and ideas.  If I experienced no mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena of any sort, evidence of the existence of a mind would be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lacking.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, whether I am concerned with the ruler, with the paper-knife, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the mind, have I direct evidence of the existence of anything more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than the whole group of qualities?  Do I ever perceive the substance?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the older philosophy, the substance (_substantia_) was conceived to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a something not directly perceived, but only inferred to exist--a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something underlying the qualities of things and, as it were, holding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them together.  It was believed in by philosophers who were quite ready
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to admit that they could not tell anything about it.  For example, John
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke (1632-1704), the English philosopher, holds to it stoutly, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: yet describes it as a mere "we know not what," whose function it is to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold together the bundles of qualities that constitute the things we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the modern philosophy men still distinguish between substance and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: qualities.  It is a useful distinction, and we could scarcely get on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without it.  But an increasing number of thoughtful persons repudiate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the old notion of substance altogether.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, they say, understand by the word "substance" the whole group of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: qualities _as a group_--not merely the qualities that are revealed at a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given time, but all those that we have reason to believe a fuller
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge would reveal.  In short, we may understand by it just what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: left when the "we know not what" of the Lockian has been discarded.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This notion of substance we may call the more modern one; yet we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hardly say that it is the notion of the plain man.  He does not make
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very clear to himself just what is in his thought, but I think we do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him no injustice in maintaining that he is something of a Lockian, even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if he has never heard of Locke.  The Lockian substance is, as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reader has seen, a sort of "unknowable."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And now for the doctrine that the mind is nonextended and immaterial.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With these affirmations we may heartily agree; but we must admit that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the plain man enunciates them without having a very definite idea of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what the mind is.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He regards as in his mind all his sensations and ideas, all his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceptions and mental images of things.  Now, suppose I close my eyes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and picture to myself a barber's pole.  Where is the image?  We say, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mind.  Is it extended?  We feel impelled to answer, No.  But it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly _seems_ to be extended; the white and the red upon it appear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undeniably side by side.  May I assert that this mental image has no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extension whatever?  Must I deny to it _parts_, or assert that its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parts are not side by side?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems odd to maintain that a something as devoid of parts as is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematical point should yet appear to have parts and to be extended.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, if we allow the image to be extended, how can we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: refer it to a nonextended mind?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To such questions as these, I do not think that the plain man has an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: answer.  That they can be answered, I shall try to show in the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section of this chapter.  But one cannot answer them until one has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained to rather a clear conception of what is meant by the mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And until one has attained to such a conception, the statement that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind is immaterial must remain rather vague and indefinite.  As we saw
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above, even the Plotinic soul was inconsistently material rather than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immaterial.  It was not excluded from space; it was referred to space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in an absurd way.  The mind as common sense conceives it, is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successor of this Plotinic soul, and seems to keep a flavor of what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material after all.  This will come out in the next chapter, where we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall discuss mind and body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 33. THE PSYCHOLOGIST AND THE MIND.--When we ask how the psychologist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceives of the mind, we must not forget that psychologists are many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that they differ more or less from each other in their opinions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we say "the psychologist" believes this or that, we mean usually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no more than that the opinion referred to is prevalent among men of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that class, or that it is the opinion of those whom we regard as its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more enlightened members.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Taking the words in this somewhat loose sense, I shall ask what the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist's opinion is touching the four points set forth in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: preceding section.  How far does he agree with the plain man?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) There can be no doubt that he refers the mind to the body in some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: way, although he may shake his head over the use of the word "in."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) As to whether the mind acts and reacts with matter, in any sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the words analogous to that in which they are commonly used, there is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: division in the camp.  Some affirm such interaction; some deny it.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter will be discussed in the next chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) The psychologist--the more modern one--inclines to repudiate any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substance or substratum of the sort accepted in the Middle Ages and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believed in by many men now.  To him the mind is the whole complex of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena in their interrelations.  In other words, the mind is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not an unknown and indescribable something that is merely inferred; it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is something revealed in consciousness and open to observation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) The psychologist is certainly not inclined to regard the mind or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any idea belonging to it as material or as extended.  But he does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize implicitly, if not explicitly, that ideas are composite.  To
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him, as to the plain man, the image held in the memory or imagination
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _seems_ to be extended, and he can distinguish its parts.  He does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do much towards clearing away the difficulty alluded to at the close of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the last section.  It remains for the metaphysician to do what he can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with it, and to him we must turn if we wish light upon this obscure
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subject.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 34. THE METAPHYSICIAN AND THE MIND.--I have reserved for the next
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter the first two points mentioned as belonging to the plain man's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of the mind.  In what sense the mind may be said to be in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body, and how it may be conceived to be related to the body, are topics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that deserve to be treated by themselves in a chapter on "Mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Body."  Here I shall consider what the metaphysician has to say about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mind as substance, and about the mind as nonextended and immaterial.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
