text: It has been said that the Lockian substance is really an "unknowable."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: No one pretends to have experience of it; it is revealed to no sense;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is, indeed, a name for a mere nothing, for when we abstract from a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing, in thought, every single quality, we find that there is left to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us nothing whatever.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We cannot say that the substance, in this sense of the word, is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _reality_ of which the qualities are _appearances_.  In Chapter V we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: saw just what we may legitimately mean by realities and appearances,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it was made clear that an unknowable of any sort cannot possibly be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reality to which this or that appearance is referred.  Appearances
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and realities are experiences which are observed to be related in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain ways.  That which is not open to observation at all, that of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we have, and can have, no experience, we have no reason to call
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reality of anything.  We have, in truth, no reason to talk about it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at all, for we know nothing whatever about it; and when we do talk
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about it, it is because we are laboring under a delusion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is equally true whether we are concerned with the substance of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things or with the substance of minds.  An "unknowable" is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "unknowable" in any case, and we may simply discard it.  We lose
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing by so doing, for one cannot lose what one has never had, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what, by hypothesis, one can never have.  The loss of a mere word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should occasion us no regret.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, we have seen that we do not lose the world of real material things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in rejecting the "Unknowable" (Chapter V).  The things are complexes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: qualities, of physical phenomena; and the more we know about these, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more do we know about real things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we have also seen (Chapter IV) that physical phenomena are not the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only phenomena of which we have experience.  We are conscious of mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena as well, of the phenomena of the subjective order, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and ideas.  Why not admit that these _constitute_ the mind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as physical phenomena constitute the things which belong to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who says this says no more than that the mind is known and is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowable.  It is what it is perceived to be; and the more we know of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena, the more do we know of the mind.  Shall we call the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind as thus known a _substance_?  That depends on the significance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we give to this word.  It is better, perhaps, to avoid it, for it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is fatally easy to slip into the old use of the word, and then to say,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as men have said, that we do not know the mind as it is, but only as it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears to us to be--that we do not know the reality, but only its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearances.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And if we keep clearly before us the view of the mind which I am
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: advocating, we shall find an easy way out of the difficulties that seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to confront us when we consider it as nonextended and immaterial.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Certain complexes of mental phenomena--for example, the barber's pole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above alluded to--certainly appear to be extended.  Are they really
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extended?  If I imagine a tree a hundred feet high, is it really a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hundred feet high?  Has it any real size at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Our problem melts away when we realize what we mean by this "real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: size."  In Chapter V, I have distinguished between apparent space and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real space.  Real space is, as was pointed out, the "plan" of the real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical world.  To occupy any portion of real space, a thing must be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real external thing; that is, the experiences constituting it must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belong to the objective order, they must not be of the class called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental.  We all recognize this, in a way.  We know that a real material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foot rule cannot be applied to an imaginary tree.  We say, How big did
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the tree seen in a dream _seem_; we do not say, How big was it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _really_?  If we did ask such a question, we should be puzzled to know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: where to look for an answer.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And this for a very good reason.  He who asks: How big was that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imaginary tree really? asks, in effect: How much real space did the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unreal tree fill?  The question is a foolish one.  It assumes that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena not in the objective order are in the objective order.  As
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well ask how a color smells or how a sound looks.  When we are dealing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the material we are not dealing with the mental, and we must never
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: forget this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The tree imagined or seen in a dream seems extended.  Its extension is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _apparent_ extension, and this apparent extension has no place in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world whatever.  But we must not confound this apparent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extension with a real mathematical point, and call the tree nonextended
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in this sense.  If we do this we are still in the old error--we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not gotten away from real space, but have substituted position in that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space for extension in that space.  Nothing mental can have even a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position in real space.  To do that it would have to be a real thing in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sense indicated.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us, then, agree with the plain man in affirming that the mind is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonextended, but let us avoid misconception.  The mind is constituted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of experiences of the subjective order.  None of these are in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space--real space.  But some of them have apparent extension, and we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must not overlook all that this implies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now for the mind as immaterial.  We need not delay long over this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point.  If we mean by the mind the phenomena of the subjective order,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and by what is material the phenomena of the objective order, surely we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may and must say that the mind is immaterial.  The two classes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena separate themselves out at once.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "The Passions," Articles 34 and 42.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER IX
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: MIND AND BODY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 35. IS THE MIND IN THE BODY?--There was a time, as we have seen in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last chapter (section 30), when it did not seem at all out of the way
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to think of the mind as in the body, and very literally in the body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who believes the mind to be a breath, or a something composed of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material atoms, can conceive it as being in the body as unequivocally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as chairs can be in a room.  Breath can be inhaled and exhaled; atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can be in the head, or in the chest, or the heart, or anywhere else in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the animal economy.  There is nothing dubious about this sense of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: preposition "in."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we have also seen (section 31) that, as soon as men began to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: realize that the mind is not material, the question of its presence in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the body became a serious problem.  If I say that a chair is in a room,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I say what is comprehensible to every one.  It is assumed that it is in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a particular place in the room and is not in some other place.  If,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: however, I say that the chair is, as a whole, in every part of the room
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at once, I seem to talk nonsense.  This is what Plotinus and those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: came after him said about the mind.  Are their statements any the less
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonsensical because they are talking about minds?  When one speaks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about things mental, one must not take leave of good sense and utter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unmeaning phrases.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If minds are enough like material things to be in anything, they must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be in things in some intelligible sense of the word.  It will not do to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say: I use the word "in," but I do not really mean _in_.  If the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaning has disappeared, why continue to use the word?  It can only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lead to mystification.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes seemed to come back to something like an intelligible meaning
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when he put the mind in the pineal gland in the brain.  Yet, as we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen, he clung to the old conception.  He could not go back to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: frank materialization of mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And the plain man to-day labors under the same difficulty.  He puts the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind in the body, in the brain, but he does not put it there frankly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and unequivocally.  It is in the brain and yet not exactly in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain.  Let us see if this is not the case.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we ask him: Does the man who wags his head move his mind about? does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he who mounts a step raise his mind some inches? does he who sits down
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on a chair lower his mind?  I think we shall find that he hesitates in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his answers.  And if we go on to say: Could a line be so drawn as to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pass through your image of me and my image of you, and to measure their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance from one another?  I think he will say, No.  He does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regard minds and their ideas as existing in space in this fashion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Furthermore, it would not strike the plain man as absurd if we said to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him: Were our senses far more acute than they are, it is conceivable
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we should be able to perceive every atom in a given human body,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and all its motions.  But would he be willing to admit that an increase
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the sharpness of sense would reveal to us directly the mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: connected with such a body?  It is not, then, in the body as the atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are.  It cannot be seen or touched under any conceivable circumstances.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What can it mean, hence, to say that it is _there_?  Evidently, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word is used in a peculiar sense, and the plain man cannot help us to a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear understanding of it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His position becomes intelligible to us when we realize that he has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inherited the doctrine that the mind is immaterial, and that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: struggles, at the same time, with the tendency so natural to man to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive it after the analogy of things material.  He thinks of it as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the body, and, nevertheless, tries to dematerialize this "in."  His
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought is sufficiently vague, and is inconsistent, as might be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expected.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we will bear in mind what was said in the closing section of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last chapter, we can help him over his difficulty.  That mind and body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are related there can be no doubt.  But should we use the word "in" to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: express this relation?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The body is a certain group of phenomena in the objective order; that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is, it is a part of the external world.  The mind consists of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences in the subjective order.  We have seen that no mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomenon can occupy space--real space, the space of the external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world--and that it cannot even have a position in space (section 34).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As mental, it is excluded from the objective order altogether.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind is not, then, strictly speaking, _in_ the body, although it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related to it.  It remains, of course, to ask ourselves how we ought to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive the relation.  This we shall do later in the present chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, it may be said, it would sound odd to deny that the mind is in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body.  Does not every one use the expression?  What can we substitute
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for it?  I answer: If it is convenient to use the expression let us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: continue to do so.  Men must talk so as to be understood.  But let us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not perpetuate error, and, as occasion demands it, let us make clear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves and to others what we have a right to understand by this _in_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we use it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 36. THE DOCTRINE OF THE INTERACTIONIST.--There is no man who does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know that his mind is related to his body as it is not to other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things.  We open our eyes, and we see things; we stretch out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our hand, and we feel them; our body receives a blow, and we feel pain;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we wish to move, and the muscles are set in motion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These things are matters of common experience.  We all perceive, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other words, that there is an interaction, in some sense of the term,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between mind and body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is important to realize that one may be quite well aware of all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such facts, and yet may have very vague notions of what one means by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body and by mind, and may have no definite theory at all of the sort of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation that obtains between them.  The philosopher tries to attain to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a clearer conception of these things.  His task, be it remembered, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to analyze and explain, not to deny, the experiences which are the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: common property of mankind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the present day the two theories of the relation of mind and body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that divide the field between them and stand opposed to each other are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _interactionism_ and _parallelism_.  I have used the word "interaction"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a little above in a loose sense to indicate our common experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the fact that we become conscious of certain changes brought about in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our body, and that our purposes realize themselves in action.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: every one who accepts this fact is not necessarily an interactionist.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The latter is a man who holds a certain more or less definite theory as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to what is implied by the fact.  Let us take a look at his doctrine.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Physical things interact.  A billiard ball in motion strikes one which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has been at rest; the former loses its motion, the latter begins to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: roll away.  We explain the occurrence by a reference to the laws of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mechanics; that is to say, we point out that it is merely an instance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the uniform behavior of matter in motion under such and such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: circumstances.  We distinguish between the state of things at one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: instant and the state of things at the next, and we call the former
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _cause_ and the latter _effect_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be observed that both cause and effect here belong to the one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: order, the objective order.  They have their place in the external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world.  Both the balls are material things; their motion, and the space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which they move, are aspects of the external world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If the balls did not exist in the same space, if the motion of the one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could not be towards or away from the other, if contact were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impossible, we would manifestly have no interaction _in the sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word employed above_.  As it is, the interaction of physical things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is something that we can describe with a good deal of definiteness.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Things interact in that they stand in certain physical relations, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undergo changes of relations according to certain laws.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, to one who conceives the mind in a grossly material way, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation of mind and body can scarcely seem to be a peculiar problem,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different from the problem of the relation of one physical thing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another.  If my mind consists of atoms disseminated through my body,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its presence in the body appears as unequivocal as the presence of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dinner in a man who has just risen from the table.  Nor can the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interaction of mind and matter present any unusual difficulties, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind is matter.  Atoms may be conceived to approach each other, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clash, to rearrange themselves.  Interaction of mind and body is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing else than an interaction of bodies.  One is not forced to give
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a new meaning to the word.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When, however, one begins to think of the mind as immaterial, the case
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is very different.  How shall we conceive an immaterial thing to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related to a material one?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes placed the mind in the pineal gland, and in so far he seemed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to make its relation to the gland similar to that between two material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  When he tells us that the soul brings it about that the gland
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bends in different directions, we incline to view the occurrence as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very natural--is not the soul in the gland?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, on the other hand, Descartes also taught that the essence of mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is _thought_ and the essence of body is _extension_.  He made the two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natures so different from each other that men began to ask themselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: how the two things could interact at all.  The mind wills, said one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher, but that volition does not set matter in motion; when the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind wills, God brings about the appropriate change in material things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The mind perceives things, said another, but that is not because they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: affect it directly; it sees things in God.  Ideas and things, said a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: third, constitute two independent series; no idea can cause a change in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things, and no thing can cause a change in ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The interactionist is a man who refuses to take any such turn as these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers.  His doctrine is much nearer to that of Descartes than it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is to any of theirs.  He uses the one word "interaction" to describe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relation between material things and also the relation between mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and body, nor does he dwell upon the difference between the two.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: insists that mind and matter stand in the one causal nexus; that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: change in the outside world may be the _cause_ of a perception coming
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into being in a mind, and that a volition may be the _cause_ of changes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What shall we call the plain man?  I think we may call him an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interactionist in embryo.  The stick in his hand knocks an apple off of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the tree; his hand seems to him to be set in motion because he wills
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.  The relation between his volition and the motion of his hand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears to him to be of much the same sort as that between the motion
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the stick and the fall of the apple.  In each case he thinks he has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to do with the relation of cause and effect.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The opponent of the interactionist insists, however, that the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is satisfied with this view of the matter only because he has not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: completely stripped off the tendency to conceive the mind as a material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing.  And he accuses the interactionist of having fallen a prey to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same weakness.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Certainly, it is not difficult to show that the interactionists write
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as though the mind were material, and could be somewhere in space.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: late Dr. McCosh fairly represents the thought of many, and he was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: capable of expressing himself as follows;[1] "It may be difficult to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ascertain the exact point or surface at which the mind and body come
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: together and influence each other, in particular, how far into the body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (Descartes without proof thought it to be in the pineal gland), but it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is certain, that when they do meet mind knows body as having its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: essential properties of extension and resisting energy."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How can an immaterial thing be located at some point or surface within
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the body?  How can a material thing and an immaterial thing "come
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: together" at a point or surface?  And if they cannot come together,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what have we in mind when we say they interact?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The parallelist, for it is he who opposes interactionism, insists that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we must not forget that mental phenomena do not belong to the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: order as physical phenomena.  He points out that, when we make the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "interaction" cover the relations of mental phenomena to physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena as well as the relations of the latter to each other, we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assimilating heedlessly facts of two different kinds and are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obliterating an important distinction.  He makes the same objection to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: calling the relations between mental phenomena and physical phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _causal_.  If the relation of a volition to the movement of the arm is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not the same as that of a physical cause to its physical effect, why,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he argues, do you disguise the difference by calling them by the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 37. THE DOCTRINE OF THE PARALLELIST.--Thus, the parallelist is a man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who is so impressed by the gulf between physical facts and mental facts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he refuses to regard them as parts of the one order of causes and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effects.  You cannot, he claims, make a single chain out of links so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diverse.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Some part of a human body receives a blow; a message is carried along a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensory nerve and reaches the brain; from the brain a message is sent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out along a motor nerve to a group of muscles; the muscles contract,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and a limb is set in motion.  The immediate effects of the blow, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ingoing message, the changes in the brain, the outgoing message, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contraction of the muscles--all these are physical facts.  One and all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may be described as motions in matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But the man who received the blow becomes conscious that he was struck,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and both interactionist and parallelist regard him as becoming
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious of it when the incoming message reaches some part of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain.  What shall be done with this consciousness?  The interactionist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: insists that it must be regarded as a link in the physical chain of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causes and effects--he breaks the chain to insert it.  The parallelist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintains that it is inconceivable that such an insertion should be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: made.  He regards the physical series as complete in itself, and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: places the consciousness, as it were, on a _parallel_ line.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It must not be supposed that he takes this figure literally.  It is his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effort to avoid materializing the mind that forces him to hold the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position which he does.  To put the mind in the brain is to make of it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a material thing; to make it parallel to the brain, in the literal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense of the word, would be just as bad.  All that we may understand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him to mean is that mental phenomena and physical, although they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related, cannot be built into the one series of causes and effects.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is apt to speak of them as _concomitant_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must not forget that neither parallelist nor interactionist ever
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dreams of repudiating our common experiences of the relations of mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena and physical.  Neither one will, if he is a man of sense,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abandon the usual ways of describing such experiences.  Whatever his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theory, he will still say: I am suffering because I struck my hand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: against that table; I sat down because I chose to do so.  His doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not supposed to deny the truth contained in such statements; it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed only to give a fuller understanding of it.  Hence, we cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condemn either doctrine simply by an uncritical appeal to such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements and to the experiences they represent.  We must look much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deeper.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, what can the parallelist mean by _referring_ sensations and ideas
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the brain and yet denying that they are _in_ the brain?  What is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this reference?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us come back to the experiences of the physical and the mental as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they present themselves to the plain man.  They have been discussed at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: length in Chapter IV.  It was there pointed out that every one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguishes without difficulty between sensations and things, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that every one recognizes explicitly or implicitly that a sensation is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an experience referred in a certain way to the body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When the eyes are open, we _see_; when the ears are open, we _hear_;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when the hand is laid on things, we _feel_.  How do we know that we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiencing sensations?  The setting tells us that.  The experience in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question is given together with an experience of the body.  This is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _concomitance of the mental and the physical_ as it appears in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of us all; and from such experiences as these the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher who speaks of the concomitance of physical and mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena must draw the whole meaning of the word.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us here sharpen a little the distinction between sensations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  Standing at some distance from the tree, I see an apple fall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the ground.  Were I only half as far away, my experience would not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be exactly the same--I should have somewhat different sensations.  As
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we have seen (section 17), the apparent sizes of things vary as we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: move, and this means that the quantity of sensation, when I observe the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apple from a nearer point, is greater.  The man of science tells me
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the image which the object looked at projects upon the retina of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the eye grows larger as we approach objects.  The thing, then, may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remain unchanged; our sensations will vary according to the impression
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is made upon our body.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  When I have learned something of physics, I am ready to admit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, although light travels with almost inconceivable rapidity, still,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its journey through space does take time.  Hence the impression made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon my eye by the falling apple is not simultaneous with the fall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself; and if I stand far away it is made a little later than when I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: am near.  In the case in point the difference is so slight as to pass
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unnoticed, but there are cases in which it seems apparent even to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unlearned that sensations arise later than the occurrences of which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take them to be the report.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, I stand on a hill and watch a laborer striking with his sledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the distant railway.  I hear the sound of the blow while I see his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tool raised above his head.  I account for this by saying that it has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taken some time for the sound-waves to reach my ear, and I regard my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation as arising only when this has been accomplished.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But this conclusion is not judged sufficiently accurate by the man of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science.  The investigations of the physiologist and the psychologist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have revealed that the brain holds a peculiar place in the economy of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the body.  If the nerve which connects the sense organ with the brain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be severed, the sensation does not arise.  Injuries to the brain affect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mental life as injuries to other parts of the body do not.  Hence,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is concluded that, to get the real time of the emergence of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation, we must not inquire merely when an impression was made upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the organ of sense, but must determine when the message sent along the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nerve has reached some part of the brain.  The resulting brain change
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is regarded as the true concomitant of the sensation.  If there is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain change of a certain kind, there is the corresponding sensation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It need hardly be said that no one knows as yet much about the brain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motions which are supposed to be concomitants of sensations, although a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: good deal is said about them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is very important to remark that in all this no new meaning has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given to the word "concomitance."  The plain man remarks that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations and their changes must be referred to the body.  With the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body disposed in a certain way, he has sensations of a certain kind;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with changes in the body, the sensations change.  He does not perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sensations to be in the body.  As I recede from a house I have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole series of visual experiences differing from each other and ending
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a faint speck which bears little resemblance to the experience with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which I started.  I have had, as we say, a series of sensations, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: groups of such.  Did any single group, did the experience which I had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at any single moment, seem to me to be _in my body_?  Surely not.  Its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation to my body is other than that.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And when the man of science, instead of referring sensations vaguely to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the body, refers them to the brain, the reference is of precisely the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same nature.  From our common experience of the relation of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical and the mental he starts out.  He has no other ground on which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to stand.  He can only mark the reference with greater exactitude.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have been speaking of the relation of sensations to the brain.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scarcely necessary for me to show that all other mental phenomena must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be referred to the brain as well, and that the reference must be of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same nature.  The considerations which lead us to refer ideas to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain are set forth in our physiologies and psychologies.  The effects
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of cerebral disease, injuries to the brain, etc., are too well known to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: need mention; and it is palpably as absurd to put ideas in the brain as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is to put sensations there.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the parallelist, if he be a wise man, will not attempt to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _explain_ the reference of mental phenomena to the brain--to _explain_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relation between mind and matter.  The relation appears to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unique.  Certainly it is not identical with the relation between two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things.  We explain things, in the common acceptation of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word, when we show that a case under consideration is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exemplification of some general law--when we show, in other words, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it does not stand alone.  But this does stand alone, and is admitted to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stand alone.  We admit as much when we say that the mind is immaterial,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and yet hold that it is related to the body.  We cannot, then, ask for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an _explanation_ of the relation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But this does not mean that the reference of mental phenomena to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body is a meaningless expression.  We can point to those experiences of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitance that we all have, distinguish them carefully from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations of another kind, and say: This is what the word means,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether it be used by the plain man or by the man of science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have said above: "If there is a brain change of a certain kind, there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the corresponding sensation."  Perhaps the reader will feel inclined
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to say here: If you can say as much as this, why can you not go a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little farther and call the brain change the _cause_ of the sensation?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But he who speaks thus, forgets what has been said above about the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uniqueness of the relation.  In the objective order of our experiences,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the external world, we can distinguish between antecedents and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consequents, between causes and their effects.  The causes and their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effects belong to the one order, they stand in the same series.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation of the physical to the mental is, as we have seen, a different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation.  Hence, the parallelist seems justified in objecting to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assimilation of the two.  He prefers the word "concomitance," just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: because it marks the difference.  He does not mean to indicate that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation is any the less uniform or dependable when he denies that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is causal.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 38. IN WHAT SENSE MENTAL PHENOMENA HAVE A TIME AND PLACE.--We have seen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in Chapters VI and VII what space and time--real space and time--are.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They are the plan of the real external world and its changes; they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aspects of the objective order of experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this order no mental phenomenon can belong.  It cannot, as we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen (section 35), occupy any portion of space or even have a location
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in space.  It is equally true that no series of mental changes can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occupy any portion of time, real time, or even fill a single moment in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the stream of time.  There are many persons to whom this latter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statement will seem difficult of acceptance; but the relation of mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena to space and to time is of the same sort, and we can consider
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the two together.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Psychologists speak unhesitatingly of the localization of sensations in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the brain, and they talk as readily of the moment at which a sensation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arises and of the duration of the sensation.  What can they mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such expressions?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen that sensations are not in the brain, and their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: localization means only the determination of their concomitant physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena, of the corresponding brain-change.  And it ought to be clear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even from what has been said above that, in determining the moment at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which a sensation arises, we are determining only the time of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitant brain process.  Why do we say that a sensation arises later
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than the moment at which an impression is made upon the organ of sense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and earlier than the resulting movement of some group of muscles?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Because the change in the brain, to which we refer the sensation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occurs later than the one and earlier than the other.  This has a place
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in real time, it belongs to that series of world changes whose
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: succession constitutes real time.  If we ask _when_ anything happened,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we always refer to this series of changes.  We try to determine its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place in the world order.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we ask: When was Julius Caesar born?  We are given a year and a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: day.  How is the time which has elapsed since measured?  By changes in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the physical world, by revolutions of the earth about the sun.  We ask:
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When did he conceive the plan of writing his Commentaries?  If we get
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an answer at all, it must be an answer of the same kind--some point in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the series of physical changes which occur in real time must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indicated.  Where else should we look for an answer?  In point of fact,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we never do look elsewhere.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  We have distinguished between apparent space and real space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 34).  We have seen that, when we deny that a mental image can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occupy any portion of space, we need not think of it as losing its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parts and shrivelling to a point.  We may still attribute to it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparent space; may affirm that it seems extended.  Let us mark the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same distinction when we consider time.  The psychologist speaks of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: duration of a sensation.  Has it real duration?  It is not in time at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, and, of course, it cannot, strictly speaking, occupy a portion of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time.  But we can try to measure the duration of the physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitant, and call this the real duration of the sensation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We all distinguish between the real time of mental phenomena, in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense indicated just above, and the apparent time.  We know very well
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the one may give us no true measure of the other.  A sermon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _seems_ long; was it _really_ long?  There is only one way of measuring
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its real length.  We must refer to the clock, to the sun, to some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: change in the physical world.  We _seem_ to live years in a dream; was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the dream _really_ a long one?  The real length can only be determined,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if at all, by a physical reference.  Those apparent years of the dream
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have no place in the real time which is measured by the clock.  We do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not have to cut it and insert them somewhere.  They belong to a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different order, and cannot be inserted any more than the thought of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: patch can be inserted in a rent in a real coat.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We see, thus, when we reflect upon the matter, that mental phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot, strictly speaking, be said to have a time and place.  He who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attributes these to them materializes them.  But their physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitants have a time and place, and mental phenomena can be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ordered by a reference to these.  They can be assigned a time and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place of existing in a special sense of the words not to be confounded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the sense in which we use them when we speak of the time and place
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of material things.  This makes it possible to relate every mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomenon to the world system in a definite way, and to distinguish it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly from every other, however similar.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We need not, when we come to understand this, change our usual modes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speech.  We may still say: The pain I had two years ago is like the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pain I have to-day; my sensation came into being at such a moment; my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regret lasted two days.  We speak that we may be understood; and such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phrases express a truth, even if they are rather loose and inaccurate.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we must not be deceived by such phrases, and assume that they mean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what they have no right to mean.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 39. OBJECTIONS TO PARALLELISM.--What objections can be brought against
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelism?  It is sometimes objected by the interactionist that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abandons the plain man's notion of the mind as a substance with its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attributes, and makes of it a mere collection of mental phenomena.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be admitted that the parallelist usually holds a view which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: differs rather widely from that of the unlearned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But even supposing this objection well taken, it can no longer be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as an objection specifically to the doctrine of parallelism,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the view of the mind in question is becoming increasingly popular,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it is now held by influential interactionists as well as by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelists.  One may believe that the mind consists of ideas, and may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: still hold that ideas can cause motions in matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is, however, another objection that predisposes many thoughtful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons to reject parallelism uncompromisingly.  It is this.  If we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit that the chain of physical causes and effects, from a blow given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the body to the resulting muscular movements made in self-defense,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is an unbroken one, what part can we assign to the mind in the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: transaction?  Has it _done_ anything?  Is it not reduced to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position of a passive spectator?  Must we not regard man as "a physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: automaton with parallel psychical states"?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such an account of man cannot fail to strike one as repugnant; and yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is the parallelist himself whom we must thank for introducing us to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.  The account is not a caricature from the pen of an opponent.  "An
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: automaton," writes Professor Clifford,[2] "is a thing that goes by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself when it is wound up, and we go by ourselves when we have had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: food.  Excepting the fact that other men are conscious, there is no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason why we should not regard the human body as merely an exceedingly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complicated machine which is wound up by putting food into the mouth.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is not _merely_ a machine, because consciousness goes with it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The mind, then, is to be regarded as a stream of feelings which runs
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallel to, and simultaneous with, a certain part of the action of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body, that is to say, that particular part of the action of the brain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which the cerebrum and the sensory tracts are excited."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The saving statement that the body is not _merely_ a machine, because
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness goes with it, does not impress one as being sufficient to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: redeem the illustration.  Who wants to be an automaton with an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accompanying consciousness?  Who cares to regard his mind as an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "epiphenomenon"--a thing that exists, but whose existence or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonexistence makes no difference to the course of affairs?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The plain man's objection to such an account of himself seems to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abundantly justified.  As I have said earlier in this chapter, neither
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interactionist nor parallelist has the intention of repudiating the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of world and mind common to us all.  We surely have evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enough to prove that minds count for something.  No house was ever
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: built, no book was ever written, by a creature without a mind; and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: better the house or book, the better the mind.  _That_ there is a fixed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and absolutely dependable relation between the planning mind and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing accomplished, no man of any school has the right to deny.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only legitimate question is: _What is the nature_ of the relation?  Is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it _causal_, or should it be conceived to be _something else_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The whole matter will be more fully discussed in Chapter XI.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
