text: chapter I shall close with a brief summary of the points which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reader will do well to bear in mind when he occupies himself with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) Parallelism is a protest against the interactionist's tendency to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: materialize the mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) The name is a figurative expression, and must not be taken
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: literally.  The true relation between mental phenomena and physical is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given in certain common experiences that have been indicated, and it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a unique relation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) It is a fixed and absolutely dependable relation.  It is impossible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that there should be a particular mental fact without its corresponding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical fact; and it is impossible that this physical fact should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: occur without its corresponding mental fact.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) The parallelist objects to calling this relation _causal_, because
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this obscures the distinction between it and the relation between facts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: both of which are physical.  He prefers the word "concomitance."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (5) Such objections to parallelism as that cited above assume that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitance of which the parallelist speaks is analogous to physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitance.  The chemist puts together a volume of hydrogen gas and a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: volume of chlorine gas, and the result is two volumes of hydrochloric
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acid gas.  We regard it as essential to the result that there should be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the two gases and that they should be brought together.  But the fact
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the chemist has red hair we rightly look upon as a concomitant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomenon of no importance.  The result would be the same if he had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: black hair or were bald.  But this is not the concomitance that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interests the parallelist.  The two sorts of concomitance are alike
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only in the one point.  Some phenomenon is regarded as excluded from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the series of causes and effects under discussion.  On the other hand,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the difference between the two is all-important; in the one case, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitant phenomenon is an accidental circumstance that might just as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well be absent; in the other, it is nothing of the sort; it _cannot_ be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absent--the mental fact _must_ exist if the brain-change in question
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exists.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is quite possible that, on reading this list of points, one may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inclined to make two protests.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: First: Is a parallelism so carefully guarded as this properly called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _parallelism_ at all?  To this I answer: The name matters little.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have used it because I have no better term.  Certainly, it is not the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelism which is sometimes brought forward, and which peeps out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the citation from Clifford.  It is nothing more than an insistence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the truth that we should not treat the mind as though it were a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material thing.  If any one wishes to take the doctrine and discard the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name, I have no objection.  As so guarded, the doctrine is, I think,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Second: If it is desirable to avoid the word "cause," in speaking of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relation of the mental and the physical, on the ground that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: otherwise we give the word a double sense, why is it not desirable to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: avoid the word "concomitance"?  Have we not seen that the word is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ambiguous?  I admit the inconsistency and plead in excuse only that I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have chosen the lesser of two evils.  It is fatally easy to slip into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the error of thinking of the mind as though it were material and had a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place in the physical world.  In using the word "concomitance" I enter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a protest against this.  But I have, of course, no right to use it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without showing just what kind of concomitance I mean.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "First and Fundamental Truths," Book I, Part II, Chapter II.  New
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: York, 1889.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [2] "Lectures and Essays," Vol. II, p. 57.  London, 1879.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER X
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: HOW WE KNOW THERE ARE OTHER MINDS
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 40. IS IT CERTAIN THAT WE KNOW IT?--I suppose there is no man in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sober senses who seriously believes that no other mind than his own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exists.  There is, to be sure, an imaginary being more or less
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussed by those interested in philosophy, a creature called the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Solipsist, who is credited with this doctrine.  But men do not become
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solipsists, though they certainly say things now and then that other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men think logically lead to some such unnatural view of things; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more rarely they say things that sound as if the speaker, in some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moods, at least, might actually harbor such a view.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus the philosopher Fichte (1762-1814) talks in certain of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writings as though he believed himself to be the universe, and his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: words cause Jean Paul Richter, the inimitable, to break out in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: characteristic way: "The very worst of it all is the lazy, aimless,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aristocratic, insular life that a god must lead; he has no one to go
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with.  If I am not to sit still for all time and eternity, if I let
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: myself down as well as I can and make myself finite, that I may have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something in the way of society, still I have, like petty princes, only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my own creatures to echo my words. . . .  Every being, even the highest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Being, wishes something to love and to honor.  But the Fichtean
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine that I am my own body-maker leaves me with nothing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatever--with not so much as the beggar's dog or the prisoner's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spider. . . .  Truly I wish that there were men, and that I were one of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them. . . .  If there exists, as I very much fear, no one but myself,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unlucky dog that I am, then there is no one at such a pass as I."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Just how much Fichte's words meant to the man who wrote them may be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter for dispute.  Certainly no one has shown a greater moral
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earnestness or a greater regard for his fellowmen than this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher, and we must not hastily accuse any one of being a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solipsist.  But that to certain men, and, indeed, to many men, there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have come thoughts that have seemed to point in this direction--that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not a few have had doubts as to their ability to _prove_ the existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of other minds--this we must admit.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It appears somewhat easier for a man to have doubts upon this subject
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when he has fallen into the idealistic error of regarding the material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world, which seems to be revealed to him, as nothing else than his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "ideas" or "sensations" or "impressions."  If we will draw the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "telephone exchange" into the clerk, there seems little reason for not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: including all the subscribers as well.  If other men's bodies are my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations, may not other men's minds be my imaginings?  But doubts may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be felt also by those who are willing to admit a real external world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How do we know that our inference to the existence of other minds is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justifiable inference?  Can there be such a thing as _verification_ in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this field?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For we must remember that no man is directly conscious of any mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: except his own.  Men cannot exhibit their minds to their neighbors as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they exhibit their wigs.  However close may seem to us to be our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intercourse with those about us, do we ever attain to anything more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than our ideas of the contents of their minds?  We do not experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these contents; we picture them, we represent them by certain proxies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To be sure, we believe that the originals exist, but can we be quite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sure of it?  Can there be a _proof_ of this right to make the leap from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one consciousness to another?  We seem to assume that we can make it,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and then we make it again and again; but suppose, after all, that there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were nothing there.  Could we ever find out our error?  And in a field
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: where it is impossible to prove error, must it not be equally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impossible to prove truth?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The doubt has seemed by no means a gratuitous one to certain very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensible practical men.  "It is wholly impossible," writes Professor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Huxley,[1] "absolutely to prove the presence or absence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness in anything but one's own brain, though by analogy, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are justified in assuming its existence in other men."  "The existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of my conception of you in my consciousness," says Clifford,[2]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "carries with it a belief in the existence of you outside of my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness. . . .  How this inference is justified, how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness can testify to the existence of anything outside of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself, I do not pretend to say: I need not untie a knot which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world has cut for me long ago.  It may very well be that I myself am
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the only existence, but it is simply ridiculous to suppose that anybody
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: else is.  The position of absolute idealism may, therefore, be left out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of count, although each individual may be unable to justify his dissent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from it."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These are writers belonging to our own modern age, and they are men of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science.  Both of them deny that the existence of other minds is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing that can be _proved_; but the one tells us that we are "justified
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in assuming" their existence, and the other informs us that, although
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "it may very well be" that no other mind exists, we may leave that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possibility out of count.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Neither position seems a sensible one.  Are we justified in assuming
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what cannot be proved? or is the argument "from analogy" really a proof
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of some sort?  Is it right to close our eyes to what "may very well
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be," just because we choose to do so?  The fact is that both of these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writers had the conviction, shared by us all, that there are other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds, and that we know something about them; and yet neither of them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could see that the conviction rested upon an unshakable foundation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, I have no desire to awake in the mind of any one a doubt of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence of other minds.  But I think we must all admit that the man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who recognizes that such minds are not directly perceived, and who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: harbors doubts as to the nature of the inference which leads to their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption, may, perhaps, be able to say that _he feels certain_ that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there are other minds; but must we not at the same time admit that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is scarcely in a position to say: _it is certain_ that there are other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds?  The question will keep coming back again: May there not, after
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all, be a legitimate doubt on the subject?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To set this question at rest there seems to be only one way, and that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is this: to ascertain the nature of the inference which is made, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see clearly what can be meant by _proof_ when one is concerned with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such matters as these.  If it turns out that we have proof, in the only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense of the word in which it is reasonable to ask for proof, our doubt
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: falls away of itself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 41. THE ARGUMENT FOR OTHER MINDS.--I have said early in this volume
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 7) that the plain man perceives that other men act very much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as he does, and that he attributes to them minds more or less like his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: own.  He reasons from like to like--other bodies present phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which, in the case of his own body, he perceives to be indicative of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind, and he accepts them as indicative of mind there also.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologist makes constant use of this inference; indeed, he could not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: develop his science without it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: John Stuart Mill (1806-1873), whom it is always a pleasure to read
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: because he is so clear and straightforward, presents this argument in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the following form:[3]--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "By what evidence do I know, or by what considerations am I led to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believe, that there exist other sentient creatures; that the walking
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and speaking figures which I see and hear, have sensations and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughts, or, in other words, possess Minds?  The most strenuous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Intuitionist does not include this among the things that I know by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: direct intuition.  I conclude it from certain things, which my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of my own states of feeling proves to me to be marks of it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These marks are of two kinds, antecedent and subsequent; the previous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conditions requisite for feeling, and the effects or consequences of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.  I conclude that other human beings have feelings like me, because,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first, they have bodies like me, which I know, in my own case, to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the antecedent condition of feelings; and because, secondly, they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exhibit the acts, and other outward signs, which in my own case I know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by experience to be caused by feelings.  I am conscious in myself of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series of facts connected by a uniform sequence, of which the beginning
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is modifications of my body, the middle is feelings, the end is outward
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: demeanor.  In the case of other human beings I have the evidence of my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses for the first and last links of the series, but not for the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intermediate link.  I find, however, that the sequence between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first and last is as regular and constant in those other cases as it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in mine.  In my own case I know that the first link produces the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: through the intermediate link, and could not produce it without.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Experience, therefore, obliges me to conclude that there must be an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intermediate link; which must either be the same in others as in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: myself, or a different one.  I must either believe them to be alive, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be automatons; and by believing them to be alive, that is, by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposing the link to be of the same nature as in the case of which I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have experience, and which is in all respects similar, I bring other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human beings, as phenomena, under the same generalizations which I know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by experience to be the true theory of my own existence.  And in doing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so I conform to the legitimate rules of experimental inquiry.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: process is exactly parallel to that by which Newton proved that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: force which keeps the planets in their orbits is identical with that by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which an apple falls to the ground.  It was not incumbent on Newton to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prove the impossibility of its being any other force; he was thought to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have made out his point when he had simply shown that no other force
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: need be supposed.  We know the existence of other beings by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: generalization from the knowledge of our own; the generalization merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: postulates that what experience shows to be a mark of the existence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something within the sphere of our consciousness, may be concluded to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a mark of the same thing beyond that sphere."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the plain man accepts the argument from analogy, here insisted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon, every day of his life.  He is continually forming an opinion as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the contents of other minds on a basis of the bodily manifestations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented to his view.  The process of inference is so natural and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: instinctive that we are tempted to say that it hardly deserves to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: called an inference.  Certainly the man is not conscious of distinct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: steps in the process; he perceives certain phenomena, and they are at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: once illuminated by their interpretation.  He reads other men as we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: read a book--the signs on the paper are scarcely attended to, our whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought is absorbed in that for which they stand.  As I have said
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above, the psychologist accepts the argument, and founds his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclusions upon it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Upon what ground can one urge that this inference to other minds is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doubtful one?  It is made universally.  We have seen that even those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who have theoretic objections against it, do not hesitate to draw it,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a matter of fact.  It appears unnatural in the extreme to reject it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What can induce men to regard it with suspicion?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I think the answer to this question is rather clearly suggested in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sentence already quoted from Professor Huxley:  "It is wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impossible absolutely to prove the presence or absence of consciousness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in anything but one's own brain, though, by analogy, we are justified
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in assuming its existence in other men."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Here Professor Huxley admits that we have something like a proof, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he regards the inference as _justified_.  But he does not think that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have _absolute proof_--the best that we can attain to appears to be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: degree of probability falling short of the certainty which we should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: like to have.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, it should be remarked that the discredit cast upon the argument
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for other minds has its source in the fact that it does not satisfy a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain assumed standard.  What is that standard?  It is the standard
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of proof which we may look for and do look for where we are concerned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to establish the existence of material things with the highest degree
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of certainty.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are all sorts of indirect ways of proving the existence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things.  We may read about them in a newspaper, and regard
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them as highly doubtful; we may have the word of a man whom, on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole, we regard as veracious; we may infer their existence, because we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive that certain other things exist, and are to be accounted for.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Under certain circumstances, however, we may have proof of a different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: kind: we may see and touch the things themselves.  Material things are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: open to direct inspection.  Such a direct inspection constitutes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _absolute proof_, so far as material things are concerned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we have no right to set this up as our standard of absolute proof,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we are talking about other minds.  In this field it is not proof
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at all.  Anything that can be directly inspected is not another mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We cannot cast a doubt upon the existence of colors by pointing to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fact that we cannot smell them.  If they could be smelt, they would not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be colors.  We must in each case seek a proof of the appropriate kind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What have we a right to regard as absolute proof of the existence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another mind?  Only this: the analogy upon which we depend in making
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our inference must be a very close one.  As we shall see in the next
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section, the analogy is sometimes very remote, and we draw the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inference with much hesitation, or, perhaps, refuse to draw it at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not, however, the _kind of inference_ that makes the trouble; it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the lack of detailed information that may serve as a basis for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inference.  Our inference to other minds is unsatisfactory only in so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: far as we are ignorant of our own minds and bodies and of other bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Were our knowledge in these fields complete, we should know without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fail the signs of mind, and should know whether an inference were or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were not justified.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And _justified_ here means proved--proved in the only sense in which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have a right to ask for proof.  No single fact is known that can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discredit such a proof.  Our doubt is, then, gratuitous and can be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dismissed.  We may claim that we have _verification_ of the existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of other minds.  Such verification, however, must consist in showing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, in any given instance, the signs of mind really are present.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot consist in presenting minds for inspection as though they were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One more matter remains to be touched upon in this section.  It has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doubtless been observed that Mill, in the extract given above, seems to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place "feelings," in other words, mental phenomena, between one set of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bodily motions and another.  He makes them the middle link in a chain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whose first and third links are material.  The parallelist cannot treat
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind in this way.  He claims that to make mental phenomena effects or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causes of bodily motions is to make them material.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Must, then, the parallelist abandon the argument for other minds?  Not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at all.  The force of the argument lies in interpreting the phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented by other bodies as one knows by experience the phenomena of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one's own body must be interpreted.  He who concludes that the relation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between his own mind and his own body can best be described as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "parallelism," must judge that other men's minds are related to their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bodies in the same way.  He must treat his neighbor as he treats
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself.  The argument from analogy remains the same.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 42. WHAT OTHER MINDS ARE THERE?--That other men have minds nobody
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: really doubts, as we have seen above.  They resemble us so closely,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their actions are so analogous to our own, that, although we sometimes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: give ourselves a good deal of trouble to ascertain what sort of minds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they have, we never think of asking ourselves whether they have minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor does it ever occur to the man who owns a dog, or who drives a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: horse, to ask himself whether the creature has a mind.  He may complain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it has not much of a mind, or he may marvel at its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intelligence--his attitude will depend upon the expectations which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has been led to form.  But regard the animal as he would regard a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bicycle or an automobile, he will not.  The brute is not precisely like
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us, but its actions bear an unmistakable analogy to our own; pleasure
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and pain, hope and fear, desire and aversion, are so plainly to be read
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into them that we feel that a man must be "high gravel blind" not to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see their significance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, it has been possible for man, under the prepossession of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a mistaken philosophical theory, to assume the whole brute creation to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be without consciousness.  When Descartes had learned something of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mechanism of the human body, and had placed the human soul--_hospes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: comesque corporis_--in the little pineal gland in the midst of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain, the conception in his mind was not unlike that which we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we picture to ourselves a locomotive engine with an engineer in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its cab.  The man gives intelligent direction; but, under some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: circumstances, the machine can do a good deal in the absence of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man; if it is started, it can run of itself, and to do this, it must go
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: through a series of complicated motions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes knew that many of the actions performed by the human body are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not the result of conscious choice, and that some of them are in direct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contravention of the will's commands.  The eye protects itself by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dropping its lid, when the hand is brought suddenly before it; the foot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: jerks away from the heated object which it has accidentally touched.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The body was seen to be a mechanism relatively independent of the mind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and one rather complete in itself.  Joined with a soul, the circle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its functions was conceived to be widened; but even without the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assistance of the soul, it was thought that it could keep itself busy,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and could do many things that the unreflective might be inclined to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attribute to the efficiency of the mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The bodies of the brutes Descartes regarded as mechanisms of the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general nature as the human body.  He was unwilling to allow a soul to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any creature below man, so nothing seemed left to him save to maintain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the brutes are machines without consciousness, and that their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparently purposive actions are to be classed with such human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: movements as the sudden closing of the eye when it is threatened with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the hand.  The melancholy results of this doctrine made themselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evident among his followers.  Even the mild and pious Malebranche could
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be brutal to a dog which fawned upon him, under the mistaken notion
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it did not really hurt a dog to kick it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: All this reasoning men have long ago set aside.  For one thing, it has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come to be recognized that there may be consciousness, perhaps rather
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dim, blind, and fugitive, but still consciousness, which does not get
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: itself recognized as do our clearly conscious purposes and volitions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Many of the actions of man which Descartes was inclined to regard as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unaccompanied by consciousness may not, in fact, be really unconscious.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And, in the second place, it has come to be realized that we have no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to class all the actions of the brutes with those reflex actions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in man which we are accustomed to regard as automatic.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The belief in animal automatism has passed away, it is to be hoped,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: never to return.  That lower animals have minds we must believe.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what sort of minds have they?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is hard enough to gain an accurate notion of what is going on in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human mind.  Men resemble each other more or less closely, but no two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are precisely alike, and no two have had exactly the same training.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may misunderstand even the man who lives in the same house with me and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is nearly related to me.  Does he really suffer and enjoy as acutely as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he seems to? or must his words and actions be accepted with a discount?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The greater the difference between us, the more danger that I shall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misjudge him.  It is to be expected that men should misunderstand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: women; that men and women should misunderstand children; that those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: differ in social station, in education, in traditions and habits of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life, should be in danger of reading each other as one reads a book in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a tongue imperfectly mastered.  When these differences are very great,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the task is an extremely difficult one.  What are the emotions, if he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has any, of the Chinaman in the laundry near by?  His face seems as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult of interpretation as are the hieroglyphics that he has pasted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: up on his window.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we come to the brutes, the case is distinctly worse.  We think
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we can attain to some notion of the minds to be attributed to such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: animals as the ape, the dog, the cat, the horse, and it is not nonsense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to speak of an animal psychology.  But who will undertake to tell us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything definite of the mind of a fly, a grasshopper, a snail, or a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cuttlefish?  That they have minds, or something like minds, we must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believe; what their minds are like, a prudent man scarcely even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attempts to say.  In our distribution of minds may we stop short of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even the very lowest animal organisms?  It seems arbitrary to do so.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: More than that; some thoughtful men have been led by the analogy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between plant life and animal life to believe that something more or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: less remotely like the consciousness which we attribute to animals must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be attributed also to plants.  Upon this belief I shall not dwell, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: here we are evidently at the limit of our knowledge, and are making the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vaguest of guesses.  No one pretends that we have even the beginnings
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a plant psychology.  At the same time, we must admit that organisms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of all sorts do bear some analogy to each other, even if it be a remote
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one; and we must admit also that we cannot _prove_ plants to be wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: devoid of a rudimentary consciousness of some sort.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As we begin with man and descend the scale of beings, we seem, in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upper part of the series, to be in no doubt that minds exist.  Our only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question is as to the precise contents of those minds.  Further down we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: begin to ask ourselves whether anything like mind is revealed at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That this should be so is to be expected.  Our argument for other minds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the argument from analogy, and as we move down the scale our analogy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: grows more and more remote until it seems to fade out altogether.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who harbors doubts as to whether the plants enjoy some sort of psychic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life, may well find those doubts intensified when he turns to study the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: crystal; and when he contemplates inorganic matter he should admit that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the thread of his argument has become so attenuated that he cannot find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 43. THE DOCTRINE OF MIND-STUFF.--Nevertheless, there have been those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who have attributed something like consciousness even to inorganic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter.  If the doctrine of evolution be true, argues Professor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Clifford,[4] "we shall have along the line of the human pedigree a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series of imperceptible steps connecting inorganic matter with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves.  To the later members of that series we must undoubtedly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ascribe consciousness, although it must, of course, have been simpler
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than our own.  But where are we to stop?  In the case of organisms of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain complexity, consciousness is inferred.  As we go back along the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: line, the complexity of the organism and of its nerve-action insensibly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diminishes; and for the first part of our course we see reason to think
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the complexity of consciousness insensibly diminishes also.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if we make a jump, say to the tunicate mollusks, we see no reason there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to infer the existence of consciousness at all.  Yet not only is it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impossible to point out a place where any sudden break takes place, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is contrary to all the natural training of our minds to suppose a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: breach of continuity so great."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must not, says Clifford, admit any breach of continuity.  We must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assume that consciousness is a complex of elementary feelings, "or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather of those remoter elements which cannot even be felt, but of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which the simplest feeling is built up."  We must assume that such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: elementary facts go along with the action of every organism, however
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simple; but we must assume also that it is only when the organism has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reached a certain complexity of nervous structure that the complex of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychic facts reaches the degree of complication that we call
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Consciousness.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So much for the assumption of something like mind in the mollusk, where
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Clifford cannot find direct evidence of mind.  But the argument does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not stop here: "As the line of ascent is unbroken, and must end at last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in inorganic matter, we have no choice but to admit that every motion
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of matter is simultaneous with some . . . fact or event which might be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part of a consciousness."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Of the universal distribution of the elementary constituents of mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Clifford writes as follows: "That element of which, as we have seen,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even the simplest feeling is a complex, I shall call _Mind-stuff_.  A
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moving molecule of inorganic matter does not possess mind or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness; but it possesses a small piece of mind-stuff.  When
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: molecules are so combined together as to form the film on the under
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: side of a jellyfish, the elements of mind-stuff which go along with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them are so combined as to form the faint beginnings of Sentience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When the molecules are so combined as to form the brain and nervous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of a vertebrate, the corresponding elements of mind-stuff are so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: combined as to form some kind of consciousness; that is to say, changes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the complex which take place at the same time get so linked together
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the repetition of one implies the repetition of the other.  When
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter takes the complex form of a living human brain, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: corresponding mind-stuff takes the form of a human consciousness,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: having intelligence and volition."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is the famous mind-stuff doctrine.  It is not a scientific
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine, for it rests on wholly unproved assumptions.  It is a play of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the speculative fancy, and has its source in the author's strong desire
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to fit mental phenomena into some general evolutionary scheme.  As he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is a parallelist, and cannot make of physical phenomena and of mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one single series of causes and effects, he must attain his end by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: making the mental series complete and independent in itself.  To do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this, he is forced to make several very startling assumptions:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) We have seen that there is evidence that there is consciousness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhere--it is revealed by certain bodies.  Clifford assumes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness, or rather its raw material, _mind-stuff_, to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: everywhere.  For this assumption we have not a whit of evidence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) To make of the stuff thus attained a satisfactory evolutionary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series, he is compelled to assume that mental phenomena are related to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: each other much as physical phenomena are related to each other.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: notion he had from Spinoza, who held that, just as all that takes place
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the physical world must be accounted for by a reference to physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causes, so all happenings in the world of ideas must be accounted for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by a reference to mental causes, _i.e._ to ideas.  For this assumption
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is no more evidence than for the former.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) Finally, to bring the mental phenomena we are familiar with,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations of color, sound, touch, taste, etc., into this evolutionary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scheme, he is forced to assume that all such mental phenomena are made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: up of elements which do not belong to these classes at all, of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something that "cannot even be felt."  For this assumption there is as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little evidence as there is for the other two.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fact is that the _mind-stuff_ doctrine is a castle in the air.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is too fanciful and arbitrary to take seriously.  It is much better to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come back to a more sober view of things, and to hold that there is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence that other minds exist, but no evidence that every material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing is animated.  If we cannot fit this into our evolutionary scheme,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perhaps it is well to reexamine our evolutionary scheme, and to see
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether some misconception may not attach to that.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "Collected Essays," Vol. I, p. 219, New York, 1902.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [2] "On the Nature of Things-in-Themselves," in "Lectures and Essays,"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Vol. II.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [3] "Examination of Sir William Hamilton's Philosophy," Chapter XII.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [4] "On the Nature of Things-in-Themselves."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XI
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: OTHER PROBLEMS OF WORLD AND MIND
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 44. IS THE MATERIAL WORLD A MECHANISM?--So far we have concerned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves with certain leading problems touching the external world and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mind,--problems which seem to present themselves unavoidably to those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who enter upon the path of reflection.  And we have seen, I hope, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is much truth, as well as some misconception, contained in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather vague opinions of the plain man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But the problems that we have taken up by no means exhaust the series of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those that present themselves to one who thinks with patience and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persistency.  When we have decided that men are not mistaken in believing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that an external world is presented in their experience; when we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: corrected our first crude notions of what this world is, and have cleared
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: away some confusions from our conceptions of space and time; when we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained to a reasonably clear view of the nature of the mind, and of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature of its connection with the body; when we have escaped from a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tumble into the absurd doctrine that no mind exists save our own, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have turned our backs upon the rash speculations of the adherents of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "mind-stuff"; there still remain many points upon which we should like to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have definite information.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the present chapter I shall take up and turn over a few of these, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it must not be supposed that one can get more than a glimpse of them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: within such narrow limits.  First of all we will raise the question
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether it is permissible to regard the material world, which we accept,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as through and through a mechanism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There can be little doubt that there is a tendency on the part of men of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science at the present day so to regard it.  It should, of course, be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: frankly admitted that no one is in a position to prove that, from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cosmic mist, in which we grope for the beginnings of our universe, to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: organized whole in which vegetable and animal bodies have their place,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is an unbroken series of changes all of which are explicable by a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reference to mechanical laws.  Chemistry, physics, and biology are still
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: separate and distinct realms, and it is at present impossible to find for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them a common basis in mechanics.  The belief of the man of science must,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hence, be regarded as a faith; the doctrine of the mechanism of nature is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a working hypothesis, and it is unscientific to assume that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything more.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There can be no objection to a frank admission that we are not here
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: walking in the light of established knowledge.  But it does seem to savor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of dogmatism for a man to insist that no increase in our knowledge can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ever reveal that the physical world is an orderly system throughout, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that all the changes in material things are explicable in terms of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one unified science.  Earnest objections have, however, been made to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tendency to regard nature as a mechanism.  To one of the most curious of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them we have been treated lately by Dr. Ward in his book on "Naturalism
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and Agnosticism."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is there ingeniously argued that, when we examine with care the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental concepts of the science of mechanics, we find them to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: self-contradictory and absurd.  It follows that we are not justified in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turning to them for an explanation of the order of nature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The defense of the concepts of mechanics we may safely leave to the man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of science; remembering, of course, that, when a science is in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: making, it is to be expected that the concepts of which it makes use
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should undergo revision from time to time.  But there is one general
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consideration that it is not well to leave out of view when we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contemplating such an assault upon the notion of the world as mechanism
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as is made by Dr. Ward.  It is this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such attacks upon the conception of mechanism are not purely destructive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in their aim.  The man who makes them wishes to destroy one view of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of things in order that he may set up another.  If the changes in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the system of material things cannot be accounted for mechanically, it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: argued, we are compelled to turn for our explanation to the action and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interaction of minds.  This seems to give mind a very important place in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the universe, and is believed to make for a view of things that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guarantees the satisfaction of the highest hopes and aspirations of man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That a recognition of the mechanical order of nature is incompatible with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such a view of things as is just above indicated, I should be the last to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit.  The notion that it is so is, I believe, a dangerous error.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an error that tends to put a man out of sympathy with the efforts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science to discover that the world is an orderly whole, and tempts him to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rejoice in the contemplation of human ignorance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But the error is rather a common one; and see to what injustice it may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lead one.  It is concluded that the conception of _matter_ is an obscure
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one; that we do not know clearly what we mean when we speak of the _mass_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a body; that there are disputes as to proper significance to be given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the words _cause_ and _effect_; that the _laws of motion_, as they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at present formulated, do not seem to account satisfactorily for the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
