text: behavior of all material particles.  From this it is inferred that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must give up the attempt to explain mechanically the order of physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, suppose that it were considered a dangerous and heterodox doctrine,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the changes in the system of things are due to the activities of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds.  Would not those who now love to point out the shortcomings of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science of mechanics discover a fine field for their destructive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: criticism?  Are there no disputes as to the ultimate nature of mind?  Are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men agreed touching the relations of mind and matter?  What science even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attempts to tell us how a mind, by an act of volition, sets material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: particles in motion or changes the direction of their motion?  How does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one mind act upon another, and what does it mean for one mind to act upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If the science of mechanics is not in all respects as complete a science
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as it is desirable that it should be, surely we must admit that when we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turn to the field of mind we are not dealing with what is clear and free
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from difficulties.  Only a strong emotional bias can lead a man to dwell
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with emphasis upon the difficulties to be met with in the one field, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to pass lightly over those with which one meets in the other.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One may, however, refuse to admit that the order of nature is throughout
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mechanical, without taking any such unreasonable position as this.  One
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may hold that many of the changes in material things do not _appear_ to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be mechanical, and that it is too much of an assumption to maintain that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are such, even as an article of faith.  Thus, when we pass from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of the inorganic to that of organic life, we seem to make an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immense step.  No one has even begun to show us that the changes that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take place in vegetable and animal organisms are all mechanical changes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How can we dare to assume that they are?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With one who reasons thus we may certainly feel a sympathy.  The most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ardent advocate of mechanism must admit that his doctrine is a working
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hypothesis, and not _proved_ to be true.  Its acceptance would, however,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be a genuine convenience from the point of view of science, for it does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: introduce, at least provisionally, a certain order into a vast number of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: facts, and gives a direction to investigation.  Perhaps the wisest thing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to do is, not to combat the doctrine, but to accept it tentatively and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: examine carefully what conclusions it may seem to carry with it--how it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may affect our outlook upon the world as a whole.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 45. THE PLACE OF MIND IN NATURE.--One of the very first questions which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we think of asking when we contemplate the possibility that the physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world is throughout a mechanical system is this: How can we conceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds to be related to such a system?  That minds, and many minds, do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exist, it is not reasonable to doubt.  What shall we do with them?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One must not misunderstand the mechanical view of things.  When we use
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "machine," we call before our minds certain gross and relatively
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simple mechanisms constructed by man.  Between such and a flower, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: butterfly, and a human body, the difference is enormous.  He who elects
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to bring the latter under the title of mechanism cannot mean that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discerns no difference between them and a steam engine or a printing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: press.  He can only mean that he believes he might, could he attain to a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: glimpse into their infinite complexity, find an explanation of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical changes which take place in them, by a reference to certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general laws which describe the behavior of material particles everywhere.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And the man who, having extended his notion of mechanism, is inclined to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: overlook the fact that animals and men have minds, that thought and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feeling, plan and purpose, have their place in the world, may justly be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accused of a headlong and heedless enthusiasm.  Whatever may be our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinion on the subject of the mechanism of nature, we have no right to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minimize the significance of thought and feeling and will.  Between that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which has no mind and that which has a mind there is a difference which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be obliterated by bringing both under the concept of mechanism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is a difference which furnishes the material for the sciences of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychology and ethics, and gives rise to a whole world of distinctions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which find no place in the realm of the merely physical.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are, then, minds as well as bodies; what place shall we assign to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these minds in the system of nature?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Several centuries ago it occurred to the man of science that the material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world should be regarded as a system in which there is constant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: transformation, but in which nothing is created.  This way of looking at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things expressed itself formerly in the statement that, through all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changes that take place in the world, the quantity of matter and motion
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remains the same.  To-day the same idea is better expressed in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of the eternity of mass and the conservation of energy.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain language, this doctrine teaches that every change in every part of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the physical world, every motion in matter, must be preceded by physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conditions which may be regarded as the equivalent of the change in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But this makes the physical world a closed system, a something complete
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in itself.  Where is there room in such a system for minds?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does indeed seem hard to find in such a system a place for minds, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one conceives of minds as does the interactionist.  We have seen (section
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 36) that the interactionist makes the mind act upon matter very much as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one particle of matter is supposed to act upon another.  Between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical and the mental he assumes that there are _causal_ relations;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _i.e._ physical changes must be referred to mental causes sometimes, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental changes to physical.  This means that he finds a place for mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: facts by inserting them as links in the one chain of causes and effects
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with physical facts.  If he is not allowed to break the chain and insert
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them, he does not know what to do with them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The parallelist has not the same difficulty to face.  He who holds that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena must not be built into the one series of causes and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effects with physical phenomena may freely admit that physical phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: form a closed series, an orderly system of their own, and he may yet find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a place in the world for minds.  He refuses to regard them as a part of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world-mechanism, but he _relates_ them to physical things, conceiving
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them as _parallel to_ the physical in the sense described (sections
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 37-39).  He insists that, even if we hold that there are gaps in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical order of causes and effects, we cannot conceive these gaps to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: filled by mental phenomena, simply because they are mental phenomena.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They belong to an order of their own.  Hence, the assumption that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical series is unbroken does not seem to him to crowd mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena out of their place in the world at all.  They must, in any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: case, occupy the place that is appropriate to them (section 38).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It will be noticed that this doctrine that the chain of physical causes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and effects is nowhere broken, and that mental phenomena are related to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it as the parallelist conceives them to be, makes the world-system a very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: orderly one.  Every phenomenon has its place in it, and can be accounted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for, whether it be physical or mental.  To some, the thought that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world is such an orderly thing is in the highest degree repugnant.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object that, in such a world, there is no room for _free-will_; and they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object, further, that there is no room for the _activity of minds_.  Both
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of these objections I shall consider in this chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But first, I must say a few words about a type of doctrine lately
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: insisted upon,[1] which bears some resemblance to interactionism as we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: usually meet with it, and, nevertheless, tries to hold on to the doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the conservation of energy.  It is this:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The concept of energy is stretched in such a way as to make it cover
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena as well as physical.  It is claimed that mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena and physical phenomena are alike "manifestations of energy,"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that the coming into being of a consciousness is a mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "transformation," a something to be accounted for by the disappearance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the physical world of a certain equivalent--perhaps of some motion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It will be noticed that this is one rather subtle way of obliterating the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between mental phenomena and physical.  In so far it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: resembles the interactionist's doctrine.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In criticism of it we may say that he who accepts it has wandered away
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from a rather widely recognized scientific hypothesis, and has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substituted for it a very doubtful speculation for which there seems to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be no whit of evidence.  It is, moreover, a speculation repugnant to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific mind, when its significance is grasped.  Shall we assume
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without evidence that, when a man wakes in the morning and enjoys a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental life suspended or diminished during the night, his thoughts and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feelings have come into being at the expense of his body?  Shall we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assume that the mass of his body has been slightly diminished, or that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motions have disappeared in a way that cannot be accounted for by a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reference to the laws of matter in motion?  This seems an extraordinary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption, and one little in harmony with the doctrine of the eternity
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of mass and the conservation of energy as commonly understood.  We need
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not take it seriously so long as it is quite unsupported by evidence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 46. THE ORDER OF NATURE AND "FREE-WILL."--In a world as orderly as, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the previous section, this world is conceived to be, is there any room
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for freedom?  What if the man of science is right in suspecting that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series of physical causes and effects is nowhere broken?  Must we then
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclude that we are never free?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To many persons it has seemed that we are forced to draw this conclusion,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it is not surprising that they view the doctrine with dismay.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: argue: Mental phenomena are made parallel with physical, and the order of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical phenomena seems to be determined throughout, for nothing can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happen in the world of matter unless there is some adequate cause of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happening.  If, then, I choose to raise my finger, that movement must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admitted to have physical causes, and those causes other causes, and so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on without end.  If such a movement must always have its place in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causal series of this kind, how can it be regarded as a free movement?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is determined, and not free.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, it is far from a pleasant thing to watch the man of science busily
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at work trying to prove that the physical world is an orderly system, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all the while to feel in one's heart that the success of his efforts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condemns one to slavery.  It can hardly fail to make one's attitude
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: towards science that of alarm and antagonism.  From this I shall try to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: free the reader by showing that our freedom is not in the least danger,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that we may look on unconcerned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we approach that venerable dispute touching the freedom of the will,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which has inspired men to such endless discussions, and upon which they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have written with such warmth and even acrimony, the very first thing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do is to discover what we have a right to mean when we call a man _free_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As long as the meaning of the word is in doubt, the very subject of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dispute is in doubt.  When may we, then, properly call a man free?  What
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the normal application of the term?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I raise my finger.  Every man of sense must admit that, under normal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conditions, I can raise my finger or keep it down, _as I please_.  There
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is no ground for a difference of opinion so far.  But there is a further
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point upon which men differ.  One holds that my "pleasing" and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brain-change that corresponds to it have their place in the world-order;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that is, he maintains that every volition can be _accounted for_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Another holds that, under precisely the same circumstances, one may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "please" or not "please"; which means that the "pleasing" cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholly accounted for by anything that has preceded.  The first man is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _determinist_, and the second a "_free-willist_."  I beg the reader to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observe that the word "free-willist" is in quotation marks, and not to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: suppose that it means simply a believer in the freedom of the will.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When in common life we speak of a man as free, what do we understand by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word?  Usually we mean that he is free from external compulsion.  If
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my finger is held by another, I am not free to raise it.  But I may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: free in this sense, and yet one may demur to the statement that I am a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: free man.  If a pistol be held to my head with the remark, "Hands up!" my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finger will mount very quickly, and the bystanders will maintain that I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: had no choice.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We speak in somewhat the same way of men under the influence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intoxicants, of men crazed by some passion and unable to take into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consideration the consequences of their acts, and of men bound by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spell of hypnotic suggestion.  Indeed, whenever a man is in such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condition that he is glaringly incapable of leading a normal human life
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and of being influenced by the motives that commonly move men, we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inclined to say that he is not free.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But does it ever occur to us to maintain that, in general, the possession
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a character and the capacity of being influenced by considerations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make it impossible for a man to be free?  Surely not.  If I am a prudent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man, I will invest my money in good securities.  Is it sensible to say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that I cannot have been free in refusing a twenty per cent investment,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _because I am by nature prudent_?  Am I a slave _because I eat when I am
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hungry_, and can I partake of a meal freely, only when there is no reason
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: why I should eat at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who calls me free only when my acts do violence to my nature or cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be justified by a reference to anything whatever has strange notions of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: freedom.  Patriots, poets, moralists, have had much to say of freedom;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men have lived for it, and have died for it; men love it as they love
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their own souls.  Is the object of all this adoration the metaphysical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absurdity indicated above?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To insist that a man is free only in so far as his actions are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unaccountable is to do violence to the meaning of a word in very common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: use, and to mislead men by perverting it to strange and unwholesome uses.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Yet this is done by the "free-willist."  He keeps insisting that man is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: free, and then goes on to maintain that he cannot be free unless he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "free."  He does not, unfortunately, supply the quotation marks, and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: profits by the natural mistake in identity.  As he defines freedom it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becomes "freedom," which is a very different thing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What is this "freedom"?  It is not freedom from external constraint.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not freedom from overpowering passion.  It is freedom from all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motives, good as well as bad, that we can conceive of as influencing man,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and freedom also from oneself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is well to get this quite clear.  The "free-willist" maintains that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _in so far as a man is "free,"_ his actions cannot be accounted for by a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reference to the order of causes at all--not by a reference to his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: character, hereditary or acquired; not by a reference to his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surroundings.  "Free" actions, in so far as they are "free," have, so to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speak, sprung into being out of the void.  What follows from such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine?  Listen:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) It follows that, in so far as I am "free," I am not the author of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what appear to be my acts; who can be the cause of causeless actions?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) It follows that no amount of effort on my part can prevent the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearance of "free" acts of the most deplorable kind.  If one can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condition their appearance or non-appearance, they are not "free" acts.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) It follows that there is no reason to believe that there will be any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: congruity between my character and my "free" acts.  I may be a saint by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature, and "freely" act like a scoundrel.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (4) It follows that I can deserve no credit for "free" acts.  I am not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their author.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (5) It follows that, in so far as I am "free," it is useless to praise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: me, to blame me, to punish me, to endeavor to persuade me.  I must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given over to unaccountable sainthood or to a reprobate mind, as it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happens to happen.  I am quite beyond the pale of society, for my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: neighbor cannot influence my "free" acts any more than I can.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (6) It follows that, in so far as I am "free," I am in something very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: like a state of slavery; and yet, curiously enough, it is a slavery
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without a master.  In the old stories of Fate, men were represented as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: puppets in the hand of a power outside themselves.  Here I am a puppet in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no hand; but I am a puppet just the same, for I am the passive spectator
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of what appear to be my acts.  I do not do the things I seem to do.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are done for me or in me--or, rather, they are not done, but just happen.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such "freedom" is a wretched thing to offer to a man who longs for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: freedom; for the freedom to act out his own impulses, to guide his life
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: according to his own ideals.  It is a mere travesty on freedom, a fiction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the philosophers, which inspires respect only so long as one has not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pierced the disguise of its respectable name.  True freedom is not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing to be sought in a disorderly and chaotic world, in a world in which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: actions are inexplicable and character does not count.  Let us rinse our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds free of misleading verbal associations, and let us realize that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "free-will" neighbor would certainly not be to us an object of respect.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He would be as offensive an object to have in our vicinity as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "free-will" gun or a "free-will" pocketknife.  He would not be a rational
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: creature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Our only concern need be for freedom, and this is in no danger in an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: orderly world.  We all recognize this truth, in a way.  We hold that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man of good character freely chooses the good, and a man of evil
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: character freely chooses evil.  Is not this a recognition of the fact
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the choice is a thing to be accounted for, and is, nevertheless, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: free choice?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have been considering above the world as it is conceived to be by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelist, but, to the reader who may not incline towards parallelism,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I wish to point out that these reasonings touching the freedom of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will concern the interactionist just as closely.  They have no necessary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: connection with parallelism.  The interactionist, as well as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelist, may be a determinist, a believer in freedom, or he may be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "free-willist."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He regards mental phenomena and physical phenomena as links in the one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chain of causes and effects.  Shall he hold that certain mental links are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "free-will" links, that they are wholly unaccountable?  If he does, all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that has been said above about the "free-willist" applies to him.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believes in a disorderly world, and he should accept the consequences of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his doctrine.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 47. THE PHYSICAL WORLD AND THE MORAL WORLD.--I have said a little way
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: back that, when we think of bodies as having minds, we are introduced to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a world of distinctions which have no place in the realm of the merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical.  One of the objections made to the orderly world of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelist was that in it there is no room for the activity of minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Before we pass judgment on this matter, we should try to get some clear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: notion of what we may mean by the word "activity."  The science of ethics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must go by the board, if we cannot think of men as _doing_ anything, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acting rightly or acting wrongly.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us conceive a billiard ball in motion to come into collision with one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at rest.  We commonly speak of the first ball as active, and of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: second as the passive subject upon which it exercises its activity.  Are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we justified in thus speaking?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In one sense, of course, we are.  As I have several times had occasion to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remark, we are, in common life, justified in using words rather loosely,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: provided that it is convenient to do so, and that it does not give rise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to misunderstandings.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, in a stricter sense, we are not justified in thus speaking, for in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doing so we are carrying over into the sphere of the merely physical a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction which does not properly belong there, but has its place in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another realm.  The student of mechanics tells us that the second ball
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has affected the first quite as much as the first has affected the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: second.  We cannot simply regard the first as cause and the second as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: effect, nor may we regard the motion of the first as cause and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subsequent motion of the second as its effect alone.  _The whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: situation at the one instant_--both balls, their relative positions and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their motion and rest--must be taken as the cause of _the whole situation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at the next instant_, and in this whole situation the condition of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: second ball has its place as well as that of the first.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If, then, we insist that to have causal efficiency is the same thing as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be active, we should also admit that the second ball was active, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: quite as active as the first.  It has certainly had as much to do with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the total result.  But it offends us to speak of it in this way.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prefer to say that the first was active and the second was acted upon.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What is the source of this distinction?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Its original source is to be found in the judgments we pass upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious beings, bodies with minds; and it could never have been drawn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if men had not taken into consideration the relations of minds to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: changes in the physical world.  As carried over to inanimate things it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a transferred distinction; and its transference to this field is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: strictly justifiable, as has been indicated above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I must make this clear by an illustration.  I hurry along a street
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: towards the university, because the hour for my lecture is approaching.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I am struck down by a falling tile.  In my advance up the street I am
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as active; in my fall to the ground I am regarded as passive.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, looking at both occurrences from the purely physical point of view,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we have nothing before us but a series of changes in the space relations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of certain masses of matter; and in all those changes both my body and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its environment are concerned.  As I advance, my body cannot be regarded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as the sole cause of the changes which are taking place.  My progress
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would be impossible without the aid of the ground upon which I tread.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor can I accuse the tile of being the sole cause of my demolition.  Had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I not been what I was and where I was, the tile would have fallen in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vain.  I must be regarded as a concurrent cause of my own disaster, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my unhappy state is attributable to me as truly as it is to the tile.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Why, then, am I in the one case regarded as active and in the other as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: passive?  In each case I am a cause of the result.  How does it happen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, in the first instance, I seem to most men to be _the_ cause, and in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the second to be not a cause at all?  The rapidity of my motion in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first instance cannot account for this judgment.  He who rides in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: police van and he who is thrown from the car of a balloon may move with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: great rapidity and yet be regarded as passive.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Men speak as they do because they are not content to point out the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical antecedents of this and that occurrence and stop with that.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They recognize that, between my advance up the street and my fall to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ground there is one very important difference.  In the first case what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happening _may be referred to an idea in my mind_.  Were the idea not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there, I should not do what I am doing.  In the second case, what has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: happened _cannot be referred to an idea in my mind_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Here we have come to the recognition that there are such things as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _purposes_ and _ends_; that an idea and some change in the external world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may be related as _plan_ and _accomplishment_.  In other words, we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been brought face to face with what has been given the somewhat
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misleading name of _final cause_.  In so far as that in the bringing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: about of which I have had a share is my _end_, I am _active_; in so far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as it is not my end, but comes upon me as something not planned, I am
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _passive_.  The enormous importance of the distinction may readily be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen; it is only in so far as I am a creature who can have purposes, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _desire_ and _will_, _foresight_ and _prudence_, _right_ and _wrong_, can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have a significance for me.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have dwelt upon the meaning of the words "activity" and "passivity,"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and have been at pains to distinguish them from cause and effect, because
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the two pairs of terms have often been confounded with each other, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this confusion has given rise to a peculiarly unfortunate error.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this error that lies at the foundation of the objection referred to at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the beginning of this section.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen that certain men of science are inclined to look upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical world as a great system, all the changes in which may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accounted for by an appeal to physical causes.  And we have seen that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: parallelist regards ideas, not as links in this chain, but as parallel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with physical changes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is argued by some that, if this is a true view of things, we must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: embrace the conclusion that _the mind cannot be active at all_, that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can _accomplish nothing_.  We must look upon the mind as an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "epiphenomenon," a useless decoration; and must regard man as "a physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: automaton with parallel psychical states."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such abuse of one's fellow-man seems unchristian, and it is wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uncalled for on any hypothesis.  Our first answer to it is that it seems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be sufficiently refuted by the experiences of common life.  We have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abundant evidence that men's minds do count for something.  I conclude
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that I want a coat, and I order one of my tailor; he believes that I will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pay for it, he wants the money, and he makes the coat; his man desires to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earn his wages and he delivers it.  If I had not wanted the coat, if the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tailor had not wanted my money, if the man had not wanted to earn his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wages, the end would not have been attained.  No philosopher has the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to deny these facts.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Ah! but, it may be answered, these three "wants" are not supposed to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the _causes_ of the motions in matter which result in my appearing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well-dressed on Sunday.  They are only _concomitant phenomena_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this I reply: What of that?  We must not forget what is meant by such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concomitance (section 39).  We are dealing with a fixed and necessary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation, not with an accidental one.  If these "wants" had been lacking,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there would have been no coat.  So my second answer to the objector is,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, on the hypothesis of the parallelist, the relations between mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena and physical phenomena are just as dependable as that relation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between physical phenomena which we call that of cause and effect.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, since activity and causality are not the same thing, there is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no ground for asserting that the mind cannot be active, merely because it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not material and, hence, cannot be, strictly speaking, a cause of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motions in matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The plain man is entirely in the right in thinking that minds are active.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The truth is that _nothing can be active except as it has a mind_.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation of purpose and end is the one we have in view when we speak of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the activity of minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, thus, highly unjust to a man to tell him that he is "a physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: automaton with parallel psychical states," and that he is wound up by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: putting food into his mouth.  He who hears this may be excused if he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feels it his duty to emit steam, walk with a jerk, and repudiate all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: responsibility for his actions.  Creatures that think, form plans, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _act_, are not what we call automata.  It is an abuse of language to call
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them such, and it misleads us into looking upon them as we have no right
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to look upon them.  If men really were automata in the proper sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word, we could not look upon them as wise or unwise, good or bad; in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: short, the whole world of moral distinctions would vanish.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Perhaps, in spite of all that has been said in this and in the preceding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section, some will feel a certain repugnance to being assigned a place in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a world as orderly as our world is in this chapter conceived to be--a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world in which every phenomenon, whether physical or mental, has its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: definite place, and all are subject to law.  But I suppose our content or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discontent will not be independent of our conception of what sort of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world we conceive ourselves to be inhabiting.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we conclude that we are in a world in which God is revealed, if the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: orderliness of it is but another name for Divine Providence, we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scarcely feel the same as we would if we discovered in the world nothing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the Divine.  I have in the last few pages been discussing the doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of purposes and ends, teleology, but I have said nothing of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of that doctrine for Theism.  The reader can easily see that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it lies at the very foundation of our belief in God.  The only arguments
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for theism that have had much weight with mankind have been those which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have maintained there are revealed in the world generally evidences of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plan and purpose at least analogous to what we discover when we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scrutinize the actions of our fellow-man.  Such arguments are not at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mercy of either interactionist or parallelist.  On either hypothesis they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stand unshaken.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With this brief survey of some of the most interesting problems that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: confront the philosopher, I must content myself here.  Now let us turn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and see how some of the fundamental problems treated in previous chapters
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have been approached by men belonging to certain well-recognized schools
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And since it is peculiarly true in philosophy that, to understand the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present, one must know something of the past, we shall begin by taking a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: look at the historical background of the types of philosophical doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to which reference is constantly made in the books and journals of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] Ostwald, "Vorlesungen ueber Naturphilosophie," s. 396.  Leipzig, 1902.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: IV. SOME TYPES OF PHILOSOPHICAL THEORY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: THEIR HISTORICAL BACKGROUND
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 48. THE DOCTRINE OF REPRESENTATIVE PERCEPTION.--We have seen in Chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: II that it seems to the plain man abundantly evident that he really is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surrounded by material things and that he directly perceives such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  This has always been the opinion of the plain man and it seems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: probable that it always will be.  It is only when he begins to reflect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon things and upon his knowledge of them that it occurs to him to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call it in question.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Very early in the history of speculative thought it occurred to men,

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any single instance, a material thing?  And the doubt here suggested

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difficulties presented by any philosophical doctrine are not always

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knows immediately only its own ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher (1632-1704), whose classic work, "An Essay concerning Human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as much as I will), if my hand stands still, or though I move my pen,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: if my eyes be shut; nor, when those characters are once made on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: paper, can I choose afterward but see them as they are; that is, have

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the ideas of such letters as I have made.  Whence it is manifest, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are not barely the sport and play of my own imagination, when I

text: thought do not obey them; nor yet cease to be, whenever I shall fancy

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: according to the figures I made them."

text: Locke is as bad as Descartes.  Evidently he regards himself as able to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: instance.

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The type of doctrine represented by Descartes and Locke is that of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Representative Perception_.  It holds that we know real external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 49. THE STEP TO IDEALISM.--The admirable clearness with which Locke
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writes makes it the easier for his reader to detect the untenability of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his position.  He uses simple language, and he never takes refuge in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague and ambiguous phrases.  When he tells us that the mind is wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shut up to its ideas, and then later assumes that it is not shut up to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its ideas, but can perceive external things, we see plainly that there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be a blunder somewhere.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: George Berkeley (1684-1753), Bishop of Cloyne, followed out more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rigorously the consequences to be deduced from the assumption that all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our direct knowledge is of ideas; and in a youthful work of the highest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: genius entitled "The Principles of Human Knowledge," he maintained that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is no material world at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we examine with care the objects of sense, the "things" which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present themselves to us, he argues, we find that they resolve
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves into sensations, or "ideas of sense."  What can we mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "apple," if we do not mean the group of experiences in which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: alone an apple is presented to us?  The word is nothing else than a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name for this group as a group.  Take away the color, the hardness, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: odor, the taste; what have we left?  And color, hardness, odor, taste,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and anything else that may be referred to any object as a quality, can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exist, he claims, only in a perceiving mind; for such things are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing else than sensations, and how can there be an unperceived
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensation?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The things which we perceive, then, he calls complexes of ideas.  Have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we any reason to believe that these ideas, which exist in the mind, are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be accepted as representatives of things of a different kind, which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are not mental at all?  Not a shadow of a reason, says Berkeley; there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is simply no basis for inference at all, and we cannot even make clear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what it is that we are setting out to infer under the name of matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We need not, therefore, grieve over the loss of the material world, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we have suffered no loss; one cannot lose what one has never had.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the objects of human knowledge, the only things of which it means
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything to speak, are: (1) Ideas of Sense; (2) Ideas of Memory and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Imagination; (3) The Passions and Operations of the Mind; and (4) The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Self that perceives all These.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: From Locke's position to that of Berkeley was a bold step, and it was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much criticised, as well it might be.  It was felt then, as it has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: felt by many down to our own time, that, when we discard an external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world distinct from our ideas, and admit only the world revealed in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ideas, we really do lose.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is legitimate to criticise Berkeley, but it is not legitimate to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misunderstand him; and yet the history of his doctrine may almost be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: called a chronicle of misconceptions.  It has been assumed that he drew
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no distinction between real things and imaginary things, that he made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world no better than a dream, etc.  Arbuthnot, Swift, and a host of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the greater and lesser lights in literature, from his time to ours,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have made merry over the supposed unrealities in the midst of which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Berkeleian must live.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it should be remembered that Berkeley tried hard to do full justice
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the world of things in which we actually find ourselves; not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hypothetical, inferred, unperceived world, but the world of the things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we actually perceive.  He distinguished carefully between what is real
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and what is merely imaginary, though he called both "ideas"; and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognized something like a system of nature.  And, by the argument
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from analogy which we have already examined (section 41), he inferred
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the existence of other finite minds and of a Divine Mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But just as John Locke had not completely thought out the consequences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which might be deduced from his own doctrines, so Berkeley left, in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turn, an opening for a successor.  It was possible for that acutest of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analysts, David Hume (1711-1776), to treat him somewhat as he had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treated Locke.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Among the objects of human knowledge Berkeley had included the _self_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that perceives things.  He never succeeded in making at all clear what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he meant by this object; but he regarded it as a substance, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believed it to be a cause of changes in ideas, and quite different in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its nature from all the ideas attributed to it.  But Hume maintained
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that when he tried to get a good look at this self, to catch it, so to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speak, and to hold it up to inspection, he could not find anything
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatever save perceptions, memories, and other things of that kind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The self is, he said, "but a bundle or collection of different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceptions which succeed each other with inconceivable rapidity, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are in a perpetual flux and movement."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As for the objects of sense, our own bodies, the chairs upon which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sit, the tables at which we write, and all the rest--these, argues
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
