title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but we have no evidence whatever to prove that they do thus exist.  Are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not the objects of sense, after all, only sensations or impressions?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Do we not experience these sensations or impressions interruptedly?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Who sees or feels a table continuously day after day?  If the table is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but a name for the experiences in question, if we have no right to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: infer material things behind and distinct from such experiences, are we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not forced to conclude that the existence of the things that we see and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feel is an interrupted one?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hume certainly succeeded in raising more questions than he succeeded in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: answering.  We are compelled to admire the wonderful clearness and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simplicity of his style, and the acuteness of his intellect, in every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter.  But we cannot help feeling that he does injustice to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world in which we live, even when we cannot quite see what is wrong.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Does it not seem certain to science and to common sense that there is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an order of nature in some sense independent of our perceptions, so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that objects may be assumed to exist whether we do or do not perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we read Hume we have a sense that we are robbed of our real

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world; and his account of the mind makes us feel as a badly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tied sheaf of wheat may be conceived to feel--in danger of falling

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apart at any moment.  Berkeley we unhesitatingly call an _Idealist_,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 50. THE REVOLT OF "COMMON SENSE."--Hume's reasonings were too important
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be ignored, and his conclusions too unpalatable to satisfy those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: came after him.  It seemed necessary to seek a way of escape out of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this world of mere ideas, which appeared to be so unsatisfactory a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world.  One of the most famous of such attempts was that made by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Scotchman Thomas Reid (1710-1796).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: At one time Reid regarded himself as the disciple of Berkeley, but the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consequences which Hume deduced from the principles laid down by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: former led Reid to feel that he must build upon some wholly different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foundation.  He came to the conclusion that the line of philosophers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from Descartes to Hume had made one capital error in assuming "that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing is perceived but what is in the mind that perceives it."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Once admit, says Reid, that the mind perceives nothing save ideas, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we must also admit that it is impossible to prove the existence either
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of an external world or of a mind different from "a bundle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceptions."  Hence, Reid maintains that we perceive--not infer, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive--_things_ external to the mind.  He writes:[2]--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Let a man press his hand against the table--_he feels it hard_.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a certain feeling of touch, from which he concludes, without any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasoning, or comparing ideas, that there is something external really
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existing, whose parts stick so firmly together that they cannot be

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: displaced without considerable force.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "There is here a feeling, and a conclusion drawn from it, or some way

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclusion, the feeling is the medium by which we are led to that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclusion.  Let a man attend distinctly to this medium, and to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conclusion, and he will perceive them to be as unlike as any two things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in nature.  The one is a sensation of the mind, which can have no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than it is felt; the other is in the table, and we conclude, without

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any difficulty, that it was in the table before it was felt, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: continues after the feeling is over.  The one implies no kind of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extension, nor parts, nor cohesion; the other implies all these.  Both,

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a species of pain; but adamantine hardness does not imply the least
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from this feeling, rather than softness, or any other quality

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatsoever.  But, in reality, all mankind are led by their constitution
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to conclude hardness from this feeling."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is well worth while to read this extract several times, and to ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: oneself what Reid meant to say, and what he actually said.  He is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: objecting, be it remembered, to the doctrine that the mind perceives
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immediately only its own ideas or sensations and must infer all else.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His contention is that we _perceive_ external things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Does he say this?  He says that we have feelings of touch _from which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we conclude_ that there is something external; that there is a feeling,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "_and a conclusion drawn from it, or some way suggested by it_;" that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "the hardness of the table is the _conclusion_, and the feeling is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _medium_ by which we are _led to the conclusion_."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Could Descartes or Locke have more plainly supported the doctrine of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: representative perception?  How could Reid imagine he was combatting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that doctrine when he wrote thus?  The point in which he differs from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them is this: he maintains that we draw the conclusion in question
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without any reasoning, and, indeed, in the absence of any conceivable
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason why we should draw it.  We do it instinctively; we are led by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the constitution of our nature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In effect Reid says to us: When you lay your hand on the table, you
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have a sensation, it is true, but you also know the table is hard.  How
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do you know it?  I cannot tell you; you simply know it, and cannot help
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowing it; and that is the end of the matter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Reid's doctrine was not without its effect upon other philosophers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Among them we must place Sir William Hamilton (1788-1856), whose
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writings had no little influence upon British philosophy in the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: half of the last century.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hamilton complained that Reid did not succeed in being a very good
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Natural Realist_, and that he slipped unconsciously into the position
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he was concerned to condemn.  Sir William tried to eliminate this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error, but the careful reader of his works will find to his amusement
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that this learned author gets his feet upon the same slippery descent.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And much the same thing may be said of the doctrine of Herbert Spencer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1820-1903), who claims that, when we have a sensation, we know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly that there is an external thing, and then manages to sublimate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that external thing into an Unknowable, which we not only do not know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly, but even do not know at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: All of these men were anxious to avoid what they regarded as the perils
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of Idealism, and yet they seem quite unable to retain a foothold upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the position which they consider the safer one.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Reid called his doctrine the philosophy of "Common Sense," and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought he was coming back from the subtleties of the metaphysicians to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the standpoint of the plain man.  That he should fall into difficulties
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and inconsistencies is by no means surprising.  As we have seen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 12), the thought of the plain man is far from clear.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly believes that we perceive an external world of things, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the inconsistent way in which Descartes and Locke appeal from ideas to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the things themselves does not strike him as unnatural.  Why should not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a man test his ideas by turning to things and comparing the former with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the latter?  On the other hand, he knows that to perceive things we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must have sense organs and sensations, and he cannot quarrel with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologists for saying that we know things only in so far as they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed to us through our sensations.  How does he reconcile these two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: positions?  He does not reconcile them.  He accepts them as they stand.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Reid and various other philosophers have tried to come back to "Common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sense" and to stay there.  Now, it is a good position to come back to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the purpose of starting out again.  The experience of the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man, the truths which he recognizes as truths, these are not things to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be despised.  Many a man whose mind has been, as Berkeley expresses it,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "debauched by learning," has gotten away from them to his detriment,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and has said very unreasonable things.  But "Common Sense" cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the ultimate refuge of the philosopher; it can only serve him as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material for investigation.  The scholar whose thought is as vague and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistent as that of the plain man has little profit in the fact
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the apparatus of his learning has made it possible for him to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ponderously and unintelligibly vague and inconsistent.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hence, we may have the utmost sympathy with Reid's protest against the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of representative perception, and we may, nevertheless,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complain that he has done little to explain how it is that we directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know external things and yet cannot be said to know things except in so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: far as we have sensations or ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 51. THE CRITICAL PHILOSOPHY.--The German philosopher, Immanuel Kant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1724-1804), was moved, by the skeptical conclusions to which Hume's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy seemed to lead, to seek a way of escape, somewhat as Reid
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was.  But he did not take refuge in "Common Sense"; he developed an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ingenious doctrine which has had an enormous influence in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical world, and has given rise to a Kantian literature of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proportions that no man can hope to read all of it, even if he devotes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his life to it.  In Germany and out of it, it has for a hundred years
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and more simply rained books, pamphlets, and articles on Kant and his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy, some of them good, many of them far from clear and far from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: original.  Hundreds of German university students have taken Kant as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the subject of the dissertation by which they hoped to win the degree
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of Doctor of Philosophy;--I was lately offered two hundred and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seventy-four such dissertations in one bunch;--and no student is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed to have even a moderate knowledge of philosophy who has not an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acquaintance with that famous work, the "Critique of Pure Reason."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is to be expected from the outset that, where so many have found so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much to say, there should reign abundant differences of opinion.  There
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are differences of opinion touching the interpretation of Kant, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touching the criticisms which may be made upon, and the development
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which should be given to, his doctrine.  It is, of course, impossible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to go into all these things here; and I shall do no more than indicate,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in untechnical language and in briefest outline, what he offers us in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place of the philosophy of Hume.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant did not try to refute, as did Reid, the doctrine, urged by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes and by his successors, that all those things which the mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly perceives are to be regarded as complexes of ideas.  On the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrary, he accepted it, and he has made the words "phenomenon" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "noumenon" household words in philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The world which seems to be spread out before us in space and time is,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he tells us, a world of things _as they are revealed to our senses and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our intelligence_; it is a world of manifestations, of phenomena.  What
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things-in-themselves are like we have no means of knowing; we know only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things as they appear to us.  We may, to be sure, talk of a something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinct from phenomena, a something not revealed to the senses, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought of, a _noumenon_; but we should not forget that this is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: negative conception; there is nothing in our experience that can give
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it a filling, for our experience is only of phenomena.  The reader will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: find an unmistakable echo of this doctrine in Herbert Spencer's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of the "Unknowable" and its "manifestations."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, Berkeley had called all the things we immediately perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _ideas_.  As we have seen, he distinguished between "ideas of sense"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and "ideas of memory and imagination."  Hume preferred to give to these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two classes different names--he called the first _impressions_ and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: second _ideas_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The associations of the word "impression" are not to be mistaken.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke had taught that between ideas in the memory and genuine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations there is the difference that the latter are due to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "brisk acting" of objects without us.  Objects impress us, and we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations or impressions.  To be sure, Hume, after employing the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "impression," goes on to argue that we have no evidence that there are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external objects, which cause impressions.  But he retains the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "impression," nevertheless, and his use of it perceptibly colors his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In Kant's distinction between phenomena and noumena we have the lineal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: descendant of the old distinction between the circle of our ideas and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the something outside of them that causes them and of which they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposed to give information.  Hume said we have no reason to believe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such a thing exists, but are impelled by our nature to believe in it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant is not so much concerned to prove the nonexistence of noumena,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things-in-themselves, as he is to prove that the very conception is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: empty one.  His reasonings seem to result in the conclusion that we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make no intelligible statement about things so cut off from our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience as noumena are supposed to be; and one would imagine that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would have felt impelled to go on to the frank declaration that we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no reason to believe in noumena at all, and had better throw away
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: altogether so meaningless and useless a notion.  But he was a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conservative creature, and he did not go quite so far.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So far there is little choice between Kant and Hume.  Certainly the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: former does not appear to have rehabilitated the external world which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: had suffered from the assaults of his predecessors.  What important
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difference is there between his doctrine and that of the man whose
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: skeptical tendencies he wished to combat?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difference is this: Descartes and Locke had accounted for our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of things by maintaining that things act upon us, and make an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impression or sensation--that their action, so to speak, begets ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is a very ancient doctrine as well as a very modern one; it is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine that most men find reasonable even before they devote
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves to the study of philosophy.  The totality of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impressions received from the external world, they are accustomed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regard as our _experience_ of external things; and they are inclined to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think that any knowledge of external things not founded upon experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can hardly deserve the name of knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, Hume, when he cast doubt upon the existence of external things,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: did not, as I have said above, divest himself of the suggestions of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word "impression."  He insists strenuously that all our knowledge is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: founded upon experience; and he holds that no experience can give us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge that is necessary and universal.  We know things as they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed to us in our experience; but who can guarantee that we may not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have new experiences of a quite different kind, and which flatly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contradict the notions which we have so far attained of what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible and impossible, true and untrue.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is here that Kant takes issue with Hume.  A survey of our knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: makes clear, he thinks, that we are in the possession of a great deal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of information that is not of the unsatisfactory kind that, according
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to Hume, all our knowledge of things must be.  There, for example, are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all the truths of mathematics.  When we enunciate a truth regarding the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relations of the lines and angles of a triangle, we are not merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unfolding in the predicate of our proposition what was implicitly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contained in the subject.  There are propositions that do no more than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this; they are _analytical_, _i.e._ they merely analyze the subject.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, when we say: Man is a rational animal, we may merely be defining
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "man"--unpacking it, so to speak.  But a _synthetic_ judgment
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is one in which the predicate is not contained in the subject; it adds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to one's information.  The mathematical truths are of this character.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So also is the truth that everything that happens must have a cause.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Do we connect things with one another in this way merely because we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have had _experience_ that they are thus connected?  Is it because they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are _given_ to us connected in this way?  That cannot be the case, Kant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: argues, for what is taken up as mere experienced act cannot be known as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universally and necessarily true.  We perceive that these things _must_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be so connected.  How shall we explain this necessity?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We can only explain it, said Kant, in this way: We must assume that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is given us from without is merely the raw material of sensation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the _matter_ of our experience; and that the ordering of this matter,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the arranging it into a world of phenomena, the furnishing of _form_,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the work of the mind.  Thus, we must think of space, time,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: causality, and of all other relations which obtain between the elements
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our experience, as due to the nature of the mind.  It perceives the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world of phenomena that it does, because it _constructs_ that world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Its knowledge of things is stable and dependable because it cannot know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any phenomenon which does not conform to its laws.  The water poured
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into a cup must take the shape of the cup; and the raw materials poured
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into a mind must take the form of an orderly world, spread out in space
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and time.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant thought that with this turn he had placed human knowledge upon a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfactory basis, and had, at the same time, indicated the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: limitations of human knowledge.  If the world we perceive is a world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we make; if the forms of thought furnished by the mind have no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other function than the ordering of the materials furnished by sense;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: then what can we say of that which may be beyond phenomena?  What of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _noumena_?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems clear that, on Kant's principles, we ought not to be able to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say anything whatever of _noumena_.  To say that such may exist appears
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: absurd.  All conceivable connection between them and existing things as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we know them is cut off.  We cannot think of a noumenon as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _substance_, for the notions of substance and quality have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: declared to be only a scheme for the ordering of phenomena.  Nor can we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of one as a cause of the sensations that we unite into a world,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for just the same reason.  We are shut up logically to the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena, and that world of phenomena is, after all, the successor of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world of ideas advocated by Berkeley.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is not the place to discuss at length the value of Kant's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contribution to philosophy.[3]  There is something terrifying in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prodigious length at which it seems possible for men to discuss it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant called his doctrine "Criticism," because it undertook to establish
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the nature and limits of our knowledge.  By some he has been hailed as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a great enlightener, and by others he has been accused of being as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dogmatic in his assumptions as those whom he disapproved.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But one thing he certainly has accomplished.  He has made the words
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "phenomena" and "noumena" familiar to us all, and he has induced a vast
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number of men to accept it as established fact that it is not worth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: while to try to extend our knowledge beyond phenomena.  One sees his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence in the writings of men who differ most widely from one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: [2] "An Inquiry into the Human Mind," Chapter V, section 5.

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

title: An Introduction to Philosophy
