text: REALISM AND IDEALISM
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 52. REALISM.--The plain man is a realist.  That is to say, he believes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a world which is not to be identified with his own ideas or those of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any other mind.  At the same time, as we have seen (section 12), the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between the mind and the world is by no means clear to him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not difficult, by judicious questioning, to set his feet upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: slippery descent that shoots a man into idealism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The vague realism of the plain man may be called _Naive_ or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Unreflective Realism_.  It has been called by some _Natural Realism_,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but the latter term is an unfortunate one.  It is, of course, natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the unreflective man to be unreflective, but, on the other hand, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is also natural for the reflective man to be reflective.  Besides, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dubbing any doctrine "natural," we are apt to assume that doctrines
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasted with it may properly be called "unnatural" or "artificial."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is an ancient rhetorical device, to obtain sympathy for a cause in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which one may happen to be interested by giving it a taking name; but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is a device frowned upon by logic and by good sense.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One kind of realism is, then, naive realism.  It is the position from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we all set out, when we begin to reflect upon the system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  It is the position to which some try to come back, when their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflections appear to be leading them into strange or unwelcome paths.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen how Thomas Reid (section 50) recoiled from the conclusions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to which the reasonings of the philosophers had brought him, and tried
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to return to the position of the plain man.  The attempt was a failure,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and was necessarily a failure, for Reid tried to come back to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position of the plain man _and still be a philosopher_.  He tried to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: live in a cloud and, nevertheless, to see clearly--a task not easy to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accomplish.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It should be remarked, however, that he tried, at least, to insist that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we know the external world _directly_.  We may divide realists into two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: broad classes, those who hold to this view, and those who maintain that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we know it only indirectly and through our ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The plain man belongs, of course, to the first class, if it is just to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speak of a man who says inconsistent things as being wholly in any one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class.  Certainly he is willing to assert that the ground upon which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stands and the staff in his hand are perceived by him directly.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we are compelled to recognize that there are subdivisions in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first class of realists.  Reid tried to place himself beside the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man and failed to do so.  Hamilton (section 50) tried also, and he is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not to be classed precisely either with the plain man or with Reid.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: informs us that the object as it appears to us is a composite something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the building up of which the knowing mind contributes its share, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: medium through which the object is perceived its share, and the object
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in itself its share.  He suggests, by way of illustration, that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external object may contribute one third.  This seems to make, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: least, _something_ external directly known.  But, on the other hand, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintains that the mind knows immediately only what is in immediate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contact with the bodily organ--with the eyes, with the hands, etc.; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he believes it knows this immediately because it is actually present in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all parts of the body.  And, further, in distinguishing as he does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between existence "as it is in itself" and existence "as it is revealed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to us," and in shutting us up to the latter, he seems to rob us even of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the modicum of externality that he has granted us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have already mentioned Herbert Spencer (section 50) as a man not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without sympathy for the attempt to rehabilitate the external world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He is very severe with the "insanities" of idealism.  He is not willing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even to take the first step toward it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He writes:[1] "The postulate with which metaphysical reasoning sets out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is that we are primarily conscious only of our sensations--that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly know we have these, and that if there be anything beyond
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these serving as cause for them, it can be known only by inference from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "I shall give much surprise to the metaphysical reader if I call in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question this postulate; and the surprise will rise into astonishment
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if I distinctly deny it.  Yet I must do this.  Limiting the proposition
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to those epiperipheral feelings produced in us by external objects (for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these are alone in question), I see no alternative but to affirm that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the thing primarily known is not that a sensation has been experienced,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but that there exists an outer object."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: According to this, the outer object is not known through an inference;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is known directly.  But do not be in haste to class Spencer with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man, or with Reid.  Listen to a citation once before made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 22), but worth repeating in this connection: "When we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taught that a piece of matter, regarded by us as existing externally,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be really known, but that we can know only certain impressions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: produced on us, we are yet, by the relativity of thought, compelled to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of these in relation to a cause--the notion of a real existence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which generated these impressions becomes nascent.  If it be proved
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that every notion of a real existence which we can frame is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistent with itself,--that matter, however conceived by us, cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be matter as it actually is,--our conception, though transfigured, is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not destroyed: there remains the sense of reality, dissociated as far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as possible from those special forms under which it was before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represented in thought."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is interesting to place the two extracts side by side.  In the one,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are told that we do not know external objects by an inference from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our sensations; in the other we are taught that the piece of matter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we regard as existing externally cannot be really known; that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can know only certain impressions produced on us, and must refer them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to a cause; that this cause cannot be what we think it.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficult for the man who reads such statements not to forget that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Spencer regarded himself as a realist who held to a direct knowledge of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something external.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are, as it is evident, many sorts of realists that may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gathered into the first class mentioned above--men who, however
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconsistent they may be, try, at least, to maintain that our knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the external world is a direct one.  And it is equally true that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there are various sorts of realists that may be put into the second
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These men have been called _Hypothetical Realists_.  In the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter it was pointed out that Descartes and Locke belong to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class.  Both of these men believed in an external world, but believed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that its existence is a thing to be inferred.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, when a man has persuaded himself that the mind can know directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only its own ideas, and must infer the world which they are supposed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: represent, he may conceive of that external world in three different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ways.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) He may believe that what corresponds to his idea of a material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: object, for example, an apple, is in very many respects like the idea
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in his mind.  Thus, he may believe that the odor, taste, color,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hardness, etc., that he perceives directly, or as ideas, have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: corresponding to them real external odor, taste, color, hardness, etc.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not easy for a man to hold to this position, for a very little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection seems to make it untenable; but it is theoretically possible
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for one to take it, and probably many persons have inclined to the view
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when they have first been tempted to believe that the mind perceives
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly only its ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) He may believe that such things as colors, tastes, and odors cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be qualities of external bodies at all, but are only effects, produced
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon our minds by something very different in kind.  We seem to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive bodies, he may argue, to be colored, to have taste, and to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: odorous; but what we thus perceive is not the external thing; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external thing that produces these appearances cannot be regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: having anything more than "solidity, extension, figure, motion or rest,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and number."  Thus did Locke reason.  To him the external world as it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: really exists, is, so to speak, a paler copy of the external world as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we seem to perceive it.  It is a world with fewer qualities, but,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: still, a world with qualities of some kind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) But one may go farther than this.  One may say: How can I know that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: even the extension, number, and motion of the things which I directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive have corresponding to them extension, number, and motion, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an outer world?  If what is not colored can cause me to perceive color,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: why may not that which is not extended cause me to perceive extension?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And, moved by such reflections, one may maintain that there exists
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outside of us that which we can only characterize as an Unknown Cause,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a Reality which we cannot more nearly define.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This last position resembles very closely one side of Spencer's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine--that represented in the last of the two citations, as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reader can easily see.  It is the position of the follower of Immanuel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant who has not yet repudiated the noumenon or thing-in-itself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussed in the last chapter (section 51).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I am not concerned to defend any one of the varieties of Direct or of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hypothetical Realism portrayed above.  But I wish to point out that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they all have some sort of claim to the title _Realism_, and to remind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reader that, when we call a man a realist, we do not do very much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the way of defining his position.  I may add that the account of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world contained in Chapter IV is a sort of realism also.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If this last variety, which I advocate, _must_ be classified, let it be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: placed in the first broad class, for it teaches that we know the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world directly.  But I sincerely hope that it will not be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: judged wholly by the company it keeps, and that no one will assign to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it either virtues or defects to which it can lay no just claim.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Before leaving the subject of realism it is right that I should utter a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: note of warning touching one very common source of error.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fatally easy for men to be misled by the names which are applied to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  Sir William Hamilton invented for a certain type of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysical doctrine the offensive epithet "nihilism."  It is a type
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which appeals to many inoffensive and pious men at the present day,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some of whom prefer to call themselves idealists.  Many have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: induced to become "free-willists" because the name has suggested to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them a proper regard for that freedom which is justly dear to all men.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We can scarcely approach with an open mind an account of ideas and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sensations which we hear described as "sensationalism," or worse yet,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as "sensualism."  When a given type of philosophy is set down as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "dogmatism," we involuntarily feel a prejudice against it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who reads as reflectively as he should will soon find out that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers "call names" much as other men do, and that one should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: always be on one's guard.  "Every form of phenomenalism," asseverated a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: learned and energetic old gentleman, who for many years occupied a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chair in one of our leading institutions of learning, "necessarily
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: leads to atheism."  He inspired a considerable number of students with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such a horror for "phenomenalism" that they never took pains to find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: out what it was.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I mention these things in this connection, because I suspect that not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: few in our own day are unduly influenced by the associations which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cling to the words "realism" and "idealism."  Realism in literature, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many persons understand it, means the degradation of literature to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: portrayal of what is coarse and degrading, in a coarse and offensive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: way.  Realism in painting often means the laborious representation upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: canvas of things from which we would gladly avert our eyes if we met
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them in real life.  With the word "idealism," on the other hand, we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apt to connect the possession of ideals, a regard for what is best and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: noblest in life and literature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The reader must have seen that realism in the philosophic sense of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word has nothing whatever to do with realism in the senses just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mentioned.  The word is given a special meaning, and it is a weakness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to allow associations drawn from other senses of the word to color our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: judgment when we use it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And it should be carefully held in view that the word "idealism" is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given a special sense when it is used to indicate a type of doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasted with the doctrine of the realist.  Some forms of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical idealism have undoubtedly been inspiring; but some have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been, and are, far from inspiring.  They should not be allowed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: posture as saints merely because they are cloaked with an ambiguous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 53. IDEALISM.--Idealism we may broadly define as the doctrine that all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence is mental existence.  So far from regarding the external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world as beyond and independent of mind, it maintains that it can have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its being only in consciousness.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen (section 49) how men were led to take the step to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealism.  It is not a step which the plain man is impelled to take
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without preparation.  To say that the real world of things in which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perceive ourselves to live and move is a something that exists only in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mind strikes him as little better than insane.  He who becomes an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealist usually does so, I think, after weighing the arguments
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented by the hypothetical realist, and finding that they seem to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carry one farther than the latter appears to recognize.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The type of idealism represented by Berkeley has been called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Subjective Idealism_.  Ordinarily our use of the words "subjective"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and "objective" is to call attention to the distinction between what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: belongs to the mind and what belongs to the external order of things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: My sensations are subjective, they are referred to my mind, and it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumed that they can have no existence except in my mind; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: qualities of things are regarded as objective, that is, it is commonly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believed that they exist independently of my perception of them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Of course, when a man becomes an idealist, he cannot keep just this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction.  The question may, then, fairly be raised: How can he be a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _subjective idealist_?  Has not the word "subjective" lost its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this one has to answer: It has, and it has not.  The man who, with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: strict consistency, makes the desk at which he sits as much his "idea"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as is the pain in his finger or his memory of yesterday, cannot keep
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold of the distinction of subjective and objective.  But men are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: always as consistent as this.  Remember the illustration of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "telephone exchange" (section 14).  The mind is represented as situated
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at the brain terminals of the sensory nerves; and then brain, nerves,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and all else are turned into ideas in this mind, which are merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "projected outwards."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, in placing the mind at a definite location in the world, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasting it with the world, we retain the distinction between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subjective and objective--what is in the mind can be distinguished from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is beyond it.  On the other hand, in making the whole system of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external things a complex of ideas in the mind, we become idealists,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and repudiate realism.  The position is an inconsistent one, of course,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but it is possible for men to take it, for men have taken it often
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enough.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The idealism of Professor Pearson (section 14) is more palpably
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subjective than that of Berkeley, for the latter never puts the mind in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a "telephone exchange."  Nevertheless, he names the objects of sense,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which other men call material things, "ideas," and he evidently
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assimilates them to what we commonly call ideas and contrast with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  Moreover, he holds them in some of the contempt which men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reserve for "mere ideas," for he believes that idolaters might be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: induced to give over worshiping the heavenly bodies could they be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persuaded that these are nothing more than their own ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With the various forms of subjective idealism it is usual to contrast
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the doctrine of _Objective Idealism_.  This does not maintain that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world which I perceive is my "idea"; it maintains that the world is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "idea."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is rather a nice question, and one which no man should decide
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without a careful examination of the whole matter, whether we have any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to retain the word "idea" when we have rubbed out the distinction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is usually drawn between ideas and external things.  If we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintain that all men are always necessarily selfish, we stretch the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaning of the word quite beyond what is customary, and selfishness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becomes a thing we have no reason to disapprove, since it characterizes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: saint and sinner alike.  Similarly, if we decide to name "idea," not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only what the plain man and the realist admit to have a right to that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name, but also the great system which these men call an external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material world, it seems right to ask; Why use the word "idea" at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What does it serve to indicate?  Not a distinction, surely, for the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: word seems to be applicable to all things without distinction.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such considerations as these lead me to object to the expression
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "objective idealism": if the doctrine is really _objective_, _i.e._ if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it recognizes a system of things different and distinct from what men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: commonly call ideas, it scarcely seems to have a right to the title
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _idealism_; and if it is really _idealism_, and does not rob the word
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idea of all significance, it can scarcely be _objective_ in any proper
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense of the word.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Manifestly, there is need of a very careful analysis of the meaning of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word "idea," and of the proper significance of the terms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "subjective" and "objective," if error is to be avoided and language
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: used soberly and accurately.  Those who are not in sympathy with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of the objective idealists think that in such careful analysis
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and accurate statement they are rather conspicuously lacking.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We think of Hegel (1770-1831) as the typical objective idealist.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not easy to give an accurate account of his doctrine, for he is far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from a clear writer, and he has made it possible for his many admirers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to understand him in many ways.  But he seems to have accepted the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of things that most men call the real external world, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have regarded it as the Divine Reason in its self-development.  And
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: most of those whom we would to-day be inclined to gather together under
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the title of objective idealists appear to have been much influenced,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly or indirectly, by his philosophy.  There are, however, great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: differences of opinion among them, and no man should be made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: responsible for the opinions of the class as a class.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have said a few pages back that some forms of idealism are inspiring,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that some are not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bishop Berkeley called the objects of sense ideas.  He regarded all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ideas as inactive, and thought that all changes in ideas--and this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: includes all the changes that take place in nature--must be referred to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the activity of minds.  Some of those changes he could refer to finite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds, his own and others.  Most of them he could not, and he felt
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impelled to refer them to a Divine Mind.  Hence, the world became to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him a constant revelation of God; and he uses the word "God" in no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: equivocal sense.  It does not signify to him the system of things as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole, or an Unknowable, or anything of the sort.  It signifies a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spirit akin to his own, but without its limitations.  He writes:[2]--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "A human spirit or person is not perceived by sense, as not being an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idea; when, therefore, we see the color, size, figure, and motions of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man, we perceive only certain sensations or ideas excited in our own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds; and these being exhibited to our view in sundry distinct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: collections serve to mark out unto us the existence of finite and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: created spirits like ourselves.  Hence, it is plain we do not see a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man,--if by _man_ is meant that which lives, moves, perceives, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinks as we do,--but only such a certain collection of ideas as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directs us to think there is a distinct principle of thought and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motion, like to ourselves, accompanying and represented by it.  And
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: after the same manner we see God; all the difference is that, whereas
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some one finite and narrow assemblage of ideas denotes a particular
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human mind, whithersoever we direct our view, we do at all times and in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all places perceive manifest tokens of the Divinity--everything we see,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hear, feel, or any wise perceive by sense, being a sign or effect of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the power of God; as is our perception of those very motions which are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: produced by men."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With Berkeley's view of the world as a constant revelation of God, many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men will sympathize who have little liking for his idealism as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealism.  They may criticise in detail his arguments to prove the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nonexistence of a genuinely external world, but they will be ready to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit that his doctrine is an inspiring one in the view that it takes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the world and of man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With this I wish to contrast the doctrine of another idealist, Mr.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bradley, whose work, "Appearance and Reality," has been much discussed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the last few years, in order that the reader may see how widely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different forms of idealism may differ from each other, and how absurd
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is to praise or blame a man's philosophy merely on the ground that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is idealistic.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Mr. Bradley holds that those aspects of our experience which we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accustomed to regard as real--qualities of things, the relations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between things, the things themselves, space, time, motion, causation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: activity, the self--turn out when carefully examined to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: self-contradictory and absurd.  They are not real; they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unrealities, mere appearances.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But these appearances exist, and, hence, must belong to reality.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reality must be sentient, for "there is no being or fact outside of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that which is commonly called psychical existence."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, what is this reality with which appearances--the whole world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things which seem to be given in our experience--are contrasted?  Mr.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bradley calls it the Absolute, and indicates that it is what other men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize as the Deity.  How shall we conceive it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We are told that we are to conceive it as consisting of the contents of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finite minds, or "centers of experience," subjected to "an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all-pervasive transfusion with a reblending of all material."  In the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Absolute, finite things are "transmuted" and lose "their individual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natures."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What does this mean in plain language?  It means that there are many
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finite minds of a higher and of a lower order, "centers of experience,"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that the contents of these are unreal appearances.  There is not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: God or Absolute outside of and distinct from these, but rather one that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in some sense _is their reality_.  This mass of unrealities transfused
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and transmuted so that no one of them retains its individual nature is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Absolute.  That is to say, time must become indistinguishable from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space, space from motion, motion from the self, the self from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: qualities of things, etc., before they are fit to become constituents
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the Absolute and to be regarded as real.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As the reader has seen, this Absolute has nothing in common with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: God in which Berkeley believed, and in which the plain man usually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: believes.  It is the night in which all cats are gray, and there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears to be no reason why any one should harbor toward it the least
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sentiment of awe or veneration.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Whether such reasonings as Mr. Bradley's should be accepted as valid or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should not, must be decided after a careful examination into the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foundations upon which they rest and the consistency with which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inferences are drawn from premises.  I do not wish to prejudge the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter.  But it is worth while to set forth the conclusions at which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arrives, that it may be clearly realized that the associations which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: often hang about the word "idealism" should be carefully stripped away
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we are forming our estimate of this or that philosophical doctrine.
