text: CHAPTER XIV
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: MONISM AND DUALISM
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 54. THE MEANING OF THE WORDS.--In common life men distinguish between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds and material things, thus dividing the things, which taken
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: together make up the world as we know it, into two broad classes.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: think of minds as being very different from material objects, and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the latter as being very different from minds.  It does not occur to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them to find in the one class room for the other, nor does it occur to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them to think of both classes as "manifestations" or "aspects" of some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one "underlying reality."  In other words, the plain man to-day is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Dualist_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the last chapter (section 52) I have called him a Naive Realist; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: here I shall call him a _Naive Dualist_, for a man may regard mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter as quite distinct kinds of things, without trying to elevate his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinion, through reflection, into a philosophical doctrine.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflective man may stand by the opinion of the plain man, merely trying
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to make less vague and indefinite the notions of matter and of mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He then becomes a _Philosophical Dualist_.  There are several varieties
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of this doctrine, and I shall consider them a little later (section 58).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is possible for one to be less profoundly impressed by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: differences which characterize matter and mind.  One may feel inclined
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to refer mental phenomena to matter, and to deny them the prominence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accorded them by the dualist.  On the other hand, one may be led by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one's reflections to resolve material objects into mere ideas, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: claim that they can have no existence except in a mind.  Finally, it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible to hold that both minds and material things, as we know them,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are only manifestations, phenomena, and that they must be referred to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an ulterior "reality" or "substance."  One may claim that they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "aspects" of the one reality, which is neither matter nor mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These doctrines are different forms of _Monism_.  In whatever else they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: differ from one another, they agree in maintaining that the universe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not contain two kinds of things fundamentally different.  Out of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the duality of things as it seems to be revealed to the plain man they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: try to make some kind of a unity.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 35. MATERIALISM.--The first of the forms of monism above mentioned is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _Materialism_.  It is not a doctrine to which the first impulse of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man leads him at the present time.  Even those who have done no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reading in philosophy have inherited many of their ways of looking at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things from the thinkers who lived in the ages past, and whose opinions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have become the common property of civilized men.  For more than two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thousand years the world and the mind have been discussed, and it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impossible for any of us to escape from the influence of those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussions and to look at things with the primitive simplicity of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholly untutored.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it was not always so.  There was a time when men who were not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: savages, but possessed great intellectual vigor and much cultivation,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: found it easy and natural to be materialists.  This I have spoken of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before (section 30), but it will repay us to take up again a little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more at length the clearest of the ancient forms of materialism, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the Atomists, and to see what may be said for and against it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Democritus of Abdera taught that nothing exists except atoms and empty
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: space.  The atoms, he maintained, differ from one another in size,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shape, and position.  In other respects they are alike.  They have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: always been in motion.  Perhaps he conceived of that motion as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: originally a fall through space, but there seems to be uncertainty upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this point.  However, the atoms in motion collide with one another, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these collisions result in mechanical combinations from which spring
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into being world-systems.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: According to this doctrine, nothing comes from nothing, and nothing can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: become nonexistent.  All the changes which have ever taken place in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world are only changes in the position of material particles--they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regroupings of atoms.  We cannot directly perceive them to be such, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our senses are too dull to make such fine observations, but our reason
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tells us that such is the case.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Where, in such a world as this, is there room for mind, and what can we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mean by mind?  Democritus finds a place for mind by conceiving it to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consist of fine, smooth, round atoms, which are the same as the atoms
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which constitute fire.  These are distributed through the whole body,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and lie among the other atoms which compose it.  They are inhaled with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and exhaled into the outer air.  While they are in the body their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: functions are different according as they are located in this organ or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in that.  In the brain they give rise to thought, in the heart to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anger, and in the liver to desire.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I suppose no one would care, at the present time, to become a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Democritean.  The "Reason," which tells us that the mind consists of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fine, round atoms, appears to have nothing but its bare word to offer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us.  But, apart from this, a peculiar difficulty seems to face us; even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposing there are atoms of fire in the brain, the heart, and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: liver, what are the _thought_, _anger_, and _desire_, of which mention
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is made?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Shall we conceive of these last as atoms, as void space, or as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motion of atoms?  There really seems to be no place in the world for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them, and _these are the mind so far as the mind appears to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed_--they are _mental phenomena_.  It does not seem that they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be identified with anything that the Atomistic doctrine admits as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existing.  They are simply overlooked.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is the modern materialism more satisfactory?  About half a century ago
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there was in the scientific world something like a revival of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: materialistic thinking.  It did not occur to any one to maintain that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the mind consists of fine atoms disseminated through the body, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements almost as crude were made.  It was said, for example, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the brain secretes thought as the liver secretes bile.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems a gratuitous labor to criticise such statements as these in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: detail.  There are no glands the secretions of which are not as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unequivocally material as are the glands themselves.  This means that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such secretions can be captured and analyzed; the chemical elements of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they are composed can be enumerated.  They are open to inspection
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in precisely the same way as are the glands which secrete them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Does it seem reasonable to maintain that thoughts and feelings are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related to brains in this way?  Does the chemist ever dream of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: collecting them in a test tube, and of drawing up for us a list of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their constituent elements?  When the brain is active, there are, to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sure, certain material products which pass into the blood and are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finally eliminated from the body; but among these products no one would
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be more surprised than the materialist to discover pains and pleasures,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: memories and anticipations, desires and volitions.  This talk of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought as a "secretion" we can afford to set aside.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor need we take much more seriously the seemingly more sober statement
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that thought is a "function" of the brain.  There is, of course, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense in which we all admit the statement; minds are not disembodied,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and we have reason to believe that mind and brain are most intimately
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related.  But the word "function" is used in a very broad and loose
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense when it serves to indicate this relation; and one may employ it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in this way without being a materialist at all.  In a stricter sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word, the brain has no functions that may not be conceived as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mechanical changes,--as the motion of atoms in space,--and to identify
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena with these is inexcusable.  It is not theoretically
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inconceivable that, with finer senses, we might directly perceive the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: motions of the atoms in another man's brain; it is inconceivable that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we should thus directly perceive his melancholy or his joy; they belong
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to another world.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 56. SPIRITUALISM.--The name _Spiritualism_ is sometimes given to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine that there is no existence which we may not properly call mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or spirit.  It errs in the one direction as materialism errs in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One must not confound with this doctrine that very different one,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Spiritism, which teaches that a certain favored class of persons called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mediums may bring back the spirits of the departed and enable us to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold communication with them.  Such beliefs have always existed among
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the common people, but they have rarely interested philosophers.  I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall have nothing to say of them in this book.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There have been various kinds of spiritualists.  The name may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: applied to the idealists, from Berkeley down to those of our day; at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some of the varieties of their doctrine we have taken a glance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (sections 49, 53).  To these we need not recur; but there is one type
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of spiritualistic doctrine which is much discussed at the present day
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and which appears to appeal strongly to a number of scientific men.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must consider it for a moment.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have examined Professor Clifford's doctrine of Mind-stuff (section
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 43).  Clifford maintained that all the material things we perceive are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our perceptions--they are in our consciousness, and are not properly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external at all.  But, believing, as he did, that all nature is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: animated, he held that every material thing, every perception, may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: taken as a revelation of something not in our consciousness, of a mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or, at least, of a certain amount of mind-stuff.  How shall we conceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relation between what is in our mind and the something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: corresponding to it not in our mind?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must, says Clifford, regard the latter as the _reality_ of which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: former is the _appearance_ or _manifestation_.  "What I perceive as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: your brain is really in itself your consciousness, is You; but then
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that which I call your brain, the material fact, is merely my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perception."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This doctrine is _Panpsychism_, in the form in which it is usually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brought to our attention.  It holds that the only real existences are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds, and that physical phenomena must be regarded as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: manifestations under which these real existences make us aware of their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presence.  The term panpsychism may, it is true, be used in a somewhat
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different sense.  It may be employed merely to indicate the doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that all nature is animated, and without implying a theory as to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation between bodies perceived and the minds supposed to accompany
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What shall we say to panpsychism of the type represented by Clifford?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, I think, sufficiently answered in the earlier chapters of this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: volume:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) If I call material facts my perceptions, I do an injustice to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between the physical and the mental (Chapter IV).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) If I say that all nature is animated, I extend illegitimately the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: argument for other minds (Chapter X).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (3) If I say that mind is the reality of which the brain is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearance, I misconceive what is meant by the distinction between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearance and reality (Chapter V).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 57. THE DOCTRINE OF THE ONE SUBSTANCE.--In the seventeenth century
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes maintained that, although mind and matter may justly be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as two substances, yet it should be recognized that they are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not really independent substances in the strictest sense of the word,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but that there is only one substance, in this sense, and mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter are, as it were, its attributes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His thought was that by attribute we mean that which is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent, but must be referred to something else; by substance, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mean that which exists independently and is not referred to any other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing.  It seemed to follow that there could be only one substance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Spinoza modified Descartes' doctrine in that he refused to regard mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and matter as substances at all.  He made them unequivocally attributes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the one and only substance, which he called God.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The thought which influenced Spinoza had impressed many minds before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his time, and it has influenced many since.  One need not follow him in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: naming the unitary something to which mind and matter are referred
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substance.  One may call it Being, or Reality, or the Unknowable, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Energy, or the Absolute, or, perhaps, still something else.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine has taken many forms, but he who reads with discrimination
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will see that the various forms have much in common.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They agree in maintaining that matter and mind, as they are revealed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our experience, are not to be regarded as, in the last analysis, two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinct kinds of thing.  They are, rather, modes or manifestations of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one and the same thing, and this is not to be confounded with either.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who incline to this doctrine take issue with the materialist, who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assimilates mental phenomena to physical; and they oppose the idealist,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who assimilates physical phenomena to mental, and calls material things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "ideas."  We have no right, they argue, to call that of which ideas and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things are manifestations either mind or matter.  It is to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguished from both.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this doctrine the title of _Monism_ is often appropriated.  In this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter I have used the term in a broader sense, for both the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: materialist and the spiritualist maintain that there is in the universe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but one kind of thing.  Nevertheless, when we hear a man called a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: monist without qualification, we may, perhaps, be justified in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assuming, in the absence of further information, that he holds to some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one of the forms of doctrine indicated above.  There may be no logical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justification for thus narrowing the use of the term, but logical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justification goes for little in such matters.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Various considerations have moved men to become monists in this sense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the word.  Some have been influenced by the assumption--one which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men felt impelled to make early in the history of speculative
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought--that the whole universe must be the expression of some unitary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: principle.  A rather different argument is well illustrated in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writings of Professor Hoeffding, a learned and acute writer of our own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time.  It has influenced so many that it is worth while to delay upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Professor Hoeffding holds that mental phenomena and physical phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be regarded as parallel (see Chapter IX), and that we must not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive of ideas and material things as interacting.  He writes:[1]--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "If it is contrary to the doctrine of the persistence of physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: energy to suppose a transition from the one province to the other, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if, nevertheless, the two provinces exist in our experience as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinct, then the two sets of phenomena must be unfolded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simultaneously, each according to its laws, so that for every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomenon in the world of consciousness there is a corresponding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomenon in the world of matter, and conversely (so far as there is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason to suppose that conscious life is correlated with material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena).  The parallels already drawn point directly to such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation; it would be an amazing accident, if, while the characteristic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: marks repeated themselves in this way, there were not at the foundation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an inner connection.  Both the _parallelism_ and the _proportionality_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between the activity of consciousness and cerebral activity point to an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _identity_ at bottom.  The difference which remains in spite of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: points of agreement compels us to suppose that one and the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: principle has found its expression in a double form.  We have no right
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to take mind and body for two beings or substances in reciprocal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interaction.  We are, on the contrary, impelled to conceive the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material interaction between the elements composing the brain and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nervous system _as an outer form of the inner ideal unity of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consciousness_.  What we in our inner experience become conscious of as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought, feeling, and resolution, is thus represented in the material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world by certain material processes of the brain, which as such are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subject to the law of the persistence of energy, although this law
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot be applied to the relation between cerebral and conscious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: processes.  It is as though the same thing were said in two languages."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Some monists are in the habit of speaking of the one Being to which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they refer phenomena of all sorts as the "Absolute."  The word is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague one, and means very different things in different philosophies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It has been somewhat broadly defined as "the ultimate principle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: explanation of the universe."  He who turns to one principle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: explanation will conceive the Absolute in one way, and he who turns to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another will, naturally, understand something else by the word.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the idealist may conceive of the Absolute as an all-inclusive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Mind, of which finite minds are parts.  To Spencer, it is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unknowable, a something behind the veil of phenomena.  Sometimes it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means to a writer much the same thing that the word God means to other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men; sometimes it has a significance at the farthest remove from this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 53).  Indeed, the word is so vague and ambiguous, and has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proved itself the mother of so many confusions, that it would seem a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: desirable thing to drop it out of philosophy altogether, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: substitute for it some less ambiguous expression.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems clear from the preceding pages, that, before one either
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accepts or rejects monism, one should very carefully determine just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what one means by the word, and should scrutinize the considerations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which may be urged in favor of the particular doctrine in question.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are all sorts of monism, and men embrace them for all sorts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasons.  Let me beg the reader to bear in mind;--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) The monist may be a materialist; he may be an idealist; he may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: neither.  In the last case, he may, with Spinoza, call the one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Substance God; that is, he may be a Pantheist.  On the other hand, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may, with Spencer, call it the Unknowable, and be an Agnostic.  Other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shades of opinion are open to him, if he cares to choose them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) It does not seem wise to assent hastily to such statements as; "The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universe is the manifestation of one unitary Being"; or: "Mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter are the expression of one and the same principle."  We find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: revealed in our experience mental phenomena and physical phenomena.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what sense they are one, or whether they are one in any sense,--this is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something to be determined by an examination of the phenomena and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relations in which we find them.  It may turn out that the universe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is one only in the sense that all phenomena belong to the one orderly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system.  If we find that this is the case, we may still, if we choose,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call our doctrine monism, but we should carefully distinguish such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: monism from those represented by Hoeffding and Spencer and many others.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There seems little reason to use the word, when the doctrine has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so far modified.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 58. DUALISM.--The plain man finds himself in a world of physical things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and of minds, and it seems to him that his experience directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: testifies to the existence of both.  This means that the things of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which he has experience appear to belong to two distinct classes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not mean, of course, that he has only two kinds of experiences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The phenomena which are revealed to us are indefinitely varied; all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical phenomena are not just alike, and all mental phenomena are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: just alike.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, amid all the bewildering variety that forces itself upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our attention, there stands out one broad distinction, that of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical and the mental.  It is a distinction that the man who has done
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no reading in the philosophers is scarcely tempted to obliterate; to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him the world consists of two kinds of things widely different from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: each other; minds are not material things and material things are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds.  We are justified in regarding this as the opinion of the plain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man even when we recognize that, in his endeavor to make clear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself what he means by minds, he sometimes speaks as though he were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: talking about something material or semi-material.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the materialist allows these two classes to run together; so does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the idealist.  The one says that everything is matter; the other, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: everything is mind.  It would be foolish to maintain that nothing can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be said for either doctrine, for men of ability have embraced each.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But one may at least say that both seem to be refuted by our common
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of the world, an experience which, so far as it is permitted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to testify at all, lifts up its voice in favor of _Dualism_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Dualism is sometimes defined as the doctrine that there are in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world two kinds of substances, matter and mind, which are different in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: kind and should be kept distinct.  There are dualists who prefer to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: avoid the use of the word substance, and to say that the world of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiences consists of physical phenomena and of mental phenomena, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that these two classes of facts should be kept separate.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The dualist may maintain that we have a direct knowledge of matter and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of mind, and he may content himself with such a statement, doing little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to make clear what we mean by matter and by mind.  In this case, his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: position is little different from that of the plain man who does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attempt to philosophize.  Thomas Reid (section 50) belongs to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, the dualist may attempt to make clear, through
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical reflection, what we mean by the matter and mind which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience seems to give us.  He may conclude:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) That he must hold, as did Sir William Hamilton, that we perceive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly only physical and mental phenomena, but are justified in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inferring that, since the phenomena are different, there must be two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: kinds of underlying substances to which the phenomena are referred.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, he may distinguish between the two substances and their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: manifestations, as some monists distinguish between the one substance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and its manifestations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) Or he may conclude that it is futile to search for substances or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: realities of any sort _behind_ phenomena, arguing that such realities
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are never revealed in experience, and that no sound reason for their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption can be adduced.  In this case, he may try to make plain what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind and matter are, by simply analyzing our experiences of mind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter and coming to a clearer comprehension of their nature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As the reader has probably remarked, the philosophy presented in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earlier chapters of this book (Chapters III to XI) is _dualistic_ as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well as _realistic_.  That is to say, it refuses to rub out the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinction between physical phenomena and mental phenomena, either by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dissolving the material world into ideas; by calling ideas secretions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or functions of the brain; or by declaring them one in a fictitious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: entity behind the veil and not supposed to be exactly identical with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: either.  And as it teaches that the only reality that it means anything
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to talk about must be found in experience, it is a dualism of the type
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: described in the paragraph which immediately precedes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such a philosophy does not seem to do violence to the common experience
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of minds and of physical things shared by us all, whether we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers or are not.  It only tries to make clear what we all know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dimly and vaguely.  This is, I think, a point in its favor.  However,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men of great ability and of much learning have inclined to doctrines
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: very different; and we have no right to make up our minds on such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subject as this without trying to give them an attentive and an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impartial hearing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 59. SINGULARISM AND PLURALISM.--There are those who apply to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: various forms of monism the title _Singularism_, and who contrast with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this _Pluralism_, a word which is meant to cover the various doctrines
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which maintain that there is more than one ultimate principle or being
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the universe.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is argued that we should have some word under which we may bring
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such a doctrine, for example, as that of the Greek philosopher
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Empedocles (born about 490 B.C.).  This thinker made earth, water,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fire, and air the four material principles or "roots" of things.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: was not a monist, and we can certainly not call him a dualist.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  The term pluralism has been used to indicate the doctrine that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individual finite minds are not parts or manifestations of one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all-embracing Mind,--of God or the Absolute,--but are relatively
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent beings.  This doctrine has been urged in our own time, with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: eloquence and feeling, by Professor Howison.[2]  Here we have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pluralism which is idealistic, for it admits in the universe but one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _kind_ of thing, minds; and yet refuses to call itself monistic.  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will readily be seen that in this paragraph and in the one preceding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word is used in different senses.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I have added the above sentences to this chapter that the reader may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have an explanation of the meaning of a word sometimes met with.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the title of the chapter is "Monism and Dualism," and it is of this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrast that it is especially important to grasp the significance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "Outlines of Psychology," pp. 64-65, English translation, 1891.

author: Fullerton, George Stuart
