text: CHAPTER XV
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: RATIONALISM, EMPIRICISM, CRITICISM, AND CRITICAL EMPIRICISM
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 60. RATIONALISM.--As the content of a philosophical doctrine must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: determined by the _initial assumptions_ which a philosopher makes and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by the _method_ which he adopts in his reasonings, it is well to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: examine with some care certain broad differences in this respect which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: characterize different philosophers, and which help to explain how it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is that the results of their reflections are so startlingly different.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I shall first speak of _Rationalism_, which I may somewhat loosely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: define as the doctrine that the reason can attain truths independently
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of observation--can go beyond experienced fact and the deductions which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience seems to justify us in making from experienced fact.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: definition cannot mean much to us until it is interpreted by a concrete
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: example, and I shall turn to such.  It must, however, be borne in mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the word "rationalism" is meant to cover a great variety of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinions, and we have said comparatively little about him when we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: called a man a rationalist in philosophy.  Men may agree in believing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the reason can go beyond experienced fact, and yet may differ
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarding the particular truths which may be thus attained.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, when Descartes found himself discontented with the philosophy that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he and others had inherited from the Middle Ages, and undertook a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reconstruction, he found it necessary to throw over a vast amount of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what had passed as truth, if only with a view to building up again upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a firmer foundation.  It appeared to him that much was uncritically
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accepted as true in philosophy and in the sciences which a little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection revealed to be either false or highly doubtful.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Accordingly, he decided to clear the ground by a sweeping doubt, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: begin his task quite independently.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In accordance with this principle, he rejected the testimony of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses touching the existence of a world of external things.  Do not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the senses sometimes deceive us?  And, since men seem to be liable to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error in their reasonings, even in a field so secure as that of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematical demonstration, he resolved further to repudiate all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasonings he had heretofore accepted.  He would not even assume
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself to be in his right mind and awake; might he not be the victim
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a diseased fancy, or a man deluded by dreams?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Could anything whatever escape this all-devouring doubt?  One truth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seemed unshakable: his own existence, at least, emerged from this sea
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of uncertainties.  I may be deceived in thinking that there is an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world, and that I am awake and really perceive things; but I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surely cannot be deceived unless I exist.  _Cogito, ergo sum_--I think,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hence I exist; this truth Descartes accepted as the first principle of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the new and sounder philosophy which he sought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As we read farther in Descartes we discover that he takes back again a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: great many of those things that he had at the outset rejected as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uncertain.  Thus, he accepts an external world of material things.  How
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does he establish its existence?  He cannot do it as the empiricist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does it, by a reference to experienced fact, for he does not believe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the external world is directly given in our experience.  He thinks
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are directly conscious only of our _ideas_ of it, and must somehow
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prove that it exists over against our ideas.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: By his principles, Descartes is compelled to fall back upon a curious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: roundabout argument to prove that there is a world.  He must first
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prove that God exists, and then argue that God would not deceive us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into thinking that it exists when it does not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, when we come to examine Descartes' reasonings in detail we find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what appear to us some very uncritical assumptions.  Thus, he proves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the existence of God by the following argument:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I exist, and I find in me the idea of God; of this idea I cannot be the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: author, for it represents something much greater than I, and its cause
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be as great as the reality it represents.  In other words, nothing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: less than God can be the cause of the idea of God which I find in me,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and, hence, I may infer that God exists.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Where did Descartes get this notion that every idea must have a cause
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which contains as much external reality as the idea does represented
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reality?  How does he prove his assumption?  He simply appeals to what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he calls "the natural light," which is for him a source of all sorts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: information which cannot be derived from experience.  This "natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: light" furnishes him with a vast number of "eternal truths", these he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has not brought under the sickle of his sweeping doubt, and these help
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him to build up again the world he has overthrown, beginning with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one indubitable fact discussed above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To the men of a later time many of Descartes' eternal truths are simply
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inherited philosophical prejudices, the results of the reflections of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earlier thinkers, and in sad need of revision.  I shall not criticise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them in detail.  The important point for us to notice is that we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: here a type of philosophy which depends upon truths revealed by the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason, independently of experience, to carry one beyond the sphere of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I again remind the reader that there are all sorts of rationalists, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the philosophical sense of the word.  Some trust the power of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unaided reason without reserve.  Thus Spinoza, the pantheist, made the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: magnificent but misguided attempt to deduce the whole system of things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical and things mental from what he called the attributes of God,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Extension and Thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, one may be a good deal of an empiricist, and yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something of a rationalist, too.  Thus Professor Strong, in his recent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brilliant book, "Why the Mind has a Body," maintains that we know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intuitively that other minds than our own exist; know it without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gathering our information from experience, and without having to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: establish the fact in any way.  This seems, at least, akin to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine of the "natural light," and yet no one can say that Professor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Strong does not, in general, believe in a philosophy of observation and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experiment.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 61. EMPIRICISM.--I suppose every one who has done some reading in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history of philosophy will, if his mother tongue be English, think of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the name of John Locke when empiricism is mentioned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke, in his "Essay concerning Human Understanding," undertakes "to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inquire into the original, certainty, and extent of human knowledge,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: together with the grounds and degrees of belief, opinion, and assent."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His sober and cautious work, which was first published in 1690, was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: peculiarly English in character; and the spirit which it exemplifies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: animates also Locke's famous successors, George Berkeley (1684-1753),
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: David Hume (1711-1776), and John Stuart Mill (1806-1873).  Although
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke was a realist, Berkeley an idealist, Hume a skeptic, and Mill
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what has been called a sensationalist; yet all were empiricists of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sort, and emphasized the necessity of founding our knowledge upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, Locke was familiar with the writings of Descartes, whose work he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admired, but whose rationalism offended him.  The first book of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Essay" is devoted to the proof that there are in the mind of man no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "innate ideas" and no "innate principles."  That is to say, Locke tries
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to show that one must not seek, in the "natural light" to which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Descartes turned, a distinct and independent source of information,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Let us, then," he continues, "suppose the mind to be, as we say, white
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: paper, void of all characters, without any ideas; how comes it to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: furnished?  Whence comes it by that vast store which the busy and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: boundless fancy of man has painted on it, with an almost endless
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: variety?  Whence has it all the materials of reason and knowledge?  To
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this I answer in one word, from experience; in that all our knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is founded, and from that it ultimately derives itself.  Our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observation, employed either about external sensible objects, or about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the internal operations of our minds, perceived and reflected on by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves, is that which supplies our understandings with all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: materials of thinking.  These two are the fountains of knowledge, from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whence all the ideas we have, or can naturally have, do spring." [1]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, all we know and all we ever shall know of the world of matter and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of minds must rest ultimately upon observation,--observation of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external things and of our own mind.  We must clip the erratic wing of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a "reason" which seeks to soar beyond such knowledge; which leaves the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solid earth, and hangs suspended in the void.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "But hold," exclaims the critical reader; "have we not seen that Locke,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as well as Descartes (section 48), claims to know what he cannot prove
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by direct observation or even by a legitimate inference from what has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been directly observed?  Does he not maintain that the mind has an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: immediate knowledge or experience only of its own ideas?  How can he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prove that there are material extended things outside causing these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ideas?  And if he cannot prove it by an appeal to experience, to direct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observation, is he not, in accepting the existence of the external
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world at all, just as truly as Descartes, a rationalist?"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The objection is well taken.  On his own principles, Locke had no right
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to believe in an external world.  He has stolen his world, so to speak;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he has taken it by violence.  Nevertheless, as I pointed out in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section above referred to, Locke is not a rationalist of _malice
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prepense_.  He _tries_ to be an empiricist.  He believes in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: external world because he thinks it is directly revealed to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: senses--he inconsistently refers to experience as evidence of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It has often been claimed by those who do not sympathize with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: empiricism that the empiricists make assumptions much as others do, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have not the grace to admit it.  I think we must frankly confess that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man may try hard to be an empiricist and may not be wholly successful.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, reflection forces us to the conclusion that when we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: defined empiricism as a doctrine which rests throughout upon an appeal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to "experience" we have not said anything very definite.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What is _experience_?  What may we accept as directly revealed fact?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The answer to such questions is far from an easy one to give.  It is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: harder matter to discuss intelligently than any one can at all realize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: until he has spent some years in following the efforts of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers to determine what is "revealed fact."  We are supposed to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have experience of our own minds, of space, of time, of matter.  What
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are these things as revealed in our experience?  We have seen in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earlier chapters of this book that one cannot answer such questions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: off-hand.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 62.  CRITICISM.--I have in another chapter (section 51) given a brief
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: account of the philosophy of Immanuel Kant.  He called his doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Criticism," and he distinguished it from "Dogmatism" and "Empiricism."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Every philosophy that transcends experience, without first critically
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: examining our faculty of knowledge and determining its right to spread
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its wings in this way, Kant calls "dogmatism."  The word seems rather
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an offensive one, in its usual signification, at least; and it is as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: well not to use it.  As Kant used the word, Descartes was a dogmatist;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but let us rather call him a rationalist.  He certainly had no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intention of proceeding uncritically, as we shall see a little later.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we call him a dogmatist we seem to condemn him in advance, by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: applying to him an abusive epithet.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Empiricism, according to Kant, confines human knowledge to experience,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and thus avoids the errors which beset the dogmatist.  But then, as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hume seemed to have shown, empiricism must run out into skepticism.  If
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all our knowledge has its foundations in experience, how can we expect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to find in our possession any universal or necessary truths?  May not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: later experience contradict an earlier?  How can we be sure that what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has been will be?  Can we _know_ that there is anything fixed and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain in our world?

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearness of apprehension the following: "Consider what effects, which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: might conceivably have practical bearings, we conceive the object of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our conception to have.  Then, our conception of these effects is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole of our conception of the object."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This thought has been taken up by others and given a development which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Mr. Peirce regards with some suspicion.  He refers[4] especially to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: development it has received at the hands of Professor William James, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his two essays, "The Will to Believe" and "Philosophical Conceptions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and Practical Results." [5]  Professor James is often regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foremost among the pragmatists.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I shall not attempt to define pragmatism, for I do not believe that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine has yet attained to that definiteness of formulation which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: warrants a definition.  We seem to have to do not so much with a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear-cut doctrine, the limits and consequences of which have been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: worked out in detail, as with a tendency which makes itself apparent in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the works of various writers under somewhat different forms.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I may roughly describe it as the tendency to take that to be _true_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which is _useful_ or _serviceable_.  It is well illustrated in the two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: essays to which reference is made above.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, Professor James dwells upon the unsatisfactoriness and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uncertainty of philosophical and scientific knowledge: "Objective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence and certitude are doubtless very fine ideals to play with, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: where on this moonlit and dream-visited planet are they found?"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, among those things regarding which it appears impossible to attain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to intellectual certitude, there are matters of great practical moment,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and which affect deeply the conduct of life; for example, the doctrines
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of religion.  Here a merely skeptical attitude seems intolerable.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In such cases, argues Professor James, "we have the right to believe at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our own risk any hypothesis that is live enough to tempt our will."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is important to notice that there is no question here of a logical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right.  We are concerned with matters regarding which, according to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Professor James, we cannot look for intellectual evidence.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumed that we believe simply because we choose to believe--we believe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arbitrarily.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is further important to notice that what is a "live" hypothesis to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one man need not tempt the will of another man at all.  As our author
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: points out, a Turk would naturally will to believe one thing and a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Christian would will to believe another.  Each would will to believe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what struck him as a satisfactory thing to believe.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What shall we say to this doctrine?  I think we must say that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly not a philosophical _method of attaining to truth_.  Hence, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has not properly a place in this chapter among the attempts which have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been made to attain to the truth of things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, in fact, not concerned with truths, but with assumptions, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with assumptions which are supposed to be made on the basis of no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence.  It is concerned with "seemings."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The distinction is a very important one.  Our Turk cannot, by willing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to believe it, make his hypothesis true; but he can make it _seem_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true.  Why should he wish to make it seem true whether it is true or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not?  Why should he strive to attain to a feeling of subjective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainty, not by logically resolving his doubts, but by ignoring them?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The answer is given us by our author.  He who lives in the midst of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doubts, and refuses to cut his knot with the sword of belief, misses
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the good of life.  This is a practical problem, and one of no small
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: moment.  In the last section of this book I have tried to indicate what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is wise for a man to do when he is confronted by doubts which he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot resolve.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Into the general question whether even a false belief may not, under
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some circumstances, be more serviceable than no belief at all, I shall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not enter.  The point I wish to emphasize is that there is all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difference in the world between _producing a belief_ and _proving a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We are compelled to accept it as a fact that men, under the influence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of feeling, can believe in the absence of evidence, or, for that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter, can believe in spite of evidence.  But a truth cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: established in the absence of evidence or in the face of adverse
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence.  And there is a very wide field in which it is made very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear to us that beliefs adopted in the absence of evidence are in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: danger of being false beliefs.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The pragmatist would join with the rest of us in condemning the Turk or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Christian who would simply will to believe in the rise or the fall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of stocks, and would refuse to consult the state of the market.  Some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hypotheses are, in the ordinary course of events, put to the test of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: verification.  We are then made painfully aware that beliefs and truths
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are quite distinct things, and may not be in harmony.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the pragmatist does not apply his principle to this field.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: confines it to what may not inaptly be called the field of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unverifiable.  The Turk, who wills to believe in the hypothesis that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appeals to him as a pious Turk, is in no such danger of a rude
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: awakening as is the man who wills to believe that stocks will go up or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: down.  But mark what this means: it means that _he is not in danger of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: finding out what the truth really is_.  It does not mean that he is in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possession of the truth.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So I say, the doctrine which we are discussing is not a method of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attaining to truth.  What it really attempts to do is to point out to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us how it is prudent for us to act when we cannot discover what the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth is.[6]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "An Essay concerning Human Understanding," Book II, Chapter I,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section 2.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: [2] Book I, Chapter I, section 4.

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [3] Book I, Chapter I, section 1.

text: [4] "Dictionary of Philosophy and Psychology," article "Pragmatism."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [5] Published in 1897 and 1898.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [6] For references to later developments of pragmatism, see the note on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy

text: page 312.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: V. THE PHILOSOPHICAL SCIENCES
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XVI
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: LOGIC
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 65. INTRODUCTORY: THE PHILOSOPHICAL SCIENCES.--I have said in the first
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter of this book (section 6) that there is quite a group of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences that are regarded as belonging peculiarly to the province of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the teacher of philosophy to-day.  Having, in the chapters preceding,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given some account of the nature of reflective thought, of the problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touching the world and the mind which present themselves to those who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflect, and of some types of philosophical theory which have their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: origin in such reflection, I turn to a brief consideration of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Among these I included logic, psychology, ethics, and aesthetics,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysics, and the history of philosophy.  I did not include
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: epistemology or "the theory of knowledge" as a separate discipline, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my reasons for this will appear in Chapter XIX.  I remarked that, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complete the list, we should have to add the philosophy of religion and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an investigation into the principles and methods of the sciences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: generally.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Why, it was asked, should this group of disciplines be regarded as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: field of the philosopher, when others are excluded?  The answer to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question which finds the explanation of the fact to lie in a mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: historical accident was declared unsatisfactory, and it was maintained
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the philosophical sciences are those in which we find ourselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carried back to the problems of reflective thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: With a view to showing the truth of this opinion, I shall take up one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by one the philosophical sciences.  Of the history of philosophy I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall not speak in this part of the work, but shall treat of it in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Chapter XXIII.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 66. THE TRADITIONAL LOGIC.--Most of us begin our acquaintance with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: logic in the study of some such elementary manual as Jevons' "Lessons
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in Logic."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In such books we are shown how terms represent things and classes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things or their attributes, and how we unite them into propositions or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements.  It is indicated at length what statements may be made on a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: basis of certain other statements and what may not; and emphasis is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: laid upon the dangers which arise out of a misunderstanding of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: language in which we are forced to express our thoughts.  Finally,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there are described for us the experimental methods by which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: workers in the sciences have attained to the general information about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world which has become our heritage.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such books are useful.  It is surely no small profit for a student to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gain the habit of scrutinizing the steps by which he has come into the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possession of a certain bit of information, and to have a quick eye for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: loose and inconsistent reasonings.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is worthy of remark that one may study such a book as this and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: yet remain pretty consistently on what may be called the plane of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: common understanding.  One seems to make the assumptions made in all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the special sciences, _e.g._ the assumption that there is a world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: real things and that we can know them and reason about them.  We are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not introduced to such problems as: What _is_ truth?  and Is _any_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge valid?  Nor does it seem at once apparent that the man who is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: studying logic in this way is busying himself with a philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discipline.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 67. THE "MODERN LOGIC."--It is very puzzling for the student to turn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from such a text-book as the one above mentioned to certain others
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which profess to be occupied with the same science, and which, yet,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appear to treat of quite different things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, in Dr. Bosanquet's little work on "The Essentials of Logic," the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reader is at once plunged into such questions as the nature of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge, and what is meant by the real world.  We seem to be dealing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with metaphysics, and not with logic, as we have learned to understand
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the term.  How is it that the logician comes to regard these things as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: within his province?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: A multitude of writers at the present day are treating logic in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: way, and in some great prominence is given to problems which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher recognizes as indisputably his own.  The term "modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: logic" is often employed to denote a logic of this type; one which does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not, after the fashion of the natural sciences generally, proceed on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the basis of certain assumptions, and leave deeper questions to some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other discipline, but tries to get to the bottom of things for itself.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The tendency to run into metaphysics is peculiarly marked in those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: writers who have been influenced by the work of the philosopher Hegel.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I shall not here ask why those who belong to one school are more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inclined to be metaphysical than are those who belong to another, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall approach the broader question why the logicians generally are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inclined to be more metaphysical than those who work in certain other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: special sciences, such as mathematics, for example.  Of the general
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tendency there can be no question.  The only problem is: Why does this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tendency exist?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 68. LOGIC AND PHILOSOPHY.--Let us contrast the science of arithmetic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with logic; and let us notice, regarding it, the following points:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, like logic, a _general_ science, in that the things treated of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in many sciences may be numbered.  It considers only a certain aspect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, that things may be counted, added together, subtracted, etc., is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guaranteed by the experience of the plain man; and the methods of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: determining the numerical relations of things are gradually developed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before his eyes, beginning with operations of great simplicity.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, verification is possible, and within certain limits
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: verification by direct inspection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this we may add, that there has gradually been built up a fine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system of unambiguous symbols, and it is possible for a man to know
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: just what he is dealing with.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, a certain beaten path has been attained, and a man may travel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this very well without having forced on his attention the problems of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflective thought.  The knowledge of numbers with which he starts is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sufficient equipment with which to undertake the journey.  That one is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on the right road is proved by the results one obtains.  As a rule,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: disputes can be settled by well-tried mathematical methods.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is, then, a common agreement as to initial assumptions and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: methods of work, and useful results are attained which seem to justify
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: both.  Here we have the normal characteristics of a special science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must not forget, however, that, even in the mathematical sciences,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before a beaten path was attained, disputes as to the significance of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: numbers and the cogency of proofs were sufficiently common.  And we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must bear in mind that even to-day, where the beaten path does not seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholly satisfactory, men seem to be driven to reflect upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of their assumptions and the nature of their method.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we find it not unnatural that a man should be led to ask; What is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a minus quantity really?  Can anything be less than nothing? or that he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should raise the questions: Can one rightly speak of an infinite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number?  Can one infinite number be greater than another, and, if so,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what can greater mean?  What are infinitesimals? and what can be meant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by different orders of infinitesimals?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He who has interested himself in such questions as these has betaken
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself to philosophical reflection.  They are not answered by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: employing mathematical methods.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us now turn to logic.  And let us notice, to begin with, that it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: broader in its application than the mathematical sciences.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concerned to discover what constitutes _evidence_ in every field of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is, it is true, a part of logic that may be developed somewhat
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: after the fashion of mathematics.  Thus, we may examine the two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements: All men are mortal, and Caesar is a man; and we may see
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly that, given the truth of these, we must admit that Caesar is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mortal.  We may make a list of possible inferences of this kind, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point out under what circumstances the truth of two statements implies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the truth of a third, and under what circumstances the inference cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be made.  Our results can be set forth in a system of symbols.  As in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematics, we may abstract from the particular things reasoned about,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and concern ourselves only with the forms of reasoning.  This gives us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the theory of the _syllogism_; it is a part of logic in which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mathematician is apt to feel very much at home.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But this is by no means all of logic.  Let us consider the following
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: points:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (1) We are not concerned to know only what statements may be made on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the basis of certain other statements.  We want to know what is true
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and what is false.  We must ask: Has a man the right to set up these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: particular statements and to reason from them?  That some men accept as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true premises which are repudiated by others is an undoubted fact.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, it is maintained by certain philosophers that we may assume that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: any view of the universe which is repellant to our nature cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: true.  Shall we allow this to pass unchallenged?  And in ethics, some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have held that it is under all circumstances wrong to lie; others have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: denied this, and have held that in certain cases--for example, to save
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life or to prevent great and unmerited suffering--lying is permissible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Shall we interest ourselves only in the deductions that each man makes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from his assumed premises, and pay no attention to the truth of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: premises themselves?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (2) Again.  The vast mass of the reasonings that interest men are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expressed in the language that we all use and not in special symbols.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But language is a very imperfect instrument, and all sorts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misunderstandings are possible to those who express their thoughts in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Few men know exactly how much is implied in what they are saying.  If I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say: All men are mortal, and an angel is not a man; therefore, an angel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not mortal; it is not at once apparent to every one in what respect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: my argument is defective.  He who argues: Feathers are light; light is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrary to darkness; hence, feathers are contrary to darkness; is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: convicted of error without difficulty.  But arguments of the same kind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and quite as bad, are to be found in learned works on matters less
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: familiar to us, and we often fail to detect the fallacy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, Herbert Spencer argues, in effect, in the fourth and fifth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapters of his "First Principles," as follows:--
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We are conscious of the Unknowable,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The Unknowable lies behind the veil of phenomena,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hence, we are conscious of what lies behind the veil of phenomena.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is only the critical reader who notices that the Unknowable in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first line is the "raw material of consciousness," and the Unknowable
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the second is something not in consciousness at all.  The two senses
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the word "light" are not more different from one another.  Such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apparent arguments abound, and it often requires much acuteness to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: able to detect their fallacious character.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we take into consideration the two points indicated above, we see
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the logician is at every turn forced to reflect upon our knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as men do not ordinarily reflect.  He is led to ask: What is truth?  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot accept uncritically the assumptions which men make; and he must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: endeavor to become very clearly conscious of the real meaning and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole meaning of statements expressed in words.  Even in the simple
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: logic with which we usually begin our studies, we learn to scrutinize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: statements in a reflective way; and when we go deeper, we are at once
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in contact with philosophical problems.  It is evidently our task to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attain to a clearer insight into the nature of our experience and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaning of proof than is attainable by the unreflective.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Logic, then, is a reflective science, and it is not surprising that it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has held its place as one of the philosophical sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: PSYCHOLOGY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 69. PSYCHOLOGY AND PHILOSOPHY.--I think I have said enough in Chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: II (section 10) about what we mean when we speak of psychology as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natural science and as an independent discipline.  Certainly there are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many psychologists who would not care to be confused with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers, and there are some that regard philosophy with suspicion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, psychology is commonly regarded as belonging to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical group.  That this is the case can scarcely be thought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: surprising when we see how the psychologist himself speaks of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation of his science to philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "I have kept," writes Professor James[1] in that delightful book which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has become the common property of us all, "close to the point of view
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of natural science throughout the book.  Every natural science assumes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain data uncritically, and declines to challenge the elements
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between which its own 'laws' obtain, and from which its own deductions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are carried on.  Psychology, the science of finite individual minds,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumes as its data (1) _thoughts and feelings_, and (2) _a physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world_ in time and space with which they coexist, and which (3) _they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know_.  Of course, these data themselves are discussable; but the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussion of them (as of other elements) is called metaphysics and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: falls outside the province of this book."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is an admirable statement of the scope of psychology as a natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science, and also of the relations of metaphysics to the sciences.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it would not be fair to Professor James to take this sentence alone,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and to assume that, in his opinion, it is easy to separate psychology
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: altogether from philosophy.  "The reader," he tells us in the next
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: paragraph, "will in vain seek for any closed system in the book.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mainly a mass of descriptive details, running out into queries which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only a metaphysics alive to the weight of her task can hope
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successfully to deal with."  And in the opening sentence of the preface
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he informs us that some of his chapters are more "metaphysical" than is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: suitable for students going over the subject for the first time.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That the author is right in maintaining that it is not easy to draw a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear line between philosophy and psychology, and to declare the latter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholly independent, I think we must concede.  An independent science
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should be sure of the things with which it is dealing.  Where these are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague and indefinite, and are the subject of constant dispute, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot march forward with assurance.  One is rather forced to go back
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and examine the data themselves.  The beaten track of the special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science has not been satisfactorily constructed.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We are forced to admit that the science of psychology has not yet
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: emerged from the state in which a critical examination of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foundations is necessary, and that the construction of the beaten path
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is still in progress.  This I shall try to make clear by illustrations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The psychologist studies the mind, and his ultimate appeal must be to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: introspection, to a direct observation of mental phenomena, and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their relations to external things.  Now, if the observation of mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena were a simple and an easy thing; if the mere fact that we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious of sensations and ideas implied that we are _clearly_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscious of them and are in a position to describe them with accuracy,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychology would be a much more satisfactory science than it is.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we are not thus conscious of our mental life.  We can and do use
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our mental states without being able to describe them accurately.  In a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense, we are conscious of what is there, but our consciousness is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather dim and vague, and in our attempts to give an account of it we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are in no little danger of giving a false account.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the psychologist assumes that we perceive both physical phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and mental--the external world and the mind.  He takes it for granted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we perceive mental phenomena to be related to physical.  He is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hardly in a position to make this assumption, and then to set it aside
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a thing he need not further consider.  Does he not tell us, as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: result of his investigations, that we can know the external world only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as it is reflected in our sensations, and thus seem to shut the mind up
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: within the circle of mental phenomena merely, cutting off absolutely a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: direct knowledge of what is extra-mental?  If we can know only mental
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena, the representatives of things, at first hand, how can we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tell that they are representatives? and what becomes of the assumption
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we _perceive_ that mind is related to an external world?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It may be said, this problem the psychologist may leave to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysician.  Certainly, it is one of those problems that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysician discusses; it has been treated in Chapter IV.  But my
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contention is, that he who has given no thought to the matter may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: easily fall into error as to the very nature of mental phenomena.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For example, when we approach or recede from a physical object we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a series of experiences which are recognized as sensational.  When we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: imagine a tree or a house we are also experiencing a mental phenomenon.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: All these experiences _seem_ plainly to have extension in some sense of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the word.  We appear to perceive plainly part out of part.  In so far,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these mental things seem to resemble the physical things which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrast with what is mental.  Shall we say that, because these things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are mental and not physical, their apparent extension is a delusion?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Shall we say that they really have no parts?  Such considerations have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impelled psychologists of eminence to maintain, in flat contradiction
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to what seems to be the unequivocal testimony of direct introspection,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the total content of consciousness at any moment must be looked
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon as an indivisible, part-less unit.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We cannot, then, depend merely on direct introspection.  It is too
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uncertain in its deliverances.  If we would make clear to ourselves
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what mental phenomena really are, and how they | differ from physical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena, we must fall back upon the reflective analysis of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience which occupies the metaphysician (section 34).  Until we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have done this, we are in great danger of error.  We are actually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: uncertain of our materials.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  The psychologist speaks of the relation of mind and body.  Some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychologists incline to be parallelists, some are warm advocates of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interactionism.  Now, any theory of the relation of mind to body must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: depend on observation ultimately.  If we had not direct experience of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation between the physical and the mental somewhere, no hypothesis
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on the subject would ever have emerged.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But our experiences are not perfectly clear and unequivocal to us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Their significance does not seem to be easily grasped.  To comprehend
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it one is forced to that reflective examination of experience which is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: characteristic of the philosopher (Chapter IX).
