title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Here it may again be said: Leave the matter to the meta-physician and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: go on with your psychological work.  I answer: The psychologist is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the same position as the botanist or the zooelogist.  He is studying
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind in its relation to body.  It cannot but be unsatisfactory to him
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to leave that relation wholly vague; and, as a matter of fact, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: usually takes up with one theory or another.  We have seen (section 36)
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he may easily adopt a theory that leads him to overlook the great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difference between physical phenomena and mental phenomena, and to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treat them as though they were the same.  This one may do in spite of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all that introspection has to say about the gulf that separates them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Psychology is, then, very properly classed among the philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences.  The psychologist is not sufficiently sure of his materials
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be able to dispense with reflective thought, in many parts of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: field.  Some day there may come to be a consensus of opinion touching
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental facts, and the science may become more independent.  A
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beaten track may be attained; but that has not yet been done.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 70. THE DOUBLE AFFILIATION OF PSYCHOLOGY.--In spite of what has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: said above, we must not forget that psychology is a _relatively_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent science.  One may be a useful psychologist without knowing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much about philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As in logic it is possible to write a text-book not greatly different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in spirit and method from text-books concerned with the sciences not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: classed as philosophical, so it is possible to make a useful study of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena without entering upon metaphysical analyses.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science, as in common life, we can _use_ concepts without subjecting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them to careful analysis.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, our common experience reveals that mind and body are connected.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, for a specific purpose, leave the _nature_ of this connection
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague, and may pay careful attention to the physiological conditions of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mental phenomena, studying in detail the senses and the nervous system.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, further, endeavor to render our knowledge of mental phenomena
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more full and accurate by experimentation.  In doing this we may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: compelled to make use of elaborate apparatus.  Of such mechanical aids
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to investigation our psychological laboratories are full.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is to such work as this that we owe what is called the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "physiological" and the "experimental" psychology.  One can carry on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such investigations without being a metaphysician.  But one can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scarcely carry them on without having a good knowledge of certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences not commonly supposed to be closely related to psychology at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all.  Thus, one should be trained in chemistry and physics and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physiology, and should have a working knowledge of laboratory methods.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, it is desirable to have a sufficient knowledge of mathematics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to enable one to handle experimental data.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The consideration of such facts as these sometimes leads men to raise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the question: Should psychology affiliate with philosophy or with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical sciences?  The issue is an illegitimate one.  Psychology is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one of the philosophical sciences, and cannot dispense with reflection;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but that is no reason why it should not acknowledge a close relation to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain physical sciences as well.  Parts of the field can be isolated,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and one may work as one works in the natural sciences generally; but if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one does nothing more, one's concepts remain unanalyzed, and, as we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have seen in the previous section, there is some danger of actual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misconception.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "Psychology," Preface.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XVIII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ETHICS AND AESTHETICS
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 71. COMMON SENSE ETHICS.--We may, if we choose, study the actions of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men merely with a view to ascertaining what they are and describing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them accurately.  Something like this is done by the anthropologist,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who gives us an account of the manners and customs of the various races
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of mankind; he tells us _what is_; he may not regard it as within his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: province at all to inform us regarding _what ought to be_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But men do not merely act; they judge their actions in the light of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some norm or standard, and they distinguish between them as right and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wrong.  The systematic study of actions as right and wrong yields us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the science of ethics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Like psychology, ethics is a special science.  It is concerned with a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhat limited field of investigation, and is not to be confounded
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with other sciences.  It has a definite aim distinct from theirs.  And,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: also like psychology, ethics is classed as one of the philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences, and its relation to philosophy is supposed to be closer than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that of such sciences as physics and mathematics.  It is fair to ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: why this is so.  Why cannot ethics proceed on the basis of certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions independently, and leave to some other discipline the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question of an inquiry into the nature and validity of those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: About half a century ago Dr. William Whewell, one of the most learned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of English scholars, wrote a work entitled "The Elements of Morality,"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which he attempted to treat the science of ethics as it is generally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admitted that one may treat the science of geometry.  The book was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather widely read a generation since, but we meet with few references
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to it in our time.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Morality and the philosophy of morality," argues the author, "differ
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the same manner and in the same degree as geometry and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy of geometry.  Of these two subjects, geometry consists of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: series of positive and definite propositions, deduced one from another,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in succession, by rigorous reasoning, and all resting upon certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: definitions and self-evident axioms.  The philosophy of geometry is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: quite a different subject; it includes such inquiries as these: Whence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the cogency of geometrical proof?  What is the evidence of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: axioms and definitions?  What are the faculties by which we become
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aware of their truth? and the like.  The two kinds of speculation have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been pursued, for the most part, by two different classes of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons,--the geometers and the metaphysicians; for it has been far
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more the occupation of metaphysicians than of geometers to discuss such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: questions as I have stated, the nature of geometrical proofs,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: geometrical axioms, the geometrical faculty, and the like.  And if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: construct a complete system of geometry, it will be almost exactly the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: same, whatever be the views which we take on these metaphysical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: questions." [1]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such a system Dr. Whewell wishes to construct in the field of ethics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His aim is to give us a view of morality in which moral propositions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are "deduced from axioms, by successive steps of reasoning, so far as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to form a connected system of moral truth."  Such a "sure and connected
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge of the duties of man" would, he thinks, be of the greatest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: importance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In accordance with this purpose, Dr. Whewell assumes that humanity,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justice, truth, purity, order, earnestness, and moral purpose are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental principles of human action; and he thinks that all who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit as much as this will be able to go on with him in his development
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a system of moral rules to govern the life of man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It would hardly be worth while for me to speak at length of a way of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treating ethics so little likely to be urged upon the attention of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reader who busies himself with the books which are appearing in our own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: day, were it not that we have here an admirable illustration of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attempt to teach ethics as though it were such a science as geometry.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The shortcomings of the method become very evident to one who reads the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: work attentively.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we are forced to ask ourselves, have we really a collection of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ultimate moral principles which are analogous to the axioms of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: geometry?  For example, to take but a single instance, Dr. Whewell
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: formulates the Principle of Truth as follows: "We must conform to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universal understanding among men which the use of language
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: implies";[2] and he remarks later; "The rules: _Lie not_, Perform your
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: promise, are of universal validity; and the conceptions of _lie_ and of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _promise_ are so simple and distinct that, in general, the rules may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly and easily applied." [3]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, we are struck by the fact that this affirmation of the universal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: validity of the principle of truth is made in a chapter on "Cases of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Conscience," in a chapter concerned with what seem to be conflicts
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between duties; and this chapter is followed by one which treats of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "Cases of Necessity," _i.e._ cases in which a man is to be regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justified in violating common rules when there seems to be urgent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason for so doing.  We are told that the moralist cannot say: Lie
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not, except in great emergencies; but must say: Lie not at all.  But we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are also told that he must grant that there are cases of necessity in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which transgressions of moral rules are excusable; and this looks very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much as if he said: Go on and do the thing while I close my eyes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This hardly seems to give us a "sure and connected knowledge of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: duties of man" deduced from axiomatic principles.  On what authority
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall we suspend for the time being this axiomatic principle or that?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is there some deeper principle which lends to each of them its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: authority, and which may, for cause, withdraw it?  There is no hint of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such in the treatment of ethics which we are considering, and we seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to have on our hands, not so much a science, as a collection of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: practical rules, of the scope of which we are more or less in the dark.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The interesting thing to notice is that this view of ethics is very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: closely akin to that adapted unconsciously by the majority of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons we meet who have not interested themselves much in ethics as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: By the time that we have reached years of discretion we are all in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possession of a considerable number of moral maxims.  We consider it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wrong to steal, to lie, to injure our neighbor.  Such maxims lie in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minds side by side, and we do not commonly think of criticising them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But now and then we face a situation in which one maxim seems to urge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one course of action and another maxim a contrary one.  Shall we tell
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the truth and the whole truth, when so doing will bring grave
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misfortune upon an innocent person?  And now and then we are brought to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the realization that all men do not admit the validity of all our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maxims.  Judgments differ as to what is right and what is wrong.  Who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall be the arbiter?  Not infrequently a rough decision is arrived at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the assumption that we have only to interrogate "conscience"--in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption, in other words, that we carry a watch which can be counted
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon to give the correct time, even if the timepieces of our neighbors
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are not to be depended upon.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The common sense ethics cannot be regarded as very systematic and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consistent, or as very profound.  It is a collection of working rules,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of practical maxims; and, although it is impossible to overestimate its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: value as a guide to life, its deficiencies, when it is looked at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: critically, become evident, I think, even to thoughtful persons who are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not scientific at all.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Many writers on ethics have simply tried to turn this collection of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: working rules into a science, somewhat as Dr. Whewell has done.  This
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the peculiar weakness of those who have been called the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "intuitionalists"--though I must warn the reader against assuming that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this term has but the one meaning, and that all those to whom it has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been applied should be placed in the same class.  Here it is used to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indicate those who maintain that we are directly aware of the validity
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of certain moral principles, must accept them as ultimate, and need
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only concern ourselves with the problem of their application.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 72. ETHICS AND PHILOSOPHY.--When John Locke maintained that there are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no "innate practical principles," or innate moral maxims, he pointed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence to the "enormities practiced without remorse" in different
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ages and by different peoples.  The list he draws up is a curious and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an interesting one.[4]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In our day it has pretty generally come to be recognized by thoughtful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men that a man's judgments as to right and wrong reflect the phase of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: civilization, or the lack of it, which he represents, and that their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance cannot be understood when we consider them apart from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their historic setting.  This means that no man's conscience is set up
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as an ultimate standard, but that every man's conscience is regarded as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: furnishing material which the science of ethics must take into account.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: May we, broadening the basis upon which we are to build, and studying
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the manners, customs, and moral judgments of all sorts and conditions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of men, develop an empirical science of ethics which will be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent of philosophy?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not seem that we can do this.  We are concerned with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychological phenomena, and their nature and significance are by no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means beyond dispute.  For example, there is the feeling of moral
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: obligation, of which ethics has so much to say.  What is this feeling,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and what is its authority?  Is it a thing to be explained?  Can it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: impel a man, let us say, a bigot, to do wrong?  And what can we mean by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: credit and discredit, by responsibility and free choice, and other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concepts of the sort?  All this must remain very vague to one who has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not submitted his ethical concepts to reflective analysis of the sort
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we have a right to call philosophical.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Furthermore, it does not seem possible to decide what a man should or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should not do, without taking into consideration the circumstances in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which he is placed.  The same act may be regarded as benevolent or the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reverse according to its context.  If we will but grant the validity of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the premises from which the medieval churchman reasoned, we may well
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ask whether, in laying hands violently upon those who dared to form
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent judgments in matters of religion, he was not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conscientiously doing his best for his fellow-man.  He tried by all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means to save some, and to what he regarded as a most dangerous malady
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he applied a drastic remedy.  By what standard shall we judge him?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There can be no doubt that our doctrine of the whole duty of man must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be conditioned by our view of the nature of the world in which man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lives and of man's place in the world.  Has ethics nothing to do with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: religion?  If we do not believe in God, and if we think that man's life
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ends with the death of the body, it is quite possible that we shall set
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for him an ethical standard which we should have to modify if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: adopted other beliefs.  The relation of ethics to religion is a problem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the student of ethics can scarcely set aside.  It seems, then,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the study of ethics necessarily carries us back to world problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which cannot be approached except by the path of philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection.  We shall see in Chapter XX that the theistic problem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly belongs to this class.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is worthy of our consideration that the vast majority of writers on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ethics have felt strongly that their science runs out into metaphysics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We can scarcely afford to treat their testimony lightly.  Certainly it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not possible for one who has no knowledge of philosophy to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: understand the significance of the ethical systems which have appeared
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the past.  The history of ethics may be looked upon as a part of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history of philosophy.  Only on the basis of some general view as to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature and man have men decided what man ought to do.  As we have seen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above, this appears sufficiently reasonable.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 73. AESTHETICS.--Of aesthetics, or the science of the beautiful, I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall say little.  There is somewhat the same reason for including it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: among the philosophical sciences that there is for including ethics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Those who have paid little attention to science or to philosophy are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apt to dogmatize about what is and what is not beautiful just as they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: dogmatize about what is and what is not right.  They say
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unhesitatingly; This object is beautiful, and that one is ugly.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as if they said: This one is round, and that one square.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Often it quite escapes their attention that what they now regard as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beautiful struck them as unattractive a short time before; and will,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: perhaps, when the ceaseless change of the fashions has driven it out of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vogue, seem strange and unattractive once more.  Nor do they reflect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon the fact that others, who seem to have as good a right to an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinion as they, do not agree with them in their judgments; nor upon
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the further fact that the standard of beauty is a thing that has varied
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from age to age, differs widely in different countries, and presents
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: minor variations in different classes even in the same community.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The dogmatic utterances of those who are keenly susceptible to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: aesthetic aspects of things but are not given to reflection stand in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: striking contrast to the epitome of the popular wisdom expressed in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: skeptical adage that there is no disputing about tastes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We cannot interpret this adage broadly and take it literally, for then
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we should have to admit that men's judgments as to the beautiful cannot
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constitute the material of a science at all, and that there can be no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such thing as progress in the fine arts.  The notion of progress
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: implies a standard, and an approximation to an ideal.  Few would dare
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to deny that there has been progress in such arts as painting and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: music; and when one has admitted so much as this, one has virtually
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admitted that a science of aesthetics is, at least, possible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The science studies the facts of the aesthetic life as ethics studies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the facts of the moral life.  It can take no man's taste as furnishing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a standard: it must take every man's taste as a fact of significance.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is driven to reflective analysis--to such questions as, what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: beauty? and what is meant by aesthetic progress?  It deals with elusive
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: psychological facts the significance of which is not easily grasped.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is a philosophical science, and is by no means in a position to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: follow a beaten path, dispensing with a reflective analysis of its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: materials.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] Preface.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [2] section 269.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [3] section 376.
