text: CHAPTER XIX
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: METAPHYSICS
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 74. WHAT IS METAPHYSICS?--The reader has probably already remarked that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in some of the preceding chapters the adjectives "metaphysical" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "philosophical" have been used as if they were interchangeable, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain connections, at least.  This is justified by common usage; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the present chapter I shall be expected by no one, I think, to prove
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that metaphysics is a philosophical discipline.  My task will rather be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to show how far the words "metaphysics" and "philosophy" have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different meaning.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In Chapters III to XI, I have given a general view of the problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which present themselves to reflective thought, and I have indicated
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that they are not problems which can conveniently be distributed among
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the several special sciences.  Is there an external world?  What is it?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What are space and time?  What is the mind?  How are mind and body
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: related?  How do we know that there are other minds than ours? etc.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These have been presented as _philosophical_ problems; and when we turn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: back to the history of speculative thought we find that they are just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the problems with which the men whom we agree to call philosophers have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chiefly occupied themselves.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But when we turn to our treatises on _metaphysics_, we also find that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these are the problems there discussed.  Such treatises differ much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: among themselves, and the problems are not presented in the same form
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or in the same order; but one who can look beneath the surface will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: find that the authors are busied with much the same thing--with some or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all of the problems above mentioned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How, then, does metaphysics differ from philosophy?  The difference
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becomes clear to us when we realize that the word philosophy has a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: broader and looser signification, and that metaphysics is, so to speak,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the core, the citadel, of philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen (Chapter II) that the world and the mind, as they seem to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be presented in the experience of the plain man, do not stand forth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with such clearness and distinctness that he is able to answer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intelligently the questions we wish to ask him regarding their nature.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is not merely that his information is limited; it is vague and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indefinite as well.  And we have seen, too, that, however the special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences may increase and systematize his information, they do not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear away such vagueness.  The man still uses such concepts as "inner"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and "outer," "reality," "the mind," "space," and "time," with no very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: definite notion of what they mean.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, the attempt to clear away this vagueness by the systematic
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analysis of such concepts--in other words, the attempt to make a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thorough analysis of our experience--is metaphysics.  The metaphysician
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: strives to limit his task as well as he may, and to avoid unnecessary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: excursions into the fields occupied by the special sciences, even those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which lie nearest to his own, such as psychology and ethics.  There is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a sense in which he may be said to be working in the field of a special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science, though he is using as the material for his investigations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concepts which are employed in many sciences; but it is clear that his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discipline is not a special science in the same sense in which geometry
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and physics are special sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, the special sciences stand, as we have already seen in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the case of several of them, very near to his own.  If he broadens his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: view, and deliberately determines to take a survey of the field of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge as illuminated by the analyses that he has made, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: becomes something more than a _metaphysician_; he becomes a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _philosopher_.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This does not in the least mean that he becomes a storehouse of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: miscellaneous information, and an authority on all the sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sometimes the philosophers have attempted to describe the world of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter and of mind as though they possessed some mysterious power of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowing things that absolved them from the duty of traveling the weary
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: road of observation and experiment that has ended in the sciences as we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have them.  When they have done this, they have mistaken the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of their calling.  A philosopher has no more right than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another man to create information out of nothing.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is possible, even for one who is not acquainted with the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body of facts presented in a science, to take careful note of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions upon which that science rests, to analyze the concepts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which it makes use, to mark the methods which it employs, and to gain a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fair idea of its scope and of its relation to other sciences.  Such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection upon our scientific knowledge is philosophical reflection,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and it may result in a classification of the sciences, and in a general
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: view of human knowledge as a whole.  Such a view may be illuminating in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the extreme; it can only be harmful when its significance is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misunderstood.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, it may be argued, why may not the man of science do all this for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: himself?  Why should he leave it to the philosopher, who is presumably
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: less intimately acquainted with the sciences than he is?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To this I answer: The work should, of course, be done by the man who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will do it best.  All our subdivision of labor should be dictated by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: convenience.  But I add, that experience has shown that the workers in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the special sciences have not as a rule been very successful when they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have tried to philosophize.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Science is an imperious mistress; she demands one's utmost efforts; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when a man turns to philosophical reflection merely "by the way," and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the scraps of time at his disposal after the day's work is done, his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical work is apt to be rather superficial.  Moreover, it does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not follow that, because a man is a good mathematician or chemist or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physicist, he is gifted with the power of reflective analysis.  Then,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: too, such men are apt to be imperfectly acquainted with what has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: done in the past; and those who are familiar with the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy often have occasion to remark that what is laid before them,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in ignorance of the fact that it is neither new nor original, is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine which has already made its appearance in many forms and has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been discussed at prodigious length in the centuries gone by.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In certain sciences it seems possible to ignore the past, to a great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extent, at least.  What is worth keeping has been kept, and there is a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solid foundation on which to build for the future.  But with reflective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought it is not so.  There is no accepted body of doctrine which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have the right to regard as unassailable.  We should take it as a safe
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maxim that the reflections of men long dead _may_ be profounder and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more worthy of our study than those urged upon our attention by the men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our day.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And this leads me to make a remark upon the titles given to works on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysics.  It seems somewhat misleading to label them: "Outlines of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Metaphysics" or "Elements of Metaphysics."  Such titles suggest that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are dealing with a body of doctrine which has met with general
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acceptance, and may be compared with that found in handbooks on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: special sciences.  But we should realize that, when we are concerned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the profounder investigations into the nature of our experience,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we tread upon uncertain ground and many differences of opinion obtain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We should, if possible, avoid a false semblance of authority.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 75. EPISTEMOLOGY.--We hear a great deal at the present day of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Epistemology, or the Theory of Knowledge.  I have not classed it as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinct philosophical science, for reasons which will appear below.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen in Chapter XVI that it is possible to treat of logic in a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simple way without growing very metaphysical; but we have also seen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that when we go deeply into questions touching the nature of evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and what is meant by truth and falsity, we are carried back to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical reflection at once.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, for convenience, group together these deeper questions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarding the nature of knowledge and its scope, and call the subject
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our study "Epistemology."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it should be remarked, in the first place, that, when we work in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this field, we are exercising a reflective analysis of precisely the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: type employed in making the metaphysical analyses contained in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earlier chapters of this book.  We are treating our experience as it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not treated in common thought and in science.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And it should be remarked, in the second place, that the investigation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our knowledge inevitably runs together with an investigation into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the nature of things known, of the mind and the world.  Suppose that I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: give the titles of the chapters in Part III of Mr. Hobhouse's able work
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on "The Theory of Knowledge."  They are as follows: Validity; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Validity of Knowledge; the Conception of External Reality; Substance;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the Conception of Self; Reality as a System; Knowledge and Reality; the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Grounds of Knowledge and Belief.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Are not these topics metaphysical?  Let us ask ourselves how it would
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: affect our views of the validity and of the limits of our knowledge, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we were converted to the metaphysical doctrines of John Locke, or of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Bishop Berkeley, or of David Hume, or of Thomas Reid, or of Immanuel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kant.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, then, regard epistemology as a part of logic--the metaphysical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part--or as a part of metaphysics; it does not much matter which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: call it, since we mean the same thing.  But its relation to metaphysics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is such that it does not seem worth while to call it a separate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discipline.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Before leaving this subject there is one more point upon which I should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: touch, if only to obviate a possible misunderstanding.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We find in Professor Cornelius's clear little book, "An Introduction to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Philosophy" (Leipzig, 1903; it has unhappily not yet been translated
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into English), that metaphysics is repudiated altogether, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: epistemology is set in its place.  But this rejection of metaphysics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not necessarily imply the denial of the value of such an analysis
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our experience as I have in this work called metaphysical.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Metaphysics is taken to mean, not an analysis of experience, but a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: groping behind the veil of phenomena for some reality not given in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience.  In other words, what Professor Cornelius condemns is what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: many of the rest of us also condemn under another name.  What he calls
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysics, we call bad metaphysics; and what he calls epistemology,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we call metaphysics.  The dispute is really a dispute touching the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proper name to apply to reflective analysis of a certain kind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As it is the fashion in certain quarters to abuse metaphysics, I set
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reader on his guard.  Some kinds of metaphysics certainly ought to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be repudiated under whatever name they may be presented to us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XX
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: THE PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 76. RELIGION AND REFLECTION.--A man may be through and through ethical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in his thought and feeling, and yet know nothing of the science of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ethics.  He may be possessed of the finest aesthetic taste, and yet may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know nothing of the science of aesthetics.  It is one thing to be good,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and another to know clearly what goodness means; it is one thing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: love the beautiful, and another to know how to define it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Just so a man may be thoroughly religious, and may, nevertheless, have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflected very little upon his religious belief and the foundations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon which it rests.  This does not mean that his belief is without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: foundation.  It may have a firm basis or it may not.  But whatever the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: case may be, he is not in a position to say much about it.  He _feels_
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he is right, but he cannot prove it.  The man is, I think we must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: admit, rather blind as to the full significance of his position, and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is, in consequence, rather helpless.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such a man is menaced by certain dangers.  We have seen in the chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: on ethics that men are by no means at one in their judgments as to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rightness or wrongness of given actions.  And it requires a very little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection to teach us that men are not at one in their religious
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: notions.  God and His nature, the relation of God to man, what the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: religious life should be, these things are the subject of much dispute;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and some men hold opinions regarded by others as not merely erroneous
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but highly pernicious in their influence.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Shall a man simply assume that the opinions which he happens to hold
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are correct, and that all who differ with him are in error?  He has not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: framed his opinions quite independently for himself.  We are all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influenced by what we have inherited from the past, and what we inherit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may be partly erroneous, even if we be right in the main.  Moreover, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are all liable to prejudices, and he who has no means of distinguishing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such from sober truths may admit into his creed many errors.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lesson of history is very instructive upon this point.  The fact is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that a man's religious notions reflect the position which he occupies
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the development of civilization very much as do his ethical notions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  Even supposing that a man has enlightened notions and is living
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a religious life that the most instructed must approve; if he has never
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflected, and has never tried to make clear to himself just what he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: really does believe and upon what grounds he believes it, how will it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be with him when his position is attacked by another?  Men are, as I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have said, not at one in these matters, and there are few or none of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the doctrines put forward as religions that have not been attacked
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: again and again.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, those who depend only upon an instinctive feeling may be placed in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the very painful position of seeing no answer to the objections brought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: against them.  What is said may seem plausible; it may even seem true,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and is it right for a man to oppose what appears to be the truth?  One
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may be shocked and pained, and may feel that he who makes the assault
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _cannot_ be right, and yet may be forced to admit that a relentless
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: logic, or what presents itself as such, has every appearance of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: establishing the repellent truth that robs one of one's dearest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possession.  The situation is an unendurable one; it is that of the man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who guards a treasure and recognizes that there is no lock on the door.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Surely, if there is error mixed with truth in our religious beliefs, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is desirable that we should have some way of distinguishing between the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth and the error.  And if our beliefs really have a foundation, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is desirable that we should know what that foundation is, and should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not be at the mercy of every passer-by who takes the notion to throw a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stone at us.  But these desirable ends, it seems clear, cannot be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained without reflection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 77. THE PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION.--The reflection that busies itself with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these things results in what is called the philosophy of religion.  To
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: show that the name is an appropriate one and that we are concerned with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a philosophical discipline, I shall take up for a moment the idea of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: God, which most men will admit has a very important place in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conception of religion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Does God exist?  We may feel very sure that He does, and yet be forced
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to admit that the evidence of His existence is not so clear and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undeniable as to compel the assent of every one.  We do not try to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prove the existence of the men we meet and who talk to us.  No one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinks of denying their existence; it is taken for granted.  Even the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: metaphysician, when he takes up and discusses the question whether we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can prove the existence of any mind beyond our own, does not seriously
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doubt whether there are other minds or not.  It is not so much what we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know, as how we know it, that interests him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But with the existence of God it is different.  That men do not think
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that an examination of the evidence can be dispensed with is evident
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the books that are written and lectures that are delivered year
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: after year.  There seem to be honest differences of opinion, and we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: feel compelled to offer men proofs--to show that belief is reasonable.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: How shall we determine whether this world in which we live is such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world that we may take it as a revelation of God?  And of what sort of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a Being are we speaking when we use the word "God"?  The question is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not an idle one, for men's conceptions have differed widely.  There is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the savage, with a conception that strikes the modern civilized man as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: altogether inadequate; there is the thoughtful man of our day, who has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inherited the reflections of those who have lived in the ages gone by.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And there is the philosopher, or, perhaps, I should rather say, there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are the philosophers.  Have they not conceived of God as a group of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: abstract notions, or as a something that may best be described as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unknowable, or as the Substance which is the identity of thought and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extension, or as the external world itself?  All have not sinned in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this way, but some have, and they are not men whom we can ignore.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we turn from all such notions and, in harmony with the faith of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: great body of religious men in the ages past, some of whom were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers but most of whom were not, cling close to the notion that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: God is a mind or spirit, and must be conceived according to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analogy, at least, of the human mind, the mind we most directly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know--if we do this, we are still confronted by problems to which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughtful man cannot refuse attention.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: What do we mean by a mind?  This is a question to which one can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scarcely give an intelligent answer unless one has exercised one's
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: faculty of philosophic reflection.  And upon what sort of evidence does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one depend in establishing the existence of minds other than one's own?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This has been discussed at length in Chapter X, and the problem is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certainly a metaphysical one.  And if we believe that the Divine Mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not subject to the limitations which confine the human, how shall we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceive it?  The question is an important one.  Some of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers and theologians who have tried to free the Divine Mind
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from such limitations have taken away every positive mark by which we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize a mind to be such, and have left us a naked "Absolute" which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is no better than a labeled vacuum.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, we cannot refuse to consider the question of God's relation
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the world.  This seems to lead back to the broader question: How are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we to conceive of any mind as related to the world?  What is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: relation between mind and matter?  If any subject of inquiry may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: properly be called metaphysical, surely this may be.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We see, then, that there is little wonder that the thoughtful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consideration of the facts and doctrines of religion has taken its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: place among the philosophical sciences.  Aesthetics has been called
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: applied psychology; and I think it is scarcely too much to say that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are here concerned with applied metaphysics, with the attempt to obtain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a clear understanding of the significance of the facts of religion in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the light of those ultimate analyses which reveal to us the real nature
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the world of matter and of minds.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XXI
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: PHILOSOPHY AND THE OTHER SCIENCES
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 78. THE PHILOSOPHICAL AND NON-PHILOSOPHICAL SCIENCES.--We have seen in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the preceding chapters that certain of the sciences can scarcely be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cultivated successfully in complete separation from philosophy.  It has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: also been indicated in various places that the relation of other
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences to philosophy is not so close.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the sciences of arithmetic, algebra, and geometry may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successfully prosecuted by a man who has reflected little upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature of numbers and who has never asked himself seriously what he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: means by space.  The assumptions which he is justified in making, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the kind of operations which he has the right to perform, do not seem,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a rule, to be in doubt.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So it is also in the sciences of chemistry and physics.  There is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing to prevent the chemist or the physicist from being a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher, but he is not compelled to be one.  He may push forward
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the investigations proper to his profession regardless of the type of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy which it pleases him to adopt.  Whether he be a realist or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: an idealist, a dualist or a monist, he should, as chemist or physicist,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: treat the same sort of facts in the same sort of a way.  His path
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appears to be laid out for him, and he can do work the value of which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is undisputed by traveling quietly along it, and without stopping to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consider consciously what kind of a path it is.  There are many who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: work in this way, and they succeed in making important contributions to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Such sciences as these I call the non-philosophical sciences to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distinguish them from the group of sciences I have been discussing at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: length.  What marks them out is, that the facts with which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigator has to deal are known by him with sufficient clearness to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: leave him usually in little doubt as to the use which he can make of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them.  His knowledge is clear enough for the purpose in hand, and his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: work is justified by its results.  What is the relation of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences as these to philosophy?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 79. THE STUDY OF SCIENTIFIC PRINCIPLES AND METHODS.--It is one thing to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have the instinct of the investigator and to be able to feel one's way
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: along the road that leads to new knowledge of a given kind, and it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another thing to have the reflective turn of mind that makes one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly conscious of just what one has been doing and how one has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doing it.  Men reasoned before there was a science of logic, and the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences made their appearance before what may be called the logic of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sciences had its birth.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "It may be truly asserted," writes Professor Jevons,[1] "that the rapid
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: progress of the physical sciences during the last three centuries has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not been accompanied by a corresponding advance in the theory of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasoning.  Physicists speak familiarly of Scientific Method, but they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: could not readily describe what they mean by that expression.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Profoundly engaged in the study of particular classes of natural
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: phenomena, they are usually too much engrossed in the immense and ever
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accumulating details of their special sciences to generalize upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: methods of reasoning which they unconsciously employ.  Yet few will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deny that these methods of reasoning ought to be studied, especially by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those who endeavor to introduce scientific order into less successful
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and methodical branches of knowledge."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Professor Jevons suggests that it is lack of time and attention that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prevents the scientific investigator from attaining to a clear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conception of what is meant by scientific method.  This has something
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to do with it, but I think we may also maintain that the work of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigator and that of the critic are somewhat different in kind, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: require somewhat different powers of mind.  We find a parallel to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: elsewhere.  Both in literature and in art men may be in the best sense
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: productive, and yet may be poor critics.  We are often wofully
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: disappointed when we attend a lecture on poetry by a poet, or one on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: painting by an artist.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It may be said: If what is maintained above regarding the possibility
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of prosecuting scientific researches without having recourse to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflective thought is true, why should the man of science care whether
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the principles and methods of the non-philosophical sciences are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigated or are merely taken for granted?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I answer: It should be observed that the statements made in the last
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section were somewhat guarded.  I have used the expressions "as a rule"
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and "usually."  I have spoken thus because one can work in the way
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: described, without danger of error, only where a beaten track has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained and is followed.  In Chapter XVI it was pointed out that even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the mathematical sciences one may be forced to reflect upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of one's symbols.  As I write this, a pamphlet comes to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hand which is concerned to prove that "every cause is potentially
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: capable of producing several effects," and proves it by claiming that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the square root of four ([square root symbol]4) is a _cause_ which may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have as _effect_ either two (2) or minus two (-2).
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is this mathematical reasoning?  Are mathematical relations ever those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of cause and effect?  And may one on the basis of such reasonings claim
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that in nature the relation of cause and effect is not a fixed and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: invariable one?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Even where there is a beaten track, there is some danger that men may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wander from it.  And on the confines of our knowledge there are fields
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in which the accepted road is yet to be established.  Science makes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constant use of hypotheses as an aid to investigation.  What hypotheses
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may one frame, and what are inadmissible?  How important an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigation of this question may be to the worker in certain branches
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of science will be clear to one who will read with attention Professor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Poincare's brilliant little work on "Science and Hypothesis." [2]
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There is no field in art, literature, or science in which the work of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the critic is wholly superfluous.  "There are periods in the growth of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science," writes Professor Pearson in his deservedly popular work, "The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Grammar of Science," [3] "when it is well to turn our attention from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: its imposing superstructure and to examine carefully its foundations.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The present book is primarily intended as a criticism of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental concepts of modern science, and as such finds its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justification in the motto placed upon its title-page."  The motto in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question is a quotation from the French philosopher Cousin: "Criticism
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is the life of science."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have seen in Chapter XVI that a work on logic may be a comparatively
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simple thing.  It may describe the ways in which men reason when they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason correctly, and may not go deep into metaphysical questions.  On
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the other hand, it may be deeply metaphysical.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we approach the part of logic which deals with the principles and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: methods of the sciences, this difference is forced upon our attention.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One may set forth the assumptions upon which a science rests, and may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: describe the methods of investigation employed, without going much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: below the plane of common thought.  As a type of such works I may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mention the useful treatise by Professor Jevons cited earlier in this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chapter.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, our investigations may be more profound, and we may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scrutinize the very foundations upon which a science rests.  Both the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other works referred to illustrate this method of procedure.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For example, in "The Grammar of Science," we find our author
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussing, under the title "The Facts of Science," such problems as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the following: the Reality of Things; Sense-impressions and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Consciousness; the Nature of Thought; the External Universe; Sensations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as the Ultimate Source of the Materials of Knowledge; and the Futility
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of "Things-in-themselves."  The philosophical character of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussions does not need to be pointed out at length.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [1] "The Principles Of Science," London, 1874, Preface.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [2] English translation, New York, 1905.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: [3] Second edition, London, 1900.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: VI. ON THE STUDY OF PHILOSOPHY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XXII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: THE VALUE OF THE STUDY OF PHILOSOPHY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 80. THE QUESTION OF PRACTICAL UTILITY.--Why should men study
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy?  The question is a natural one, for man is a rational
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: being, and when the worth of a thing is not at once evident to him, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: usually calls for proof of its worth.  Our professional schools, with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the exception of schools of theology, usually pay little attention to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical studies; but such studies occupy a strong position in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: colleges, and a vast number of persons not students in the technical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense think it worth while to occupy themselves with them more or less.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Wherever liberal studies are prosecuted they have their place, and it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is an honored place.  Is this as it should be?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Before we ask whether any given study is of practical value, it is wise
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to determine what the word "practical" shall be taken to mean.  Shall
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we say that we may call practical only such learning as can be turned
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to direct account in earning money later?  If we restrict the meaning
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the word in this way, we seem to strike a blow at liberal studies in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, no one would think of maintaining that the study of mathematics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not of practical value--sometimes and to some persons.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physicist and the engineer need to know a good deal about mathematics.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But how is it with the merchant, the lawyer, the clergyman, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physician?  How much of their algebra, geometry, and trigonometry do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these remember after they have become absorbed in the practice of their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: several callings, and how often do they find it necessary to use
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: anything beyond certain simple rules of arithmetic?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sometimes we are tempted to condemn the study of the classics as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unpractical, and to turn instead to the modern languages and to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical sciences.  Now, it is, of course, a fair question to ask what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should and what should not be regarded as forming part of a liberal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: education, and I shall make no effort to decide the question here.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it should be borne well in mind that one cannot decide it by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: determining what studies are practical in the sense of the word under
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussion.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we keep strictly to this sense, the modern languages are to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: majority of Americans of little more practical value than are the Latin
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and Greek.  We scarcely need them except when we travel abroad, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when we do that we find that the concierge and the waiter use English
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with surprising fluency.  As for the sciences, those who expect to earn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a living through a knowledge of them, seek, as a rule, that knowledge
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in a technical or professional school, and the rest of us can enjoy the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fruit of their labors without sharing them.  It is a popular fallacy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that because certain studies have a practical value to the world at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: large, they must necessarily have a practical value to every one, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: can be recommended to the individual on that account.  It is worth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: while to sit down quietly and ask oneself how many of the bits of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: information acquired during the course of a liberal education are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: directly used in the carrying on of a given business or in the practice
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of a given profession.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nevertheless, we all believe that liberal education is a good thing for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the individual and for the race.  One must not too much restrict the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaning of the word "practical."  A civilized state composed of men who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know nothing save what has a direct bearing upon their especial work in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: life is an absurdity; it cannot exist.  There must be a good deal of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general enlightenment and there must be a considerable number of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individuals who have enjoyed a high measure of enlightenment.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This becomes clear if we consider the part played in the life of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: state by the humblest tradesman.  If he is to be successful, he must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: able to read, write, and keep his accounts, and make, let us say,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shoes.  But when we have said this, we have summed him up as a workman,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but not as a man, and he is also a man.  He may marry, and make a good
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: or a bad husband, and a good or a bad father.  He stands in relations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to his neighborhood, to the school, and to the church; and he is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without his influence.  He may be temperate or intemperate, frugal or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extravagant, law-abiding or the reverse.  He has his share, and no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: small share, in the government of his city and of his state.  His
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence is indeed far-reaching, and that it may be an influence for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: good, he is in need of all the intellectual and moral enlightenment
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we can give him.  It is of the utmost practical utility to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: state that he should know a vast number of things which have no direct
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bearing upon the making and mending of shoes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And if this is true in the case of the tradesman, it is scarcely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: necessary to point out that the physician, the lawyer, the clergyman,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the whole army of those whom we regard as the leaders of men and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the molders of public opinion have spheres of non-professional activity
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of great importance to the state.  They cannot be mere specialists if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they would.  They must influence society for good or ill; and if they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are ignorant and unenlightened, their influence cannot be good.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we consider the life of man in a broad way, we see how essential
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is that many men should be brought to have a share in what has been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gained by the long travail of the centuries past.  It will not do to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ask at every step whether they can put to direct professional use every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bit of information gained.  Literature and science, sweetness and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: light, beauty and truth, these are the heritage of the modern world;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and unless these permeate its very being, society must undergo
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: degeneration.  It is this conviction that has led to the high
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appreciation accorded by intelligent men to courses of liberal study,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and among such courses those which we have recognized as philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must take their place.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 81. WHY PHILOSOPHICAL STUDIES ARE USEFUL.--But let us ask a little more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: specifically what is to be gained by pursuing distinctively
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical studies.  Why should those who go to college, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intelligent persons who cannot go to college, care to interest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves in logic and ethics, psychology and metaphysics?  Are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: these studies rather dry, in the first place, and rather profitless, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the second?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: As to the first point, I should stoutly maintain that if they are dry,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is somebody's fault.  The most sensational of novels would be dry if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: couched in the language which some philosophers have seen fit to use in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expressing their thoughts.  He who defines "existence" as "the still
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and simple precipitate of the oscillation between beginning to be and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ceasing to be" has done his best to alienate our affections from the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 82. METAPHYSICS AND PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION.--Perhaps it will be said:

title: An Introduction to Philosophy

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves devoted little attention to philosophy?  It would be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interesting to know how many, to whom Spencer is but a name, have felt
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the influence of the agnosticism of which he was the apostle.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I say this without meaning to criticise here any of the types of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine referred to.  My thesis is only that philosophy and life go
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hand in hand, and that the prying into the deeper mysteries of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: universe cannot be regarded as a matter of no practical moment.  Its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: importance ought to be admitted even by the man who has little hope
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he will himself be able to attain to a doctrine wholly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfactory and wholly unshakable.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For, if the study of the problems of metaphysics does nothing else for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a given individual, it, at least, enables him to comprehend and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: criticise intelligently the doctrines which are presented for his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: acceptance by others.  It is a painful thing to feel quite helpless in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the face of plausible reasonings which may threaten to rob us of our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: most cherished hopes, or may tend to persuade us of the vanity of what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we have been accustomed to regard as of highest worth.  If we are quite
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unskilled in the examination of such doctrines, we may be captured by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the loosest of arguments--witness the influence of Spencer's argument
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the "Unknowable," in the "First Principles"; and if we are ignorant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the history of speculative thought, we may be carried away by old
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and exploded notions which pose as modern and impressive only because
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they have been given a modern dress.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We can, of course, refuse to listen to those who would talk with us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But this savors of bigotry, and the world will certainly not grow
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wiser, if men generally cultivate a blind adherence to the opinions in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they happen to be brought up.  A cautious conservatism is one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thing, and blind obstinacy is another.  To the educated man (and it is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: probable that others will have to depend on opinions taken at second
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hand) a better way of avoiding error is open.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Finally, it will not do to overlook the broadening influence of such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: studies as we are discussing.  How dogmatically men are in the habit of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expressing themselves upon those obscure and difficult problems which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deal with matters that lie on the confines of human knowledge!  Such an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption of knowledge cannot but make us uncomprehending and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unsympathetic.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are many subjects upon which, if we hold an opinion at all, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should hold it tentatively, waiting for more light, and retaining a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: willingness to be enlightened.  Many a bitter and fruitless quarrel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: might be avoided, if more persons found it possible to maintain this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical attitude of mind.  Philosophy is, after all, reflection,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and the reflective man must realize that he is probably as liable to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error as are other men.  He is not infallible, nor has the limit of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: human knowledge been attained in his day and generation.  He who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: realizes this will not assume that his neighbor is always wrong, and he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will come to have that wide, conscientious tolerance, which is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indifference, but which is at the farthest remove from the zeal of mere
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bigotry.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart
