text: CHAPTER XXIII
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: WHY WE SHOULD STUDY THE HISTORY OF PHILOSOPHY
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 83. THE PROMINENCE GIVEN TO THE SUBJECT.--When one reflects upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: number of lecture courses given every year at our universities and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: colleges on the history of philosophy, one is struck by the fact that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy is not treated as are most other subjects with which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: student is brought into contact.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we study mathematics, or chemistry, or physics, or physiology, or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: biology, the effort is made to lay before us in a convenient form the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: latest results which have been attained in those sciences.  Of their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history very little is said; and, indeed, as we have seen (section 6),
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lectures on the history of the inductive sciences are apt to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as philosophical in their character and aims rather than as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: merely scientific.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The interest in the history of philosophy is certainly not a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: diminishing one.  Text-books covering the whole field or a part of it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are multiplied; extensive studies are made and published covering the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: work of individual philosophers; innumerable historical discussions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: make their appearance in the pages of current philosophical journals.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: No student is regarded as fairly acquainted with philosophy who knows
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing of Plato and Aristotle, Descartes and Spinoza, Berkeley and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Hume, Kant and Hegel, and the rest.  We should look upon him as having
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a very restricted outlook if he had read only the works of the thinkers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of our own day; indeed, we should not expect him to have a proper
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: comprehension even of these, for their chapters must remain blind and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meaningless to one who has no knowledge of what preceded them and has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given birth to the doctrines there set forth.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is a fair question to ask: Why is philosophy so bound up with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: study of the past?  Why may we not content ourselves with what has up
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the present been attained, and omit a survey of the road along which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our predecessors have traveled?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 84. THE ESPECIAL IMPORTANCE OF HISTORICAL STUDIES TO REFLECTIVE
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: THOUGHT.--In some of the preceding chapters dealing with the various
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical sciences, it has been indicated that, in the sciences we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: do not regard as philosophical, men may work on the basis of certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: commonly accepted assumptions and employ methods which are generally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: regarded as trustworthy within the given field.  The value both of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fundamental assumptions and of the methods of investigation appear to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be guaranteed by the results attained.  There are not merely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observation and hypothesis; there is also verification, and where this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is lacking, men either abandon their position or reserve their judgment.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, a certain body of interrelated facts is built up, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of which, in many fields at least, is apparent even to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: layman.  Nor is it wholly beyond him to judge whether the results of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific investigations can be verified.  An eclipse, calculated by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: methods which he is quite unable to follow, may occur at the appointed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hour and confirm his respect for the astronomer.  The efficacy of a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: serum in the cure of diseases may convince him that work done in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: laboratory is not labor lost.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems evident that the several sciences do really rise on stepping
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stones of their dead selves, and that those selves of the past are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: really dead and superseded.  Who would now think of going back for his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science to Plato's "Timaeus," or would accept the description of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physical world contained in the works of Aristotle?  What chemist or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: physicist need busy himself with the doctrine of atoms and their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clashings presented in the magnificent poem of Lucretius?  Who can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: forbear a smile--a sympathetic one--when he turns over the pages of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Augustine's "City of God," and sees what sort of a world this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remarkable man believed himself to inhabit?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is the historic and human interest that carries us back to these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things.  We say: What ingenuity! what a happy guess! how well that was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasoned in the light of what was actually known about the world in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those days!  But we never forget that what compels our admiration does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so because it makes us realize that we stand in the presence of a great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind, and not because it is a foundation-stone in the great edifice
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which science has erected.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But it is not so in philosophy.  It is not possible to regard the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical reflections of Plato and of Aristotle as superseded in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same sense in which we may so regard their science.  The reason for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this lies in the difference between scientific thought and reflective
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The two have been contrasted in Chapter II of this volume.  It was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there pointed out that the sort of thinking demanded in the special
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sciences is not so very different from that with which we are all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: familiar in common life.  Science is more accurate and systematic, it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has a broader outlook, and it is free from the imperfections which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vitiate the uncritical and fragmentary knowledge which experience of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the world yields the unscientific.  But, after all, the world is much
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the same sort of a world to the man of science and to his uncritical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: neighbor.  The latter can, as we have seen, understand what, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: general, the former is doing, and can appropriate many of his results.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, it often happens that the man who has not, with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: pains and labor, learned to reflect, cannot even see that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher has a genuine problem before him.  Thus, the plain man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accepts the fact that he has a mind and that it knows the world.  That
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: both mental phenomena and physical phenomena should be carefully
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: observed and classified he may be ready to admit.  But that the very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceptions of mind and of what it means to know a world are vague and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indefinite in the extreme, and stand in need of careful analysis, he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: does not realize.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In other words, he sees that our knowledge needs to be extended and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rendered more accurate and reliable, but he does not see that, if we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are to think clearly and consciously, all our knowledge needs to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: gone over in a different way.  In common life it is quite possible to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: use in the attainment of practical ends knowledge which has not been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analyzed and of the full meaning of which we are ignorant.  I hope it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has become evident in the course of this volume that something closely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: analogous is true in the field of science.  The man of science may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: measure space and time, and may study the phenomena of the human mind,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without even attempting to answer all the questions which may be raised
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as to what is meant, in the last analysis, by such concepts as space,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: time, and the mind.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That such concepts should be analyzed has, I hope, been made clear, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only that erroneous and misleading notions as to these things should be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: avoided.  But when a man with a genius for metaphysical analysis
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: addresses himself to this task, he cannot simply hand the results
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained by his reflections over to his less reflective fellow-man.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: His words are not understood; he seems to be dealing with shadows, with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unrealities; he has passed from the real world of common thought into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another world which appears to have little relation to the former.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor can verification, indubitable proof, be demanded and furnished as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it can in many parts of the field cultivated by the special sciences.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may judge science fairly well without ourselves being scientists,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but it is not possible to judge philosophy without being to some extent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a philosopher.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In other words, the conclusions of reflective thought must be judged by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: following the process and discovering its cogency or the reverse.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, when the philosopher lays before us an argument to prove that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must regard the only ultimate reality in the world as unknowable, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must abandon our theistic convictions, how shall we make a decision as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to whether he is right or is wrong?  May we expect that the day will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come when he will be justified or condemned as is the astronomer on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: day predicted for an eclipse?  Neither the philosophy of Locke, nor
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that of Descartes, nor that of Kant, can be vindicated as can a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prediction touching an eclipse of the sun.  To judge these men, we must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: learn to think with them, to survey the road by which they travel; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this we cannot do until we have learned the art.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Whether we like to admit it or not, we must admit, if we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fair-minded and intelligent, that philosophy cannot speak with the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: authority as science, where science has been able to verify its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: results.  There are, of course, scientific hypotheses and speculations
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which should be regarded as being quite as uncertain as anything
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brought forward by the philosophers.  But, admitting this, the fact
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remains that there is a difference between the two fields as a whole,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and that the philosopher should learn not to speak with an assumption
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of authority.  No final philosophy has been attained, so palpably firm
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in its foundation, and so admittedly trustworthy in its construction,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we are justified in saying: Now we need never go back to the past
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unless to gratify the historic interest.  It is a weakness of young
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men, and of older men of partisan temper, to feel very sure of matters
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which, in the nature of things, must remain uncertain.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Since these things are so, and since men possess the power of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection in very varying degree, it is not surprising that we find it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: worth while to turn back and study the thoughts of those who have had a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: genius for reflection, even though they lived at a time when modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: science was awaiting its birth.  Some things cannot be known until
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other things are known; often there must be a vast collection of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: individual facts before the generalizations of science can come into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: being.  But many of the problems with which reflective thought is still
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: struggling have not been furthered in the least by information which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: has been collected during the centuries which have elapsed since they
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: were attacked by the early Greek philosophers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we are still discussing the distinction between "appearance" and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "reality," and many and varied are the opinions at which philosophers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arrive.  But Thales, who heads the list of the Greek philosophers, had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: quite enough material, given in his own experience, to enable him to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solve this problem as well as any modern philosopher, had he been able
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to use the material.  He who is familiar with the history of philosophy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will recognize that, although one may smile at Augustine's accounts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the races of men, and of the spontaneous generation of small animals,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no one has a right to despise his profound reflections upon the nature
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of time and the problems which arise out of its character as past,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: present, and future.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The fact is that metaphysics does not lag behind because of our lack of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material to work with.  The difficulties we have to face are nothing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: else than the difficulties of reflective thought.  Why can we not tell
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clearly what we mean when we use the word "self," or speak of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "knowledge," or insist that we know an "external world"?  Are we not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: concerned with the most familiar of experiences?  To be sure we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are--with experiences familiarly, but vaguely and unanalytically, known
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and, hence, only half known.  All these experiences the great men of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the past had as well as we; and if they had greater powers of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection, perhaps they saw more deeply into them than we do.  At any
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rate, we cannot afford to assume that they did not.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One thing, however, I must not omit to mention.  Although one man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot turn over bodily the results of his reflection to another, it by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: no means follows that he cannot give the other a helping hand, or warn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him of dangers by himself stumbling into pitfalls, as the case may be.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We have an indefinite advantage over the solitary thinkers who opened
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: up the paths of reflection, for we have the benefit of their teaching.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And this brings me to a consideration which I must discuss in the next
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: section.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 85. THE VALUE OF DIFFERENT POINTS OF VIEW.--The man who has not read is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: like the man who has not traveled--he is not an intelligent critic, for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he has nothing with which to compare what falls within the little
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: circle of his experiences.  That the prevailing architecture of a town
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is ugly can scarcely impress one who is acquainted with no other town.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we live in a community in which men's manners are not good, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their standard of living not the highest, our attention does not dwell
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much upon the fact, unless some contrasted experience wakes within us a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: clear consciousness of the difference.  That to which we are accustomed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we accept uncritically and unreflectively.  It is difficult for us to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see it somewhat as one might see it to whom it came as a new experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Of course, there may be in the one town buildings of more and of less
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: architectural beauty; and there may be in the one community differences
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of opinion that furnish intellectual stimulus and keep awake the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: critical spirit.  Still, there is such a thing as a prevalent type of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: architecture, and there is such a thing as the spirit of the times.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who is carried along by the spirit of the age may easily conclude that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is, is right, because he hears few raise their voices in protest.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To estimate justly the type of thought in which he has been brought up,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he must have something with which to compare it.  He must stand at a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distance, and try to judge it as he would judge a type of doctrine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: presented to him for the first rime.  And in the accomplishment of this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: task he can find no greater aid than the study of the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is at first something of a shock to a man to discover that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumptions which he has been accustomed to make without question have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been frankly repudiated by men quite as clever as he, and, perhaps,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more critical.  It opens the eyes to see that his standards of worth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have been weighed by others and have been found wanting.  It may well
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: incline him to reexamine reasonings in which he has detected no flaw,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: when he finds that acute minds have tried them before, and have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: declared them faulty.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Nor can it be without its influence upon his judgment of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance of a doctrine, when it becomes plain to him that this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance can scarcely be fully comprehended until the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the doctrine is known.  For example, he thinks of the mind as somehow
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in the body, as interacting with it, as a substance, and as immaterial.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the course of his reading it begins to dawn upon his consciousness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he has not thought all this out for himself; he has taken these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: notions from others, who in turn have had them from their predecessors.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: He begins to realize that he is not resting upon evidence independently
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: found in his own experience, but has upon his hands a sheaf of opinions
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which are the echoes of old philosophies, and whose rise and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: development can be traced over the stretch of the centuries.  Can he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: help asking himself, when he sees this, whether the opinions in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: question express the truth and the whole truth?  Is he not forced to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take the critical attitude toward them?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And when he views the succession of systems which pass in review before
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: him, noting how a truth may be dimly seen by one writer, denied by
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another, taken up again and made clearer by a third, and so on, how can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: he avoid the reflection that, as there was some error mixed with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth presented in earlier systems, so there probably is some error in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whatever may happen to be the form of doctrine generally received in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his own time?  The evolution of humanity is not yet at an end; men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: still struggle to see clearly, and fall short of the ideal; it must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a good thing to be freed from the dogmatic assumption of finality
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: natural to the man of limited outlook.  In studying the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy sympathetically we are not merely calling to our aid critics
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who possess the advantage of seeing things from a different point of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: view, but we are reminding ourselves that we, too, are human and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fallible.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 86. PHILOSOPHY AS POETRY, AND PHILOSOPHY AS SCIENCE.--The recognition
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the truth that the problems of reflection do not admit of easy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: solution and that verification can scarcely be expected as it can in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the fields of the special sciences, need not, even when it is brought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: home to us, as it is apt to be, by the study of the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy, lead us to believe that philosophies are like the fashions,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a something gotten up to suit the taste of the day, and to be dismissed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without regret as soon as that taste changes.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Philosophy is sometimes compared with poetry.  It is argued that each
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: age must have its own poetry, even though it be inferior to that which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it has inherited from the past.  Just so, it is said, each age must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have its own philosophy, and the philosophy of an earlier age will not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfy its demands.  The implication is that in dealing with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy we are not concerned with what is true or untrue in itself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: considered, but with what is satisfying to us or the reverse.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, it would sound absurd to say that each age must have its own
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: geometry or its own physics.  The fact that it has long been known that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the sum of the interior angles of a plane triangle is equal to two
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right angles, does not warrant me in repudiating that truth; nor am I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: justified in doing so, and in believing the opposite, merely because I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: find the statement uninteresting or distasteful.  When we are dealing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with such matters as these, we recognize that truth is truth, and that,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: if we mistake it or refuse to recognize it, so much the worse for us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Is it otherwise in philosophy?  Is it a perfectly proper thing that, in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one age, men should be idealists, and in another, materialists; in one,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theists, and in another, agnostics?  Is the distinction between true
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and false nothing else than the distinction between what is in harmony
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with the spirit of the times and what is not?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That it is natural that there should be such fluctuations of opinion,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we may freely admit.  Many things influence a man to embrace a given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: type of doctrine, and, as we have seen, verification is a difficult
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: problem.  But have we here, any more than in other fields, the right to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assume that a doctrine was true at a given time merely because it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: _seemed_ to men true at that time, or because they found it pleasing?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The history of science reveals that many things have long been believed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be true, and, indeed, to be bound up with what were regarded as the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: highest interests of man, and that these same things have later been
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discovered to be false--not false merely for a later age, but false for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all time; as false when they were believed in as when they were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: exploded and known to be exploded.  No man of sense believes that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Ptolemaic system was true for a while, and that then the Copernican
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: became true.  We say that the former only _seemed_ true, and that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enthusiasm of its adherents was a mistaken enthusiasm.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is well to remember that philosophies are brought forward because it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is believed or hoped that they are true.  A fairy tale may be recited
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and may be approved, although no one dreams of attaching faith to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: events narrated in it.  But a philosophy attempts to give us some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: account of the nature of the world in which we live.  If the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher frankly abandons the attempt to tell us what is true, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with a Celtic generosity addresses himself to the task of saying what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: will be agreeable to us, he loses his right to the title.  It is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enough that he stirs our emotions, and works up his unrealities into
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: something resembling a poem.  It is not primarily his task to please,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as it is not the task of the serious worker in science to please those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whom he is called upon to instruct.  Truth is truth, whether it be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific truth or philosophical truth.  And error, no matter how
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: agreeable or how nicely adjusted to the temper of the times, is always
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error.  If it is error in a field in which the detection and exposure
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of error is difficult, it is the more dangerous, and the more should we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be on our guard against it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We may, then, accept the lesson of the history of philosophy, to wit,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we have no right to regard any given doctrine as final in such a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense that it need no longer be held tentatively and as subject to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possible revision; but we need not, on that account, deny that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy is, what it has in the past been believed to be, an earnest
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: search for truth.  A philosophy that did not even profess to be this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: would not be listened to at all.  It would be regarded as too trivial
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to merit serious attention.  If we take the word "science" in the broad
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sense to indicate a knowledge of the truth more exact and satisfactory
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: than that which obtains in common life, we may say that every
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy worthy of the name is, at least, an attempt at scientific
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge.  Of course, this sense of the word "science" should not be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: confused with that in which it has been used elsewhere in this volume.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 87. HOW TO READ THE HISTORY OF PHILOSOPHY.--He who takes up the history
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of philosophy for the first time is apt to be impressed with the fact
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he is reading something that might not inaptly be called the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: history of human error.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It begins with crude and, to the superficial spectator, seemingly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: childish attempts in the field of physical science.  There are clever
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guesses at the nature of the physical world, but the boldest of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speculations are entered upon with no apparent recognition of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: difficulty of the task undertaken, and with no realization of the need
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for caution.  Somewhat later a different class of problems makes its
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: appearance--the problems which have to do with the mind and with the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature of knowledge, reflective problems which scarcely seem to have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: come fairly within the horizon of the earliest thinkers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: These problems even the beginner may be willing to recognize as
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical; but he may conscientiously harbor a doubt as to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: desirability of spending time upon the solutions which are offered.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: System rises after system, and confronts him with what appear to be new
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: questions and new answers.  It seems as though each philosopher were
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: constructing a world for himself independently, and commanding him to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accept it, without first convincing him of his right to assume this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: tone of authority and to set up for an oracle.  In all this conflict of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinions where shall we seek for truth?  Why should we accept one man
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as a teacher rather than another?  Is not the lesson to be gathered
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: from the whole procession of systems best summed up in the dictum of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Protagoras: "Man is the measure of all things"--each has his own truth,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and this need not be truth to another?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This, I say, is a first impression and a natural one.  I hasten to add:
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this should not be the last impression of those who read with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thoughtful attention.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One thing should be emphasized at the outset: nothing will so often
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bear rereading as the history of philosophy.  When we go over the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ground after we have obtained a first acquaintance with the teachings
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the different philosophers, we begin to realize that what we have in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our hands is, in a sense, a connected whole.  We see that if Plato and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Aristotle had not lived, we could not have had the philosophy which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: passed current in the Middle Ages and furnished a foundation for the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: teachings of the Church.  We realize that without this latter we could
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not have had Descartes, and without Descartes we could not have had
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke and Berkeley and Hume.  And had not these lived, we should not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have had Kant and his successors.  Other philosophies we should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: undoubtedly have had, for the busy mind of man must produce something.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But whatever glimpses at the truth these men have vouchsafed us have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been guaranteed by the order of development in which they have stood.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: They could not independently have written the books that have come down
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This should be evident from what has been said earlier in this chapter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and elsewhere in this book.  Let us bear in mind that a philosopher
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: draws his material from two sources.  First of all, he has the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience of the mind and the world which is the common property of us
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all.  But it is, as we have seen, by no means easy to use this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: material.  It is vastly difficult to reflect.  It is fatally easy to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: misconceive what presents itself in our experience.  With the most
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: earnest effort to describe what lies before us, we give a false
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: description, and we mislead ourselves and others.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the second place, the philosopher has the interpretations of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience which he has inherited from his predecessors.  The influence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of these is enormous.  Each age has, to a large extent, its problems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: already formulated or half formulated for it.  Every man must have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ancestors, of some sort, if he is to appear upon this earthly stage at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: all; and a wholly independent philosopher is as impossible a creature
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as an ancestorless man.  We have seen how Descartes (section 60) tried
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to repudiate his debt to the past, and how little successful he was in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doing so.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, we make a mistake if we overlook the genius of the individual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thinker.  The history of speculative thought has many times taken a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: turn which can only be accounted for by taking into consideration the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: genius for reflective thought possessed by some great mind.  In the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: crucible of such an intellect, old truths take on a new aspect,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: familiar facts acquire a new and a richer meaning.  But we also make a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mistake if we fail to see in the writings of such a man one of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stages which has been reached in the gradual evolution of human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: thought, if we fail to realize that each philosophy is to a great
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: extent the product of the past.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When one comes to understand these things, the history of philosophy no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: longer presents itself as a mere agglomeration of arbitrary and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent systems.  And an attentive reading gives us a further key
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to the interpretation of what seemed inexplicable.  We find that there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may be distinct and different streams of thought, which, for a while,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: run parallel without commingling their waters.  For centuries the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Epicurean followed his own tradition, and walked in the footsteps of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: his own master.  The Stoic was of sterner stuff, and he chose to travel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: another path.  To this day there are adherents of the old church
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy, Neo-Scholastics, whose ways of thinking can only be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: understood when we have some knowledge of Aristotle and of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence upon men during the Middle Ages.  We ourselves may be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Kantians or Hegelians, and the man at our elbow may recognize as his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: spiritual father Comte or Spencer.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not follow that, because one system follows another in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: chronological order, it is its lineal descendant.  But some ancestor a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: system always has, and if we have the requisite learning and ingenuity,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we need not find it impossible to explain why this thinker or that was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influenced to give his thought the peculiar turn that characterizes it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sometimes many influences have conspired to attain the result, and it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is no small pleasure to address oneself to the task of disentangling
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the threads which enter into the fabric.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Moreover, as we read thus with discrimination, we begin to see that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: great men of the past have not spoken without appearing to have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sufficient reason for their utterances in the light of the times in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they lived.  We may make it a rule that, when they seem to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speaking arbitrarily, to be laying before us reasonings that are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasonings, dogmas for which no excuse seems to be offered, the fault
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lies in our lack of comprehension.  Until we can understand how a man,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: living in a certain century, and breathing a certain moral and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intellectual atmosphere, could have said what he did, we should assume
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we have read his words, but not his real thought.  For the latter
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: there is always a psychological, if not a logical, justification.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And this brings me to the question of the language in which the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophers have expressed their thoughts.  The more attentively one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reads the history of philosophy, the clearer it becomes that the number
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of problems with which the philosophers have occupied themselves is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: overwhelmingly great.  If each philosophy which confronts us seems to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us quite new and strange, it is because we have not arrived at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: stage at which it is possible for us to recognize old friends with new
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: faces.  The same old problems, the problems which must ever present
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves to reflective thought, recur again and again.  The form is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: more or less changed, and the answers which are given to them are not,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of course, always the same.  Each age expresses itself in a somewhat
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different way.  But sometimes the solution proposed for a given problem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is almost the same in substance, even when the two thinkers we are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contrasting belong to centuries which lie far apart.  In this case,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only our own inability to strip off the husk and reach the fruit itself
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prevents us from seeing that we have before us nothing really new.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, if we read the history of philosophy with patience and with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discrimination, it grows luminous.  We come to feel nearer to the men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the past.  We see that we may learn from their successes and from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their failures; and if we are capable of drawing a moral at all, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: apply the lesson to ourselves.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XXIV
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: SOME PRACTICAL ADMONITIONS
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 88. BE PREPARED TO ENTER UPON A NEW WAY OF LOOKING AT THINGS.--We have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seen that reflective thought tries to analyze experience and to attain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to a clear view of the elements that make it up--to realize vividly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is the very texture of the known world, and what is the nature of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge.  It is possible to live to old age, as many do, without even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a suspicion that there may be such a knowledge as this, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nevertheless to possess a large measure of rather vague but very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: serviceable information about both minds and bodies.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is something of a shock to learn that a multitude of questions may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be asked touching the most familiar things in our experience, and that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our comprehension of those things may be so vague that we grope in vain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for an answer.  Space, time, matter, minds, realities,--with these
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things we have to do every day.  Can it be that we do not know what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they are?  Then we must be blind, indeed.  How shall we set about
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: enlightening our ignorance?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Not as we have enlightened our ignorance heretofore.  We have added
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fact to fact; but our task now is to gain a new light on all facts, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see them from a different point of view; not so much to extend our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: knowledge as to deepen it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It seems scarcely necessary to point out that our world, when looked at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: for the first time in this new way, may seem to be a new and strange
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world.  The real things of our experience may appear to melt away, to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be dissolved by reflection into mere shadows and unrealities.  Well do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I remember the consternation with which, when almost a schoolboy, I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: first made my acquaintance with John Stuart Mill's doctrine that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things about us are "permanent possibilities of sensation."  To Mill,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of course, chairs and tables were still chairs and tables, but to me
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they became ghosts, inhabitants of a phantom world, to find oneself in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which was a matter of the gravest concern.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I suspect that this sense of the unreality of things comes often to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those who have entered upon the path of reflection, It may be a comfort
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to such to realize that it is rather a thing to be expected.  How can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one feel at home in a world which one has entered for the first time?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One cannot become a philosopher and remain exactly the man that one was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before.  Men have tried to do it,--Thomas Reid is a notable instance
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: (section 50); but the result is that one simply does not become a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher.  It is not possible to gain a new and a deeper insight
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into the nature of things, and yet to see things just as one saw them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before one attained to this.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If, then, we are willing to study philosophy at all, we must be willing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to embrace new views of the world, if there seem to be good reasons for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so doing.  And if at first we suffer from a sense of bewilderment, we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must have patience, and must wait to see whether time and practice may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not do something toward removing our distress.  It may be that we have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only half understood what has been revealed to us.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 89. BE WILLING TO CONSIDER POSSIBILITIES WHICH AT FIRST STRIKE ONE AS
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ABSURD.--It must be confessed that the philosophers have sometimes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brought forward doctrines which seem repellent to good sense, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little in harmony with the experience of the world which we have all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our lives enjoyed.  Shall we on this account turn our backs upon them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and refuse them an impartial hearing?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, the idealist maintains that there is no existence save psychical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: existence; that the material things about us are really mental things.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One of the forms taken by this doctrine is that alluded to above, that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things are permanent possibilities of sensation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I think it can hardly be denied that this sounds out of harmony with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the common opinion of mankind.  Men do not hesitate to distinguish
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: between minds and material things, nor do they believe that material
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: things exist only in minds.  That dreams and hallucinations exist only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in minds they are very willing to admit; but they will not admit that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this is true of such things as real chairs and tables.  And if we ask
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them why they take such a position, they fall back upon what seems
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given in experience.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, as the reader of the earlier chapters has seen, I think that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: plain man is more nearly right in his opinion touching the existence of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a world of non-mental things than is the idealistic philosopher.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: latter has seen a truth and misconceived it, thus losing some truth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he had before he began to reflect.  The former has not seen the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth which has impressed the idealist, and he has held on to that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: vague recognition that there are two orders of things given in our
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: experience, the physical and the mental, which seems to us so
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unmistakable a fact until we fall into the hands of the philosophers.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But all this does not prove that we have a right simply to fall back
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: upon "common sense," and refuse to listen to the idealist.  The
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deliverances of unreflective common sense are vague in the extreme; and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: though it may seem to assure us that there is a world of things
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: non-mental, its account of that world is confused and incoherent.  He
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who must depend on common sense alone can find no answer to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealists; he refuses to follow them, but he cannot refute them.  He is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reduced to dogmatic denial.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This is in itself an uncomfortable position.  And when we add to this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the reflection that such a man loses the truth which the idealist
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: emphasizes, the truth that the external world of which we speak must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be, if we are to know it at all, a world revealed to our senses, a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: world given in our experience, we see that he who stops his ears
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remains in ignorance.  The fact is that the man who has never weighed
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the evidence that impresses the idealist is not able to see clearly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is meant by that external world in which we all incline to put
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such faith.  We may say that he _feels_ a truth blindly, but does not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Let us take another illustration.  If there is one thing that we feel
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be as sure as the existence of the external world, it is that there
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are other minds more or less resembling our own.  The solipsist may try
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to persuade us that the evidence for such minds is untrustworthy.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may see no flaw in his argument, but he cannot convince us.  May we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ignore him, and refuse to consider the matter at all?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Surely not, if we wish to substitute clear thinking for vague and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indefinite opinion.  We should listen with attention, strive to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: understand all the reasonings laid before us, and then, if they seem to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: lead to conclusions really not in harmony with our experience, go
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: carefully over the ground and try to discover the flaw in them.  It is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only by doing something like this that we can come to see clearly what
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is meant when we speak of two or more minds and the relation between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: them.  The solipsist can help us, and we should let him do it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We should, therefore, be willing to consider seriously all sorts of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrines which may at first strike us as unreasonable.  I have chosen
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two which I believe to contain error.  But the man who approaches a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine which impresses him as strange has no right to assume at the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: outset that it contains error.  We have seen again and again how easy
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it is to misapprehend what is given in experience.  The philosopher may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be in the right, and what he says may repel us because we have become
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accustomed to certain erroneous notions, and they have come to seem
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: self-evident truths.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 90. DO NOT HAVE TOO MUCH RESPECT FOR AUTHORITY.--But if it is an error
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to refuse to listen to the philosopher, it is surely no less an error
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to accord him an authority above what he has a right to demand.  Bear
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in mind what was said in the last chapter about the difference between
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
