author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the special sciences and philosophy.  There is in the latter field no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: body of doctrine that we may justly regard as authoritative.  There are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "schools" of philosophy, and their adherents fall into the very human
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: error of feeling very sure that they and those who agree with them are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right; and the emphasis with which they speak is apt to mislead those
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who are not well informed.  I shall say a few words about the dangers
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the "school."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we look about us, we are impressed by the fact that there are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "schools" of philosophy, somewhat as there are religious sects and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: political parties.  An impressive teacher sets the mark of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: personality and of his preferences upon those who come under his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence.  They are not at an age to be very critical, and, indeed,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: they have not as yet the requisite learning to enable them to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: critical.  They keep the trend which has been given them early in life,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and, when they become teachers, they pass on the type of thought with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they have been inoculated, and the circle widens.  "Schools" may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: arise, of course, in a different way.  An epoch-making book may sweep
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men off of their feet and make of them passionate adherents.  But he
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who has watched the development of the American universities during the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: last twenty-five years must be impressed with the enormous influence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which certain teachers have had in giving a direction to the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophic thought of those who have come in contact with them.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expect the pupils of a given master to have a given shade of opinion,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and very often we are not disappointed in our guess.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is entirely natural that this should be so.  Those who betake
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves to the study of philosophy are men like other men.  They
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have the same feelings, and the bending of the twig has the same
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: significance in their case that it has in that of others.  It is no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: small compliment to a teacher that he can thus spread his influence,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and leave his proxies even when he passes away.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But, when we strive to "put off humanity" and to look at the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter under the cold light of reason, we may well ask ourselves,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whether he who unconsciously accepts his philosophy, in whole or in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: part, because it has been the philosophy of his teacher, is not doing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is done by those persons whose politics and whose religion take
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: their color from such accidental circumstances as birth in a given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: class or family traditions?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I am far from saying that it is, in general, a bad thing for the world
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that men should be influenced in this way by one another.  I say only
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that, when we look at the facts of the case, we must admit that even
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: our teachers of philosophy do not always become representatives of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: peculiar type of thought for which they stand, merely through a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deliberate choice from the wealth of material which the history of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: speculative thought lays before them.  They are influenced by others to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: take what they do take, and the traces of this influence are apt to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remain with them through life.  He who wishes to be entirely impartial
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: must be on his guard against such influences as these, and must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: distrust prejudices for or against certain doctrines, when he finds
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he imbibed them at an uncritical age and has remained under their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influence ever since.  Some do appear to be able to emancipate
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: themselves, and to outgrow what they first learned.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is, as I have said, natural that there should be a tendency to form
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: "schools" in philosophy.  And there are certain things that make this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: somewhat uncritical acceptance of a doctrine very attractive.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: In the first place, if we are willing to take a system of any sort as a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whole, it saves us a vast amount of trouble.  We seem to have a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: citadel, a point of vantage from which we can look out upon life and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: interpret it.  If the house we live in is not in all respects ideal, at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: least it is a house, and we are not homeless.  There is nothing more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: intolerable to most men than the having of no opinions.  They will
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: change one opinion for another, but they will rarely consent to do
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without altogether.  It is something to have an answer to offer to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those who persist in asking questions; and it is something to have some
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: sort of ground under one's feet, even if it be not very solid ground.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  Man is a social creature, and he is greatly fortified in his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: opinions by the consciousness that others share them with him.  If we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: become adherents of a "school," we have the agreeable consciousness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we are not walking alone through the maze of speculations that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: confronts those who reflect.  There appears to be a traveled way in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which we may have some confidence.  Are we not following the crowd, or,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: at least, a goodly number of the pilgrims who are seeking the same goal
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with ourselves?  Under such circumstances we are not so often impelled
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to inquire anxiously whether we are after all upon the right road.  We
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assume that we have made no mistake.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Under such circumstances we are apt to forget that there are many such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: roads, and that these have been traveled in ages past by troops very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: much like our own, who also cherished the hope that they were upon the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one and only highway.  In other words, we are apt to forget the lesson
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the history of philosophy.  This is a serious mistake.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: And what intensifies our danger, if we belong to a school which happens
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to be dominant and to have active representatives, is that we get very
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: little real criticism.  The books that we write are usually criticised
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: by those who view our positions sympathetically, and who are more
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: inclined to praise than to blame.  He who looks back upon the past is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: struck with the fact that books which have been lauded to the skies in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one age have often been subjected to searching criticism and to a good
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: deal of condemnation in the next.  Something very like this is to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: expected of books written in our own time.  It is, however, a pity that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we should have to wait so long for impartial criticism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This leads me to say a word of the reviews which fill our philosophical
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: journals, and which we must read, for it is impossible to read all the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: books that come out, and yet we wish to know something about them.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: To the novice it is something of a surprise to find that books by men
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: whom he knows to be eminent for their ingenuity and their learning are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: condemned in very offhand fashion by quite young men, who as yet have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained to little learning and to no eminence at all.  One sometimes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is tempted to wonder that men admittedly remarkable should have
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fathered such poor productions as we are given to understand them to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be, and should have offered them to a public that has a right to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: indignant.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Now, there can be no doubt that, in philosophy, a cat has the right to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: look at a king, and has also a right to point out his misdoings, if
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such there be.  But it seems just to indicate that, in this matter,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: certain cautions should be observed.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If a great man has been guilty of an error in reasoning, there is no
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reason why it should not be pointed out by any one who is capable of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: detecting it.  The authority of the critic is a matter of no moment
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: where the evidence is given.  In such a case, we take a suggestion and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we do the criticising for ourselves.  But where the evidence is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: given, where the justice of the criticism is not proved, the case is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: different.  Here we must take into consideration the authority of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: critic, and, if we follow him at all, we must follow him blindly.  Is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: it safe to do this?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It is never safe in philosophy, or, at any rate, it is safe so seldom
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the exceptions are not worth taking into account.  Men write from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the standpoint of some school of opinion; and, until we know their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: prepossessions, their statements that this is good, that is bad, the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: third thing is profound, are of no significance whatever.  We should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simply set them aside, and try to find out from our reviewer what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: contained in the book under criticism.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: One of the evils arising out of the bias I am discussing is, that books
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and authors are praised or condemned indiscriminately because of their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: point of view, and little discrimination is made between good books and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: poor books.  There is all the difference in the world between a work
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which can be condemned only on the ground that it is realistic or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: idealistic in its standpoint, and those feeble productions which are to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be condemned from every point of view.  If we consistently carry out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the principle that we may condemn all those who are not of our party,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we must give short shrift to a majority of the great men of the past.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: So I say, beware of authority in philosophy, and, above all, beware of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that most insidious form of authority, the spirit of the "school."  It
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cannot but narrow our sympathies and restrict our outlook.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 91. REMEMBER THAT ORDINARY RULES OF EVIDENCE APPLY.--What I am going to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: say in this section is closely related to what has been said just
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: above.  To the disinterested observer it may seem rather amusing that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: one should think it worth while to try to show that we have not the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: right to use a special set of weights and measures when we are dealing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with things philosophical.  There was a time when men held that a given
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrine could be philosophically false, and, at the same time,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: theologically true; but surely the day of such twists and turnings is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: past!
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I am by no means sure that it is past.  With the lapse of time, old
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: doctrines take on new aspects, and come to be couched in a language
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that suits the temper of the later age.  Sometimes the doctrine is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: veiled and rendered less startling, but remains essentially what it was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: before, and may be criticised in much the same way.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I suppose we may say that every one who is animated by the party spirit
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discussed above, and who holds to a group of philosophical tenets with
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: a warmth of conviction out of proportion to the authority of the actual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence which may be claimed for them, is tacitly assuming that the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: truth or falsity of philosophical dogmas is not wholly a matter of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: evidence, but that the desires of the philosopher may also be taken
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into account.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: This position is often taken unconsciously.  Thus, when, instead of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: proving to others that a given doctrine is false, we try to show them
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it is a dangerous doctrine, and leads to unpalatable consequences,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we assume that what seems distasteful cannot be true, and we count on
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the fact that men incline to believe what they like to believe.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: May we give this position the dignity of a philosophical doctrine and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: hold that, in the somewhat nebulous realm inhabited by the philosopher,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: men are not bound by the same rules of evidence that obtain elsewhere?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: That this is actually done, those who read much in the field of modern
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophy are well aware.  Several excellent writers have maintained
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we need not, even if there seems to be evidence for them, accept
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: views of the universe which do not satisfy "our whole nature."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We should not confuse with this position the very different one which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: maintains that we have a right to hold tentatively, and with a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: willingness to abandon them should evidence against them be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: forthcoming, views which we are not able completely to establish, but
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which seem reasonable.  One may do this with perfect sincerity, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: without holding that philosophical truth is in any way different from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: scientific truth.  But the other position goes beyond this; it assumes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that man must be satisfied, and that only that can be true which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfies him.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: I ask, is it not significant that such an assumption should be made
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only in the realm of the unverifiable?  No man dreams of maintaining
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that the rise and fall of stocks will be such as to satisfy the whole
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nature even of the elect, or that the future history of man on this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: planet is a thing to be determined by some philosopher who decides for
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: us what would or would not be desirable.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Surely all truths of election--those truths that we simply choose to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: have true--are something much less august than that Truth of Evidence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which sometimes seems little to fall in with our desires, and in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: face of which we are humble listeners, not dictators.  Before the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: latter we are modest; we obey, lest we be confounded.  And if, in the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophic realm, we believe that we may order Truth about, and make
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: her our slave, is it not because we have a secret consciousness that we
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are not dealing with Truth at all, but with Opinion, and with Opinion
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that has grown insolent because she cannot be drawn from her obscurity
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and be shown to be what she is?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Sometimes it is suddenly revealed to a man that he has been accepting
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: two orders of truth.  I once walked and talked with a good scholar who
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: discoursed of high themes and defended warmly certain theses.  I said
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to him: If you could go into the house opposite, and discover
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unmistakably whether you are in the right or in the wrong,--discover it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as unmistakably as you can discover whether there is or is not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: furniture in the drawing-room,--would you go?  He thought over the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: matter for a while, and then answered frankly; No! I should not go; I
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should stay out here and argue it out.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 92. AIM AT CLEARNESS AND SIMPLICITY.--There is no department of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: investigation in which it is not desirable to cultivate clearness and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: simplicity in thinking, speaking, and writing.  But there are certain
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reasons why we should be especially on our guard in philosophy against
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the danger of employing a tongue "not understanded of the people."
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: There are dangerous pitfalls concealed under the use of technical words
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and phrases.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The value of technical expressions in the special sciences must be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceded.  They are supposed to be more exact and less ambiguous than
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: terms in ordinary use, and they mark an advance in our knowledge of the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: subject.  The distinctions which they indicate have been carefully
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: drawn, and appear to be of such authority that they should be generally
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: accepted.  Sometimes, as, for example, in mathematics, a conventional
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: set of symbols may quite usurp the function of ordinary language, and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: may enormously curtail the labor of setting forth the processes and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: results of investigation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But we must never forget that we have not in philosophy an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: authoritative body of truth which we have the right to impose upon all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: who enter that field.  A multitude of distinctions have been made and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: are made; but the representatives of different schools of thought are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not at one touching the value and significance of these distinctions.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If we coin a word or a phrase to mark such, there is some danger that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we fall into the habit of using such words or phrases, as we use the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: coins in our purse, without closely examining them, and with the ready
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: assumption that they must pass current everywhere.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, there is always a possibility that our technical expressions may
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be nothing less than crystallized error.  Against this we should surely
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: be on our guard.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Again.  When we translate the language of common life into the dialect
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the learned, there is danger that we may fall into the error of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: supposing that we are adding to our knowledge, even though we are doing
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: nothing save to exchange one set of words for another.  Thus, we all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: know very well that one mind can communicate with another.  One does
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not have to be a scholar to be aware of this.  If we choose to call
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this "intersubjective intercourse," we have given the thing a sounding
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: name; but we know no more about it than we did before.  The problem of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the relation between minds, and the way in which they are to be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: conceived as influencing each other, remains just what it was.  So,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: also, we recognize the everyday fact that we know both ourselves and
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: what is not ourselves.  Shall we call this knowledge of something not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves "self-transcendence"?  We may do so if we wish, but we ought
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to realize that this bestowal of a title makes no whit clearer what is
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: meant by knowledge.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Unhappily, men too often believe that, when they have come into the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: possession of a new word or phrase, they have gained a new thought.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The danger is great in proportion to the breadth of the gulf which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: separates the new dialect from the old language of common life in which
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: we are accustomed to estimate things.  Many a philosopher would be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: bereft, indeed, were he robbed of his vocabulary and compelled to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: express his thoughts in ordinary speech.  The theories which are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: implicit in certain recurring expressions would be forced to come out
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: into the open, and stand criticism without disguise.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: But can one write philosophical books without using words which are not
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: in common use among the unphilosophic?  I doubt it.  Some such words it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: seems impossible to avoid.  However, it does seem possible to bear in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: mind the dangers of a special philosophical terminology and to reduce
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: such words to a minimum.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Finally, we may appeal to the humanity of the philosopher.  The path to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection is a sufficiently difficult one as it is; why should he roll
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rocks upon it and compel those who come after him to climb over them?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: If truths are no truer for being expressed in a repellent form, why
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: should he trick them out in a fantastic garb?  What we want is the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: naked truth, and we lose time and patience in freeing our mummy from
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the wrappings in which learned men have seen fit to encase it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: 93. DO NOT HASTILY ACCEPT A DOCTRINE.--This brings me to the last of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the maxims which I urge upon the attention of the reader.  All that has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: been said so far may be regarded as leading up to it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difficulty that confronts us is this: On the one hand, we must
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: recognize the uncertainty that reigns in this field of investigation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: We must ever weigh probabilities and possibilities; we do not find
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: ourselves in the presence of indubitable truths which all competent
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: persons stand ready to admit.  This seems to argue that we should learn
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: to suspend judgment, and should be most wary in our acceptance of one
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosophical doctrine and our rejection of another.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: On the other hand, philosophy is not a mere matter of intellectual
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: curiosity.  It has an intimate connection with life.  As a man thinks,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: so is he, to a great extent, at least.  How, then, can one afford to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: remain critical and negative?  To counsel this seems equivalent to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: advising that one abandon the helm and consent to float at the mercy of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wind and tide.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: The difficulty is a very real one.  It presents itself insistently to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: those who have attained to that degree of intellectual development at
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which one begins to ask oneself questions and to reflect upon the worth
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and meaning of life.  An unreflective adherence to tradition no longer
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: satisfies such persons.  They wish to know why they should believe in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: this or that doctrine, and why they should rule their lives in harmony
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: with this or that maxim.  Shall we advise them to lay hold without
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: delay of a set of philosophical tenets, as we might advise a disabled
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man to aid himself with any staff that happens to come to hand?  Or
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: shall we urge them to close their eyes to the light, and to go back
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: again to the old unreflective life?
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Neither of these counsels seems satisfactory, for both assume tacitly
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that it does not much matter what the _truth_ is, and that we can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: afford to disregard it.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Perhaps we may take a suggestion from that prudent man and acute
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: philosopher, Descartes.  Discontented with the teachings of the schools
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as they had been presented to him, he resolved to set out upon an
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: independent voyage of discovery, and to look for a philosophy of his
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: own.  It seemed necessary to him to doubt, provisionally at least, all
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he had received from the past.  But in what house should he live
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: while he was reconstructing his old habitation?  Without principles of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: some sort he could not live, and without reasonable principles he could
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: not live well.  So he framed a set of provisional rules, which should
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: guide his life until he had new ground beneath his feet.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: When we examine these rules, we find that, on the whole, they are such
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: as the experience of mankind has found prudent and serviceable.  In
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: other words, we discover that Descartes, until he was in a position to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: see clearly for himself, was willing to be led by others.  He was a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: unit in the social order, and he recognized that truth.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: It does not seem out of place to recall this fact to the consciousness
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of those who are entering upon the reflective life.  Those who are
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rather new to reflection upon philosophical matters are apt to seize
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: single truths, which are too often half-truths, and to deduce their
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: consequences remorselessly.  They do not always realize the extreme
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: complexity of society, or see the full meaning of the relations in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: which they stand to the state and to the church.  Breadth of view can
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: only come with an increase of knowledge and with the exercise of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: reflection.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: For this reason I advise patience, and a willingness to accept the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: established order of things until one is very sure that one has
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: attained to some truth--some real truth, not a mere truth of
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: election--which may serve as the basis of a reconstruction.  The first
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: glimpses of truth cannot be depended upon to furnish such a foundation.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Thus, we may suspend judgment, and, nevertheless, be ready to act.  But
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: is not this a mere compromise?  Certainly.  All life is a compromise;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and in the present instance it means only that we should keep our eyes
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: open to the light, whatever its source, and yet should nourish that
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: wholesome self-distrust that prevents a man from being an erratic and

text: the one chain.  Witness the series of German thinkers: Kant, Fichte,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Schelling, Hegel, Schopenhauer; or the series of British thinkers:
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: Locke, Berkeley, Hume, Mill.  Herbert Spencer represents a confluence
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: of the streams.  The spirit of his doctrine is predominantly British;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: but he got his "Unknowable" from Kant, through Hamilton and Mansel.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: At any point in a given stream there may be a division.  Thus, Kant was
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: awakened to his creative effort by Hume.  But Mill is also the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: successor of Hume, and more truly the successor, for he carries on the
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: traditional way of approaching philosophical problems, while Kant
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: rebels against it, and heads a new line.
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: CHAPTER XXIV, sections 88-93.  I hardly think it is necessary for me to
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: comment upon this chapter.  The recommendations amount to this: that a
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: man should be fair-minded and reasonable, free from partisanship,
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: cautious, and able to suspend judgment where the evidence is not clear;
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: also that where the light of reason does not seem to him to shine
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: brightly and to illumine his path as he could wish, he should be
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: influenced in his actions by the reflection that he has his place in
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: the social order, and must meet the obligations laid upon him by this
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: fact.  When the pragmatist emphasizes the necessity of accepting ideals
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: and living by them, he is doing us a service.  But we must see to it
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that he does not lead us into making arbitrary decisions and feeling
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: that we are released from the duty of seeking for evidence.  Read
title: An Introduction to Philosophy
author: Fullerton, George Stuart

text: together sections 64, 91, and 93.
